Elden Ring: The Epic Adventure You Never Knew You Needed!

Are you ready to dive into a world where dying repeatedly is just part of the fun? Look no further than Elden Ring!
Get ready to spend hours wandering aimlessly through stunning landscapes, only to be brutally murdered by the first enemy you encounter. It's all part of the charm!
With a story line so convoluted, you'll need a degree in cryptic messages to figure out what's going on. Who needs a coherent plot anyway?
The game's difficulty level is like trying to juggle flaming swords while riding a unicycle on a tightrope. But hey, what's life without a little challenge, right?
Enjoy the satisfaction of finally defeating a boss, only to realize you've been fighting the tutorial boss all along. Surprise!
Forget about sleep, food, or social interaction. Elden Ring demands your full attention, and it won't take no for an answer!
Experience the thrill of exploration as you stumble upon hidden treasures, secret pathways, and deadly traps that make you question your life choices.
In conclusion, Elden Ring is like a roller coaster ride through a maze of chaos, despair, and occasional moments of triumph. So buckle up, embrace the madness, and remember: Praise the Sun (or whatever's left of it)!

[h1]If you have ever been on the fence about [i]difficult[/i] games, this is the best one to start with![/h1]
 
This was my first souls game from From Software, so I was pretty terrible at first but something about this game kept me coming back. From walking out to see the Erdtree for the first time to realizing the mind blowing size of the multi layered map as I traveled down the wells, I was (and still am) hooked. I almost never buy games that are not on sale but the game design is like nothing out there. I bought the game on release for the PC and was completely absorbed for those two weeks. Afterwords I bought the game for PlayStation (my main gaming platform) and beat it again because I loved it so much. Worth every penny

The curiosity the world fills you with to explore anything that looks interesting always leads to a fun adventure. And the combat and weapons are top notch. So many different ways to tackle the challenges the game throws at you. I have done playthroughs with Blood katanas, Magic, Faith, Dragons and Strength builds and all are fun and unique. The boss variety is insane and each playthrough brings new challenges. 

Some of the negatives I have of the game is that it was very hard for me to understand the great lore of the game without watching Vaati Vidya on YT. Some recent patches to the game have improved this but my first playthrough I was lost and in awe most of the time wishing I knew more of what was going on. And screw the crustaceans and birds in this game!! Starting a new character after beating the game a few times can also be a bit of a drag because the game is so big. It's impossible to remember where everything is and the joy of exploring isnt the same on subsequent playthroughs.

Don't be scared to use the tools given to you to help overcome challenges, its not cheating. From spirit ashes, summons, over leveling or watching YT guides you can (and will) beat anything in this game. And while your first playthrough is the most impactful, theres so much to do in the game that I was still finding new areas and bosses in my 3rd or 4th playthrough. Not to mention when you become worn out and want a new game like ER, From Software has 5-7 more premium titles to get sucked into. And it runs great on the steam deck!
"A Boy Who Has Been Reincarnated in The Lands Between Explores Peacefully As A Lvl 220 Adventurer, ~ I who was a DEXT User Will Try A Different Built This Time, And Will Find The Elden Ring"

Hark, ye denizens of gaming realms, for I bring thee tidings of Elden Ring, a creation most divine. 'Tis a tapestry woven with threads of valor, despair, and unyielding challenge, a testament to the craftsmanship of FromSoftware. Lo, I declare unto thee, this game deserveth naught but the highest praise, a perfect score of ten upon ten.

From the very moment thy journey doth commence, thou art greeted by a world both wondrous and treacherous. The lands between beckon thee with open arms, yet harbor dangers most insidious. Each step taketh one further into the abyss of lore and mystery, where secrets lie in wait for the curious and the brave.

The combat, oh, how it doth sing with the clamor of steel upon steel! Every encounter, a dance of death, where skill and strategy art paramount. To falter is to face ruin, yet to persevere is to taste the sweetest nectar of victory. The bosses, they tower like the great behemoths of yore, each a test of mettle and might, demanding respect and cunning from those who dare oppose them.

Verily, the world itself is a character, alive with beauty and terror. From the towering spires of ancient keeps to the darkened depths of forgotten dungeons, every locale doth tell its own tale. The art and design are a feast for the eyes, and the music, a balm for the weary soul, enhancing every moment with a symphony of epic grandeur.

Yet, 'tis not merely the grandiosity that doth captivate, but the minutiae as well. The lore, penned by the sagacious hand of George R.R. Martin, is deep and compelling, weaving a narrative that ensnares the mind and stirs the heart. The characters, though fleeting in their presence, leave an indelible mark, their stories intertwined with thy own.

In truth, Elden Ring is a game that doth transcend mere entertainment. It is a journey, a trial, and a triumph, crafted with the utmost care and reverence for the art of game-making. 'Tis a beacon of what gaming can achieve, a paragon of its kind.

So, to thee, fellow adventurers, I say: Take up thy controller, steel thy nerves, and embrace the challenge that is Elden Ring. For in its trials and tribulations, thou shalt find the truest form of glory.

Huzzah! Elden Ring is a masterpiece worthy of legends, a ten out of ten, and a tale for the ages.

BEST GAME EVER MADE 10/10
fun
You have to get naked to get one of the endings...
An epic dark fantasy game that is very challenging and rewarding.  This game at first seems overwhelming but with patience and practice you can make steady progress through a vibrant world of grand adventure. You can enjoy this game for hours on end, just be ready to die and be reborn...often.
This game is awesome, I've played over 1k hours (I've played on other consoles as well as steam) and I still don't get bored. It's a game that makes you feel strong and unstoppable until you run into that next boss. Unlike other games, this game doesn't just require better gear to progress, it requires actual skill and you need to know what you're doing if you wanna succeed. The best part of the game though is the satisfaction after killing that one boss that you've been stuck on, it gives a sense of pride and happiness that no other game has given me. Finally right now is a great time to get the game (as of posting the review) because the dlc is coming out in 10 days. Again great game would highly recommend to everyone.

I think it's alright?
In all fairness this game is really good and a masterpiece in almost every way. However there are a few things that keep me from giving this a 10/10 and will stay at a 9/10. Some bosses or dungeon bosses feel like a large difficulty spike after beating literal gods or demigods. Two of these instances were the Valiant Gargoyles and Black Knife Tiche. Don't get me wrong I love a good challenge but like I just fought a literal void god in Astel and now this random assassin is fucking me up more than he could? And those fucking gargoyles love to spam poison breath which seems like an oversight. There are a few others like this but these were my main two.

My other "complaint" is more a personal preference and I know people disagree based on how they like to play. That being said, I would have liked some more QOL changes such as letting me know when I've completed a dungeon, a little clearer on where certain NPCs are, and a basic quest tracker. Now I know what you're thinking by that last part but hear me out. I don't need the game to hold my hand and tell me exactly where to go and what to do but I would like keeping them organized and at least some very basic information about what to do. For example once you start certain NPC questlines like Ranni or Sellen letting us see our current task maybe just as simple as find the city of Nokron would be appreciated keeping it organized. As for the main quest, something along the lines of once you have two great runes and talk to Ofnir, just a little note in the tracker saying "Journey to the capital Leyndell".

great game. death rite bird kys
As a Souls Enjoyer with about 2k hours across the fromsoft library. this game is a flawed masterpiece. Your first playthrough, for the first 2/3rds of the game will be some of the best gaming you'll ever experience. That last 1/3rd is just as magical, buuuuuuuuut. The end game feels like it's been balanced by a 3rd grade bully. Too many stunlocks in the form of 2-3 attack combos that feel like a 1 shot. That harsh trial and error, is not fun. Using a max health regen build with 45-50 vigor.  With at least 3 full completions of every fromsoft Souls game(ok one and a half for demon souls), I comfortably say these numbers are a deep departure from the usual formula. 
I blame the introduction of spirit ashes, Theyre a wonderful tool that you're welcome to use. However I believe fromsoft tried to please everyone here and missed the mark. The bosses are all built to be solo-able to please the purists, but I believe they're aggressively balanced with the assumption you're bringing spirit ashes into the fight. 
Bosses and mobs also literally re-act to your inputs for the first time in the series. Not with a delay that might reflect the AI reacting to your character's actions. But they will fly right into a full combo exactly when you hit that estus button. The animations often occur simultaneously. But the bosses are massively varied and fun, the visuals are majestic and intense. There are more secrets than a Sanderson novel. almost a perfect game. If they just did something about that end game balancing. . . .

only place i can get a hug... 10/10
best game ever
Compared to the rest of the Souls/Borne titles, Elden Ring is by far the most accessible and casual. Players like myself who cut their teeth on original Souls may be somewhat disappointed, however those who are new to the series may find much more enjoyment in Elden Ring than they would in the other more "hardcore" entries.

The open world adds about as much as it detracts from the experience. It's certainly a breath of fresh air in many ways. It is almost a meditative experience to ride around on your horse, occasionally finding dungeons to explore or a random NPC. The content is typically dense enough to justify the massive size of the map. However, there are some locations on the map that essentially amount to sprawling nothingness. Ultimately, the best most memorable parts of the game are the segments which are more linear, as they provide a tighter, denser, more entertaining and comprehensive experience. 

NPC questlines are more frustrating than ever before. Forget trying to complete any questlines without a guide. Even when you do happen to encounter an NPC, they generally do not give any indication of how to proceed with their questline. Previous titles were able to get away with this somewhat, but Elden Ring's size alone makes completing these quests on your own nearly impossible. 

The lore in this entry is extremely vague and difficult to follow, as usual for the series. But this time there is also a very confusing naming scheme. All important characters in this game have extremely similar sounding names, which makes keeping track of who is who extremely painful. Malenia, Melina, Miquella, Maliketh. Godfrey, Godrick, Godwyn, Godefroy. Thankfully, you can simply ignore the deeper story of the game without missing out on much.

The multiplayer aspect of this game is much weaker than the others. You cannot be invaded when playing solo. Likewise, when you can only invade players who have at least one summon. Therefore, you are generally forced to fight 2v1 in PVP. Even as someone who never really engaged in PVP, I was disappointed by this. Getting invaded at a critical moment was always an unforgettably exciting experience that you will never have in this game. 

Thankfully, Elden Ring excels at what are essentially the main selling points of every game in this series: gameplay and boss fights. The gameplay is tight, fluid, polished, and fun. The boss fights are diverse and challenging. For every great boss in this game there are ten mediocre bosses, but that is somewhat inevitable for a game of this size. The great bosses more than make up for the mediocre ones, and even the mediocre bosses are still fun to fight and pad out the content of the game.

Judging Elden Ring by its own merit independent of its sibling titles, its a very well made and highly polished hardcore open-world RPG. Even judging it alongside its predecessors, I couldn't say Elden Ring falls short of the standard. It is by far the most ambitious title in the series, and that naturally results in various shortcomings. But despite those issues it is undeniably impressively well designed. 

Not my favorite Souls/Borne title, but still highly recommended.

BGE
sure

Epic, this is a gold standard for developers.
very good
very good game
My brother bought me this game as a gift. This game is a 10/10 masterpiece. Choose to play how you want: Follow a guide or follow your heart. The game is full of surprises, secrets, and just utter beauty. Punishing at times and oh so rewarding other times. You will, without a doubt, love this game. Keep in mind that if you've never played a souls-like game before, like myself, you will be doing yourself a disservice by not giving this game a try. I will say, I did look things up to have an idea of where to go at my level, but nothing was spoiled. I know it can be brutal, horrifying, and punishing consistently, but the game is just undeniably beautiful. The times you win are amazing. The times you lose, gives you a chance to learn. I've beaten the game and have not started a NG+, but I am waiting for the DLC to come out so that I can instantly progress into the new story. Now tarnished...are you ready to begin your journey in the Lands Between?

Super hard. so much fun.
I haven't played this game since about a month or two after release. Did about two NG+ runs and got wiped out from the loop. At the time they hadn't patched the Rivers of Blood and it made the game and boss fights so unbelievably trivial. 
Malenia, who? Rivers of Blood with the clone spirit, done in one go. Cool.
Malikith, who? Same as above.

Weapon Arts were a dope addition to the souls format and FromSoft did an amazing job bringing the Dark souls esque world to an open world, but taking 3 months to patch out weapons/arts that should've been balanced during the playtests before release was a blunder. Made any future additions to Elden Ring, like this new DLC seem boring and redundant.

Easily the best single player game I've ever played - by a large margin. 
I can't really tell anything new that hasn't already been told 100 times by critics and players alike.
Everything about this game is outstanding, the world building, the aesthetics, the combat, exploration. You can get lost in this big and immersive world with a new adventure around every corner - each of which is worth exploring. 
How you want to play the game is completely in your own hands, there's a vast number of different options to alter the game towards your preference. 
I don't know why I've waited so long until I first picked the game up, but I can tell you that I am glad I finally did! If you give the game a chance and the time to get into it, I'm pretty sure you will not regret it!

A red haired girl sliced me into pieces without my consent. Would recomend
It's a good souls game, but there are some experience-breaking issues. First of all - technical issues. 2.5 years since release and freezing and stuttering due to shader cache or whatever weren't resolved, no matter what rig you have (mine is 5800x3d+4080+48Gb Ram). Now about gameplay itself - good old souls mechanics, lot's of different enemies and bosses - those are positive moments. Completely unneeded open world, overwhelmig count of ashes of war (weapon perks) and spells, while most of it are too weak or completely useless. Also too many story characteres with crossing storylines compared to previous games, honestly, i wasn't able to track their stories progression and complete them all. In conclusion i would recommend this game only to dark souls fans, not for average gamer.

[h1]Game of the Decade[/h1]

Elden Ring may very well be the best video game of this decade, boasting unparalleled world-building. With the upcoming DLC set to further enrich the already immersive world created by Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin, my only suggestion for improvement is to make NPC storylines and quests easier to follow. Currently, they are easily missable, often requiring players to consult community guides or wikis to fully experience them.
What a game!

Try Finger
TL;DR: Yes, I recommend Elden Ring. It's been the best game available for the last two years and will likely remain so for a long time. Whether at full price or half, it's worth every penny.


Elden Ring has been successful, but I‚Äôd never call it a masterpiece. To me, personally, it was a downgrade to the Souls formula of level design that has been working just fine for all these years. Also, if not for the basic Souls formula, there wouldn‚Äôt have been Elden Ring at all. I‚Äôve played all the Souls games to the point where I can do no-damage boss fights comfortably and speedruns just for fun. I‚Äôve spent a ridiculous amount of time grinding Souls games since Demon‚Äôs Souls, and I‚Äôd like to share some thoughts.

Elden Ring has simply fallen into the trap of open-world appeal to the masses, the cursed Ubisoft formula (big map, fog of war you unlock by activating towers, etc. ‚Äî I‚Äôm sure you recognize this trope as it‚Äôs become a meme in gaming). I don‚Äôt know if we can all agree on this, but I‚Äôll say it: Elden Ring is just an open-world Souls game. It has separate lore, for sure, but it has the same old Dark Souls gameplay and tone with some tweaks here and there. 

There‚Äôs this ingenious craftiness in level design that we find in older games, such as old Resident Evil/Silent Hill games, older Dark Souls, etc. They are small in size with limited maps, but that‚Äôs the whole point to get this craftiness I‚Äôm talking about. Remember that first locked door you encounter when you start a game? That ladder you can‚Äôt reach? That cliff that looks like it leads somewhere but you‚Äôre not sure if you want to jump? Traps and world interaction, even through a mere text or simple NPC dialogue, easily missable items/events that play a crucial role in game progression‚Äîthese small details, when put together, give you the complete picture. This interconnection between several stages is what made Dark Souls so good in terms of brilliant level design.

Now, open world kills this aspect and makes you want more. More places, more scenery, more enemies‚Äîyou always want more exposure to new stuff to uncover, and sadly, the game can only offer so much because of limited resources. So, even if the game is huge, you get a big presentation every time you visit a new area, but then you begin to notice the laziness and shortcomings of those landscapes, especially when they‚Äôre bloated with the same enemy types and copy-pasted patterns of dungeons, progression, and boss fights.

Honestly, to me at least, the whole appeal of Souls games revolves around gameplay. Despite being clunky at times and deliberately made to feel constantly oppressed by enemies and bosses, Souls games or Elden Ring have solid and well-thought gameplay with consistent frame data, and it‚Äôs one of those games you can master with enough time and practice. I also believe that the adventure aspect or huge landscapes, be it open world or not, have very little to no impact on me enjoying the game.

Other aspects I like are the boss fights and encounters with ruthless enemies. Your ability to find solutions to overcome said obstacles, whether by outplaying them through sheer skill, finding workarounds, or simply grinding for more levels and better gear to brute-force your way with stronger stats. All of these features can be achieved in a much smaller game where you don‚Äôt even need a map, just like the old Souls games.

Like I said in the beginning, FromSoft wanted to hop on the bandwagon of open-world games and appeal to more people. They‚Äôve been studying the market after all and want to sell. They‚Äôre slowly shifting from the kind of arcade-like mindset that‚Äôs gameplay hyper-focused to a somewhat realistic game design, with slower movement, clunkier recovery animations, bigger world that offers multiple choices to find solutions which translates to less skill required, thus less difficulty. I see where they‚Äôre coming from, but to be honest, I‚Äôm not a fan. Because for all this time, I‚Äôve always regarded Japanese developers as those who prioritize gameplay over everything else. If you‚Äôve been playing their games for a long time and compare them to Western developers, you can notice the difference in philosophy when making games. But now I can see them walking similar paths.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong though, I still believe Elden Ring‚Äôs gameplay is good; they didn‚Äôt change the core radically, but I think that‚Äôs coming and is inevitable.

Again, to me, Elden Ring isn‚Äôt a masterpiece. It‚Äôs a decent Souls game that shone in a time when all other games were bad; it was the only decent choice. It was actually guilty of similar things made by many mainstream games but used a slightly different approach. That slight difference isn‚Äôt novel, mind you‚Äîit‚Äôs always been there. It was none other than the Dark Souls gameplay formula.

I bought this game because I heard it was like Skyrim. If you‚Äôre reading this because you heard the same. I‚Äôm here to inform you that information is very much false. You can‚Äôt compare the two games. It‚Äôs like comparing a fork and a spoon. This game has no chill. You are thrusted straight into a hostile world where the combat will either make you or break you. There‚Äôs no in-between; you‚Äôll either love this game or hate it. The game is beautiful visually. It runs extremely smooth without ever experiencing any fps drops. There are quest, but there‚Äôs no quest log. The world is big and full of unexpected dangers. You need to optimize your character build from the start of the game, otherwise you‚Äôre going to be having a rough time later. I recommend this game for my fellow gamers who still love a challenge. If you‚Äôre the type who likes to play casually & prefer being spoon-fed; this game is not for you.

I never intended to play through this game because I didn't think I'd enjoy it, but I'm so glad I gave it a shot. It ended up being one of my favorite games to date. This game is one of my favourites of all time, probably up there with Zelda Ocarina of Time and Kena Bridge of Spirits. But this is not a 10/10 game for me. 8.5/10.
The music, graphics and open world map design is impeccable and it's still the most beautiful game I've ever seen.
However, the story telling is incredibly lacking and the way in which you are expected to progress is explained very vaguely in game.
The voice acting performances are top tier and character design is amazing; that is, if you even manage to find the NPCs and follow some very odd lines of enquiry to navigate their quests.
I love hidden lore as much as the next fantasy RPG girlie, and EldenWiki is a godsend but the work you have to put in will not be to everyone's taste.

I've played Dark Souls 1,2 and 3 and finished all of them multiple times, played Bloodborne and liked ir (didnt love it because i lost my ps4) and Sekiro is a game on my wishlist. 
All this to say I was hoping Elder Ring was going to be one of those games where I beat every boss, try a bunch of weapons and most important play with friends.
At the time I had a bunch of problems with connections, the fact that summons leave after each and every boss in a open world game reminds me of games from 30 years ago, every game usually needs a guide but this time is more a guide that needs a game on the second screen. Theres a slight slight way nudge in terms on directions but even that's too much, I'm all for game that don't hold your hand, but there's fathers that support you and fathers that just don't give a flying fuck what you do.
And its hard for me to say but it might be the worse 60 euros I spent in my life, and I bought Cyperpunk on release, but that at least had the makings of a good game this one feels like a tech demo that was over hyped and just over jerked from the fan base.

indeed a good game
Very rich and compelling in terms of gameplay, story and game design. 
And the open world, the choices of what you want to do next are seemingly vast. At times to a painful extent if you do not pay attention to what is being told and hinted at . 

The main questline is pretty straightforward, although the smaller, individual questlines can suffer from being too unlinear and open in terms of continuation. This at times results in doing a quest for someone, in which they thereafter change location to a seemingly hard to guess spot.
I admit that I had to sometimes use a guide to find the continuation of the questline, or a specific item. Only to find one or the other at a location that just managed to baffle me. "How the hell was I supposed to find this / you?" was a sentiment I shared a couple of times.

But the story and the tellings of the sorrounding lore are EXPERTLY written. And they are not spoonfed in the slightest, which is a welcome change of pace in terms of storytelling.
This also means you will not have a grasp on everything in your first playthrough. But in this case this type of storytelling complements the game immensely and adds in replayability.
I cannot say much more than that the story is in the same vein as Tolkien's work, and the delivery method is almost biblical in its scale and telling. Reviewing something like this is way above my ability.

The world itself is not what I would call massive in size, but the amount of locations, undergrounds, points of interests and other things is astounding. I thoroughly enjoyed just exploring and finding things out.

Other than that?
A fair share of the caves and dungeons in the game share similar layouts which at times make them seem like rehashes, aswell as some "bosses"
But that did not bother me personally during my first time playthrough.

The scenery and the world is very pretty. Pretty with vibrant colours, differing atmospheres and landscapes.
Something I enjoy dearly.

The lack of a journal or anything much similar to keep track of things is welcomed and changes the landscape and the way one is playing. The game could make you think it expected you to have an actual journal beside you to write in at times.

I also fucking love Wondorous Physick and Erdtree avatars.

9.5/10

In my eyes this is truly Miyazaki's greatest work. From the story telling and the mechanics, to the underlying impact your choices can have on the world. This game truly has it all.

As a souls game, eldern ring does exactly what can be expected of it. It challenges you to keep fighting that certain boss or level. "If I just learn those patterns" or "Oh no, I was so close!" are sentences which I believe you'll hear/experience a lot. But that is the beauty of these games. You keep and keep going, and in the end. You're left with an amazing experience.

One of the greatest games ever made so far.

Positives:
- A true open-world exploration game where you go where you wanna go, see that cool thing over there? let's go there! who knows what you might find.
- Challenging and fair enemy encounters (for the most part) where you have to pay attention to you every move in order to win.
- So many weapons, armors and playing styles that it feels like there is a near endless amount of builds you can play around with.
- A long adventure that isn't filled with repetitive copy and paste side-quests that feels like a to-do list.
- Respects your time and intelligence.
- Great characters and NPC stories.
- Bosses wont just stand there and let you heal like some moron.
- Bosses combos are made up of attacks that can be interchanged with each other, which makes it so you cant just remember the string of attacks in a combo, you have to instead truly look at what they are doing next to properly avoid their attacks.
- Some of the best level-design Fromsoft has ever made (especially the legacy dungeons), the biggest reason why IMO is thanks to the dedicated jump button which adds so many more possibilities in what Fromsoft could do with the level-design.

Negatives:
- Horse combat sucks.
- Dragons are a major letdown compared to what we got before in DS3 with Midir. Only dragons worth fighting are Lichdragon Fortissax and Dragonlord Placidusax.
- Crafting is kinda boring and wasn't as mandatory for your survival as i had hoped it would be.
- Some bigger bosses (Fire Giant, Tree Spirits, ect.) have attacks that are fully off-screen which makes it near impossible to react to the animation of the attack, which forces you to completely rely on your muscle memory of the timing of the attack, which isn't skill-based since it cant be done unless you have seen the attack multiple times before.
- Some steps in NPC-questlines can be very hard to find/understand.
- Repeat mini bosses can be a bit of a letdown sometimes.

Conclusion:
While it's not flawless, it is truly a masterpiece of a game that other developers should learn a thing or two from.
10/10 one of my favorite games ever played.

I did it all before
After playing MMORPGs for about 20 years, I had absolutely grown tired of them. The games started to feel more like a job than a form of entertainment, and I lost all hope. 

I have such an unusual taste in games: I enjoy creating my own builds, having the option for PvP, and sometimes I just want to jump in and do whatever I feel like on certain days.

I was recommended open-world games, but they never captured my interest. They were fun for about 30 minutes, and then I would find myself looking for something else.

This game is the best game I have ever played.

I can play for an hour and have fun when I don't have much time, and I can play for five hours when I do.

I never feel like I have to play it as if it were a job.

Even though this is my first soulslike game, it has opened my eyes to this genre.

10/10 without a doubt.

skibidi
best game ever
The camera is nauseating, the lock on system poor, the ui is atrocious, and the controls have an awkward amount of input delay combined with buffering issues (why do I raise my shield to block when I took my finger off the block button 2 seconds ago?) that increase difficulty artificially. I wouldn't be surprised if some of these issues were PC related because I don't remember things being nearly this bad in previous Dark Souls titles when I played on Xbox. Additionally, boss fights can be fun and challenging but the time between bosses is a chore. If you look up guides you realize that most recommend just running past the majority of enemies in the game because actually fighting them all and engaging with the level design is an arduous chore that cumulatively consumes hours and hours with little to no reward or purpose. 

Finally, and this is more of a personal gripe than I think a universally shared sentiment, I am tired the developer insisting on a lack of QOL changes. Why don't shortcuts reset after I die so that I have to call the elevator back to the floor on which I respawn? If you run out of arrows, getting more is easy but you will have to spend 5 minutes getting the points to buy more arrows, going to the vendor to purchase them, and then returning to the spot where you were when you needed the arrows in the first place. Just let me spawn with arrows after I die. Why is there no questlog so I can at least remember what is going on and have a general idea of what I should do if I want to progress a character's story? People defend this game saying these aspects are part of its charm, but whatever charm these aspects brought to the game faded quickly for me. The game insists on wasting players' time and keeping them in the dark and at this point in my life, with limited time, I really can't recommend a game where you can look back on a gaming session and genuinely feel you have accomplished nothing, not because you didn't try, but because the game, by design, stifles progress through its opacity.
No maidens?
One of the easier entry from the famous FromSoft, though don't let that mean easier to play, its still very much a Souls game in its core, but hurdles and routes to pursue the next milestone is ultimately up to you. Its its first Open World game, mechanics and UI is easy to understand.

The story is told to you as a living environment, where you'll collect details of the lore via dialogue and item description and enemy engagement. If you want to feel like a nameless hero of yor in a grand adventure within a lost world, you'll not be disappointed.

If you find yourself enjoying Elden Ring, definitely check the Soul series as a rite of passage.
My favorite game of all time, 11/10.

 A game where you‚Äôre as likely to be slain by the breathtaking views as you are by the actual enemies. It‚Äôs a world so vast, you‚Äôll need a second life just to explore it all. And let‚Äôs not forget the bosses, who are so tough, they make your tax returns look like a walk in the park.

In Elden Ring, you‚Äôll lose more souls than a ghostbuster on overtime, but the thrill of victory? Priceless. It‚Äôs the perfect blend of beauty, brutality, and ‚ÄúWhy did I just walk off that cliff again?‚Äù moments.

So, if you enjoy stunning landscapes, challenging combat, and the occasional existential crisis, Elden Ring is the game for you. Just remember, it‚Äôs not about the destination; it‚Äôs about the countless times you‚Äôll respawn along the way. 10/10 would get defeated by gravity again.

yes but its super f*ucking hard tho
This game is largely great, its amazing.  I have literally spent hundreds of hours in it and I find new things with every new play through.  My experience with it would largely be glowing, if not for what just happened to me.  Which makes me want to tell you I love everything about this game.  However before you play there are some things you need to know.  First you can spend hundreds of hours in the game and not encounter one error.   God help you if you do.  If your game gets "corrupted,"  you lose EVERYTHING.   Have 150+ hours devoted to a slot?  Gone, poof!  What corrupted you?  Who knows but the straight game is more than capable of destroying your experience.   So should you buy this game, well if your willing to take frequent breaks, maintain a saving file system where you copy your own files after you exit then yes I think this game could be a great purchase.  If you don't do this, then no I would't recommend the time investment this  would entail.  If you don't take the time to maintain your own backup system this is what awaits you, a desperate search for 3rd party hacks, editing your own save files, and going through your own file system to try to find a way to backup your game.   Your choice, at least now your informed.

stupid ass game
Fantastic game in terms of content, repeatability and options to the player. It is the best ever souls / souls-like game in terms of customisation options. Graphically and story line wise the game is spot on and the continuity is there so you don't feel totally lost in the story unlike other games.
Its a solid 75 hour 100% achievement game.
The biggest downside is the game is stupidly easy compared to previous titles in the franchise. The ability to obtain a flask very early on that prevents you from ever losing runes is silly. Coming to this game from Sekiro, even not exploiting the flask i found the bosses average at best, even Melania dropped first time.
Hopefully the DLC adds an actual challenge to the game as with a standard quality build you can pretty much walk through the game.
Achievement wise, they were pretty box standard for souls and considering the size of the game, they were reasonably obtainable. I hope the DLC stays on these tracks
Well worth the purchase if you enjoy the franchise

buy it bro..?

skill issue
Still not a big fan of having 98% of the story and lore being hidden and not easily discovered but that's just a preference. What is there is good enough to keep you interested in trying to find more. Visual Design and Execution are top tier as to be expected of FromSoftware. Ambiance with the visuals tying in with the music makes it really easy to lose track of time. Outside of the forced to discover most of the story in hidden spots stuff the only real complaint I have is just the lack of options to manipulate the End-User Experience, my eyes hurt from the chromatic aberration, the lack of ability to tweak any UI or Caption visuals to better personalize their readability and the number one complaint - no FOV customization. I imagine its probably to help with how gameplay is designed to be and make the player feel, but being so close in 3rd person seems to make me have similar symptoms to motion sickness so it does kinda suck I can't tweak some of these settings without then having to use mods and going thru that whole mess to get a mod for FOV or UI to get around dumb anticheat software, too much of a headache to deal with for me to do, so it just would be cool if the game just let you. All in all, I'd recommend the game, just hope the developer allows some bit of freedom in customization of settings later down the road, or you know the stupid anticheat stuff is dropped that we all know doesn't work anyway but companies still keep shoving in there.

‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†à‚†ª‚¢ø‚£∂‚£¶‚£º‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚†ø‚£ª‚£ø‚°º‚†â‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†à‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚¢ø‚¢ø‚£ª‚£ü‚£Ω‚£≥‚°Ω‚†ì‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†à‚¢ª‚£∑‚£±‚£∂‚£∂‚†æ‚°ø‚†õ‚†ã‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†â‚†à‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I want to start off by clarifying this is not my favorite genre. I find most solo character action-RPGs to be lonely affairs, I much prefer the Mass Effects and Baldur's Gate style campaigns that focus on party characters. With that said, Elden Ring's beautiful world is loaded with incredible environments, intimidating foes, and an endless sense of wonder and exploration. The action is fluid, engaging, and varied.

I enjoyed this game primarily with heavy use of the wikipedia and tutorials. I honestly feel like that is how the game is designed to be used; it is much more fun for me to have a target artifact I want to recover from some deep catacomb, some area I missed on my own that I have to carefully backtrack and find what I missed. 

I also played through most of the game with the Seamless Co-Op mod, which changes multiplayer from limited to asking for assistance only in boss areas to making the entire game something you can explore with a friend. I much preferred this style, although it does have the downside of disconnecting you from the amusing and frequently helpful messages left for you by other players. 

All this to say - this game is a masterpiece. Even if it's not your usual cup of tea, I encourage you to try it out.  If you find it lonely, try the co-op mod. If you're stuck, don't hesitate to google a guide or watch a video on a cool build you could try. The game is worth the journey.
if you think this game is bad then you are a poopy pants!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
"Shadow bathes in light and knows weakness"
Elden Ring is a captivating game that offers an immersive and challenging experience. It's a game that will take you through a roller coaster of emotions. You'll feel anger as you face its toughest challenges, exhilaration when you finally overcome them, and sorrow for the mountains of experience points you lose along the way to some of the toughest boss encounters FromSoftware has ever conceived.

The game is set in the "Lands Between" and you play as a "Tarnished" of no renown, blessed by grace, and are compelled to make the journey to The Lands Between and become an Elden Lord. The grand story is hard to fully digest on a first playthrough, especially because there‚Äôs no in-game journal to refresh you on the events, characters, or unique terms you encounter across dozens of hours.

The open-world exploration and crafting mechanics have clearly been inspired by Nintendo‚Äôs Breath of the Wild¬≤. The game is very similar to previous Dark Souls games, but with an open-world format like Skyrim. The game's world is vast and full of things to discover. The combat is rewarding and punishing, and there's more content than most players will ever need.

However, the game's high difficulty means it may not be suitable for more casual gamers. Some fights are very difficult, and the final stretch of the game makes the first 100 hours look like a vacation. Most Souls games end with a punishing boss, or at worst two. But Elden Ring ends with four.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a masterpiece that offers a rich and rewarding gaming experience. It's a game that will test your skills and patience, but also reward you with a sense of accomplishment and awe. It's a game that's worth every hour spent playing it.

This was my introduction into the Souls games and let me tell ya, it's amazing. I made the mistake of getting super frustrated at the bosses more times than I care to admit. That being said, do your best to go into it with the mindset of learning the moves/mechanics of the game/bosses. Persevere and you will be rewarded with hands down one of the best games of the last ten years. From the intricate story to the stunning open world, there is so much to do and appreciate in this game.

Almost 150 hours in and I still have not found every item or weapon, nor every boss. If you are into Souls games, you will fall in love with this one. Just remember to go into it with a mindset of learning and adapting, and you will have the time of your life. Even if you haven't played a Souls or Souls-like game before, I still HIGHLY recommend you give it a try, you won't regret it.

Elden Ring is everything I love about From's games and so much more. The sheer amount and depth of content dwarfs any other title by a large margin. 

My favorite part of the game, especially nearing mid/late game, is how resourceful the game encourages you to be as the difficulty ramps up. It heavily rewards you for being flexible with your build and finding new tools/gear to help you overcome challenges in a way I've never seen in a Souls-Like before, and I LOVE IT.

There's honestly not much I could say about Elden ring that hasn't been said by just about anyone who's played the game, It's a masterpiece. The open world is huge but also dense with things to find and fight. 

They have taken every good mechanic from their previous games and they have made a true gem of a game. 10/10
Every enemy in this game has this really weird and annoying windup, where they'll start their attack, hold the animation for like 2-6 seconds, and then let out the attack in like 2 frames. it's more like a test of attention span rather than skill, because they hold it for so long i literally get distracted by my other monitor before it even comes out. especially Margit. he has this move where he holds his staff above his head, goes for a nice afternoon stroll, and then he'll grab it with 2 hands and do another windup for like 2 seconds, and then slam it down instantaneously. like the windup is so long i could apply for a job, go to the interview, get married, have kids, grow old, and die of terminal brain damage at the age of 53 before he lets it out. i don't mind the ridiculously long windup on stuff like bosses, but when basically everything you fight in the game does it, it just feels like a stupid gimmick. I have like 190 hours and i still do not have the timing down for margit's stupid downslam. also this game runs really bad for some reason. i've had constant stuttering issues on low settings, and i meet the requirements on steam (16GB RAM, RTX 3070, Ryzen 5 3600). also a little pet peave of mine is that every spell and magical weapon art use the same ear piercing sound. it gets incredibly annoying in some areas, and even more annoying when you go for a spellcaster. the lore's nothing special. i've watched the documentaries people made on it and there's like- nothing. like it explains the story of the bosses, and their stories aren't anything special. like Radahn fights melania and gets his feet taken away and has to ride his treasured horse in the desert forever. Mohg is an average Alabama resident and kidnaps his baby brother for some weird shit. The capital is racist and threw Mohg and Morgot in the sewers because they *gasp* have horns, and that's bad. the world design is ok imo. overall i'd probably give this a 7/10, the combat really weighs it down because it's just a waiting game.
So basically, you'll get a stick or something similar you'll spam hit over and over and over and over and over then roll then spam again over and over and over and over and over and life goes on. Eventually you either make it or chaos make you, pretty easy if you think about it.

I returned to Elden Ring after a bit of a hiatus and it is a genuinely astounding game. I continue to find entire areas to explore that I never even realized were there, and I continue to find new weapons, builds, and playstyles to engage with. And I know I'm barely scratching the surface, I'm still on my first run. It's an amazing game that deserves your time and patience, because sometimes it will test it. But I've found that the game has a great way of making you take a step back, re-evaluate, and come back to a problem later. I'm a busy person, and Elden Ring's structure means that I have a lot of check in points that make it easy to put the game down for a bit and pick it up when I have time without missing a step.

2nd best fromsoft game, right behind dark souls 2
[h3]A Journey of a Game[/h3]
Same Darksouls'esk combat, but now in an open world (and with a designated jump button).
Game is massive and can take casual players (like myself) upwards of a hundred hours to see it all, but the game is quite an impressive feat. If such an aspect seems daunting, don't be discouraged as you can chip away at the game at your own pace. 

Whilst I recommend this game, my one noticeable gripe is the heavier focus on a lot of bosses having a lot of intentionally delayed attacks, which can really throw out players dodge timing. This is more apparent with some bosses than others, but this overused aspect is done enough where some hits you take may feel unfair. 

That said; Game is a lot more generous on progression and how you chose to tackle obstacles. Being an open world vs the more linear gameplay of the Soulsborne series, it allows you to explore other areas if you end up running into a tough boss or area. Game encourages exploration, and (at times) rewards players for said exploration. 

Overall, Fromsoft took the best of what worked in their other souls games and applied them here into one big package. 
Enjoy.

the tree sentinel is harder than malenia, but other than that, pretty easy. i'm definitely the blade of miquella now
my first real attempt at playing a souls title and its quickly turned into one of my favourite games
Life-changing. First experience with a massive open world and true souls experience, and it completely changed my mindset on what a single player could be. From the sheer volume of side-quests, dungeons, nooks, and crannies to explore to the incredibly well designed and unique boss designs, this game really managed to capture the "soul" of a true medieval fantasy open world. In terms of visuals, there's little in the way of competition: the scenery and attention to detail for each and every single biome and castle was painstakingly detailed and it showed. The game-play was revolutionary in the myriad of ways to cater the game to your exact preference: from magic to strength builds, the game is playable in every way imaginable with the bosses to test your skills to their absolute max. Lastly, the story. With the legend George R. R. Martin spearheading the story, it's little surprise that the story was a masterpiece. Fed piecemeal throughout the game, it balanced answering questions with even more questions and gave opportunity to massive lore pages to explore the finer details of the game in exciting, fun new ways. However, the game can become a little difficult and almost requires you to search things up at some points to progress forward, but there are plenty of resources available. (Performance also held steady for the most part, but it's capped at 60 fps).  An absolute recommendation for anyone who's willing to struggle, explore, and enjoy a breathtaking story set amidst breathtaking visuals.

Elden Peak >>> Ubislop
Probably the best first playthrough of any game ever.
Don't really like open worlds (and imo the open world aspect of this game is not super interesting to me and sometimes detracts from the quality and memorability of areas) but this game delivers on the joy of exploration very well. The combat is tight and intense, though too many bosses have bs moves that you need to look up how to dodge. The start of the game to me is the weakest, I just could not for the life of me figure out where to go to get stronger to be able to beat Margit, so I ended beating my head against the wall for like 3 hours until I took him down. Pretty demoralizing. There were many points where I had to put the game down due to lack of interest, but eventually I came back and by god the final third of the game is so much fun. Definitely an overall good experience, though certainly not a perfect game (as with the dark souls games)

Elden Ring is possibly the best action RPG game of the last 10 years and certainly earned game of the year. Great visuals, beautiful graphics and a wild story & characters. The mechanics are easy to learn and difficult to master. It's very satisfying to play.
Don't let people lie to you about the difficulty. Elden Ring is only as hard as you want it to be. A strength build with the Lion's Claw Greatsword and Rotten Stray summon absolutely steamrolls the game and can easily be set up in less than an hour. Likewise magic can trivialize the difficulty as well. No matter your skill level, you can experience Elden Ring to the fullest.

Do I have to say something???
After on and off playing for two years, I have completed all achievements and am ready to make a review. I will start by saying if youre on the edge about buying this game, do yourself a favor and make the purchase. This is one of the best experiences I have ever had in gaming, from overcoming challenges to exploration and character customization. I have beaten the game three times now on three characters, each using a drastically different build. Finishing your first play-through is daunting as the game is HUGE, but coming back with prior knowledge and then trying out weapons and spells that your build did not allow before is worthwhile and satisfying. Elden Ring has some complex lore, and finding out what is happening is another entire can of worms you are optionally able to open through item descriptions and environment storytelling. This is a whole other layer to the game I explored my second time playing, scouring every inch of the lands between in search of new information to piece together about the demigods, the shattering, and factions. Again, this is entirely optional, the game does not hold your hand in any regard, and treats its players with a level of respect and trust barely seen in todays gaming culture. Overall, I reccommend Elden Ring to anyone looking for a vast open world, a tough challenge, and a replayable masterpiece.

Title: "Elden Ring: A Mesmerizing Symphony of Lore and Gameplay"

Elden Ring is nothing short of a magnum opus in the realm of action RPGs, brought to life by the venerable FromSoftware and the legendary narrative craftsmanship of George R.R. Martin. This collaboration has resulted in a game that is both an ode to classic high fantasy and a testament to the evolving landscape of interactive storytelling.

From the moment you step into the Lands Between, the sheer scale of Elden Ring's open world is both daunting and exhilarating. The meticulous world-building is evident in every corner, from the hauntingly beautiful ruins of ancient civilizations to the grotesque, Lovecraftian monstrosities that roam the land. The environmental storytelling is unparalleled, with each locale offering a tapestry of lore that beckons the player to explore and unravel the mysteries of this fractured world.

The gameplay mechanics are a harmonious blend of familiar Soulsborne elements and innovative new features. Combat is as visceral and precise as ever, demanding both skill and strategy. The addition of a dedicated jump button and mounted combat on your spectral steed, Torrent, adds a refreshing layer of verticality and mobility to encounters. The intricate web of character customization, spellcasting, and weaponry ensures that no two playthroughs are ever the same, encouraging players to experiment and adapt.

Multiplayer interactions, through both cooperative and competitive play, seamlessly integrate into the world. The phantasmal silhouettes of other players, bloodstains revealing their demises, and cryptic messages left behind all contribute to a sense of a shared, yet solitary, journey. This asynchronous multiplayer experience enhances the game's immersion, making the world feel alive and inhabited by countless unseen souls.

Elden Ring‚Äôs narrative is a rich, interwoven tapestry that demands active engagement. The lore is dispersed through item descriptions, NPC dialogues, and environmental cues, rewarding players who take the time to delve deeper into the story. The convergence of George R.R. Martin's mythos with Hidetaka Miyazaki's signature storytelling results in a narrative that is both grand in scope and intimate in its emotional beats.

The graphics and art direction are nothing short of breathtaking. The juxtaposition of ethereal beauty and grotesque horror creates a visual symphony that is both mesmerizing and unsettling. Each frame of Elden Ring could be a painting, meticulously crafted to evoke a sense of awe and dread.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a masterclass in game design, world-building, and storytelling. It stands as a monumental achievement in the genre, pushing the boundaries of what an open-world action RPG can be. Whether you are a seasoned Souls veteran or a newcomer to FromSoftware‚Äôs enigmatic worlds, Elden Ring offers an unforgettable journey that will be discussed and dissected for years to come. Prepare to lose yourself in the Lands Between, where every death is a lesson and every discovery is a triumph.

Many many many many hours of gameplay, able to co-op inviting friends. 

Downside: Quests are unclear and have no trackable progress in game (like a quest journal) and some activities can cause quests to be incompletable. 
Downside to co-op: You can be invaded by other players who can kill you to delay your progress who can try to bait you into enemies who wont attack them. BUT you can kill them and get runes and items as rewards. However especially at low level zones, you get invaded by people in end game gear who just want to kill lowbies to prevent them from progressing. Also cant invite players to join in an area you have defeated the big boss in. Can still be invited to their games in that zone.

Well worth it though. Many many playstyles, able to respec completely after progressing to a certain point and try other playstyles.

100/10
Lives up to hype.
i cant withstand this beauty.
[h1]The Worst: Questing[/h1]
No journal, no explanation, no narration, no lore. 
You meet a dude randomly in a field, he gives you a "cursed putrid eyeball of swamp a baby" and asks you to bring it to Bob the Cursed Eyeball Eater. You search everywhere, can't find him. Then search google just to find that he spawns in some cave that you cleared 20hrs ago and didn't even thought of returning there. You go there and find a "Ball Bearing [Bob]". Turns out when you step your foot into some world region before talking to Bob he goes ahead and dies. Congrats you've locked yourself out of reward for the rest of the game.

[h1]The Bad: Controls[/h1]
Console Port. 
Not the worst port I've seen but the fact that [b]you have one button for sprint & dodge[/b] on PC speaks volumes. And don't even get me started on target locking. You fight a boss, you skillfully dodge his attacks and charge up your counter and then some random squirrel runs into view screen. Lock switches to squirrel last second and it gets obliterated by your "mega death laser attack". YOU DIED!
You have [1..0] buttons on your keyboard to access items on PC. What you do instead? - Press [Cycle Item] couple of times and then press [Use Item]. Oh you scrolled past the healing pot? Too bad - scroll again. YOU DIED!

[h1]The Alright - Gameplay[/h1]
The bosses. 
Let's be real here - the main point of this game is killing bosses. You grind some gear and XP, learn some moves and then test your skill against "Cursed Sad Omen of Despair" or something. You get head bashed in tens of times then you figure out that either you're under level or your build is complete trash. You farm better gear and new levels, get some more healing pots and then kill the boss on your 5th try. Then you go find next one to fight. It is extremely satisfying to figure out bosses moves, dodge them and then punish the boss. Except Runebears.. YOU DIED!


[h1]The Good - Builds[/h1]
The amount of weapons, armor and magic is crazy! There are fixed ways you can play the game - slow melee, fast melee, magic, (not sure about bow feels lacking). But the variations of gear and skills you can apply to each of this play style is huge! Wanna be classic paladin? No problem! Wanna be mage? Sure! Wanna be naked butt dude with a leather gimp mask and whip? No-one is stopping you! This honestly is a selling point for the replayability - you can go NG+ or start a new game just to try out new build in hopes of finding something OP that would wreck the boss that gave you nightmares back when.

[h1]The Great - Art[/h1]
The world.
It is MASSIVE and beautiful.  The amount of land you can explore, nooks and crannies to wonder into and secrets to find is just mind blowing. There is something very enchanting about the art in this game. Maybe because it is so surreal and defies anything I've seen in other open world titles but its definitely breathtaking. The world feels a bit dead though and I keep wondering if it is by design or just poor communication of lore to the player.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Honestly don't know why it's critically acclaimed, I'd give it [7/10]. This i s a solid game that will keep calling you back even despite the awful console port.

CONCLUSION: Dark Souls 4 in open world (unfortunately audio, animations, hud...are pretty same. I expect different/new elements in the game with a new title). For those who have never played DS games before, the elden ring will be one of the best games ever in SL genre, it is also more accessible for weaker players in SL world. On the other hand you can find amazing boss fights here, great exploration of open world and the character development is as deep as you would expect from dark souls genre and thats my biggest plus of this game.

In the realm of Elden Ring, where ethereal mists shroud the ancient lands and forgotten kingdoms, a masterpiece emerges, wrought by the hands of celestial artisans. The tapestry of this world, woven with intricate lore and formidable foes, beckons the intrepid adventurer. Each step taken on hallowed ground unveils the grand narrative, an epic of fallen gods and cursed legacies. The combat, an art of calculated precision, demands unwavering resolve. Enigmatic landscapes, sculpted with arcane finesse, whisper secrets to those who dare explore. Elden Ring, a paragon of interactive storytelling, ensnares the soul, offering a transcendent odyssey through its somber magnificence.
Try fingers

Absolute Epicness!
Best game for solo play
One of the best games ever!
goated
FromSoftware has once again woven a masterpiece with Elden Ring, a game that transcends the boundaries of traditional RPGs and sets a new standard for open-world gaming. As a longtime fan of FromSoftware's work, I approached Elden Ring with high expectations, and I can confidently say that it not only met but exceeded every one of them.

One of the most striking aspects of Elden Ring is its vast and breathtaking open world. The Lands Between is a sprawling, interconnected realm filled with awe-inspiring landscapes, hidden secrets, and diverse ecosystems. From the towering mountains of Limgrave to the ethereal beauty of the Weeping Peninsula, every corner of the world feels meticulously crafted and teeming with life. The sense of exploration is unparalleled, with every hill and valley beckoning the player to uncover its mysteries.

But it's not just the world itself that impresses; it's what you do in it that truly sets Elden Ring apart. The game offers unparalleled freedom, allowing players to tackle challenges in any order they choose. Whether you prefer to engage in epic boss battles, delve into ancient ruins, or embark on quests for the game's myriad NPCs, there's always something new and exciting to discover. The sheer scope of content is staggering, with hundreds of hours of gameplay awaiting those who dare to venture off the beaten path.

Of course, no FromSoftware game would be complete without its trademark difficulty, and Elden Ring delivers in spades. Combat is as punishing as ever, requiring precise timing, strategic thinking, and a willingness to learn from failure. But unlike some of the developer's previous titles, Elden Ring strikes a perfect balance between challenge and accessibility. With a wide range of weapons, spells, and abilities at your disposal, there's always a solution to even the toughest of encounters, encouraging experimentation and creativity.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of Elden Ring is its storytelling. FromSoftware has crafted a rich and immersive narrative that unfolds organically as you explore the world. Through cryptic item descriptions, enigmatic NPCs, and haunting environmental storytelling, players are gradually drawn into a dark and fascinating tale of gods, dragons, and the fate of the world itself. It's a narrative that rewards patience and attention to detail, with each new revelation adding depth and meaning to the world around you.

In the end, Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece. It's a game that pushes the boundaries of what we thought possible in an open-world RPG, offering unparalleled freedom, challenge, and storytelling in equal measure. From its breathtaking world design to its punishing yet rewarding combat, every aspect of the game feels meticulously crafted and expertly executed. Whether you're a longtime fan of FromSoftware or a newcomer to the genre, Elden Ring is an experience that simply cannot be missed. With its richly detailed world, challenging gameplay, and compelling storytelling, it's not just a game ‚Äì it's a journey. And it's one that I'll gladly embark on again and again. Elden Ring is, without a doubt, a perfect 10 out of 10.

I really can't reccomend this game enough. Elden Ring is my first soulsborne game, and i (as expected) got completely destroyed in my first couple hours of playing. i ended up uninstalling is and shelfing the game for a couple of months until a friend got me into it again. now i'm about 60 hours in my save file and i can confirm that thisone of the best games i have ever played. the environment is gorgeous, the combat is exciting while also giving a sense of accomplishment, and don't even get me started on how much i love the characters and the voice acting. the biggest hurdle i believe is the combat, and how some enemies aren't even meant to be defeated the first time you encounter them. the best way to get around this though is to take things slow at first and to not bash your head into an enemy too much at the start (like i did).

Incredibly overhyped. The story might as well not exist but the characters expect you to know who they are. The boss fights are designed to punish you for trying to follow the timing of the fights. The UI is from the early 2000s. Worst aspect of this game is the camera controls. They are a crime considering how punishing this game is. I really cant over emphasizze how bad the camera is, Target lock is required for many fights because the enemies can fly/teleport/super jump but if the game doesnt detect you are looking exactly at the enemy it will spin around to your characters facing direction. This is often lethal because odds are you are side strafing or backing up. Target lock switches automatically when an enemy dies and if you happen to dodge an incoming attack from the 2nd enemy you will dodge in a different direction. The camera has a max angle and many bosses will fly up directly over you and can't be seen.  Many bosses are in confined spaces which mess with the camera if you get close to a wall. There is particular giant lizard tree thing in these spaces that is around a quarter of the room but can leap across the whole space in under a second which leads to the camera flying around or through the boss making it useless.  I honestly can't believe that there were previous games made by this developer in this genre (that they defined) because this feels like the bottom of the barrel.
10/10. Unstoppable nautilus build. De nghi Fromsoft can bang lai game. WOULD RECOMMEND.
I'm sure this is a fine game, just... not for me. if you already struggle with real life, then getting kicked in the balls by a depressingly dreary and difficult game just isn't it. no disrespect, just.... I imagine you gotta be in the right mindset to like this

If you like Dark Souls, BB, Demon Souls, ect you'll probably like this a lot. The variety of weapons, spells, and armor is almost overwhelming. As such there is a lot of build variety. PVP is business as usual if you liked it in the other games you'll like it in this game. My only complaints are some side dungeons feel kind of unnecessary (very similar), there are regular enemies reused as bosses, and npc quest lines can be very annoying to keep track of as there are many of them. Its not fun finding out a quest line is ruined because I stepped into a different zone. To be fair this has always been a thing in souls games so its whatever. Overall an amazing game that I definitely recommend, especially if your a souls fan.
Playing Elden Ring feels like trying to navigate a labyrinth blindfolded, with a chicken drumstick in one hand and a rubber ducky in the other. It's chaotic, it's absurd, and I love every second of it! 10/10, would get lost in the Land Between again... just as soon as I find my way out of this boss fight!

Shit game <3
This game is very hard. It took over my life for 2 months and there were times where I absolutely hated this game. I almost quit many times. I kept at it because I didn't want it to beat me and I found some of it fun. A lot of it feels unfairly difficult though.  
I did get serious burnout from playing this game. This game is not as good as what a lot of people say. I put so much energy in trying over and over to beat creatures and bosses that a lot of the lore was lost on me because the intense difficulty does often break the immersion as it's beyond "a bit challenging"
People will say "well this game doesn't hold your hand" which is true enough. But in many places, the game also expects you to be psychic, because there were lots of places where I thought "How was anyone supposed to know that, or figure that out" which I feel is not the same thing as "not holding your hand". When I looked for solutions, I often found many other confused people who thought the same as I did. I think those who say they didn't need to look up tips on how to beat at least some of the bosses or how to do things in the game are lying. 
I deliberately waited three months to leave a review because I knew that if I did it right after I finished the game, it would have been negative. Finishing the game was like finally leaving a relationship that has too much of a hold on you in an unhealthy way. But now some of the rose tinted glasses are kicking in a little and I'm remembering some of the good parts of the game. The music, how it looks, the landscapes/scenery, and even though I didn't know what I was doing or why I was doing it most of the time, it was good to explore this world. 
When I finally killed Elden Beast, I turned it off with 100% achievements and said "Never Again" with this game. But, three months on, I'm not so sure. Maybe when I can get the upcoming DLC on a sale, I'll get it if the sale is good enough and play it. Maybe not straight away as I need a much bigger gap away from this game before I ever pick it up again. 
This was my first Souls game. In fact, I didn't even know what a souls game was until I had started playing, and the friend who recommended it to me explained it to me. it was definitely a learning curve.  
I can't see me ever picking up a different souls game because I realised it wasn't really my thing, but I might play this again one day. Especially as I've heard this is a baby when it comes to souls games and by no means the most punishing one. 
If you like a challenge, this isn't it. The word I'd describe this game is "Punishing". It's just a whole other level. But also "Intriguing" and "Beautiful"
So I will recommend this game to try, but a soft recommend with caution. You might want to quit early on. But if you don't, it will keep pulling you back even though you often hate it. But I'm still glad that I didn't quit early.

Other than that, this is one of the best games I've ever played. Great graphics, an abundance of freedom of choice to go anywhere and do anything in the way you want to do it. Combat is challenging, and will quickly put you in your place if you aren't giving it the proper attention.

The only gripe I have with Elden Ring is that the FromSoftware mindset of "figure it out yourself" does not translate very well to an open world game. yes
AAA
I've played all the souls games and Elden Ring is easily my favorite. The game is beautiful, the bosses are interesting and challenging, character builds are better than ever, and the game is freaking HUGE. On my first playthrough I spent over 100 hours exploring everything and still managed to miss several full areas with enemies, bosses, and quests that I went back for after beating the game.

The combat and character building really shine in this game. I've never seen an RPG that gives the player this much freedom to build and fine tune their character. There are practically infinite combinations of weapons, armors, stats, spells, talismans, and weapon skills. Each playthrough with a new build is a different experience and the build variety keeps PvP fresh and exciting.

Don't be worried about the difficulty if this is your first souls game, the open world format is great for inexperienced players. When you get stuck on a boss, there‚Äôs no need to grind it out and ‚Äúgit gud‚Äù enough to progress. Just go explore the world for a bit, level up and come back later. If you‚Äôre still struggling, you can summon spirit ashes, another player, or both to help you. Not to mention there are some broken character builds that make the game much easier.

The only bad thing about this game is that many of the bosses and enemies are reused. During the first half of the game you'll see nothing but new enemies that feel like they belong, but the late game content feels more rushed. The Mountaintops and Haligtree (two endgame areas) don't have a single unique non-boss enemy in them. All duo fights are just two solo bosses from earlier thrown into one arena, which feels lazy and unfair especially when compared to good duo fights from other souls games. Most of them are optional, but the most annoying one is required to beat the game.

Overall, this is the most polished souls game to date and I think everyone should have the chance to experience it. Even with the cons it's absolutely worth the $60 price tag, but it goes on sale for around $40 every few months if you're willing to be patient.

I've never gotten hold of any of the Souls games day one, but I did get Dark Souls 3 just as the Ringed City released. While I generally hate FOMO marketing, it definitely makes a difference to play these games while there are lots of players, with everybody still figuring things out. If you're 100% certain you won't use the online parts of the game then you should wait for a sale though.

Price wise, you can get this and the upcoming DLC for nearly the same price that Elden Ring released at. Not even referring to the dodgy cd key resellers here, Shadow of the Erdtree is a big release so plenty of legitimate shops are doing deals.
Best AAA game of the decade, by quite a margin.
The best game I ever played, I love it
An excellent open-world RPG in all aspects.
It's kinda like a sekisoulsbornecuphead.
If you're a Soulsborne fan, then this game will scratch that itch.  FromSoftware really knocked it out of the park on this one.
My only complaint: I don't like the PvP in this game as much as in Dark Souls 3, but it's still better than Dark Souls 1 PvP, imho.

Other than my small issues with the PvP, I love almost everything:

The massive open world is fun to explore if you like exploring,  It's chock full of hidden items, caves, catacombs, hero graves (basically dungeons), surprise encounters...just about everything.

Huge weapon variety.  
Larger than average moveset variety for a FromSoftware game.
Ashes of War enable me to expand the potential of every weapon via adding a new move to the weapon that either enhances it inherent strengths, or to shore up the weaknesses.  I love the flexibility.

I could gush for several more paragraphs, but if I haven't convinced you by now, I'm probably not going to.
Check it out if you enjoy the poorly-defined souls-like genre.

This game was the realization of all those saturday morning living room floor imaginings I had in the 80s while playing games where you were a white square trying to find a key in a maze while lost in a caste rendered entirely by white lines. Feels like Ive been chasing those fantasies with every game Ive played since, and some have come close, but what From did with Elden Ring reminded me of that awe I felt as a kid and its easily my favorite game ever made.
