gud
Masterpiece.
This is a poorly designed game.

 * Over world map designed to waste your time: the map is full of mile-high cliffs everywhere. You'll fast-travel to a spot next to where you want to go, immediately run into a cliff, pick a direction to follow it around, and then after spending five minutes traveling in the opposite direction you'll go back and try the other direction for several minutes, and then give up and fast travel to some random spot somewhere totally else and ride for 3-4 minutes on your horse to get there. This happens all the time.

 * Encounter difficulty may as well be randomly generated: the moment you start the game you get splattered by a mid-game boss. Then after finishing the tutorial, you get immediately splattered by yet another boss hanging outside the newbie area. Meanwhile, 20 hours into the game and I'm still finding one-shottable trash mobs in higher levels zones that I just ride past and ignore because they don't give enough xp to matter. Why couldn't I have had some of those in the newbie area and why is the game wasting my time with them later on? And the ACTUAL early game bosses are so well hidden that you'll probably never find most of them without looking them up online and riding 3-5 minutes to get to them, maybe riding past a DRAGON to get to them, and then after you do this a couple times you'll stop bothering because they don't drop anything that matters.

 * Terrible itemization: Most items in the game have no reason to exist. 2% drop rate items from mobs that are worse that your new character starting gear, vendors that sell things you'll never use, a crafting system that will overfill your screen with materials for random useless things you'll never make, resistance items you'll have forgotten about by the time you find anything that does that type of damage, armor and weapon upgrades that don't matter because their bonuses are so small that it still takes exactly the same number of hits to die or kill anything. Sometimes whether you're wearing your best gear or playing naked, it just doesn't make much difference.

 * Ridiculous fake difficulty everywhere: traps in low-level areas that teleport you INSIDE of mid-game dungeon and disable your fast travel so you either delete the character and start over or check online for videos showing the path to get out and then do corpse runs for 10 minutes hoping to get lucky and have stuff miss you while you run out. Stuff mixed in with mobs you can easily fight, but oops THAT ONE can one-shot you and now it's time to do another corpse run. Weird stupid things like, if you get hit while on horseback, your horse stops running to give enemies time to kill you, stuff that kills you while you're looking at menus, artillery blasts that shoot from off-screen and can one-shot you, mobs so big that you can't see what they're doing because their butt in in your face and their weapon is offscreen behind you and of course the game doesn't let you zoom out, etc.

 * The core, central difficulty of the game comes from one thing: any time anything happens, YOUR CONTROLS STOP WORKING. Swing your sword? Can't do anything until the animation finishes. Get hit? Can't do anything until the recoil animation finishes. Get knocked off your horse? You almost have time to take a drink while you wait to stand up. And the game is completely full of these stupidly long windup and cool down animations, so you start an attack, but oops the boss stated his next move at the same time and he's faster than you so his attack will land before yours...so you mash the block key 2-3 times, but NOTHING HAPPENS because your character is stuck in an animation and dies even though you the human at the keyboard reacted in time to hit block several times, but the game just ignores you. This is the PRIMARY CORE MECHANIC of Elden Ring: waiting for animations to finish.

 * Bad port with terrible controls: Who in their right mind thought that w-f-left shift-mouseclick was a good key command for a jumping attack? What about the fact that you can't CLICK ON THE MAP to select a fast travel destination? Instead, you either vertically scroll through a list to find the name of the spot, or use wasd to scroll the map, the f to say you want to go to a spot then e to select the spot. Whoever made this has never played a PC game before, and it's like they were throwing darts of the keyboard to choose commands. Why does g bring up the map, not m? And while some of it you can remap, some of it you can't. I played for over 20 hours not knowing how to RUN because there's no key or mouse you can click to run. Instead, you have to press your dodge key...but keep holding it down for a second or so until you start running. Standing next to a message on the ground, but you're on horse back? Horses have a minimum move distance, so you tap a key to move, but you move past the thing, then turn around and tap the key again and still don't land close enough to read the message. Want to use an item you have hotkeyed? No problem, just press 2, 2, 2, over and over to scroll through the list of items you have hotkeyed, then R to use it, then 2 to get back to the original item. You can't hotkey an item to a number. The controls are just bad.

 * Even when you win, it's not fun: this isn't an action RPG. You don't "play" Elden Ring like a game. Instead, you pick an area, and then simply spam die in it over and over learning the specific move sets of the mobs that live there, trial-and-erroring your way through to figure out what the "correct" thing to do is in response to whatever action they pick from their move list. And they don't telegraph well. Sometimes it's HARD even to distinguish one of their moves from another. Like, is he going to do the exact same lead up and stab two times, or the same lead up and stab three times? If you react after two, you get hit by the third stab. But if you anticipate the third stab and don't attack, maybe he only stabs twice, then it's too late and you go back to waiting for an opening. Sometimes they'll start a move...but then if you react in a certain why they'll CHANGE their move to something else. So gameplay is about memorizing these awful combinations of, if boss does this, you do this, and then if they do A you do B but if they do C you do D. And if you're off by a quarter of a second, you just die sometimes because they do so much damage. A lot of stuff will kill you in two hits and some will kill you in one. You can be two minutes into a boss fight thinking you're going to win, but then oops, you were off by quarter of a second or misjudged one attack for another, so too bad, you're dead, start over. Typically when you find a new boss, you die instantly, then it's 2 minutes of reloading and running back only to die instantly again...over and over until you learn a couple responses to their moves so you can survival to a couple seconds...then 30 seconds...then eventually after an hour of this you're able to beat the boss. Sometimes. Or you might just give up and come back 20 levels later and STILL not be able to beat it. But when you finally do...it doesn't feel like "yay! I beat the boss!" It feels like "FINALLY IT'S OVER." 

That's what this game is. "Finally, it's over." Do you want to feel that over and over? If yes, buy Elden Ring. If not, buy something else.

Very mean, but realistic
It has to be the best game I have played
Open world: Huge, very creative environments, maybe a bit repetitive and empty at times.

Combat: Not much improved over DS3; wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle. 

Quests: Abysmal quest design, no logs and very vague instructions most of the time. It was cool in Dark Souls but it gets overwhelming with so many quests going on simultaneously in an open world.

Bosses: The absolute worst in Souls history. Using spirit ashes makes them trivial, not using them is just beyond unpleasant. There were a few I liked, but most needed you to learn obnoxious mechanics, delayed attack combos, etc., instead of forcing you to learn game mechanics like the bosses in Sekiro.

ITS FUN
Immaculate game I used fucking Abe Lincoln to beat the shit out of demi gods is was great.
Incredible work of art. In my opinion the most accessible soulsbourne game just because you can pretty much make the game as hard as you want. Instead of adding a difficulty option like most other games, they add features like summons and more powerful weapons, as well as making level grinding allot faster. The bosses are generally well designed and challenging. My favorite bosses would be Morgott, Godfrey (both versions), Godrick and of course the hardest boss of them all Rick Soldier Of God. Although some bosses are pretty frustrating and badly designed like Godskin Duo and especially Elden Beast who is also unfortunately the final boss of the game. There is also The Fire Giant who serves as a major roadblock in skill, however i do not think he is badly designed. Most of his attacks are learnable, and not too terrible to dodge, it's just the absurd amount of health and absolutely terrible camera system,which always seems to be a detriment to me during bossfights with large enemies like Fire Giant, Elden Beast and most dragons. Another difficult boss is Malenia, the hardest boss n the game and widely hated for her incredibly bullcrap attacks that hit like a truck. I have not beaten her, however i think her attacks are very learnable and not as downright rng based as Elden Beast. Oh and also this game takes allot of inspiration from Berserk which is amazing. And also there is a weapon known as Darkmoon Greatsword, which is a direct reference to The Moonlight Sword from King's Field, one of my favorite franchises (which you should deffinetly play, they are awesome games also made by Fromsoftware). This game has incredible potential for a perfect game, however some bosses are just straight up badly designed. I give Elden Ring a 9/10. Elden Beast can suck my dick.

best game till day
There is a lot to do in this game. And, on the surface, that sounds great for the average player. But for those who are true fans of the dark souls franchise, and expecting an experience similar to that, I feel like Elden Ring falls short.

The core experience of playing this game is completely different from previous titles. The open-world nature of the game, boundless consumable items/pickups, cooking???, bell-bearings and all similar nonsense simply is not in line with the dark souls experience.

As a mage build I cannot state how disappointing it was to find that Glintstone Pebble, the starting spell, is the best spell in the game until around 60+ INT (unless you happen to find the Meteorite Staff and Rock Sling--which even then, is a slow situational spell, which only works well in open space.) Leveling up staffs and weapons is extremely tedious. Instead of ending at +10 or +15, normal weapons are upgradeable to +25 in this game. That may give you an idea of how absolutely massive this game is and how long it takes to complete. (I will admit that this was my first time playing a magic build in any souls game, and my experience might have been different with another build.)

I found myself entirely sick of the experience and wanting to quit multiple times. Your game should not feel like a slog to complete. But that is inevitably what happens in these open world games. There is simply too much content. If you are not motivated to simply explore the map aimlessly, with no clear benefit to progression, you probably won't like this game.
im bad at this game but thats what keeps me going
Amazing. I don't think I've ever played a game that does open world as good as this. The game gives you an abundant amount of freedom and it's addictive to go out and explore.

Having a Map to collect for each area is a great touch, I really enjoyed opening the map and placing markers on things that looked like buildings or caves that usually led to a dungeon or a treasure chest.

Combat is challenging but fun with a staggering amount of viable weapons and spells which open up a lot of interesting builds.

The bosses are where this game shines and I can safely say fromsoft has kept the quality high.

The world feels alive, plenty of enemy variety while exploring and the NPCs have excellent dialogue that are voice acted well.

The lore and story building is a double edged sword, it does help with immersion but I had no idea what happening with the story and following NPC questlines was a nightmare. I eventually had to search online to get these answers.

I would say this is one of the 'easier' fromsoft games as you have many options to tackle a situation, such as summons, coop and builds that let you cheese bosses.

Best game
‚ù§Ô∏è One of the best if not the best ‚ù§Ô∏è
Why did I crush most of the bosses in this game? Why were there large portions of the map where enemies were no threat at all? Where overcoming adversity is the reward many people seek when playing a From Software game, exploration becomes a punishment, as it has the potential to diminish the challenge, through level-ups and resources, so greatly that exploration is the only engaging element left. 

This is to say, don't explore. Follow the trail to the big castle and if you feel too weak to take it on, head off and do a couple dungeons just to get strong enough. "What am I missing if I don't explore the open world?" you might think. As someone who found every single dungeon and item, it's not worth it. I don't believe you're meant to do everything in this game. So much of it is the same. Every dungeon looks the same and has the same bosses. You'll see them all at least twice even if you're not going for 100%.

The bosses in this game have the hardest attack patterns in any From Software game, and they're the easiest to beat. I did one attack for the whole game. I did a strength build with and ultra greatsword. These are a classic Dark Souls weapon that offer massive damage but have a slow attack speed. In this game, it doesn't matter what your weapon is, doing a jumping strong attack is just as quick and effective and I don't know why. Literally every enemy could be killed and even stunlocked by this strategy. The bosses would be so distracted by the skeletons that I summoned, that I could kill them in a minute by just doing jumping strong attacks on their back.

The game is divided into two parts. The open world filled with dungeons, and what Fromsoft calls a "Legacy Dungeon" which are long, semi-linear levels that exist in the open world but are very closed off from it. Basically your standard Dark Souls level. Had this game cut the open world completely and just stitched all of the Legacy Dungeons together, this game could have been outstanding. This is not coming from a place of nostalgia because this is the first From Software game I played and beat. It just seems like every new thing they tried was detrimental to the formula they've been using.
The greatest game ive ever played it changed my life, honestly 10 out 10 abusive relationship
Ewden Wing
Dog
glad another masterpiece didn't lose to God of war
Didn't expect death.
Undoubtedly a masterpiece.
10/10
Brah game hard AF
If you thumb up this review I won't do a damn thing because those pathetic grabs for attention are just that. This is perhaps one of the greatest games of all time. You probably know that. If you didn't now you do just do yourself a favor and buy it. Best art and design in perhaps the entire history of gaming.
Peak
fun game very adventure like game
Elden Ring is a master class in how to write, build, and bring to life a world from beyond the realm of video games. It's more of a book come to life than it is a game all of it's own, and with it's DLC coming out in just a few weeks Id figure it's due time I put together my thoughts on how Elden Ring stands up to the rest of FromSoftwares titles. 

(Spoiler Warning) ....at least for someone with only 40 hours in.


If someone on the street were to come up to me and ask "How would you describe Elden Ring in a single sentence?" I would probably tell them "It's as if Darksouls wrote a book and then made it into a video game.". No seriously I cant state that enough. The lore on display here and the world building is some of the best the teams ever created, and the fact it's an actual free roaming open world only tops the cake. Clearly having a world class writer helped the team flush this story out, but also the merge of the two almost feels seemless. I can't tell who honestly would have created or inspired whom, other than of course the combat mechanics.

Speaking of combat is just the same as it always has been. For good or for worse it's nothing revolutionary. Having sometimes a "steed" companion helps and changes the way some battles are fought, but overall It feels and acts very darksouly, all be it better made. Attempts clearly have been made to make certain aspects of previous titles fall in line with newer modern aspects, and as well previous problems the games have suffered from. One such thing is the class system which now feels robust in almost every way no matter who you choose to be. Faith, Magic, some guy with a club, it's all good here. 

Now as for me the entire grand scale and scope of the world just feels....insane. Dungeons feel real, catacomes feel like they should, fortresses are.....protected, and a pain to even try to invade. The aspects of the story and a recent massive climatic battle really tell in this game. The story fits the gameplay, and that's something wonderful. It's not just "We all are doing stuff for no reason.", no there is some serious thought to how the gameplay and the story intertwine. Probably given that the writer and the gameplay developers had their own jobs and merged together to make a wounderful sandwich. 

Anywho I think I'll leave this as a final note. The feeling that a writer and a gaming company can come together seemlessly like this is very telling. They both scream the same kind of "style", so I guess that's why the merging feels natural. Sometimes you can tell when something major shows up in a continual gaming company like FromSoftware that changes are too much and too obvious to feel like one or the other has taken proper root. Sometimes they just do one of too much, other times they just fail to feel it's consistant or coihernt. Either way this isn't the case here. In fact I hope they continue to do this, my god it's a must now.


So should you play Elden Ring? Yes, if you like Darksouls or nearly anything FromSoftware makes. It screams that, but now has the fantastic addition of feeling like your walking into an actual real life story book. And for me, that's just too good to pass up on. 
One of my fav games of all time. This is the stuff of dreams, PERFECTION!

I had this on launch, pre order and was doing the countdown until it unlocked. obviouxly beat the game, beat 99.9% of the bosses, reached over level 350+ lol and farmed alot. that battle with Malenia was EPIC.

‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∂‚£ø‚£¶‚£å‚°ô‚†ª‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°á‚£º‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø

TL;DR This is among one of the greatest games ever made, but it also sucks

I am reminded yet again that this is a disgusting DEX agenda/propaganda game. Everything heavier than a greatsword is absolute dogwater, if you want to use colossal weapons you have to dual wield and spam jump attacks which is one of the most boring ways to play the game. Even outside of heavy STR weapons, the meta is spamming Ash of War attacks, so whatever you choose it's always going to be braindead gameplay. You can choose not to do either of those things which is what I did in my 1st and 2nd playthrough but you're opting for a much worse experience, forget even the possibility of ever beating Malenia with a standard 2H colossal weapon STR build. You either go for a disgusting build or you have a bad time. Don't even get me started on it overall having the worst designed bosses in the franchise and the trash open-world. Have to clean and sanitise my hands every time I play the degenerate gameplay involved in this game.

It's aight, I still like it but only because it is Souls. One of the worst Fromsoft games just above Dark Souls 2.

(This review started off as a meme about DEX being bent but thinking about it more really pissed me off so I decided to mini-rant. Elden Ring is an amazing game, it has some of the highest peaks but it also has the lowest lows in the series and imo the lows far outnumber the peaks, which means I have far more issues with this game than praises, if I were to rant about them all this would be a multi-page essay long review. At its core Elden Ring is still a souls game so it inherits the things the series is lauded for; the best level designs in the industry, the big wtf moments, the crazy high levels of intent placed into every thing in the games from enemy placement, item placements, lore, EVERYTHING to create an unending cinematic experience with no need for cutscenes or scripted gameplay and the fact that every where you look in the open world it looks like a painting. The game is amazing but my praises for this game end there, I believe it's one of the greatest games of all time, but its one of the worst Souls games, that's just how far above Souls games are in comparison to other games that I can be so critical of this game yet still consider it to be one of the best games ever made)
Love the game but there's a ton of bullshit "I WIN" mechanics from too many enemies that just kill the fun each play through. Anyways, drop in the ocean review.
Never been more suicidal. Then again never been more in love
good
The only other game that even comes to mind when I think "best game I have ever played" is KOTOR 2. They are obviously very different, but good stories are good stories.

As someone who has just played Dark Souls 1 a bit this was an amazing game. It was definitely more beginner friendly with its open world with awesome Boss Designs and probably a great story if you manage to piece it together
MADE BY ALIENS
I am a 54-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing elden ring.
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing elden ring.
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours.
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing elden ring.
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.
Oh Elden Ring,

As a gamer who enjoys both narrative-driven games and overall experiences, I've always thought that Souls-like games weren't for me because of their feared difficulty. That single aspect of it had blocked me from playing these games, but after seeing a couple of friends trying it out a year after its release and some YouTubers like Jev having a blast with it, I decided it was time.

I want to start this review by saying I don't regret taking so long to start my Souls experience because the Christmas break I spent trying it out was one of my best school breaks ever. Experiencing and exploring The Lands Between with friends guiding me through it, giving me both tips on what to get or where to go, and headaches, telling me to go to an area saying it would be fine, and I'd get hard-stuck on a tough boss. I haven't felt so free playing a game in a long, long time. I was able to grind and get the game's platinum in a matter of three weeks.

The world is vast and honestly one of the most beautiful and unique I've ever experienced. I was baffled by how FromSoftware managed to make it feel so lively and complete, even being as open as it is. There are a couple of dungeons where, yes, you notice they are very similar when it comes to their architecture, and also some NPCs that could get a little repetitive here and there, but that's just it, the game is HUGE. You don't feel like it gets repetitive unless you are really, REALLY picky with it, especially with its characteristic areas and cities that go from beautiful, calm, and peaceful places like Limgrave, to horrid, anxiety, and fear-inducing places like the Deeproot Depths. And I cannot say this enough, EVERY AREA IS JUST SO UNIQUE AND BEAUTIFULLY BUILT, and you will easily get to pick your favorites and just stay there forever, having fun, defeating bosses, solving dungeons, and interacting with the most interesting and deep NPCs. The Lands Between were an absolute joy to explore. Thank you, FromSoftware.

When it comes to the narrative, I must say, I was a little distracted, but after beating the game twice, I got curious about it, so I looked it up. The 3+ hour videos from fans explaining the game's lore, every main character's story, and it just, GETS, DEEPER! The main villains and NPCs like Malenia, Radahn, Ranni, and others have the most interesting backgrounds, and you just want to know more about them and about their relationship with other characters. But for me, the most interesting aspect of it all was your "teammates'" backstories and progress through your quests, like Blaidd and Alexander. How the game builds the sweetest characters, just to give them the saddest endings, all in your hands, is just heartbreaking. And you must appreciate when a game and its characters reach your heart like that.

To end it off, the mechanics and sound design. First off, the mechanics, they're exactly what you are expecting and what you would expect from a FromSoftware game, even from just watching YouTube videos like I did. The only difference is they're WAY more precise than what you'd think they'd be. As I said at the very beginning of this review, I've never played any Souls game, but I have to say this game got me HOOKED just by its mechanics at the very start. The way you can be specific with your builds, making them either 100% Dex or Faith or any other stat, or 50-50, or just go nuts with them. Giving players that amount of freedom just makes the game that much more enjoyable, and when you mix that with the most pleasurable fight mechanics I've touched on to this day (if you exclude FPS games like Counter-Strike), what you get is a very addictive chocolate cake of a game. The sound design adds to it all, bringing excitement to every fight and to every area with a specific theme. Nothing beats being stuck underneath Volcano Manor with Rykard, or in that heavenly arena with the Elden Beast, fighting for your life (and runes) while having the most amazing soundtrack playing in the background. It makes the experience that much better and more desirable.

What else is there to say? FromSoftware did nothing, absolutely nothing wrong with this game. From the immense yet complete world to its occupants, from the most diverse list of common enemies to the most unique and beautiful boss fights (mind you there are around 200 bosses, depending on who you ask), and from the most leg-shaking weapons to the most heartbreaking NPC quests, this game did it all. It absolutely overcame all my expectations and delivered the most enjoyable experience I've had in years. A pleasant surprise, and the start of what I hope will be a very, very long journey through FromSoftware's catalog and other Souls games.

Now all we have left to do is wait for the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC. The hype is real!

And for those too afraid of the game's difficulty, trust me, it will be worth it once you learn how to dodge and counter. The game is a wonderful experience I hope every game-lover out there has a chance to have.
GOAT
Put a ring on it

gud
KInda like fortnite
This game is a masterpiece, listing the pros would make the review very long so I'd just list the things I personally dislike. Play the game regardless.

Cons:

Repetitive fights. Regardless of what Steam says, I played the game before. I have like 100 hours and pretty much gone through most content of the game. A lot of bosses are reused throughout the game and it ruins the immersion and the joy of fighting in those cases. "Oh, lets see what's in this cave I've been exploring for 20 minutes. Oh, another godskin. Oh, more crystal dudes." Would 100% prefer the game trading not having as many encounters for a sense of more unique fights.

Balancing. The game can be really easy. Like not even trying easy (don't even get me started on the Mimic Tear Ashes). On the other hand, game can be really hard. Like you enjoy pain kinda hard. It all depends on your loadout/leveling choices. Sure you can make the game as hard as you want, but I'd prefer if all the weapons were closer together in terms of power level and leveling them didn't make that massive DPS difference. Most bosses are already balanced around all this options (not a lot of openings, constantly chasing you for ranged builds, really long range, 2-3 hits to kill you unless you level Vigor to 40) so a lot of fights end up feeling like DPS checks rather than learning the attack patterns of the bosses. I would personally enjoy experiencing longer fights and enemies doing less damage so you can actually learn those fights.

Again, the game is still a 9.5/10. Play it.

Hey everyone, it's Caillou! I just started playing Elden Ring, and I wanted to share my thoughts on this amazing game!

Visuals and World Design
Wow, just wow! The world of Elden Ring is so big and beautiful. It‚Äôs like stepping into a huge, magical storybook! There are forests, castles, and so many cool places to explore! The graphics are super pretty, and there's so many things to do! It's like each day is something new!

Gameplay and Combat
The controls are really easy! And everyone has been super nice so far, so I haven't had to do any combat! When I started the game I was in this strange building, but when I came out I saw a bunch of shiny things on the ground! They told me to jump but I didn't! Then I saw a scary spider! I was so scared, but then the ground crumbled and I fell down. I hurt my knee and I almost cried but then this nice lady on a pony said some stuff and it made me feel better! Then I rode the elevator and opened the doors and it was so pretty! There was this guy in a mask and he was really nice. I'm not supposed to talk to strangers but I didn't know where to go so he helped me. I asked him what I should do and he said that the best choices he ever made were made-on-lists! I thought a list was a great idea but I didn't have any paper.  I think I'll ask the guy on the horse next! He looks friendly!

Story and Characters
The story is like a big mystery. You find out more by talking to characters and reading items you find! Sometimes I have to sound out the letters but I can do it! It can be a bit confusing, like when there was a message that said "If only I had a giant...But hole!" I didn't know what that meant. But I like putting the pieces together, like a puzzle! The characters you meet are really interesting, and some are kind of scary! I think it might be Halloween here! I hope there's some candy!

Difficulty and Challenge
Elden Ring is tough, but you shouldn't be scared! I used to be a afraid of dogs but then I let one lick me and I like them now! I'm going to do the same thing for all the new animals I meet here! It‚Äôs a game that makes you feel proud of yourself when you overcome the challenges! Like when I didn't know where to go but I found a glowing tree and it was that way! And some of the people who have been here aren't that good at knowing animals yet. I saw a turtle and someone called it a dog! How silly! 

Overall Experience
I'm having so much fun playing Elden Ring. It‚Äôs a game that takes you on an epic adventure and makes you feel like a superhero or a knight! If you love exploring big worlds, solving mysteries, and making new friends, you should definitely play Elden Ring! I'm gonna go say hi to my new friend now, I think he's waving at me!

I played it for a few hours and it felt overwhelming so I put it down. I came back to it a year later and something clicked and there was no turning back.

The graphical design of the game is very unique to From software. If you have played any of their previous games you will feel at home.

Good game, played something like 150 hours in the first 3 weeks while working full time so didn't sleep all that much.

The game looks good, sometimes the controls are jank but most of the time they're alright and it's my fault I died. Sometimes you might get stuck in a wall, on a piece of debris, in/under the ground or on a speck of dust, but most of the time you don't.

I was unfortunate enough to suffer random freezes that weren't graphics related, which mostly happened when playing multiplayer. It felt more like a CPU related issue than anything else and I have a AMD Ryzen 9 5900X 12-Core Processor which I thought should be able to handle this without any issues but that wasn't the case. However the freezes are less frequent and less harsh when playing alone so that was aight I guess.

Regarding the game and gameplay itself, I'm new to the genre but after this I wan't to look back at the previous Fromsoft titles. 
Bosses were mostly fun and interesting, the story was interesting but the lack of direction or at least some minimal amount of logging makes tracking them stupid difficult which is dumb and I don't care what anyone else says you should be able to keep some track of where you are in a given quest with a world that large.

Great game!
ONION RING
This game was my first true Soulsborne game; I'd played a bit of DS3 a couple years prior but did not progress enough for it to count. To be brief, this game is the origin of my love of the genre. The feeling of these games is addictive, my ADD loves the dopamine release from throwing myself at a boss again and again, learning a bit more each time until victory has achieved. Naturally there were times that highlighted the durability of my controller, but the best part of this game is learning to appreciate every boss with subsequent playthroughs (expect for space worm, you know what you did). I also appreciate how accessible the game is to new players; while summons may be "controversial" (please just touch glass and let people play how they wanna play), I appreciate their existence in giving me the support I needed early on before I became confident enough to start doing solo playthroughs. I also had a blast playing with friends, though the invasion mechanic was annoying at times.

Naturally there are still some issues I have with this game. The final boss fight could have been a lot better had the only kept the first part, made Marika the second part or at the very least gave us access to the least coordinated horse in existence. Pvp is also as unenjoyable as ever but thats pretty much a staple of these games. Questlines can also be hard to keep track of in your first playthrough which some players could find punishing should they forgo the use of wikis.

Overall this is a fantasitc game and introduction to the genre; I look forward to seeing what they have cooked up for the dlc.
√âtant rapidement frustr√© et √©nerv√© sur les jeux vid√©o (un gros rageux ouais) j'avais un peu peur de me lancer dans Elden Ring comme premier souls ! Mais j'avais encore plus peur de passer √† c√¥t√© d'un chef d'≈ìuvre. 
Eh bien si vous √™tes comme moi je peux vous assurer que vous aller adorer ! Une fois fini je n'ai eu qu'une envie c'√©tait de le relancer pour faire le jeu avec un autre style d'arme, d'autres armures etc ! Tout est super, l'environnement, les doublages, les chara design, les musiques !

STAY SAFE.
This is a game that requires you to be patient and get used to its weird and creepy world. At first, it may seem unordered, chaotic and aimless but this is how it is supposed to be. The game aims to make you feel out of place and lost, because that is what being tarnished means.

However, once you get used to the world and start to get goals little by little, its world takes you in. Your feebleness at the start gradually disappears and you start feeling more powerful in both in-game and IRL, where you hone your dodging, defending and attack timing skills. 

The world holds many secrets, some lead to alternate endings, some lead to well written stories, mostly in tragedy. Death, misery and fury are all part of this twisted world. Once you get used to it and dying, getting up and trying again, ultimately achieving victory, this game will reward you. 

The story, the customization, the design, the sounds, the quotes, everything is amazing in this game. I don't know if it is the greatest Souls game ever made, but it is certainly one of the best RPGs out there. Be patient for the first 10 hours of confusion and you won't regret it.

This game is ludricrously good. I stayed my distance from it for AGES because I thought there was some sort of penalty for dying - and I thought I'd get into a death spiral and stay a weak baby the whole time. But nah, you just drop your currency where you die, and as long as you take a second at the start of the fight you died at to reclaim that currency, there's no penalty to dying. 

It's the ultimate power fantasy, built upon a pile of your own bones.

I'm not even half way through, and I want to replay it
This is a bad open world game, and it is first and foremost an open world game. I had to have a wiki open the entire time because of the countless NPC questlines that offer no guidance, have obtuse requirements, and often get completely locked out by progressing the main questline. All of the content sprinkled across the continent is just one of a few repeated things, reusing stronger but unremarkable enemies as bosses by just buffing their stats, and sometimes there's two of them, or there's some chump enemies in the arena too - and that in particular gets frustrating. NPCs are so flat and lifeless in every regard except most of the dialogue, given they're so generically animated and never move from their spot unless they're teleporting somewhere new without any indication where they've went.

The stuff that FromSoft have experience with is the stuff that shines. The unique bosses are very memorable. The combat is well-balanced and rewarding. There's a lot of different sorceries, incantations (both of which are magic, but one is intelligence and one is faith), armament types, armors, and weapon skills available, and that's all quite fun. The aesthetics are gorgeous.

I just wish I could play with these combat mechanics, and enjoy these environments, in a better game.
The real Shattering is the friends we made along the way.

favorite game ever
I would absolutely recommend this game. I have now played this game on both PS5 and Steam, for a collective of 490 hours. I have been a FromSoftware fan since Bloodborne, and while that game might be my favorite thematically and storywise, I have to say Elden Ring is by far, the best FromSoftware game on the market. The quality of life improvements in this game have set a new standard for FromSoft games, as well as games in general. You get every cent you pay for with this game. I have friends who count this as their first FromSoft game, and on one hand I think that's lucky. On the other hand I know that backtracking to DS3, Bloodborne, or DS1, will be even more difficult for them now. I cannot wait for the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC to release, and I look forward to dumping another 100+ hours into this game.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece that transcends mere gaming. It‚Äôs an odyssey, a symphony of darkness and light, woven into the very fabric of a shattered world. FromSoftware, Miyazaki in collaboration with George R. R. Martin, has birthed a universe that defies convention, beckoning players to explore its secrets and confront their own mortality.

World-Building and Atmosphere:
The lands of Elden Ring are hauntingly beautiful. From the sun-kissed grasslands to the desolate ruins, each locale tells a story. The crumbling castles, twisted forests, and ethereal skies evoke a sense of melancholic wonder. You‚Äôll lose yourself in the grandeur of it all.

Combat and Challenge:
Combat is a ballet of steel and magic. Every swing of your sword carries weight, every dodge a desperate dance. The challenge is unyielding, but fair. Victory feels earned, and defeat is a lesson in resilience. Elden Ring doesn‚Äôt hold your hand; it grips your heart.

Lore and Mystery:
George R. R. Martin‚Äôs touch is evident in the lore. Cryptic runes, forgotten gods, and fractured histories await discovery. The game tantalizes with glimpses of a cosmic tapestry, leaving breadcrumbs for the curious to follow.

Mounts and Exploration:
Riding your steed across the plains, scaling cliffs, and leaping chasms‚Äîit‚Äôs exhilarating. Your mount isn‚Äôt just a means of travel; it‚Äôs a companion. The world opens up when you‚Äôre on horseback, and secrets reveal themselves.

Boss Fights:
The bosses are titans‚Äîmajestic and terrifying. Whether facing a fire-breathing dragon or a spectral knight, each encounter is a symphony of desperation. Learn their patterns, adapt, and triumph.

Art and Sound Design:
Elden Ring‚Äôs artistry is spellbinding. The play of light on armor, the wind rustling through ancient banners‚Äîit‚Äôs poetry. And the haunting melodies, the distant echoes‚Äîthey linger long after you‚Äôve put down the controller.

In Elden Ring, death isn‚Äôt a setback; it‚Äôs a brushstroke on your canvas. So, unsheathe your blade, kindle your spirit, and venture forth. The Elden Ring awaits, and with it, a saga that will echo through eternity.

Remember, brave adventurer, you are not alone. Countless others traverse this fractured realm, seeking purpose, redemption, and the elusive Elden Ring. Upon the dark path only I may tread.

good
"only one more try i promise"
Elden Ring continues the trend of every FromSoft game I've played, where there's a genuinely great game there, but it's near unplayable due to a few baffling decisions from the developers. The combat is well balanced and very fun, the world and graphics are also great. The difficulty even felt quite fair, if even a bit too easy at times.
But the game is marred with a bunch of bad decisions holdovers from previous titles. You cannot play this game without having a guide open on your phone. Missed the church at the beginning? No crafting kit. Missed some sites of grace? No levelling up for the first 6 hours. Don't know about non linear stat progression? Your build is fucked. I don't mind a little reliance on wikis and guides, but your game should at least be playable without them.
Also, this sorry excuse for a co-op system is downright shameful for a modern game. The seamless co-op mod fixes it, but I shouldn't have to risk being banned to play a more functional version of the game.
Overall, very disappointing since there's a lot to love about the game that's held back by FromSoft fans claiming they can do no wrong. I'm sorry, but I don't think FromSoft quests have ever been good.
Definitivamente no he salido del videojuego
fun game
This game gets better with every playthrough its ridiculous how much content there is. Also the soundtrack and lore are straight masterpieces!

very good game cant wait for dlc to get released
I have never been so calm about my streak of deaths before.
Played this on my laptop and I plan to play it on the Steam Deck when the DLC comes out later this month. Would highly recommend this game to anyone who is into Soul type games, this was definitely From Software's best souls game so far.

Graphics: The game looks beautiful, I know there was some people trying to compare it to other releases but in all honesty, with the scope of the game you can definitely appreciate how wonderful this game looks.

Story: It's a Souls game, be prepared to be confused, read a lot of item descriptions and finally watch a video from VaatiVidya and a few others to figure it out.

Gameplay: This is where the Souls games excel, you're gonna get frustrated, you're gonna die a lot, but if you stop and watch your opponent, you'll see their patterns and begin to learn how to take them down properly, There are always glitches but most of the time, the enemy is limited by the same factors you are. You'll find MANY playstyles and it's almost impossible to not find one to fit you. Don't be afraid to experiment.

Sound: This game nails the sound and music. Nothing much else to say there.

Overall: Must buy game in the souls list, if you get one, this is the one to get.

The best open world game ever made.  Yep, I sincerely believe that. Takes the mechanics of Dark Souls and perfects them in a rather fluid, player driven experience in the open world. Almost no hand-rails guiding your progress - making it about discovery and player choice. Heck, you can missed gigantic portions of the game and still get to the ending, if you wish, but by exploring the world fully, you get deeply rewarded with more content and bosses.

You don't have the right O you don't have the right
This is the peak, so far at least. Elden Ring is the boogyman that haunts other developers into postponing their release date, because it's just too good to compete with. It took every other title that Miyazaki ( the game developer guy, not the studio Ghibli guy ) dropped, and refined it into this absolute banger of a game. My hype and love for this game was as high as it was for Dark Souls III, I would've ranked it higher than Dark Souls III if Miyazaki had done 1 of 2 things. Added mimics to the game and perhaps made more objects into mimics. Looked past his love for debuff swamps and stopped adding it to the games. Thematically I liked Dark Souls III more, but this story is so much more powerful, and I'm in love with his fragmented storytelling that you have to figure out by exploring the remains.

this game is great, but it feels so overwhelming to start a new playthrough just because of the sheer amount of things to do
not a bad thing, the open world in this game actually feels more alive than most other open worlds in gaming. it's just a bit too much for me
though i'd still rate it a 7/10 just because I love the innovation this brings to the genre, with the weapon arts from ds3 being overhauled and more mechanics to make playing more interesting (e.g. shield counters and jump attacks) which makes me excited for future instalments, including the dlc

This is the game of the decade. It is to the 2020s what Skyrim was to the 2010s.

I usually play all games on easy and only turn up the difficulty when I get bored, so it took some adjustments to get to grips with the soulsborne style. This game is hard, but that's mostly in your head. If you can fight the mental exhaustion and despair that comes with dying over and over again, you will actually learn a lesson for life here. I've recently taken up Muay Thai kickboxing at the age of 40 and it actually taught me much the same lesson: When you start something hard, you suck. Don't give up. You need to fight yourself and dominate your inner bitch before you can fight others. Kind of unfortunate that I had to get this old to really figure that out, but here we are. So yeah, Elden Ring is much like sparring with people half your age: You learn by repeatedly getting kicked in the head. Don't give up and you'll see that you'll adjust and get better.

In any case, this game isn't as hard as it seems (and certainly not as hard as previous From Software games) simply because it is an open world game. Once you figure out that you're not actually stuck on that boss (looking at you, Margit) but can just as well go somewhere else and bully low-level wolves for a few hours to level up, you realise that you can compensate for old people reflexes and shitty video game skills by putting in some time in the gym (or the Weeping Peninsula) to just over-level that pesky boss massively. You will progress through the game much slower than your favourite Twitch streamer, but you will succeed eventually.

Other than this the only thing left to say is: damn what an amazing feat of worldbuilding! This is at the same time the most oblique and crazy but also oddly believable game universe I think I have ever seen. It almost rivals actual real life history in how convoluted and dumb everything is. I love it! And there are some genuinely beautiful vistas to discover as well.

TL;DR: If you genuinely want to challenge yourself in video games, if only once a decade, Elden Ring is the game to do it with. It has as much things to learn, secrets to discover and challenging enemies as three or four games by other developers. It is worth every penny twice over.

Why are you reading a review for one of the best games of all time? If you like soulsborne games, you'll love this one. 

It is a bit more forgiving than the classic Dark Souls and Demon's Souls, but I think in a good way. The open world design needs different approaches for gameplay. There's always something new to discover, quests to stumble upon or mess up, and many NPC lives to judge. 

The lore is as deep and inscrutable as ever, and it's a fascinating and beautiful setting for your character(s) to die in.

Joguei pra porra, e ainda nem matei o gigante de fogo... pqp nunca mais exploro nesse jogo
I have been off and on and off and on with this game since its release. My first playthrough (which I hadn't finished), I rushed the main bosses all the way upto the fire giant, which I then got stuck. Now on my current playthrough, I am having a lot more fun and a smoother feel in progression. Doing each individual optional boss/dungeon and now I am on my way to Leyndell, Royal Capital. Only one slight issue however. I don't recall how I got past the DRACONIC TREE SENTINEL IN THE FIRST PLACE. This is the most issue I've had with a boss since my first playthrough, dying 300 times to Godrick the Grafted. I feel like I should be levelled enough to be able to compete against a generic enemy (especially since I have rinsed Radahn and majority other bosses prior to this sentinel) but I cannot figure it out. It is a very love/hate relationship I have with this game. I love it for the progression - the feeling and satisfaction of becoming stronger to the point where every enemy feels beneath me. I love it for the gorgeous landscape in every zone in the game. I love it for the interesting and unique boss mechanics each possess. But this one, disgusting, generic enemy is my hell. I expect to continue playing this game and hopefully beat it some day, but for now at least - I am no Elden Lord. I will continue my journey, slaying every single beast that crosses my path so that some day, I might feel strong enough to fell a generic knight on a horse.

Edit: Ignore all parts where I was having trouble with the Draconic Tree Sentinel. I am again on the road to Elden Lord (tee hee)

Do you like challenging games? Yes? Do you dislike open worlds from Ubisoft? But do you like open worlds in general? Yes? Then you'll probably like one of the best open-world games of all time. And certainly one of the best games of the last 10 years. Highly recommended for every Fromsoft fan and every lover of great games that don't want to take you by the hand. You almost get nostalgic when you think of RPGs and games from the late 90s and 2000s, even the early 2010s, and rediscover Elden Ring's / Fromsoftware's passion in them.

Malania ):
I'll just start by saying this game is one of the best games I've ever played, in a sea of positive reviews I'm sure no one expects to see otherwise anyway, but I want to be part of that sea anyway, because I love it that much.

Souls style games were always something I wanted to get into, I love the aesthetic so much, it looked so appealing. But... I use to let other people scare me out of trying these more difficult games because I was worried I wouldn't be good enough and waste my money. With the DLC coming out I decided to give it another go from the beginning with a friend, and boy I'm glad I did... I had some of the most fun in video games than I had in a long time! Sure I played multiplayer, used summons when soloing so maybe I still suck compared to most players... but it was a BLAST! Even with the constant player invasions! It was frustrating and annoying at times (especially with some of that latency issues... I swear I hit him!!) But it was so fun and funny at times.. like hiding as items with my friends watching invaders desperately search for us... kicking them on ladders they were chasing us on. So many laughs were had. 

If you are scared of not being good enough.. take it from a shitty player who managed to 100% the game with friends and summons (I even solo'd Malenia ;w; How?!) It's so worth it, just remember to just have fun with it and it's not worth being scared, mad, or anything~ Play however is most fun for you cause it's just a video game! The gameplay is amazing and the story and characters are great! The frustration is worth the rewarding feeling of success at the end! I hope you have as great as a time as I did!

For me Elden ring is the first open world game that justified its open world
20 hours in and i'm barely scratching the surface. What a monumental game
While the game is good, it is a downgrade in many aspects from the original Dark Souls.

- One of the main issues is enemy attacks clipping through walls, years later from the original Dark Souls and they still didn't fix that; 
- Attacks from bosses have weird, sometimes delayed or not natural movement created specifically to throw off the timing of dodging, on the original Dark Souls the bosses are hard but fair, they didn't break how movement animation works, or made it messy to the point you can't identify what you are seeing, for the sake of making it harder for the old players who are already familiar with the dodging mechanic; 
- They have to design the movement from bosses based on the limit of the camera mechanics, they pushed bosses movement to the point the shitty camera dating back from Demon Souls can't make anything visually clear;
- The world is vast but in a negative manner, it makes replayability much worse, you have to go out of your way to get weapons, items, upgrades and so on. The areas and enemies are less distinct from what you have on Dark Souls;
- Yes, every weapon is viable to a certain degree, but the balance still sucks, and makes gameplay much less diverse;
- The game uses TAA that creates visual blur and there is no other option, you can turn off AA, but the game turns it on everytime the game is restarted, the HDR option is buggy and it only works properly sometimes.

The point is, instead of correcting what was wrong with the previous games and building on what was good, they kept many of the issues, they made the game harder on artificial ways, that is bad game design.
ye

This game is like eating a bag of trail mix blindfolded. You blindly reach into the bag and you immediately bight down on a cacophony of flavors and textures that you have no idea what to do with, but as you become more familiar with each peanut and pretzel, it just becomes that more enjoyable. The sourness of the raisins and its difficulty to chew through may put you off and cause you to pause and take a break for a moment, but that satisfaction of finding a rogue M&M always brings you back till you finish the entire bag thriving for more. But the bag is never truly empty. You go back and find the left over hidden bits and flavors that make it even more addicting to dig through, filling your mind with more questions and causing you to dig deeper into the bag. I love trail mix so much and I am so excited for the Chex Mix DLC.

It's perfect in everyway and so nostalgic, and they sure don't hesitate of making it difficult for ya.
This was my first entry in the souls series, I went into it with the mindset of a seasoned monster hunter player and it meshed pretty well, I was able to read and dodge through a lot of encounters based on that experience alone, tried out lots of playstyles in the early game, settled on a fun mix of intelligence and strength with the moonlight sword and proceeded to play into NG+4 to get all the achievements on the same save file

It's a wonderfully immersive game that can even be somewhat relaxing after getting a feel for the combat, my girlfriend briefly played Co-op with me but unless you are running with the "seamless co-op" mod then it's really cumbersome if you're trying to experience the whole game together from start to finish

With the DLC approaching I recently restarted a save file so that I can play through the regular difficulty

Don't let the community talking about the game's difficulty scare you away from trying it either, it's not nearly as hard as they say it is save for a select few encounters (*cough* melania *cough*) so you should have a great time if you are a fan of classical high fantasy

i played 118 hours in 3 weeks and i finnaly beat the game i recomend this if you want to go into seclusion and addiction if you want to beat the game
I love and hate elden ring, and honestly I‚Äôve never felt so strongly positive about a game while also despising it so much lol. 

The Good: 

-The lore and main story is some of the best fromsoftware has ever made, at least in terms of complexity and detail. 
-The side quests/characters. Most of them are really fleshed out and have a lot of depth to them, and are just simply fun overall. Ranni‚Äôs questline in particular, which is the main one, is straight up some of the best stuff fromsoftware has ever made. 
-The art/presentation is untouched by almost any game. To the cool medieval aesthetic or the weird alien touch that some areas have, or the incredibly epic bosses, it‚Äôs just amazing and nothing else. The way that the world is designed so that the erdtree is almost always visible is really well done and just adds an extra layer to the worldbuilding and level design. 
-Most of the bosses are fun to fight, even the copy pasted ones (mostly because they‚Äôre usually easy tho lol). 
-soundtrack is goated


The bad: 
-Copy pasted enemies, bosses, and assets that make exploration feel repetitive and boring, coming down to a basic open world formula that is just boring (imo. Okay, alot of this is my opinion).
-The balancing. There‚Äôs some serious whiplash where you‚Äôll be fighting super weak enemies and then all of a sudden a strong one comes in and just insta kills you, or a boss is just stupidly hard and makes you feel underleveled even when you‚Äôre not, or has an attack that just seems way too strong. Maybe I'm bad though idk. I wasn't using any summons so that certainly doesn't help me at all lol. People like to say ‚Äúif an enemy is too strong just don‚Äôt fight/come back later to kill it‚Äù, but honestly that just doesn‚Äôt feel like good level design to me. In dark souls the enemy placements/strength made sense, but in this game it just seems all over the place. 
-Level design (not talking about the open world here) as a whole is just really weak here, although it shows signs of their expertise now and then. The more closed off and dark souls-like areas are still really open, and feel really lackluster with usually just a ton of weak enemies thrown all over the place for no reason other than to fill space. In dark souls every nook and cranny is designed usually to make the not very careful player suffer horrible deaths, but those moments are few and far between in Elden Ring meaning that most players can rush through with little to no care and not suffer any consequences. Certain sections of the game are really good, but most areas are just not that complicated in their design, and pale in comparison to their previous games. 
-The themes in Elden Ring are shallow compared to dark souls. Dark souls, at least as I understand it, is all about how horrible humanity and the world can be, and how a person can rise through it all and persevere to accomplish great things. (Keep in mind I could be missing a lot as I've never watched any lore videos of either game). Elden Ring doesn‚Äôt really have the same oppressive atmosphere, and instead of persevering you can just summon an npc or other players to help you (You could do this in dark souls but they expanded it here), rather than figuring it out yourself. That goes against one of the main things that make fromsoftware games so unique and incredible. Instead Elden ring‚Äôs themes are more like ‚ÄúOhh damn that‚Äôs cool,‚Äù rather than anything thought provoking and full of thematic depth. (The characters/overall lore is full of depth but in this case I just mean the themes). 
-I feel like a lot of the music, while amazing, sounds a little same-y, and also doesn‚Äôt have the same depth as dark souls 1, where there would be emotions of a boss hidden within. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs much of a thing here, even if the soundtracks are consistently bangers.

Deep thoughts:
Elden Ring is a fantastic game. But in the process of streamlining it and putting it into an open world, a lot of what I loved so much about Dark souls is gone. This is hard to explain, but I want to compare Elden Ring to Skyrim because they are both open world games. Skyrim is all about exploration as well, and is masterfully created so that the player is getting a constant feeding of fun stuff to do and see and discover. Playing Skyrim, my emotions are very consistent like a straight line, constantly stuck at around 75%, for example. I grew up playing that game and it‚Äôs the thing that made it so successful in my opinion, or at least one of the reasons. But then there‚Äôs dark souls. It‚Äôs the complete opposite. It‚Äôs brutal and doesn‚Äôt hold your hand at all, and you have no choice but to get that stuff done or you can‚Äôt beat the game, and you don't have an easy way out for the most part aside from guides and summons, which aren't as op as in Elden Ring. All of this is why I fell in love with that game as a kid. My emotions would be a constant zigzag of rage and frustration, to sadness or fear, and then all of a sudden such an incredible joy that I had never felt before, like it was electric. From -50% to 150%. It‚Äôs a unique experience that you can‚Äôt get from any other game to that degree, and there‚Äôs a saying that ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing quite like your first souls game.‚Äù It‚Äôs very true. After that, even coming back to the game as an adult to actually finish it, that zigzag was a lot less sharp. The lows weren‚Äôt as low but the highs weren‚Äôt anywhere near where they had once been. I play fromsoftware games constantly chasing that incredible zigzag. The only thing in real life I‚Äôve ever experienced where I can get that zig zag of lows and highs is in my writing. Writing is hard, just like dark souls. You have to work to get what you want, and there isn‚Äôt any way to cut corners. But the highs? Some of the best moments of my entire life have been from writing. For a game to emulate something so close to that is nothing short of incredible.

But Elden Ring goes against it and follows games like Skyrim, Horizon Zero Dawn, any Ubisoft game probably, and other modern open world games, where they make sure you never have too hard of a time and get rid of a lot of the depth that make rpgs, rpgs.(at least compared to dark souls or classic rpgs). However, as a result, the highs are just not the same. Elden Ring is boring. It‚Äôs such a shallow straight line most of the time that it feels like a complete waste of my hours, at least when I‚Äôm exploring. Yes, there are rewards for doing it, but I see the basic open world exploration formula they used and it‚Äôs just so‚Ä¶ meh compared to almost everything else.

Regardless of everything I hate about Elden Ring, I can‚Äôt deny that it‚Äôs a fantastic game, just like Skyrim is (I'm not a particular fan of Skyrim's design concepts though in case you couldn't tell). Elden Ring is an 8/10 for me, mostly bogged down by the open world aspect that just clashes too heavily with the souls game formula, and the copy pasted content. I see why it was such a huge success, and why so many people praise it to death the way that I do with dark souls. I just hope that fromsoftware doesn‚Äôt continue with this streamlining approach that almost every AAA developer has nowadays. 

Now, do I recommend the game? Of course. Do you like massive, complex open world games with amazing, often cryptic stories throughout, and challenging bosses? This game gets a lot of praise for a reason, and is certainly a must play for any open world game fan. If that sounds like your kind of game, then go for it my friend, and good luck.
best game I've ever played it's so addictive
YOU SEE THE ELDEN RING, AND THEN YOU DIE. AND RESPAWN. AND DIE AGAIN. AND LOSE ALL YOUR SOULS...I mean...RUNES. This is a true open world non linear game. 90% of it is optional. You can go anywhere, but you'll get your ass kicked everywhere. Compared to Dark Souls, you can expect some quality of life improvements and some minor attempts to keep up with modern genre standards. You get a horse, a map, fast travel, and you can jump now, but that's about it. The game is hard. The late game mandatory areas and bosses can be a real pain. Level grinding may be required, but can still be fun. And there's co op. There's no shame in letting someone take out Malenia for you, she's the worst. I think the invasion based PVP system still sucks, but some people are into it I guess? You will struggle, but there are just so many different armor pieces, weapons, spells, and items to create any build you want. And you can respec at the Mage Academy as long as you have a larval tear. I recommend a faith + arcane + dragon incantation + bleed + crimson rot build. I also enjoy a good intelligence + dexterity + katana + sorcery + frost build. Ranni is my queen! The fun and challenge is in finding the right build for you, then watching the mimic tear do all the work. There are hundreds of missable side quests, caves, crypts, optional bosses, several endings, and new game plus, so ridiculous replay value. A dark fantasy masterpiece, despite some of the same weird FromSoftware quirks, wonky physics, and cryptic nonsense that have been around since Demon's Souls on PS3. You should play this game, but you have been warned. Death awaits.
One must imagine Sisyphus happy and a strength enjoyer.

It took me a few tries/years to actually get invested in Elden Ring and I'm glad I eventually gave it an honest shot. It's very cryptic and I honestly feel like a guide/manual/reference is required to make any progress. Once you have a grip on what to do, the world opens up, and you really start to understand the scope of how large it is. It's really hard to describe just how big the map is. Also, there are so many things to do; I definitely did not 100% this thing. I really wish there was a quest log or location markers to keep track of the game but I understand this game's ambiguity. If you like an open world and a high skill ceiling, I would recommend this.

Best Souls game I've played so far. Every person will have a different experience based on their skill level and preferences. The universe is amazing and well-written, and the side-quest stories are compelling.

My only complaint is the total lack of a quest log to remember where you were in each of the side-quests. This makes it unbearable to discover by myself, and I had to take clues from my friends or search the internet. It seems there is a mod to track all the steps you took with each quest to serve as a history of progress. This would be enough and would enhance the experience with side-quests a lot.

Despite this, it is totally one of the best experiences I have had with a game in my life.

[h2]Gateway to the Souls-like Realm: Elden Ring[/h2]

As someone who embarked on the journey of Elden Ring without prior experience in FromSoftware's realm, I must say, it was a captivating plunge into a world unlike any other. Elden Ring not only opened my eyes to the allure of Souls-like games but also left an indelible mark on my gaming soul.

What struck me most about Elden Ring was its unparalleled freedom. From the moment I set foot in the Lands Between, I was free to chart my own course, to tackle challenges in my own way. This freedom was liberating, empowering me to forge my own path through a rich and sprawling landscape teeming with secrets and dangers.

But it wasn't just the gameplay that enthralled me; it was the intricate tapestry of lore woven into every corner of the world. Elden Ring doesn't spoon-feed its story; instead, it beckons you to explore, to delve into forgotten ruins, to decipher cryptic item descriptions, and to converse with the enigmatic denizens of the land. In doing so, it rewards curiosity and engagement, inviting players to become not just spectators, but active participants in its unfolding narrative.

Of course, I would be remiss not to mention the game's formidable difficulty. Elden Ring is not for the faint of heart, presenting challenges that will test your patience, your skill, and your resolve. Yet, with each victory, no matter how hard-won, comes an unparalleled sense of accomplishment, a feeling that you have truly earned your place in this unforgiving world.

In the end, Elden Ring isn't just a game; it's an experience‚Äîa journey of discovery, exploration, and triumph. It's a testament to the power of immersive storytelling and the joy of overcoming adversity. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the Soulsborne genre or a newcomer like myself, Elden Ring is an adventure not to be missed.

I hate EAC it's probably the worst anticheat out there....
Bricked my game for years, bricked my armored core on release, bricked starship troopers and numerous other titles...
I've tried reinstalling games to no avail, deleting all EAC files and reinstalling to no avail, I've tried reinstalling windows to no avail....
I pulled the most smoothbrain idea out of my a** and it worked, drag and drop "start protected game" from VRCHAT to elden ring and now it's working.....
VRCHAT was the only dev who put in the effort to fix EAC being a worthless mess so if you're having issues with EAC and can't play online because of it then here's you're fix probably won't find it online anywhere.

malanias feet
Hark! Gather round, noble lords and fair maidens, for a tale of grand adventure and treacherous lands awaits. "Elden Ring," a marvel of our age, crafted by the hands of the wise and visionary FromSoftware, dost transport us to a realm of shadows and glory, where the brave may find fortune or fall to despair.

In this vast and wondrous world, known as the Lands Between, a tapestry of rich lore and perilous quests doth unfurl. Here, the Elden Ring, an artifact of great power, lies shattered, and with it, the very balance of the realm. The player, a tarnished soul bereft of grace, is summoned to restore order and claim the title of Elden Lord.

The lands are fraught with danger, and every step is a dance with death. Fierce beasts and eldritch horrors lurk in the shadows, ever eager to rend flesh from bone. Yet, for those with the heart of a lion and the skill of a master swordsman, there is much to gain. Hidden treasures, ancient magics, and allies of various temperaments await those who dare to seek them out.

The combat is a symphony of steel and strategy, demanding both swiftness and cunning. One must learn the ways of the blade, the bow, and the spell, for each foe requires a unique approach. The mightiest of adversaries, the fearsome bosses, are titanic in both stature and challenge, each a true test of the player's mettle.

Aye, the Lands Between are not without their beauty. From the misty peaks of the Altus Plateau to the murky depths of the Lake of Rot, the world is rendered with breathtaking artistry. The architecture is grand, the vistas vast, and the details intricate, weaving a tapestry that captivates the eye and stirs the soul.

Yet, be warned, for "Elden Ring" is not for the faint of heart. The path is fraught with trials, and only those of steadfast resolve shall prevail. But for those who endure, who rise from each defeat with renewed vigor, the rewards are beyond measure.

In sooth, "Elden Ring" is a masterpiece, a testament to the artistry and vision of its creators. It is a journey that challenges and enchants, a saga that shall be told for ages to come. So don thy armor, sharpen thy blade, and venture forth into the unknown, for the Lands Between await their savior.

best game
It's nearly perfect, it's unbelievable.
Fromsoft has done it again! It's not often that a sequel comes along and adopts an open world and can manage it to make it this engaging. Often when sequels become larger and promise an expansive open world, the level design, map, and content tend to go by the wayside, with the game offering more quantity over quality. 

What Fromsoft has done with Elden Ring is a masterclass game design. They have essentially taken the formula from their top games, and woven them into a seamless open world that contains the intricacies of the dungeons of their previous entries.

They have officially set the bar of how combat, world building , itemisation and open-world games should be designed.  Elden Ring is a Masterpiece!

Pretty fun game, It is hard though
If you walk into this game and allow yourself to run into combat against the big knight and die in the first ten minutes, I believe you're robbing yourself of the true beauty of the experience.
Elden Ring is a really ambitious project by a team who's biggest strength is avoiding any and all ludonarrative dissonance. Pay attention to the lore options and really make up a person who lived and died hearing that one day they might come back to the Land Between, or that their parents told them they might come here. Play a grounded perspective that avoids pain and death, and explore the world. 

See how far that takes you. Pay attention to the weirdness in interactions, watch for the flecks of blood and the distinctions, similarities, and causalities. Don't lose a sense of wonder. Don't lose a sense of humanity. Don't die so much that death becomes normal and life becomes a thing you ride past fast on a horse. 

Collect flowers. Pick berries. Study alchemical truth.

REAL ALL YOUR ITEMS DESCRIPTIONS :)

And have fun, Elden Ring is about to have a DLC drop and it is already polished into an incredible work by From Software.

I cannot recommend this game enough. And since youre able to level and tackle challenges at your own pace this is also very friendly to people that are new to the soulsbourne genre. This game is easily one of my most favorite games ever. The cinematography is absolutely breathtaking, they give you little to no hand holding which serves a lot of challenge and everything from boss fights to discovering different graces this game is easily the most superlative games on steam.
e
If you told me 3 years ago that I would love this game, I wouldn't have believed you. Never liked the idea of RPGs and the thought of large worlds with a grind-factor. Maybe it's the familiarity from seeing some gameplay and thoughts of others, but the exploration is fun, doesn't feel like a grind, and there's so much to find and explore that you don't realise minute to minute how far apart the milestones are. The exploration is fun as the world is filled with so much of interest regardless of if you have a full understanding of the story and how these things connect.
