Overview
Elden Ring is the latest action role-playing game from FromSoftware, renowned for its challenging gameplay and intricate world-building. Collaborating with author George R.R. Martin, FromSoftware has crafted a vast and immersive open world that sets a new benchmark in the genre.

Story and Setting
The game is set in the mysterious Lands Between, a sprawling and beautifully designed fantasy realm. Players take on the role of the Tarnished, exiles seeking to restore the shattered Elden Ring and become the Elden Lord. The narrative is rich with lore, combining the enigmatic storytelling style of Hidetaka Miyazaki with the deep, mythic world-building of George R.R. Martin. The story unfolds through environmental storytelling, NPC interactions, and item descriptions, encouraging players to piece together the intricate plot.

Gameplay
Elden Ring builds on the signature Souls-like mechanics, with challenging combat, strategic thinking, and precise timing. The open-world design is a significant departure from previous FromSoftware titles, offering players unparalleled freedom to explore.

Combat: The game features refined combat mechanics, with a variety of weapons, spells, and abilities. Each encounter demands strategy and skill, rewarding players for mastering the deep combat system.
Exploration: The Lands Between are filled with hidden secrets, challenging dungeons, and formidable bosses. Exploration is highly rewarding, with numerous side quests, hidden items, and lore to discover.
Customization: Players can extensively customize their character's appearance, stats, and equipment. The game offers multiple classes and the ability to mix and match skills, allowing for diverse playstyles.
Graphics and Design
The visual design of Elden Ring is stunning, with diverse landscapes ranging from lush forests and haunting swamps to grand castles and dark caverns. The art direction creates an atmospheric and immersive experience. The attention to detail in the world design is exceptional, making exploration feel both exciting and rewarding.

Audio and Music
The soundtrack of Elden Ring is hauntingly beautiful, complementing the dark fantasy setting perfectly. The music enhances the atmosphere during exploration and heightens the intensity of combat encounters. Voice acting is also top-notch, bringing the characters and story to life.

Pros
Expansive Open World: The game world is vast, beautifully crafted, and filled with intriguing secrets.
Challenging Combat: Combat is rewarding and requires strategic thinking.
Rich Lore: The story and world-building are deep and engaging.
Customization: Extensive character customization options cater to various playstyles.
Visuals and Sound: Stunning graphics and an atmospheric soundtrack enhance the immersive experience.
Cons
Difficulty: The challenging gameplay may be daunting for newcomers to the genre.
Pacing: The open-world design can lead to pacing issues, with some players feeling overwhelmed by the sheer amount of content.
Conclusion
Elden Ring is a masterful blend of FromSoftware's signature challenging gameplay with a rich, expansive open world. The collaboration with George R.R. Martin has resulted in a deeply immersive and lore-rich experience. While the difficulty may be intimidating for some, fans of the genre will find it to be a rewarding and unforgettable journey. Elden Ring sets a new standard for action RPGs and is a must-play for any fan of the genre.

Rating: 9.5/10

I always liked the idea of soulsborne games. Being able to learn to adapt to different enemies, having a deep lore, taking your time with the game considering we spend so much on buying these. But for some reason I could never get into these type of games.

But Elden Ring, oh, Elden Ring is just amazing once you get the hang of the game. The best part of the game is the freedom it gives you to roam around the map and take fights according to your skill level and learn the mechanics of the enemies. I almost gave up on this game when I was stuck at an enemy but decided to give it a try again and just wow now a part of me doesn't want the game to get over. The bosses are fantastic to fight and it gives you such an amazing satisfaction once you beat them.

The visuals are TOP NOTCH, the world seems dead as well as lively at times and it just makes it more appealing to the eyes. sometimes i just sit at a site of grace looking at the view kinda like a screensaver mode. 

If you want to play soulsborne type games but you could never get into it I suggest this masterpiece.

This is just barely a recommend from me, to be honest. There's a lot of jank and a lot of bull shit, but its still a good time regardless. Came back to replay before DLC drops, and the game definitely has more problems than my rose-tinted glasses had me remembering. The combat design for far too many enemies just feels so poorly thought out. 

If there was to be something that would keep you from being this game, in my opinion anyway, it'd probably be the god awful camera and lock-on mechanic. You'll also be staring at the ankles of a lot of giant, and cool looking, enemies. Enjoy dodging what you cant see.

Lore wise and story wise, it's great. Too bad I had to go watch 40 hours of a dude breaking down the lore for me on youtube because it's easier that way than the way the game does it, but i will say there is a charm to the way the game does it....it's just not a style thats for me.

As whole, 6.5/10 from me.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

game make me smash controller grrrr
Beware of good game ahead
Sadly, this game destroyed the Dark Souls legacy and turned it into delirium. Open world was a bad idea, and it simply destroyed all progression and challenge that was meant to be there. No balance at all - you could arrive at the place filled with monsters who can easily oneshot you and be frustrated like never before. Or you could accidentally become too strong for some other location and lose all interest and passion to explore. The feeling of being involved into fairly balanced and hard fight against some really well designed boss - for example, Artorias - was (and still) absolutely mindblowing. I love when Artorias hits me, because next time I will be better. I will clunch my teeth and hit him back next time. In Elden Ring bosses are too unpredictable, they spam you with so many attacks that learning quickly becomes pain in the arse (and that's on top of what I said about unbalanced level difficulty).

And what about the game's story? I don't care about any maiden or villain you show me, I can't understand what NPCs are talking about 80% of the time and I don't feel my own purpose in all of it. The world and its inhabitants are simply meaningless.

I really tried to give this game a chance, I really did. I have about 3000 hours in SoulsBorne series. But after this review, Elden Ring will be the first game that I am going to delete from my library forever. And I have played a bunch of games, believe me.

Elden Ring is beautiful - it has a ton of funny builds and weapons, gorgeous locations, varius enemies and it was made with passion. But at the same time, I feel no excitement from this adventure, no connections to other characters, no purpose in the world, the story sucks a big one. Just why, Miyazaki? Why? It is not just a betrayal, this one right here...


Elden Ring has just killed the whole generation of games for me. And the fact that people continue to hype around this video game is simply disturbing. I will replay Kings Field, Dark Souls, Demon Souls and Bloodborne, but that's it. The End.


[b]Rest in peace, my favourite video game series.[/b]

If you like the color yellow, this is the game for you. Every single yellow color palette you can think of is in this game. Oh... you want a game-play review? Right! I recommend that if this is your first Fromsoft game, like it was for me, get friends. Not only are friends just a great idea for enjoying life, but friends who have the experience help bring you into the "know" when it comes to things that will actually help you. This game was not built to help you. O no... poor maiden-less Tarnished. It was built to punish you until you find a way to overcome adversity and climb to the top of that great hill to taste the dust of victory. I know what I said. I recommend this game to my friends who have the wherewithal and tenacity to do that. I don't recommend it to my casual gaming friends who don't find mighty challenges to be entertaining.

best game ever
One of the best game plays you can find with so many viable builds as to be absurd. 
You are kidding yourself if you think it has a story ( the massive videos are mostly guessing based on a few scraps of lore here and there).
The side quests are essentially impossible without a wiki open as they all require you to go to numerous super specific locations in order with almost no guidance for most of them on a massive open world map and most have arbitrary cut off points that can cancel them  if you do specific things.
Since most builds are based on items and were they are is completely random at first glance don't feel bad to look up on wikis where stuff is. For a game that is designed to be super frustrating if you don't have knowledge it can be beautiful once everything comes together.

9/10 game would be 10/10 if ranni had four feet instead of just two
Master piece!
I spent 170 hrs on my first playthrough on PS5, so as far as the game itself, it's massive and easily a 10/10. I'm mainly writing this review to talk about performance. Like I said I played this on PS5 originally and the performance there was ok but not great. I would get a solid 60 fps in dungeons and castles, but in the open world it would frequently drop to the mid to low 50's, at times maybe even the high 40's depending on location and situation. I initially avoided the PC version because I had heard that it suffered from stutter issues, however those issues must have been patched out at some point because in my 24 hours with the game so far, it has run nearly flawlessly. It should be noted that occasionally I'll get one very large stutter a few moments after launching the game, but then everything returns to normal and I won't have a single other issue for my entire 5 hour + game session. On my system (4080/13700k) I get a solid 60 fps at all times with everything maxed out with raytraced shadows OFF. The raytracing in this game is pretty demanding and even just turning RT shadows to low can cause the frames to drop to the mid 50's during certain times of day when the sun casts long shadows for trees in some open world areas. Mostly I just play with RT shadows off to maintain that solid 60 fps at all times and that alone has made double dipping from PS5 to PC worth it, and just in time for the DLC later this month.

What more can be said? Fromsoft did it again!

U need to buy it blud
What is there left to say about Elden Ring that has not been said already? As such, I will keep this review as brief as possible, only pointing at the negatives I have with the game. Fret not, for these are few, and do not sully my overall enjoyment of this incredible game.

Open-Worlds are a double-edged sword. The freedom they bring allow for non-linear progression, and a level of adventure and discovery a linear game simply cannot dream to compare to. However, that sense of discovery simply does not exist on subsequent playthroughs. It is difficult to bring myself to play through an open-world game more than once as I already have gone through the entire game, and seen most or all of what there is to be seen. When I went down the well in Mistwood, and came upon a beautiful underground, I was floored. That sense of discovery was something I hadn't experienced in an open-world game in a while. But I doubt I will feel the same way on a second playthrough. It is tough to get excited for a story if you already know how it is going to end.

Difficult seems very unbalanced in some areas. The Haligtree had some of the most bizarre, and difficult enemy placements I've ever experienced in a FromSoftware game. What are typically bosses would outnumber you on 3v1 fights in small rooms. Not to mention some bosses are overwhelmingly fast, making it difficult to punish as slower builds. I am glad that FromSoft has balanced intelligence and dexterity builds to be more practical than previous games. I always felt that if you were not a strength build in Dark Souls, you are pretty much doomed to fail. However I feel that strength builds have been left in the dust this time around. There is a reason why the meta revolved around dexterous, blood loss builds for a while at launch.

And lastly, to fill in spaces in this enormous world, assets are frequently recycled. Catacombs all feel far too similar, and mini-bosses and bosses are reused to the point where they do not feel special. If I ever decide to return to play Elden Ring a second time on New Game+, I highly doubt I will revisit the catacombs at all.

In summary, Elden Ring is FromSoftware and Hidetaka Miyazaki's magnum opus. 

Do I prefer it over Dark Souls 1 and 3? No, I do not. 

But do I consider it the objective better game? I do.

Elden Ring implements, expands, and polishes all sorts of gameplay elements from all previous FromSoft titles. Demon Souls, Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and even Sekiro have all lead to this game.

I give Elden Ring:
9.0 Soldjars out of 10

I look forward to the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC, and whatever this incredible studio and director have in store for us next.
Elden Ring is a good culmination of FromSoft's previous works refocused into one experience. I've put too many hours into this game, and it all felt worthwhile. New players to the genre ought to have a good time, as there exists a handful of ways to overcome obstacles and defeat bosses. Exploring the massive world of The Lands Between and trying out a variety of weapon builds is a blast. Definitely a recommend!

Practically perfect. Even people who wouldn't usually be into Souls games can enjoy Elden Ring at their own pace due to the open world.
First Souls-like game I played and absolutely loved it. Stunning world building and some seriously impressive lore. Gameplay might not be for everyone but there are plenty of playstyles that can be viable for even casual gamers.

I have played through 4 times now on PC and PS5 and the PS version is definitely more optimized. PC has some random stutter issues and a bug with HDR thats still not solved. I don't like the quest design as its never clear what to do to progress questlines. seemingly random triggers and no real quest log to track anything. This makes using a guide necessary if you want to do everything. I also don't like the story. While the lore is quite good, the story is a mess. I know that's typical From Software style but if someone is playing for the story, they will be sorely disappointed. Also the big reveal at the end is not explained even slightly. No one is going to read a dozen scrolls and talk to 10 different NPCs to get fragments of the story. If I have to watch 2 hour long Vaatividya videos to make any sense of it, then its not good design.

If you don't care about the story, then this might be the best game you've ever played. Highly recommended but with a few caveats mentioned above.

I've been trying to defeat Radagon and Elden Beast for the last 8 days, totaling approximately 34 hours of failed attempts. I never said I was a God Gamer, but I thought I at least had a modicum of talent worthy to defeat these final bosses and become Elden Lord. Dear Christ in Heaven. I use to love the music of Elden Beast. It sparked wonder and awe from within the deepest chambers of my soul. And now? It haunts me in my dreams. Taunts me. There is no God. Only suffering. This damn cosmic slug! It spews it‚Äôs gold frothy light at me. It flings its galaxy smog at my face. It hurls its homing stars as I try to flee and fail. This damn cosmic slug pounds my flesh to a celestial pulp, deconstructing my atoms until I am nothing but stardust floating in a sea of a black void. There is no God. Only suffering. How many hours will I continue to torment myself? How many more days will I submit myself as a mere plaything for the Beast called Elden? Fortnite would never hurt me like this? And yet, I crave to be hurt. ‚ÄúTomorrow will be better,‚Äù I shout into the abyss. ‚ÄúTomorrow I will become Elden Lord!‚Äù Copium, sweet, sweet, copium..................................

yeah
Another amazing instalment in the From Software game library. 

Essentially, this is a proper open world Dark Souls game which worked wonderfully, the story is top notch and graphics are beautiful.

For me personally, I find games that are completely open world can be overwhelming and I struggle to do more than 1 playthrough since it has a feeling of a massive time sink as I always want to do everything in these types of games. I managed to get all achievements apart from 2 endings as I have only finished 1 playthrough.

I am 100% a PvE player and dislike PvP, so I can't really comment on the PvP side of the game other than it is very popular.

O DEATH BECOME MY BLADE ONCE MORE!
FINALLY NOT GAME SHARING THIS GAME ANYMORE SO I CAN WRITE A REVIEW ON THIS GAME Elden Ring is arguably the best game in the series, delivering an expansive and fascinating open world that's a joy to explore. The landscapes are breathtakingly beautiful, truly some of the best visuals seen in gaming. Each area is packed with secrets and challenges that keep you engaged for hours. The bosses are a standout feature; they're brilliantly designed and offer a tough but fair challenge, although a few do repeat throughout the game. Devs really nailed the climactic feel with the last two bosses‚Äîboth feel like true final bosses and provide a satisfying end to an epic journey. I enjoyed Elden Ring so much that I couldn't stop until I had unlocked all the achievements. It's a masterpiece that's not to be missed.

goated
I've tried playing this game several times over, but each time something stops me.

I do appreciate the open world. At times, it is stunningly beautiful. Enough for an Explorer like myself to fall in love with. But contrast this with the other Souls games and this one is only marginally better than Dark Souls III, and that one was garbage in my opinion. Most don't share that view, especially not since DS1 and DS2, along with Demon's Souls are my favorites and no doubt will certain readers such as potentially you discredit my view as nothing more than "git gud" because how dare I criticize what you love.

Frankly, here's my issue with Elden Ring.
The controls, are godawful. No matter how I try to rebind them, I sincerely hate them. I never feel like I am in control of my character, I am a slave to the will of the game. After a while I may adapt, but it's not a fun time. Even after adapting fully to the controls, it just never feels as good as the others did. It's certainly no Dragon's Dogma, but it's hard to beat perfection. Imagine if this game was just as fluid as DD is. Then it could certainly be something wonderful.

So take this with a grain of salt.
You may end up loving this game.
But the controls ruin any kind of enjoyment.

its perfect, i love it
It took me a little over 2 years for me to beat Elden Ring picking it up and putting it down when I would feel some burnout. As someone who naturally explores as much as they can I found that the game was full of surprises and would give you a whole arsenal of "tools" that you could use whenever you got stuck. It's one of those games that doesn't require you to explore but definitely rewards it if you do. The bosses felt fair and each time you die you felt like you were "downloading" their move set and getting better. With the ability to make the game as easy or hard as you want by using a plethora of different items, summons, and weapons it feels like it has a lot of repeatability which is something I'd want from a game that makes you want to stay in its world. Overall I'd say it was a great game and is definitely worth the challenge if you want to pick it up. I'm excited for the DLC and what that has to bring but for now I'll leave you with a rating of 9/10

It good thats all you need to know
Highest endorsement. Play without info or guides and luxuriate in exploring a beautiful, brutal world, with well-balanced but challenging exp and equip pacing, a sense of destinations in the vistas with almost continuous expansions in magnitude of a fantastic world, and decent diversity in build-based playstyle (I've now played four). Pay attention during cut-scenes, as conversation history is not immediately available. The story reveals itself in a convoluted but fun way, so pay attention to all dialogue, equipment info, etc. to tease out the grand narrative. Warrants multiple playthroughs and thus high value for money. I recommend playing with settings as high as possible while maintaining a consistent chop-free framerate. I turn down settings as I go. A long, rich, adventure of the highest order.

The game beat me. 10/10

I have to admit something, I‚Äôve only ever beaten Bloodborne and Dark Souls 2. I got lost in DS1 after Nito. Once I moved towards the end of DS3 I got busy and never returned. And when I reached the final boss in Sekiro‚Ä¶. Well, I just couldn‚Äôt do it. And finally, Elden Ring. I didn‚Äôt finish Elden Ring. 

I don‚Äôt know why yet, maybe that‚Äôs the point of this review. What made me stop? I remember having done so much. I went down into the deep caverns of The Lands Between, went far off to meet Ranni, rejected the serpent king and his advances, fought the giants, and just to save everyone here from my ramblings; I eventually made it all the way to Morgott. I killed Morgott. But then I stopped. Just kind of, dropped it. 

Perhaps a realization hits me while playing From Softwares games. A realization that I will have to keep pushing through over and over again, and that the time to do this could otherwise be spent completing other games or activities. But isn‚Äôt that silly? Games are meant to be experienced! Not just another task to scratch off the list, right!? Hm, well, what if the experience is robbing you of other experiences? What if, over the course of many years, I‚Äôve already had this experience before. Dodge, attack, get hit, heal, dodge, dodge, attack, attack, run. I‚Äôve done these same things, continued to memorize enemy patterns over and over again, went to the same screen to check if a new items stats warrant swapping out. 
But isn‚Äôt that just games? Like, most games in one way or another?

Am I bored of games? Do I not like these games? Am I not good? Can I never be good? Why am I doing this? What‚Äôs the point of any of it? Should I finally just give up? Should I put my foolish ambitions to rest?

"Elden Ring is a stunning masterpiece that elevates the action RPG genre. Combining FromSoftware's signature challenging gameplay with a vast, beautifully crafted open world, it offers a deeply immersive experience. The lore-rich story, epic boss battles, and intricate level design make every moment captivating. With its blend of exploration, combat, and atmospheric storytelling, Elden Ring is a must-play for fans of epic adventures."

cum
While a big fan of previous Fromsoftware games, Elden Ring I feel was a bad step out of the Dark Souls mold that they've so perfected by the sole choice of making the game open world. While very impressive at first, I do feel that this single action has greatly hampered the game in terms of progressing, finding quests and special objects, and keeping to areas your meant to as it is very easy to find yourself in a much higher level area than your suppose to be simply by riding your horse for a bit. Furthermore, the enemies within Elden ring get tiresome fairly quickly due to there not being a large variety of enemies like previous titles, with several of the main enemies simply being reskinned multiple times to fit different kingdoms and given one to two new attacks and atop of that, if you have played previous FS games, one is likely to note that some enemies are simple reskins of other game's enemies. The story also I feel is not as good as previous games with it feeling more like a generic fantasy universe as opposed to something grim like Bloodborne or, as mentioned a few times, Dark Souls, even though it continues to play with the whole "Life and Death" cycle that the DS series has done, though it just is not as good (For spoilers, search Youtube). While I like many of the locations, armors, weapons, and the new mount system, I was not greatly impressed by gameplay or story, which I feel was hampered by their choice to go open world, as opposed to say similar to original dark souls but larger maps, as it is very easy to miss things to help you in quests or to simply fail quests as you progressed too far into one area or simply never met them due to not finding them, this game is VERY difficult to play without a wiki and map opened up on a browser, much more than previous game and a problem I never really had in the earlier games thanks to quests being easier to find and complete thanks to these smaller locations. So, while a pretty game with some improvements to Souls-like games, I find this ultimately is a step backwards as opposed to forward in terms of quality and playability.
died over 200 times lost count after that wolf in the caslte 10/10
jork peanits when ranni
Did not dislike anything. Great game!
First things first, After 120 hours of experience in this game as my first fromsoftware game i can say 1 thing  straight. This game is NOT FOR EVERYONE. If you don't have patience and and u don't enjoy open world without lots of navigation you will have hard time. I had to use ER wiki to find out most of stuff. The game is very punishing. A game where every death has to be meaningful. If you still decide to play it this game will stay  with you for a while. Its hell of a good experience with crazy story and graphics. At some point of game when u start building towards you endgame build u become more and more crazy and you can recover from your mistakes pretty much fast. Becoming the elder lord after that long and painful road is the most excited thing i ever experienced in my gaming carrier. 
Overall i do recommend it my Elden Ring rating is 8/10. Don't get me wrong its great game it was just not my cup of tea. It require so much commitment and strategy and patience something i don't most of the times when i come back from work. But in other hand if you have a lot of free time and u want to spend more than 150 hours in game. Than this will be the game for you.
Best moments:
1. Boss fights. (Most cinematic boss fights in my life esp Radhan Event)
2. Different builds and game play options.
3. Ending and late game.
4. Geting Rewarded for exploratin.
5. When u start understanding how the game works its becomes so fun and addicitive.

Worst parts.
1.Not enough navigation outside of yellow graces on map.
2.So many things you can miss because game does not tell u what to do or where to go.
3.The zones are not with level sign (You can go in level 90 zone as level 35 and geting 1 shoted, because the game is way to open)
4..Outside of 1 tutorial in start you have nothing else to teach you how to become better.

Graphics,Combat and Story is really on point. 
I just wish i had quest Journal or something and more navigation.
Once again overall 8/10.

My biggest advice: Do not get discouraged. Do not be afraid. If you die go some where else you can always skip and come back later. Death is not ending. Death is lesson. If i did you can do it too !

Very good Immersive rpg game
Diving into Elden Ring, I found myself enraptured by a game that masterfully blends dark fantasy with open-world exploration. From the moment I set foot in the Lands Between, I knew I was in for an unforgettable experience.

Elden Ring's gameplay hooked me from the start. It retains the hallmark challenging combat that FromSoftware is renowned for, demanding precision, strategy, and patience. Yet, the open-world aspect introduced a new level of freedom that was both exhilarating and daunting. Exploring the vast, interconnected world at my own pace, discovering hidden dungeons, and engaging in spontaneous battles kept the experience fresh and exciting.

Riding my spectral steed, Torrent, across diverse landscapes‚Äîfrom eerie swamps to towering mountains‚Äîwas a delight. The ability to traverse such a large world with fluidity and speed added a new dimension to exploration. The game's world felt alive, with secrets lurking around every corner, beckoning me to uncover them.

Elden Ring is visually stunning. The art direction, blending gothic and fantastical elements, created a world that was both haunting and beautiful. The detail in the environments, from crumbling ruins to lush forests, was captivating. The game‚Äôs lighting and atmospheric effects further enhanced the sense of immersion.

The sound design and music also stood out. The ambient sounds heightened the tension during exploration, while the orchestral score added grandeur to the epic battles. The audio experience was integral to the overall atmosphere, making every moment feel significant and immersive.

On the technical front, Elden Ring performed admirably on my system. The game ran smoothly with only occasional minor hiccups, which were quickly overshadowed by the sheer enjoyment of the experience. It‚Äôs clear that FromSoftware put considerable effort into optimizing the game for a wide range of hardware.

Elden Ring exceeded my expectations in every way. It‚Äôs a game that not only challenges but also deeply rewards those who invest their time and effort. The combination of an expansive open world, intricate combat mechanics, and a richly woven narrative made it a standout experience. Whether you‚Äôre a die-hard Souls fan or a newcomer to FromSoftware‚Äôs games, Elden Ring offers a journey that is as breathtaking as it is brutal. For me, it was an unforgettable adventure through a mesmerizing and unforgiving world.

YES CHAT WE DID IT!!!
[h1]Elden Ring: A Sprawling Open-World Adventure[/h1]

Elden Ring offers players a vast open world to explore, filled with a multitude of locations waiting to be discovered. The lore woven throughout the map enriches every corner, creating a puzzle that players piece together bit by bit. The combat system is more dynamic than ever, with numerous possible builds to experiment with. However, it's worth noting that the monsters are significantly stronger than those in From Software's previous games, although some may find that the diversity of builds makes the game easier than previous "soul" titles.

The game also boasts a diverse range of atmospheres, from tranquil plains to decrepit ruins, and from putrid lakes to snow-capped mountains. While there is a plethora of monsters to encounter, some players may lament the reuse of bosses, diminishing the variety of encounters relative to the size of the world. However, the game makes up for this with its intriguing magic system, which offers players a refreshing approach to combat.

Elden Ring's lore is exceptionally rich, crafted in collaboration with acclaimed author George R. R. Martin. Hidetaka Miyazaki's vision to explore a new type of game, blending open-world exploration with the hallmark challenges of a "soul" game, is executed masterfully. However, some players may feel that the simplicity of character builds has been sacrificed in the process.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a triumph of world-building and storytelling, offering players a captivating journey through a sprawling and immersive world. While it may not be without its flaws, its ambition and depth make it a must-play for fans of open-world RPGs and From Software's previous titles alike.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling.  As a result, it is very different from other open-world games I have played such as Skyrim and Far Cry which are story and questline driven. From the get-go, Elden Ring doesn't impose any particular playstyle or route on you. You are completely free to do what you want to from the very start of the game. You can finish the main storyline and beat the final boss or you can explore the entire map without ever seeing the main bosses, it truly is up to you with no outside influence. It is truly refreshing to feel this sense of freedom in choice and exploration in any open world game.

"LENNY SUMMERS HAS COME BACK FROM THE GRAVE TO FINISH WHAT HE COULDN'T IN SAINT DENIS"
.
Elden Ring is one of those games that you just need to play at least once in your life. It's probably the closest to an actual work of art mixed in with a combo of some of FromSoft's previous games.

The game's music and art direction is so perfect for the setting being presented, and felt incredibly immersive for me. The music feels as though it belongs in a movie with how dramatic and beautiful it sounds. Probably the best in FromSoft's lineup of games in my opinion. Elden Ring's art direction is also phenomenal in about every way. The only gripe I have about it, although it may be just my own opinion, is that some parts and areas get a tad redundant and some parts recycle enemies and ideas from other sections, but it's not enough to say it's bad. 

Open world in the game is also pretty interesting and does a decent job making sure the player always has something to do, and of course has some of the best vistas I've seen in a game. Honestly I took a little too many screenshots it's so good lmao. Seeing parts of the map that I couldn't get to made me explore looking for ways to get to where I wanted/needed to go, and rather than just being a straight shot to my destination, the game always threw a number of different things that would get me sidetracked and I'd end up going on like three other whole little adventures before doing what I set out to do. It's very good for an open world.

The gameplay, I think, is a great combo of Dark Souls, Bloodbourn, and even Sekiro thrown in. FromSoft seems as though they wanted to bring the best of their older games into one, and did that they did. It really opens up the world for exploration, brings out the most interesting combat to always keep you on your toes, and has amazing locations that allow for exploration so you can find different paths through the area with many goodies to find. 

The story is about as insane as you'd expect. It's FromSoft.

The game's insanely good, if you're reading this just thinking about getting the game just get it. Don't think about it, just get it and enjoy it. Trust.
good

elden ring !!!
I PLAY, I DESTROY, I UNINSTALL (REPEAT)
Great Game
amazing worth every penny
It's just that good. It's easy to see why it has won so many awards and Honestly with 200+ hours in the game it has almost infinite replaybility. Every time I start a new Game file I find something new that I hadn't discovered before in previous Saves. Not a veteran From Soft fan. this was the first toe I've dipped into the From soft Franchise and it has me wanting to torture myself more in the likes of Sekiro and Bloodborn as well as other Souls games.
My favourite game of 2022, I played over 250 hours on PS4. The best parts of this game are:
[list]
    [*]Many great challenging bosses, especially towards the end of the game. It was really fun to beat all bosses on RL1. Top 3 bosses imo are [spoiler]Malenia, Mohg, and Horah Loux[/spoiler].
    [*]Despite what some people think, the combat system is amazing, fair, and well designed. The combat is similar to Dark Souls 3 but improved. Jump attacks are a great addition too. Also easy mode does exist, its called using magic and ash summons.
    [*]The world is very pretty especially with a reshade mod for PC.
    [*]The added quality of life features such as the stake of marika which respawns you right before boss is a great addition.
    [*]The lore is very interesting.
[/list]

The downsides of the game, while fairly minor, are:
[list]
    [*]Not all bosses are designed the best. Particularly, fromsoft seem to not be able to pull off duo boss fights (demon princes from DS3 is the only exception). 
    [*]While the open world was okay to try and is done better than most big dev studios, its makes the game have less replayability. I've beat the game 6 times, and at this point I just run through the open world, get key items and stick mostly to the legacy dungeons and certain caves. I miss the compact level design of Dark Souls 1.
    [*]There should be less weapons. For example, club and stone club are basically the same but one does more damage. I wish they designed the weapons like Bloodborne where each weapon is unique.
[/list]

Overall still an amazing game. I'm hyped the for the DLC :D
made my soul feel more fulfilled than sex.

Elden Ring Review: A Masterpiece of Modern Gaming
Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ (5/5)

Visuals and World-Building:
Elden Ring‚Äôs world is a visual feast, boasting stunningly detailed landscapes that range from lush, verdant forests to desolate, haunting wastelands. Each area is meticulously crafted, brimming with secrets waiting to be uncovered. The interconnected open world is a marvel, offering seamless transitions between diverse environments that invite endless exploration.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
Elden Ring perfects the formula that FromSoftware has honed over years of development. The combat is fluid and precise, requiring tactical acumen and quick reflexes. The introduction of mounted combat and a flexible class system adds depth and variety, allowing players to tailor their playstyle to their preferences. The challenging yet fair difficulty ensures that every victory feels hard-earned and immensely satisfying.

Story and Lore:
The narrative of Elden Ring, enriched by George R.R. Martin's storytelling genius, is an intricate web of lore and mythology. The game‚Äôs story is a grand tale of ambition, power, and loss, unfolding in a world steeped in history and legend. The lore is deeply embedded in every aspect of the game, from item descriptions to environmental storytelling, encouraging players to piece together the rich tapestry of its universe.

Audio and Soundtrack:
The audio design in Elden Ring is impeccable, with a soundtrack that enhances every moment of the game. The haunting melodies and powerful orchestral scores are perfectly suited to the game's epic scope, while the ambient sounds bring the world to life. From the quiet rustling of leaves to the thunderous roar of a boss battle, the soundscape is immersive and evocative.

Replayability and Content:
Elden Ring offers an immense amount of content, ensuring a high replay value. With multiple endings, diverse character builds, and numerous hidden secrets, players will find new experiences with each playthrough. The robust multiplayer features, including cooperative and competitive modes, add further layers of engagement and longevity to the game.

Conclusion:
Elden Ring is a landmark achievement in the world of gaming. It seamlessly combines the challenging gameplay that FromSoftware is known for with an expansive, richly detailed world and a deeply engaging story. Whether you are a long-time fan of the Soulsborne series or a newcomer eager to explore its depths, Elden Ring offers an unparalleled adventure that will leave a lasting impression.

Priced at around $59.99, Elden Ring is a must-have for any gaming enthusiast. Its extraordinary blend of artistry, challenge, and storytelling makes it not just a game, but a profound experience that redefines what is possible in the medium.

great
This game is definitely among the best I've ever played, absolutely deserved winning GOTY.

Exploration and curiosity are really rewarded - and sometimes punished with bosses or traps but it's a Soulslike, so what did I expect - although sometimes the map can get a bit big and daunting. The boss design is really great and versatile with a little bit of everything to make sure things stay fresh. Builds are also versatile and easily respeccable thanks to Rennala and the rebirth mechanic; additionally most upgrade materials become an unlimited resource once you're far enough into the game allowing for a wide variety of weapons to be used without having to settle on a single weapon and playstyle too early. The combat is as you would expect it from a FromSoft Soulslike, challenging and rewarding.

All in all an amazing game and I can't wait for Shadows of the Erdtree

THIS GAME IS A MASTERPIECE! 

To set the stage, all you know from the outset is that you play as a ‚ÄúTarnished‚Äù of no renown, blessed by grace, and are compelled to make the journey to The Lands Between and become an Elden Lord. What that actually means, how one might go about doing that, and what the deal is with that giant glowing golden tree are all things that you have to discover yourself. Like other FromSoft games, the grand story is hard to fully digest on a first playthrough, especially because there‚Äôs no in-game journal to refresh you on the events, characters, or unique terms you encounter across dozens of hours. There really should be, but it is a story I nonetheless enjoyed trying to piece together for myself. I look forward to supplementing that knowledge with the inevitable painstakingly detailed lore videos that emerge from the community later. 

It ended up being the organic side stories that kept me most enthralled rather than the grand overarching plot that credits Game of Thrones‚Äô George R.R. Martin as its scenario writer. FromSoft smartly doesn‚Äôt change much in its approach to these from the Souls games, Bloodborne, or Sekiro; you‚Äôll just naturally meet characters as you explore and discover the world and become involved in their problems. There are no ‚Äú!‚Äù markers on the map, no waypoints to guide you to them, and these characters don‚Äôt always flag you down or initially want or need anything from you. They‚Äôre just people with their own agendas and goals, whose stories are impacted based on your own actions or inactions. 

I never once felt the open-world fatigue that usually sets in when my brain gets overloaded by a map.

That was actually kind of refreshing in an open world as vast as this one, and it was always exciting to see a familiar face pop up again later as I was eager to learn about what brought them to this new part of the world and how their journey had progressed. The trade-off, of course, is that without any markers, quest log, or journal, it becomes very easy to forget about certain plot threads and accidentally leave them unresolved by the end. That‚Äôs a bummer, and I‚Äôve already felt regret at missing out on stories that some of my colleagues have had ‚Äì but for me it was worth it, because even after 87 hours, I never once felt the open-world fatigue that usually sets in when my brain gets overloaded by a map absolutely full of unresolved sidequest markers. Besides, any missed quests give me extra incentive to continue onto New Game+. 

‚ÄúFreedom‚Äù is the word that every aspect of Elden Ring‚Äôs design connects back to. From the moment you set foot in Limgrave, the first of many interconnected regions of The Lands Between, you are completely free to go wherever you want. And sure, that‚Äôs far from a new concept in open-world games, but the way it's handled here is truly extraordinary. If you wanted to, you could be an explorer and spend hours upon hours in Limgrave, delving into every mini dungeon, fighting every boss, discovering every NPC, and leveling yourself up to better prepare for what‚Äôs next. Alternatively, you could follow the Light of Grace, guiding you toward the main path and the first major dungeon ‚Äì or you could find a hidden path to a new region that‚Äôs meant for higher levels and completely bypass the first major dungeon entirely! Maybe even steal yourself a cool weapon early while you‚Äôre there. 

A few things set Elden Ring apart from games like Skyrim that provide a similar openness.
Again, this is not unprecedented, but a few things set Elden Ring apart from games like Skyrim that provide a similar openness. For one, Elden Ring doesn‚Äôt scale enemy levels to match your own at all, so jumping into a later region means you‚Äôre always dealing with stronger enemies, making the risk/reward prospect of doing so very real. But perhaps more notably, the way its different areas are connected makes finding these new ones more than a simple matter of choosing a direction and heading towards it. Limgrave is designed very specifically with a main path in mind that takes you through Stormveil Castle, and finding a way around that truly feels like you‚Äôve discovered a hidden passage or alternate route, which is a super cool feeling not present in most open worlds I‚Äôve explored.

You also have more freedom in how you approach combat than any previous FromSoft game thanks to a bunch of familiar new systems that are used in interesting ways here. Stealth is a more viable option thanks to the addition of crouch-walking, which finally lets you sneak by tough enemies or get behind them for a critical hit; there‚Äôs now horseback combat in large, open areas which gives you more mobility and the ability to attack on both sides with your right-handed weapon, but has the drawback of taking away your ability to roll out of the way of big attacks; you can craft items on the fly using materials found in the world so you can be ready for whatever a situation calls for; you can summon a large variety of creatures to fight for you, each with their own unique abilities and situational advantages; and most substantially, you can equip Ashes of War to your weapons and completely change their affinity and skill. 

Elden Ring's difficulty surprised me, even as a veteran of the Soulslike genre.
The Ashes of War system essentially combines two elements of prior Souls games ‚Äì weapon affinities and weapon skills ‚Äì by making them items that you can freely equip to your armaments. For example, let‚Äôs say I find a really good rapier and I really like the moveset, but I‚Äôm building my character with a focus on the Intelligence stat, which means it won‚Äôt get the kind of damage bonuses it needs to be a viable weapon. If I find an Art of War that bestows a magic spell onto a weapon, I can equip it and transform it into a magic weapon, thereby giving it Intelligence scaling on top of whatever skill the Ash of War has. Best of all, if I eventually decide to respec into a different build, I can still keep the same weapon and just put a different Ash of War onto it. Of course, you also have to find a specific item to unlock the different affinities, but it's nonetheless an incredibly smart addition that allows for a ton of variety in your preferred weapons.

The most important element of Elden Ring‚Äôs philosophy, though, is the freedom to just walk away and do something else when you hit a wall. Elden Ring is hard ‚Äì which is to be expected from a FromSoft game ‚Äì but its difficulty surprised me, even as a veteran of the Soulslike genre. I hit multiple points, even all the way up until the moment when I reached the very last boss, where I‚Äôd unlocked paths to several bosses and simply could not make headway on any of them. But even though I hit dead ends on those paths, there was always somewhere else I could go ‚Äì a region I hadn‚Äôt thoroughly explored, an NPC quest that I had set aside for later, a Light of Grace indicator that I had not yet followed. There was never a point in Elden Ring when I was at a complete loss of what to do, and every time I explored those other regions and followed those alternate paths I would find new gear and items, level up my stats, or learn new spells or skills that would eventually give me the extra edge I needed to power through a boss that had given me problems.

Poggers
Elden Ring is a few steps forward and a lot more steps backwards. Compared to Dark Souls 3, the highs are higher but there so many more lows, and the lows are much lower. The legacy dungeons such as Stormveil and Leyndell and main boss fights such as Godrick, Godfrey, Radahn, Maliketh, and especially Radagon are Fromsoft's best, and some mechanical additions like jumping help elevate and add another layer to the level and boss design.

While it comes with a world that is undeniably pretty and fun to explore at first, the game has many issues that really inflate in severity as you progress. Once you pass the first two or three areas, the optional content of the world severely degrades in quality. Copy-paste dungeons with limited selections of enemies and duplicate bosses tear a hole through the immersion of the game and can really drag out the runtime.

The combat of the game is not so perfect, either. Many required bosses have problems in their own right, such as the Fire Giant or Godskin Duo being abhorrent to fight due to overtuned design elements that feel engineered to force you to cheese. Furthermore, the balance of the lategame gets absurd. Enemies and bosses will kill you in two or three hits, and while that is fine to happen under certain conditions, "50 VIG with medium/heavy armor" should not be one of them. They massively stretched the standards of what you need to have acceptable tanking to the point where a setup that would make you feel near-invincible in DS3 makes you feel just barely capable in this game.

They really need to stop fucking around
perfect. You can make the game easier or harder not by a slider but by the time you prepare. If you still thinks its too hard summon a friend or two. nearly all builds are viable. You like the deafult axe more than the super duper hyper bos drop? Sure, upgrade it and run with it. the ammount of customisation and builds avainable is astonishing. Turbo gamers can rush through no summons or co-op and make the game harder, while casual players can gang on the bosses and still have a lot of fun.

good enough
Yes
A breath taking open world Souls game with many locations, dungeons, secrets, and bosses to discover and conquer on your way to become Elden Lord!

Combat is tough but fair. Exploration is more important than ever with the jumping mechanic, similar to Sekiro. The new Ashes of War system lets you change almost any weapon's special move with other abilities, allowing you to change your play style with a weapon you prefer.

Classic environmental and lore story telling of Fromsoft by reading item descriptions or interpreting the vague dialogue of the interesting NPCs that you'll meet.

Coop and invasions feel similar and are quite fun. You can still join "Covenants" but they aren't mutually exclusive anymore, meaning you can join all of them and complete their quests. Some are areas and quest might be locked behind story progression so be careful on the timing of completing them.

If you enjoyed any of the previous souls games then you will feel right at home with Elden Ring. I'd say this is more fast paced than Demon Souls or the first two Dark Souls, leaning more toward Bloodborne and Sekiro for timings and speed.

Overall a 10/10 souls game!
Dark Souls amazing depth and gameplay but with a huge open world. Truly a remarkable game that goes above and beyond. Fromsoft Never seems to disappoint. 10/10

I am not someone who typically plays "souls-like" games, but i found this game to be just awesome. This game is challenging, but it never felt "unfair" or "cheap."  Admittedly there have been points in the the game that were extremely frustrating and felt impossible to beat. There is a great deal of satisfaction that comes from overcoming these challenges. I would not consider myself good at video games, but i have been able to beat all of the major bosses (including Malenia) if you are patient and persistent you will be successful. 

This game offers great build diversity and some very interesting weapons and armor. The Story and lore are incredible and the world building is really impressive (although it is sad and pretty much no one has a happy ending) 

characters/monsters are well designed and nice to look at (even if they are hideous abominations)

combat is both punishing and rewarding. attacking/dodging/moving with intent and strategy will lead you to victory, while arrogantly attacking even the easiest of enemies will be punished if you are careless. 

I highly recommend it. it is certainly an experience that will be a standard for games for years to come.

The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human being to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can‚Äôt predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

Elden Ring is a challenging Souls-game RPG game.

I will preface this review by mentioning I've actually played the game solely using keyboard & mouse, so yes I will definitely mention that the controls and attacks were very wonky at times. The learning curve of the game is very high, the game has so many mechanics, attacks and items to use that it quickly becomes overwhelming. It is a progressive experience where you first learn the basics, then slowly integrate more strategies as time goes on. Thankfully, all you  lose on death are runes, so you can spend your runes on level ups and equipment without being penalised by dying repetitively to an hard enemy or an hard boss.

Elden Ring has a ton of main quests and side quests alike, with a cast of interesting characters and bosses. Everything follows the same theme, but each of them are very unique nonetheless. The monster design of Elden Ring is THE BEST I've ever seen in any games ever, considering I love grim and terrifying-looking creatures. The story is pretty good, but while it is probably an unpopular opinion, I think it could've been better. I felt attached to some of the characters and some parts are very intense, but I did feel detached to the story as a whole for some reason.

My favorite thing about Elden Ring is the everlasting feeling of constant progression whenever you unlock a new site of grace (fast travel waypoints) and after beating major encounters you have to work hard for to learn the mechanics of the bosses. My second favorite thing about Elden Ring is the hundreds of different weapons, armors, spells, incantations and different builds you can come up with.

The graphics are amongst the best of any games I've ever played, the cutscenes are super well made and the background are even more beautiful. Some of the animations while moving are a bit wonky, but the scenery is a breathtaking experience every single times. The spell effects are also top notch and the variety of backgrounds/dungeons/castles/shacks/etc is simply put crazy.

The soundtrack of this game is absolutely amazing, but it's mostly atmospheric or intense. It doesn't really have any memorable songs from what I could tell, but it is a very pleasurable auditory experience.

As far as the controls and overall mechanics of the game, I obviously think that a ton of things are overtuned or wonky. The platforming is very bad in some parts of the game and some bosses really feel like they hit outside of their hitbox. It also happened to me a countless amount of time I swing my weapon an inch too far from the boss and then get punished by almost dying due to missing my hit and trying to recover from it. That made most of the gameplay super frustrating and I definitely loss a ton of time to bosses and certain enemies due to that.

Also, the requirements for this game are quite high. Yes, the graphics are amazing, but my 2070 struggled with a lot of the game on the highest settings. I had only 1 crash thankfully, but I had hundreds of slowdowns when there are big explosions or a lot of smoke or whatever.

As for the expected playtime, it really is honestly almost endless. If you go for different builds, different routes, different choices, collecting everything and going up to NG+7 (or higher), you will have a few hundreds of hours in this game easily.

Overall, if you are willing to put a ton of efforts into learning a deep, complex and hard game, it is worth and it is worth the full price. Just keep in mind it is a really hard game and unless you use summons and the best setups, you will need a lot of practice to beat the first few bosses and even more to beat the harder bosses.

On my 2nd and 3rd play through (simultaneous, one on ng+ and one with my brother), and I'm still finding some new things. What keeps me coming back to this game is the sheer quantity of quality content in the form of boss fights, unique weapons and skills, and small areas that I find despite thinking I've done nearly everything.
After my first play through last year, I did my best to understand the lore hidden in the Lands between and I'm amazed at the depth this game offers. Miyazaki does not miss, this game is a masterpiece.

it's okay
I put this game down when it first came out. Can't recall why I did not get into the first time. Started watching others play and loved the game, but still didn't play it until the announcement of the DLC. Which gave me the incentive to play through the game and it has been a joy. I'm only 30+ hours in (rookie numbers), but it has been a fun experience running around and exploring the world of Elden Ring.
Epic Battles and Engaging Gameplay

The battles in Elden Ring are nothing short of epic. Every encounter feels significant, supported by impressive animations and a high level of difficulty. The difficulty is just right to enhance the feeling of reward after mastering a tough opponent. This sense of achievement is one of the main reasons why Elden Ring is so captivating.

Extensive Playtime and Exciting Exploration

Another highlight is the sheer length of the game. The world of Elden Ring offers countless hours of exploration, where new armors, weapons, abilities, and spells can be discovered. Every corner of the world is beautifully designed, inviting you to linger and marvel.

Performance Issues and Frustrations

Unfortunately, the gaming experience is marred by significant performance issues on the PC. To utilize my system‚Äôs maximum graphical performance and achieve a smooth image, I was forced to use a community program that bypasses the 60 FPS lock. This solution worked well as long as I played offline since the program does not harmonize with the Easy Anti-Cheat system and would lead to a ban if used online.

It is disappointing that the developers do not want to implement basic performance matters such as the FPS unlock themselves. Playing online was a frustrating experience with constant screen tearing and an unstable 60 FPS lock that even my RTX 3080 could not consistently maintain. This is particularly annoying since there is no cross-play, making it unnecessary to artificially limit PC players.

Pricing Policy and DLC Strategy

The developers' decision to release a DLC for a hefty ‚Ç¨40 without addressing the easily fixable flaws of the main game is hard to accept. The main game still costs ‚Ç¨60 even two years after release, which seems outrageous given the existing issues. It is understandable that fans of FromSoftware have high expectations, but in many aspects, Elden Ring feels overhyped.

Conclusion

Elden Ring has the potential to be a masterpiece but is held back by severe performance issues and a questionable pricing policy. The epic battles, engaging gameplay, and beautifully designed world cannot fully offset these flaws. FromSoftware should be ashamed of not addressing such basic performance problems while still charging high prices for the main game and the DLC. The game is definitely overrated.

Holy cumnshit. This game got me into DS3, then DS1. I'm a total from-head now. Anyways.

HIGHLY recommend this game if you like the medieval RPG-ness of Skyrim, but you want more "real" feeling combat. The combat in these games (Elven Ring, Dark Souls, other games in the series and genre "soulslikes") is SOOO good. It is tough but fair, in that, you know you were impatient/sloppy, and that's why you died. You will die A LOT. It will be FRUSTRATING. Definite controller-thrower, but do not rage. This game has actually helped some of my anger issues.

It just feels so real. The item scarcity, the combat, the way the game DOESN'T tell you EVERY single thing, or put a quest marker on a overlay compass. You just play the damn game, no one knows wtf is going on, and you keep picking up these worthless items "consume 10,000 ruin tomato for a 5 second boost in stamina" that's an exaggeration, but holy shit. This game. Everything you'd hate about this game, you love it. It's GOOD because it's HARD.

This game is huge. You will not fully explore this game even after 200 hours (I didn't). It's also BEAUTIFUL in a gloomy kind of way.

Biggest thing I wanna say is I don't even feel interested in playing skyrim or hardly any other games now. Seriously these games are that good.

good shit
at the time of writing it seems to work really well on linux using Proton Beta. Also the progression I had on my windows machine seamlessly transferred over just by installing it, meaning I didn't have to start over from scratch which is a huge plus.
I finished Elden Right for the first time on my PS5. This game is something that I thought that I will never experience in gaming. World in this game is HUUUUUUUUUUGE, you can spend 150-200 hours in it and still most probably you will not see everything. Combat pacing is similar to Dark Souls III, it is quick and responsive. Level design is on a level I have never seen in any other game. Progression feels great. You see and feel your character getting stronger with every hour played.

This game is almost perfect. But it has few problems:
- No normal coop. Really FromSoftware? Huge world in which you can spend even 200 hours but no normal coop? Thankfully that was fixed with a mod which you can download online
- if you miss some optional area in the beginning of the game and you will find it later, then you will simply steamroll through all enemies and bosses in this area. It is good to be powerful, but not THAT powerful.
- No normal cities or normal quests. I understand this approach in other games like DS1/2/3. But here it simply doesn't fit the world. Is it really so hard to introduce quest log describing the ongoing quests? Why all lore and quests have to be hidden behind this "Dark Souls" mistery curtain?
its alright

One of the greatest games to be released in recent times. This was the first souls-like game I ever played, and I couldn't put it down even after 13-hour work shifts. Truly addicting and incredibly rewarding gameplay. Amazing story, huge build variation, and unique enemies and bosses. This game provides everything you can want and expect from a AAA experience. If these types of games interest you, this is where you should start!
Very challenging, but for someone like myself who has never played a FromSoft game, this is truly a wonderful experience. Highly recommend as long as you don't mind tough fights (though I think that it's rewarding at the end).

10/10 game just play it
amazing game, tones of different endings with great story lines, and amazinggggg artwork.
Probably the only open world game I've actually enjoyed playing. The game is full of content and interesting things to find and explore.
Combat seems more forgiving and refined compared to previous games by Fromsoft. The storytelling method Fromsoft uses is still incredible and engaging, plus the game allows you to play in whatever way you want to play.
Also, play Seamless coop mod if you want to play with friends, and/or Convergance if you want more content after you finish the game.
GOog
Not done, but so far, so good. Offers lots of freedom for the most part, and many things are left unexplained, and is left to the player to figure out. It's pretty neat if you got the time to invest, and there's a true feeling of growing your character incrementally over the course of the game (rather than having power spikes at certain levels).

However, that's not to say the game doesn't piss you off every now and then. Some scenarios are made to throw you off, usually leading to near instant death without prior knowledge. Some cases are just painful/tedious, like having to walk across half a cave just to make a 2nd attempt to fight a boss.

really good game and really recomend this game if you are a big souls fan and really fun with friends.
Made me cry and also break my wall down all in one
   I want to start off by saying I absolutely hate souls like games/combat, and the first 10 hours of this game was a slog for the type of games i usually play, however once i finally immersed myself and figured out the gameplay loop, i went from HATING this game, to putting it in my top 5 single player experiences. The world building is great and if you are a lore buff there is SO MUCH here for you. if you are a gameplay buff once you realize the gameplay loop and how things are acquired and how you are rewarded for beating areas/bosses or finding secrets you will see the genius in the game design.

   To summarize if these types of games aren't for you, I recommend giving it a real honest shot i don't think you will be disappointed It got Game of the Year for a reason. From hating it - to my top 5, take it from me this game is a very rich and rewarding experience.

Now I'm just waiting on Brandon Sanderson to world build for a game like this!

I'm not a fan of how the world opens up. The constant fighting makes it less believable, and the lack of a difficulty setting doesn't help. Losing all money upon death, which is essential for advancement (except for upgrading potions), is frustrating. this is the greatest game of all time
Elden Ring is a near-perfect game, thanks to the brilliant collaboration between George R. R. Martin and Hidetaka Miyazaki. The story and setting are rich and immersive, pulling players into a dark, mysterious world.

The game's breathtaking scenery is a standout feature. Each region is unique and meticulously crafted, making exploration visually captivating. The art direction and environmental design are top-notch, ensuring that every corner of the game world is a pleasure to discover.

Gameplay strikes a perfect balance between challenge and engagement. Combat is precise and demanding, requiring skill and strategy. This level of difficulty is fair and immensely satisfying, giving a true sense of accomplishment with every victory. The variety of weapons, spells, and character builds adds depth and replayability.

The story is a masterful blend of Martin's intricate narrative style and Miyazaki's cryptic storytelling. Lore is conveyed through environmental storytelling, item descriptions, and character interactions, encouraging players to piece together the narrative themselves.

With the upcoming DLC, Shadow of the Erdtree, excitement is building within the community. The prospect of new content and challenges is tantalizing, promising to expand on the already rich world of Elden Ring.

In conclusion, Elden Ring offers a captivating world, challenging gameplay, and a compelling story. It's a must-play for any action RPG fan, and I can't wait for the release of Shadow of the Erdtree.

I‚Äôm a 45-year-old father, probably one of the oldest gamers trying to keep up with these whippersnappers. I‚Äôm a single dad to my 14-year-old son, who‚Äôs a certified master of avoiding quality time with his old man. For Christmas in 2021, his uncle gifted him this game, so naturally, it got installed faster than a dad joke can be told. By the end of the week, he had racked up 24 hours of gameplay, which was about as horrifying as discovering the internet history of a teenager.

Desperate to reconnect, I decided to dive into this digital abyss and made myself a Steam account. I figured, if you can‚Äôt beat ‚Äòem, join ‚Äòem, right? I loaded up the game, picked a character that looked suspiciously like a pixelated potato, and started wandering aimlessly in this strange new world. It felt like being the new kid in high school all over again, minus the braces and awkward dance moves.

Completely lost, I turned to my son for help. He hosted a game, and I joined, praying I wouldn't embarrass myself too much. Surprisingly, it was a blast! We bonded over slaying virtual monsters, which is way more fun than discussing algebra homework. It turned out to be the best time I‚Äôd had with my son since my wife passed away, and not just because it didn't involve any more awkward attempts at 'dad and son' small talk.

This game has since become our secret weapon for family bonding. We‚Äôve forged an alliance stronger than any superhero team, and even managed to drag our adventures out into the real world. Now, we spend more time together outside the house too‚Äîthough I still can‚Äôt get him to stop watching YouTube videos of other people playing the same game.

In the end, this game reminded me that there‚Äôs fun to be had in everything, even if it involves getting schooled by a teenager. It‚Äôs brought us closer and given us a treasure trove of ridiculous, happy memories. Who knew digital dungeons could lead to real-life family treasures?

GOTY
It took me a long time to really get into this game. For me Limgrave was just a huge empty field with a lot of concealed caves and other areas holding upgrades and resources to help advance the game. When I first started playing that's not really the kind of experience I wanted and it hurt my initial impressions.

After finally getting a helping hand from a friend and a jumpstart on my progression, I was able to tear through the rest of the game and almost finish two more NG+ cycles.

I love this game, but it almost has inverse Dark Souls 1 syndrome for me. Elden Ring's open world is almost a hindrance to me because the opening areas largely feel like padding that were designed but not really developed into interesting zones. While I've seen a lot of claims that the game consistently gives you a lot of options for places to explore and enemies to go fight against if you're stuck, I didn't start really feeling this until I was well into the Altus Plateau, which is nearly halfway through the game.

Limgrave is largely populated by world bosses that you're going to see repeatedly like dragons and Tibia Mariners and Night's Cavalry. The same is true for Caelid except that almost half of Caelid is more-or-less endgame and will likely get you killed if you wander in too early. Between the two, there are maybe three legacy dungeons, and only one of them has an end boss which is both unique and actually advances the game in a meaningful way. Everything is just so many open fields with tons of generic enemies which drop neither significant amounts of runes nor upgrade materials.

Meanwhile when you get to the Capital Outskirts, the critical path becomes a lot more apparent and the areas begin to feel more like traditional Soulslike levels with shortcuts and branching paths and other things that flow rather than just sprawl out in all directions.

If you're like me and are don't really care for the open world aspect and the need to constantly bump your face into walls to find advancement for your character build, I highly advise having the wiki open on a second monitor while you play. Doing so for me helped me develop concrete goals and locations to visit and explore for things I wanted rather than just wandering the world aimlessly looking for interesting things to interact with.

Elden Ring is the single greatest gaming experience of my life.  I had only touched a single souls game when I was 11 and only once and properly got my ass beat (BloodBorne).  However this experience as an adult really changed my life.  The game is incredible a massive sprawling open world with so many secrets, amazing armors, cool weapons, cooler bosses, fun npcs, challenging fights where it really feels like your overcoming a massive obstacle.  In conclusion elden ring is incredible I love every boss and im so glad i played it.  Amazing game 10/10 cant wait for shadow of the erd tree!!

gud
I laughed. I cried with rage. I cursed Malenia Blade of Miquella two thousand times.

I'm not a Souls fan, but I'll be damned if this game isn't a total masterpiece. From the first moment the Tree Sentinel stomped my ass in the starting area, to the absolute triumph of downing the aforementioned Malenia, [i]Elden Ring[/i] is an unforgettable open world experience that rewards exploration and risk while making you scared for your life at unexpected moments.

Months after I finished playing this game I don't remember a single detail about the convoluted story, but I remember very clearly the mood and tone of the world: dangerous, mad, unpredictable, beautiful. [i]Elden Ring[/i] doesn't hold you by the hand, which makes its early hours a challenge; but on the flipside, the sense of accomplishment you'll get from downing its challenging, sometimes aggravating boss will stay with you for a long, long time.

I just don't like interacting with this game. Once again, Fromsoft is competing to have the absolute worst PC experience imaginable.  Game is unplayable on mouse and keyboard. You can't even bind your quick-item slots to an individual key. It has to be a key combination because on controller it's also a key combination. "Just use a controller" is a pretty pathetic thing to have to say. Action rpgs on mouse and keyboard are not a new concept.

Also.. Frame rate locked to 60? in 2024? There is a third party fix, but the game's anti cheat will flag it, so you can't even unlock the framerate unless you want to play a neutered offline experience. Wonderful.

I'm obviously in the minority, but this game manages to piss me off every time I try to play it. It's absolutely unacceptable that a company with this scale is still somehow this bad at making a PC port of their own game. Unacceptable. Would like to play it but fundamental control issues make it a hard pass for me.

Not here to make a lengthy review, but I felt I needed to make A review in some form because god damn this game is something. It is massive, truly endless shit to do, EXTREMELY difficult for majority of the game, if not nearly all of it. I hated it for a good portion of my playthrough, not only for the difficulty, but because I felt the stats and attribute details were WAY too complex for me to grasp, therefore my build may have been somewhat tainted. Finally, after several tens of hours, and getting to areas that I can get good runes grinding from, I can say I am having a shitload of fun playing this game. It is truly a masterpiece, and the cutscenes and lore are INSANE.  I will say, though, prior to getting to good grinding spots, the game felt unnecessarily difficult to level up. That is my main gripe. Other than that and some wonky hitboxes, I will respectfully give this game an 8.8/10
