Verily, this be a game of divine tier, a marvel most splendid. Without a doubt, it standeth as mine most cherished and favoured game. If thou dost not possess it yet, I implore thee, procure it forthwith and with utmost haste. Truly, it is an acquisition most worthy and delightful.

After 129 hours immersed in the captivating world of Elden Ring, I can confidently say it's an absolute masterpiece that exceeds expectations in every aspect. FromSoftware has once again proven their unparalleled ability to craft a rich, immersive experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming.

First and foremost, the world of Elden Ring is breathtakingly beautiful and meticulously crafted. Every corner is filled with stunning vistas, ancient ruins, and hidden secrets waiting to be discovered. The sense of exploration is unparalleled, with every new area offering a sense of wonder and excitement as you uncover its mysteries.

The gameplay mechanics are refined to perfection, blending challenging combat with deep RPG elements seamlessly. Every battle feels like a true test of skill and strategy, requiring careful timing and precision to overcome formidable foes. The variety of weapons, spells, and abilities allows for endless experimentation, ensuring that no two encounters are ever the same.

But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its rich lore and storytelling. The world is steeped in history and mythology, with every NPC, item, and location contributing to a vast tapestry of interconnected narratives. Exploring the lore of Elden Ring is a rewarding experience in itself, as you piece together the puzzle of its world and uncover the truth behind its mysteries.

Beyond its technical and artistic achievements, Elden Ring is a game with a soul. It's a testament to the passion and dedication of its developers, who have poured their hearts and souls into creating a truly unforgettable experience. It's a game that challenges you, inspires you, and leaves a lasting impression long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is nothing short of a modern masterpiece. It's a game that sets a new standard for the industry and reaffirms FromSoftware's status as one of the greatest developers of our time. Whether you're a fan of action RPGs or simply appreciate masterful game design, Elden Ring is an experience you won't want to miss.

This is a peerless RPG; it doesn't build a world so much as force you to infer the world that exists, always seemingly a bit out of reach.  That sense of tangible surety is what drives you (well, me) to fight on, to think after each death, to memorize patterns and count hits out loud to a rhythm.  This is the culmination of the soulslike formula and it's obvious in the maturity of its systems and the easy brilliance of the visuals, sound design, and resource management systems.  Genuinely one of the best games ever made and certainly worth playing for people of any skill level,

This game should be put into a museum because it is a work of art. The music, animations, storytelling, and everything is amazing. I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a challenge, and even if you don't there are ways to make the game easier and more enjoyable via using different items, forms of magic, summons, etc. I do not recommend this game for anyone who hates a challenge, and anyone who hates grindy games. You have to do a lot of grinding to beat the game. Of course you could be a natural and go crazy, and barely have to grind the game. but for most you will need to grind a considerable amount. Overall this is an amazing game, and you should buy it and the dlc that comes out soon.

Try finger but, hole
Sweet, easy to start
Short version: Great game, just didn't get the same out of it as my previous Dark Souls experiences.

Long version: This is a well made game with bookoos of content. My main thing is I went into this expecting another Dark Souls game, and that is not what I got. The DNA is there, of course, but I constantly found just a little something missing. Upon finishing the game my thought was "Have I become a Dark Souls purist? Would I have had more fun without summons", etc. This is by far the easiest Souls game that FromSoft have put out. I do think part of this stems from the fact that if you do practically any amount of exploring, you will get overleveled. The result of this was I never got any moment of triumph from killing a boss as I killed practically every boss I encountered in 1-3 tries, including the final boss. I also ran into the problem of doing most of my lore homework by reading descriptions and what-not, but I still had little idea what was going on, and so this hurt my enjoyment of the game somewhat significantly. So while there's a ton of different builds to play with, plenty of places to explore, and lots of bosses to fight, I left this game feeling empty. I don't wish to review this as negative as it's still a solid game, I may have just inaccurately set my expectations, and was disappointed when they weren't met.
it gave me white hairs like queen Ranni . praise the stars
[h1][b]A True Masterpiece Of Gaming[/b][/h1]

When it comes to video game awards, more often than not, they feel meaningless. Plenty of games have been awarded "Best of show" and achieved "WINNER OF 50 AWARDS!" only to be released and, at best, merely be very good and, at worst, not that good.

Elden Ring deserves all the praise it gets. It is an absolute modern masterpiece and one that will age like fine wine.

This is a soul-like game refined with an open world approach that in no way is bloated but instead uses it to its advantage. Take visuals. The world of Elden Ring is lovely and bleak. Beautiful and smile. Its a testament to FromSoftware that they have done a grand job of world building, lore and visually. There is a minor blemishes but nothing to ever take away that fantasy immersion of sheer wonder and terror that Elden Ring provides. The audio is just fantastic from is orchestral score to the ambience being done to perfection.

This leads to how exploration is implemented. One one hand Elden Ring is all about exploring and taking your time in getting more powerful and skillful, knowing when you can push through and when to retreat and come back to an area/boss when you're more powerful/capable. Rushing or just being stubborn will just see you get your ass handed to you again and again with very little, if any progress. Therefore exploring is highly encouraged but instead of it just being a chore, it becomes a thrill. Not just in curiosity sake (you may find something that makes you more powerful or becomes a vital aid, you may find an area that is too much which then serves as a goal) but in different kind of environments you can find. Elden Ring is so visually diverse that just finding a new area is a reward in itself.

And boy does Elden Ring make you work. If you're not familiar with Dark Souls type of gameplay, lets just say its punishing gameplay that pushes trial and error to the forefront, making you memorize enemies and environment hazards well enough to overcome them. Yes, you will get frustrated, angry and stressed in places. But this is part of the beauty of these types of games. They build up, knowing that, if you keep trying and learning, you will eventually overcome what is causing such pain and those emotions turn into feelings of relief and satisfaction, which make it very rewarding. And to Elden Ring's credit, its not as harsh as past FromSoftware games like Dark Souls trilogy, Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice or other well known "Souls-Like" such as Nioh.

This is mostly because Elden Ring also expects you to be smart rather then overcome via 100% skill and hard work. Yes, it's all well and good being able to dodge roll and exploit openings from your enemies. But sometimes, you can take advantage of the level design, hiding in a room and cheesing the enemy with a bow while it thrashes around, doing its powerful attacks in futility. Or using a summon to distract the enemy and use hit and run attacks. it's all about "work smarter, not harder" Make no mixake, you will be working hard but you'll also find ways to make the burden less so.

Even its issues can be a blessing? A Boss exhibiting dumb AI? Enemies falling to their deaths? In most games, that lessens the experience. In Elden Ring? That's reprieve her. A "thank god it's happening" moment. You don't scoff at the small shops Elden Ring provides, you breathe a sigh of relief. And in terms of current issues, its really hard to fail the game. Maybe you can poke at the lack of lore? Well welcome to a FromSoftware game. It can feel longer than a usual soul-like game but that's just the nature of it being an Open-world game.

In reality, the only reason to not give Elden Ring a chance is because you don't like Action-Adventure and/or Open-World games. Otherwise, you owe it to yourself to play Elden Ring. Beautiful, fantastic gameplay with a ton of replayability. It's the kind of game to make you have faith in AAA. It's masterpiece.

I gotta say, as someone who didn't really like the Soulsborne genre and never tried to properly play through them before, Elden Ring is the best intro to this franchise. You will die, ALOT. But you will succeed eventually. Don't let the seemingly hard bosses get you down. Because you can and will rise to become the ELDEN LORD!

There's a reason why celebrities and mainstream figures actually like this game. You just have to be willing to jump in and find that reason yourself, fellow Tarnished. Be ready for the DLC, everyone!
Game looks amazing, is difficult but rewarding and mostly fair to the skills of the player. In general it's a well made game, but combat and targeting can feel slow and clunky at times and they could have easily added a tiny bit more narrative and directions to make things make more sense. I wouldn't want spoon feeding like in many other games, but in example it's wierd how the game intentionally pushes you forward through grace directions the "wrong way" in the beginning. This despite you being 20-30 levels underleveled and should go in the opposite direction to quest/grind the rest of the starting area instead.

It's well worth a buy if you like RPGs and challenging games. You'll probably hate it at first and curse your heart out, but just don't give up and you'll come to love it after a while. You might want to do yourself a favour and bring up a progress route map at times to check if you are where you are supposed to be instead of hating on the game and doubting yourself!
This game is wonderful and I do recommend you try it if its on sale BUT the game is not perfect the bosses will often feel very unfair and performance is still a very large problem. if you can look past those flaws this game is great 

solid 9/10

This is an absolutely amazing game that I will never beat. In many ways it is the best souls-like game that Fromsoft has put out, and certainly one of the best games in recent memory. If you've never played a souls-like game before, this might be the best place to start. Remember: keep calm, and try to time your dodges and attacks instead of button spamming. You can do it!

An amazing game. There's so much to do, and so many styles to try out, you could easily play for hundreds of hours and still not have experienced everything. THIS is Gold Standard AAA Gaming, look no further. Sure it's hard to get into, sure the difficulty ramp is a tad bit steep, but keep at it, and you'll be Elden Lord before you know it.... and with your favorite class as well. There's something for everyone - the damage-hungry player who is way too greedy, to the tank who LIKES getting hit and feeling powerful, and everything in-between those two and not. Give it a try. Stick with it. It'll grow on you.

First time playing a game of this style. Found it extremely enjoyable. Very difficult at times, but the game is forgiving enough that it's really on you if you set yourself back by losing a ton of runes or progress. There's also pathways around most hard enemies if you don't feel like taking them on at that time. If you're someone like me that prefers more casual gameplay, you can get that in this game. I've been tending to over-level and then go back for the harder bosses so I don't have to stress too much and I can just enjoy the game. But that's my play-style.

A ton of stuff to do. Biggest drawback is getting lost and not knowing where to go. I read a lot of guides and recommended pathways. Some questlines will cancel out others. Alternate endings. Tons of things to know in this game but it sucks you in.

"Elden Ring: A Haunting Symphony of Beauty and Despair"

In the realm of Elden Ring, where shadows dance and light whispers, there lies a world of haunting beauty and unyielding darkness. It‚Äôs a place where ethereal landscapes stretch into infinity, painted with the melancholy brushstrokes of a forgotten era. This is a game that doesn‚Äôt just challenge you; it consumes you.

Elden Ring is a masterwork of stark contrasts. It‚Äôs a dream woven from the fabric of nightmares, where every horizon is both a promise and a threat. The scenery captivates with its ruined splendor, each ruin and dungeon imbued with a silent, sorrowful history. The world breathes with an ancient life, whispering secrets to those brave enough to listen.

Yet, this haunting beauty is but a siren‚Äôs call. Elden Ring doesn‚Äôt coddle or soothe. It stands indifferent to your struggles, a monolith of uncaring cruelty. The land is littered with the bones of the defeated, a testament to its unforgiving nature. Here, every step is a battle, every victory hard-fought and hollow.

As you traverse this cursed landscape, you are met with adversaries that embody the world‚Äôs relentless spirit. Each foe is a dark reflection of the game's harsh beauty‚Äîsome are grotesque yet mesmerizing, some monstrous yet majestic. The combat is a grim dance of death, demanding precision and patience, where even a moment‚Äôs lapse can lead to ruin.

The lore of Elden Ring is a tapestry woven from cryptic fragments and half-remembered myths. It does not spoon-feed you its story; it lets you uncover it, through exploration and peril. It‚Äôs a journey of discovery that is both rewarding and maddening, as you piece together a narrative that is as elusive as the wind.

This is a game that harkens back to an era where games did not hold your hand, where each failure was a lesson etched in the harshest of tones. Elden Ring doesn‚Äôt care if you‚Äôre sick, weary, or if your heart is fragile. It demands your best, your utmost resolve, and then some. It‚Äôs a stern teacher, its lessons carved in the scars of countless battles.

Yet, within this brutal indifference lies a form of grace. There is a profound beauty in its darkness, a poetry in its pain. Each defeat deepens your resolve, each victory, a fleeting taste of triumph that leaves you craving more. Elden Ring is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit, a saga of persistence against insurmountable odds.

In the end, Elden Ring is not just a game; it‚Äôs an experience‚Äîa darkly beautiful journey through despair and triumph. It is a reminder that in the face of unyielding adversity, there is a strange and haunting beauty to be found. It is a challenge to be embraced, a world to be conquered, one death at a time.

tye shi

Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece, an epic blend of intricate world-building, deep lore, and challenging gameplay. FromSoftware has outdone itself, creating a vast, interconnected world teeming with secrets, unique environments, and diverse enemies. The open-world design feels organic, encouraging exploration and rewarding curiosity with rich storytelling and immersive detail.

The combat system, true to FromSoftware's tradition, is punishing yet deeply satisfying. Each encounter requires strategy and skill, making every victory feel earned. The customization options, from character builds to gear, offer incredible depth, allowing players to tailor their experience to their playstyle.

Visually, Elden Ring is stunning. The atmospheric landscapes, detailed character models, and hauntingly beautiful art design create an unforgettable experience. The soundtrack complements the game's tone perfectly, enhancing the emotional weight of the narrative.

In summary, Elden Ring is a triumph in game design, offering a challenging and richly rewarding adventure. It's a must-play for fans of the genre and a shining example of how video games can be both art and entertainment.

Build Variety is great here, only problem is that after a few playthroughs the game becomes a bit boring since you know where most everything is. Still replayable if you switch up your builds though. Buy if you like soulslike games, but if you have a problem with difficulty maybe avoid, early hours might leave a bad taste in your mouth if you don't know what you're doing.

[spoiler]Boc and I are a "thing"[/spoiler]
‚òπÔ∏è
I first played this on console when it released and quite enjoyed it. Having made the switch to PC gaming, i wanted to replay it on Steam to be ready for the DLC.

Some people will tell you that Elden Ring is the easiest game from FromSoftware and well, they're right to some extent. This mainly lies in two things: first, the open world structure allows you to skip a boss if you're feeling overwhelmed to come back later, after getting more levels and gear. That's something you couldn't really do in their previous entries. Also, you have access to a variety of powerful tools: weapons, skills, builds and summons that can make your journey much easier.

You want to do it the hardest way possible? Great, skip those, you're in for a challenge. You could use some help? Use them or summon a friend to assist you. I can perfectly understand that some people have busy lives with work and kids and don't want to spend their game time wiping dozens of time on a boss, but still want to experience the FromSoft touch. There's no better way, just play the way that gives you the most fun.

The game is Exploration with a capital E. No symbols to tell you where to go, no quest diary. It can be intimidating, specially if you tend to have FOMO. The good part is that, by closely looking at the map, you will find clues to places of interest. The play area is huge, so is the content. At times i felt like it was too much, but at least you can't accuse FromSoft to deliver you an incomplete game.

Some graphical assets are heavily reused, that's true, but it didn't really bother me that much. Speaking of graphics, if you like dark fantasy atmospheres, oh boy, you're in for a treat.

That game is making FromSoft accessible to a wider array of players and it's perfectly fine with me.
I think you already know that you want this game. It's amazing!
Yep.
love it
bad gaem
I AM MALENIA BLADE OF MIQUELLA
BEST GAME EVER.
Best opened world I've ever played despite the harsh difficulty. But if those of you have any trouble or feel like giving up, just reevaluate or even start all over as a magic user and just play around with it. F anyone telling you not to use magic or not to use summons and what not and enjoy the game for what it is. Even play co-op with friends. As someone who has played this game without summons or magic my first play through, it is very frustrated indeed. Other than the difficulty, there's still fun to have exploring, finding mobs that are easy as hell or locations that you can "thrive" in before having to face the main bosses or sections. Even if you're not a soulsbourne player and want to experience optimal game play with interesting lore and mechanics, then Elden Ring is perfect. If you like Zelda breath of the wild or tears of the kingdom, then you would love this game. Can't wait for the DLC coming June 21st! See ya'll there brave Tarnished...

The capstone of my gaming career.
NO MAIDENS?

I've never played a Souls game before and was scared to fight when I started. However, the deeper I got into the game, the more I respected the fragility of your character and the satisfaction of defeating a challenging opponent. After 150 hours, I can proudly say that I am still scared to fight but have gotten pretty good at it.

While playing, I was going through a difficult time in my personal life. Immersing myself in this game helped me make sense of the "bosses" and "demigods" I had to face in the real world and helped me get through my hardships. The beautifully tragic world and horrifying abominations I faced fit so perfectly in a heartfelt story that I'll think about long after the final battle.

If you need to face your demons, I highly recommend this game. I also promote using the Seamless Co-op mod so you can enjoy it with your friends without interruption.

This map is wayyyyy too big and filled with pointless and redundant side content, cut down the map size to 1/2 and get rid of all the mini dungeons that dont have to do with story or have an important item at the end. combat is great, best of the souls likes imo with the greatest depth and variety.
Elden Ring has quickly become one of my all-time favorite games, and with over 120 hours spent in its mesmerizing world, I can confidently say it‚Äôs a masterpiece of modern gaming. From the moment you step into its beautifully crafted landscape, you're transported into a realm where every detail is meticulously designed, every corner brimming with adventure and mystery.

The game‚Äôs visual beauty is truly breathtaking. The lush environments, intricate castles, and hauntingly beautiful ruins create an atmosphere that is both immersive and awe-inspiring. Whether you're exploring dense forests, scaling towering mountains, or delving into dark dungeons, Elden Ring‚Äôs world is a feast for the eyes and a playground for the adventurous spirit.

One of the standout features that has enhanced my experience immensely is the seamless co-op mod. Playing with friends transforms an already incredible game into an unforgettable social adventure. The mod integrates multiplayer elements flawlessly, allowing for seamless exploration and cooperative battles without the usual interruptions. Sharing the journey with friends, strategizing for epic boss fights, and uncovering hidden secrets together adds an extra layer of depth and enjoyment to the game.

Elden Ring‚Äôs gameplay mechanics are superbly balanced, providing a challenging yet rewarding experience. The combat is fluid and satisfying, with a diverse array of weapons, spells, and abilities that cater to various playstyles. The open-world design encourages exploration and rewards curiosity, making every discovery feel meaningful.

The storytelling in Elden Ring is another highlight. The lore is rich and deeply woven into the fabric of the game, inviting players to piece together the narrative through environmental storytelling, character interactions, and item descriptions. This approach creates a sense of intrigue and engagement that keeps you invested in the game world.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is not just a game; it‚Äôs an epic adventure that captivates your imagination and challenges your skills. Its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and seamless co-op capabilities make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. Highly recommended for those looking to embark on an unforgettable journey with friends in one of the most beautiful and well-crafted worlds ever created.

Elden Ring is a masterpiece that seamlessly blends the best elements of FromSoftware‚Äôs signature design with the epic fantasy world crafted by George R. R. Martin. As a player, you‚Äôll embark on a perilous quest across the Tarnished Lands, a realm shattered by the shattering of the Elden Ring.

üî• Combat and Challenge: 5/5

The combat system is both punishing and rewarding. Each swing of your sword feels weighty, and every dodge or parry requires precise timing. The challenge is intense, but overcoming it brings an unparalleled sense of accomplishment.

üåÑ World Design: 5/5

The Tarnished Lands are breathtakingly beautiful and hauntingly desolate. From the towering cliffs to the twisted forests, every location feels handcrafted with care. The interconnected world encourages exploration, and secrets await around every corner.

üëπ Creatures and Bosses: 5/5

Prepare to face off against awe-inspiring bosses and grotesque creatures. Their designs are both terrifying and captivating. Each encounter is a dance of death, and learning their patterns is essential for survival.

üé∂ Soundtrack: 5/5

The haunting melodies and epic orchestral compositions elevate the game‚Äôs atmosphere. Whether you‚Äôre battling a colossal boss or riding through the plains on horseback, the music immerses you in the world of Elden Ring.

üìú Lore and Storytelling: 5/5

George R. R. Martin‚Äôs influence shines through in the game‚Äôs lore. The fragmented history, cryptic NPCs, and hidden tales create a rich narrative tapestry. Piecing it all together is a rewarding experience.

üåü Overall: 10/10

Elden Ring is a triumph‚Äîa fusion of challenging gameplay, breathtaking visuals, and a captivating world. It‚Äôs a game that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Praise the sun, fellow tarnished!

Please excuse the paltry thirteen hours of playtime; my original 120+ was done on Playstation. I've since come back to the game on PC after building a custom rig and in anticipation of the DLC, but enough about that. Elden Ring changed the way I look at video games, full stop. From start to finish (and more than a few NG+) Elden Ring captivated me with its utter vastness, free and rewarding exploration, and deep lore. Even in my new playthrough, I'm still discovering different places to meet characters I've seen elsewhere, alternate quest rewards, and staggering challenges I'd altogether missed. Elden Ring is intensely difficult, but by God, do NOT let that stop you from experiencing the magic this game possesses.
This is my second time purchasing Elden Ring. The first was on my xbox one s about 2 weeks after release, and I had no idea what the game was about. I had heard that it was like Dark Souls but I had never watched or heard of Soulsbourne games till halfway through my play through of the game. Needless to say, this game is a masterpiece. Since my purchase on xbox i have bought sekiro, ds3, bloodbourne, and nioh and none of them have topped my experience with Elden Ring. It took me so long to beat the game because I gave up at Radahn and didn't touch the game for like 9 months. I came back though, after my friend beat the game and wouldn't shut up about it. I am so glad i did because this is now my favorite game of all time. I only recently got my PC but one of the first games I bought was this. I can't recommend this game enough. A warning though: this game is super difficult if you are new to Fromsoft games. You will die a lot and it will be frustrating but if you decide to push through it, it will bring unbelievable satisfaction. Hope this helps some people find this game!

I do highly recommend this game, but when I say that this gamebhas problems I really mean it.
One of the game‚Äôs major problem is with boss designs, with a game this big I can understand why the bosses weren‚Äôt focused as much but man it feels like your just waiting half the time to be able to attack. The boss will sometimes do 50 attacks in the air or do a bunch of delayed attacks that aren‚Äôt natural at all like how the other souls like games are. And you can only get 1 or 2 attacks or even none at all because the boss jump on the other side of the arena or startup another mvc ass combo on you. You should be reward for your patiences instead of having to wait even more its like your trying follow instructions on the cook books you get everything ready and start the stoce you burn yourself a little bit but you dodge and maneuver your way into something gordan ramsey will fine ok, but stove desides it wants to get hotter and burns your food and throws on the floor all the patiences and maneuvering for nothing(sorry if that was a bad analogy).
lastly I think the second half takes a nose dive in quality. There so many re use stuff that the area just doesn‚Äôt feel unique. And the last area was lowkey a nothing burger Placidus was a really good boss, but the run back is ass and the godskin duo is the worst design 2v1 boss ever I dont even need to talk about it you already know how ass they are and Maliketh has all the problems I talked about before with most of the bosses in the game.
All in all this game is still amazing and that first half is better than any souls game if you think that the bosses are a side dish like ds1. But that second half has some many problems and the bosses have a lot of problems, but I know that bosses in the dlc are gonna be fantastic and the area is going to be the best area ever.

Long time fan of FromSoftware! 
Easily some of their best work hands down, lots of things have already been said about Elden Ring so i'm gonna keep it brief. 

Most accessible Soulsborne game to date, if you're struggling with bosses there is so much you can swap out or use to gain advantage. ABSOLUTELY the best game of FromSoftware to start with, might even ignite your passion for FromSoftware starting here.

Story is confusing but satisfying to uncover yourself and if you can there are so many people who delve into the lore online meaning if you every want to scratch that itch this game has a massive fan content base to back it up.

Gameplay is great, it's very weighty and smooth, Fights are well put together however some bosses have FromSoftware power creep and are getting faster and faster so some bosses feel a tad overtuned which CAN be tiring for some but for me the thrill of beating these crazy bosses outweighs that feeling.
Lategame leveling can be a pain if you don't use farming spots and farming spots can get suuuper boring at times.

Community is very helpful in my searches, people will help with builds, there are tons of in depth guides and tons of summons for encounters/areas.
PvP is hit or miss in my books. Sometimes it's great! nail biting action against worthy players, the thrill of defending a host with your life is always fun and their death although saddening makes me want to learn from my mistakes and guard the host better next time.
Other times?? PvP is plain awful. Some players only use the absolute best of the best gear so they can cheese kill you or the host. Hackers have in my travels popped up more than a handful of times, Easy Anti cheat what can you do.

It's a grand experience an easy easy easy 10/10 game for me. Cannot WAIT for the DLC! 
Best of luck to you if you buy Elden Ring! and i hope you have as much of a wonderful time as i did!
[spoiler] For the Kale! For the Nomads!! MAY CHAOS TAKE THE WORLD!!! [/spoiler]

I am late to the party. Having said that, I have not ever enjoyed any other souls-like game. I tried a few, got to angry and gave up (I know, I'm sorry fromsofties). This game, however has taken over my brain. I have played 55 hours, I am apparently only about halfway through... How? Idk but I'm happy about it. 
It feels neverending, I have gone back and forth from starting game to mid game areas and feel like I am constantly finding little secrets, pathways, TREASURES. It's great, the world building incredible. 
I dont even find the 'frustrating' parts of this game that bad, its so easy to level up or upgrade weapons that anytime i find myself at a 'roadblock' I can fast travel somewhere, get better gear, level up and try again. 

I cannot sing enough praise for this game. Its incredible, even to a non fromsoftie, although i hope i can one day join the ranks.

  now to the actual review  


    [h2] Gameplay: 10/10. the gameplay is so fun and it feels awesome when you successfully dodge a combo. [/h2]

  [h2]  Direct story: 6/10. the story by its self is ok,its pretty basic but... [/h2]

   [h2] Bosses: 8/10. i love the remembrance bosses and some of the great enemy's but alot of the bosses are repetitive. [/h2]

Co-op is a joke, can't use mounts in a pointlessly large open world area, finding out how to summon/see signs once again requires google because developers are dumb and lazy,
Once you figure out how to summon your friend, you can't go more than 5 minutes of gameplay before getting invaded by a max level player who kills you in 1 hit compared to you needing ~12 hits,
Fighting is not an option, nor is running away because these brain rotted max level players will chase fresh characters for 30mins+ if they need to.
No pvp scaling or matchmaking at all, you will simply get stat diffed if your character is not maxed.

Not to mention the fact that you can't enter any dungeons or side areas in co-op because there's a fog that won't let you enter.

This game is a joke and I don't recommend anyone buying/playing unless you want a completly solo experience as you can't progress in co-op without a max lvl friend.

tldr : Trash game, trash player base, trash game design
One of the hardest games out there but also one of the best and most fun(Dont pick bandit to start tho)

I heard lots of great things about this game. Then I payed it. The game did nothing to pull me into a story. Did very little to tell you what you were supposed to be doing. Then it starts you in an area where you encounter enemies way above your level, and gives you no clue what to do. When you figure out something you think you are supposed to be doing, giant monsters or groups of wolves drop out from the sky that instakill you.

If you are a Masochist who enjoys being tormented by games and feeling enraged for no reason, this is your game! If you prefer an enjoyable experience with a story you can enjoy and care about seeing to completion, this is not the game for you.

If you enjoy boss fights that appartently (I won't ever play this anymore) take 100+ attempts to beat, only in service of a story no one cares about, this is the game for you. If you prefer a challenge that can be done in a few attempts so that you can advance a story that has captivated you, search elsewhere.

This is the biggest let down of a game I can recall.

I bet I put in 60hrs on the PS4 version.  Now that im rebuilding my library on PC and the expansion is coming out I figured Id repurchase and dig back in.  Now im not a souls fan as I dont like difficult games however Elden Ring scratched the itch I wish more souls games were like and that is only as hard as you make it.  What I liked about Elden Ring is that if you got to a point that was too difficult you could go explore somewhere else and level up as its open world.  You could also summon a random person to help you out.  Was the game fun though?  I wrestled with this question unlike any other game.  When I booted the game up for the first time on PC that music gave me this sick feeling like a drug addict looking at that favorite vise.  Im not sure I ever really like the game but the grind is just addictive.... so here I am 3hrs in and cant put it down.
I don't enjoy suffering, but I liked the open-world genre where you have to discover it yourself.
‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏°‡πÇ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏ï‡∏î‡∏µ
It is not a good game.

The world might be interesting, but the game is boring, there is no motivation to keep you going through the story, maybe the NPC have fleshed out backstories, they are just presented in a poor way, leaving them all to feel boring. 
They move around the map alot so you never know where to find them, and they dont give hints to quest. I dont know if they think its cool or innovating to not give you pointers for quests, but there is a reason it went out of fashion. 
If you ever looked anything up on Google because they game didnt make it apparent, its bad game design.

I would suffer through the difficult bosses if I actually cared about what happens next, but I dont, so I won't. 

I own most From games, but I think this was my last one. 

To anyone considering buying, you have to have loved all the other Souls games to enjoy this one, its not different, its not better, in some cases its even worse.

I've always got a lot to say about open world games, mostly about how they're not all that fun when you get down to the copy-paste content, and while Elden Ring was still guilty of some of that‚Äîseveral reused bosses and dungeons‚Äîthey achieved something special in how they went about it. There was no visible checklist of the usual bloat, in fact, there were no arrows pointing the direction to go, no hand-holding other than a quick and optional tutorial. The emphasis was on exploration, encouraging the player to discover whatever they could find.
It ate up my time, that‚Äôs for sure. It was also my first Fromsoft title and I think it was the best possible introduction. I racked up over a hundred hours with a mage build. Sure, there were some frustrations with difficult bosses, but that was a part of the package.

The only thing that I liked in this game was the variety of weapons and armors and two map places (snow area and Liurnia). The bosses are all repetitive, fast attack spams, undodgeable attacks, even the movesets look very similar. The boss designs are all meh, the only boss designs that I liked were Maliketh and Radagon, and the only boss that I liked to fight was grave warden duelist, all other fights were mid just because they were all so similar, the game did not offer anything new. After defeating Morgott the game got super stale and boring, mainly because all the bosses again were so similar and bs and that's why I just couldn't finish the game (I only needed to kill Radagon and Malenia). Yes I could kill Malenia and Radagon, but I don't see the point in continuing the game when I absolutely do not want to play it anymore. Also it's funny how Malenia has all the bs to kill you, healing after every successful hit, undodgeable aoe attack, second phase with full hp and more aggressiveness, for a side boss this should be illegal even the last boss is easier than Malenia. So yeah Idk what the devs were smoking when they made this game, it's absolutely overhyped and it's nowhere good to the previous games. I actually would not recommend to play this for a new player, just play dark souls 3 first and then try other fromsoftware games because this game could absolutely ruin the experience of souls games like it did for my friend. 5.5/10

I first entered the game and died on the first boss about 10 times, but it was alright then.

Following the guide, I summoned a teammate, but then a red player appeared too and killed us instantly while we were fighting the first boss. The player‚Äôs damage was even higher than the boss's, which I don‚Äôt think is normal.
I gave it another try, but the teammate got killed by the boss within the first half minute. I managed to solo the boss for the remaining 70% health but still ended up dying.
Then, on my third try, I summoned two teammates. Everything was going smoothly until my screen froze and the game crashed. Yeah, thanks for letting me know my 4080 can‚Äôt handle a game from 2022.
When I logged back in, it told me my save file was corrupted and I needed to start all over again.

I don‚Äôt freaking care how good or exciting the next 100 hours are supposed to be. But if the PvP system is messed up, a 4080 plus 64GB of RAM can‚Äôt handle crashes, and there are no darn save file backups, I‚Äôm not recommending this game to anyone.

Edit:
- They used the same mobs and bosses over and over again.
- The different regions of the game doesn't feel like a different and unique region most of the time. 
- The open world is big but dead in the same time. It doesn't excite me to explore this open world cause I face the same mobs over and over again.
- Dungeons are copy paste. They are not unique again. Even the bosses in those dungeons are reused bosses all the time.
- Story telling is non-existent. This is always the case with From Software but it's a huge negative point of the game. 
- The bosses are not exciting to fight at all. Their design is not good. 
- I am bored after 30 hours or so but tried to finish the game. I have explored every region and killed almost every boss but the last 2-3. If I find any motivation to kill those, I will finish the game and play the dlc to see how it is.

This game, however,
Is batshit insane by comparison

I never expected the work of Fromsoft to slowly adapt concepts around pantheons and world mechanics that perfectly correlate so many real-world thematic elements or even sciences. It's a living collage of their previous mythologies. A far more lively version of Dark Souls 3's end of the world in a way. Ages colliding in the same way people would as described by Our First Sun Brother.

This game features:

-soulslike combat + sekiro jump (finally)
                                                    {~030}~
-vast and living (ironically) open world

-a fun collection of armor and elegant weapons

-thematic and explosive magic (crank the effects slider and have fun with mods OFFLINE please)

-That classic stonefaced dialogue exhaustion that'll get ya emotional by the end

-Your own stoneface potentially dropping at the fuckery you are not prepared to witness


"Allegedly"

-what lies behind the Demon Soul's broken archstone

-Yharnam/Ariandel/Lothric survivors

best game ever 42/5

this game taught me how to git gud

"you cant play this game without knowing what git god means"-my friend
Elden Ring is a fantastic game from beginning to end - from the scenery, story and the boss fights, it's a masterpiece which captivates you with its challenge and story and bosses put you on your toes in a riveting fight. The OST's are incredible from the first to last story boss.
Whilst not necessarily new player friendly with the first main story boss, the game provides open world exploration and discovery to keep you interested about the world and the game itself. Providing many different ways for the player to experience the game; playing mage, light sword or great sword allows for great replayability along with multiple different ways to approach the story and its endings by applying vast story routes.
The world is expansive with a multitude of different areas ranging in difficulty and uniqueness for the player to face which provides a new sense of challenge, along with the boss difficulty. 
For those looking for a challenge or wanting to enter into the world/series of souls-like from Fromsoftware, this would be the game to start with as it's the easiest in the franchise in comparison to games like Dark Souls III, Bloodborne or Sekiro.
In overall, give the game a good go no matter the demotivating factors you will face with constant death. The satisfaction of beating a boss after multiple goes is seriously worth it and you will be able to see why Elden Ring has received world wide acclaim as Game of the Year.

Elden Ring - A Vast and Enchanting Masterpiece

FromSoftware's "Elden Ring," co-created with George R.R. Martin, offers a breathtaking blend of open-world exploration and challenging gameplay. Set in the expansive Lands Between, players navigate a richly detailed world filled with hidden secrets and formidable enemies. The game combines familiar Dark Souls combat with new mechanics like mounted combat and greater build customization, providing flexible paths to overcome obstacles. The narrative, enriched by Martin‚Äôs lore, is deep and intricate, inviting players to piece together the story. With hauntingly beautiful art direction and an epic score, "Elden Ring" is a monumental achievement in open-world design and gameplay.

I didn‚Äôt expect to play Elden Ring for 140 hrs like this. FromSoftware‚Äôs games aren‚Äôt my type of game, especially since I‚Äôm 45 now and have little time to play a game, so when I play the game, I expect fun, and relaxation, with some challenge. I love games like Mass Effect Trilogy and CyberPunk 2077, I played ‚Äúsoft soul-like‚Äù like Star Wars Jedi games but didn‚Äôt expect to like Elden Ring. 

For me, it‚Äôs not a perfect game, and it has runes to grind like a typical JRPG game but I like the world, I like the game‚Äôs mechanics. It‚Äôs not like Dark Souls or Sekiro or any soul-like games. It has ‚Äúhope‚Äù. If I fight with the boss and die for hunred times? Just get out of the boss area and do something else, find new talismans, find new sorceries, find new armor and weapons, find new crystal tears, do other side-quests, etc.

Admit that I am annoyed with the quest‚Äôs mechanics, I know that the dev wants players to explore, and they trust us to do it, I understand but am still annoyed.  

In the end, I enjoyed my time. It‚Äôs a very unique, creatively interesting game. I‚Äôm not a fan of your games but I respect you, Miyazaki-san.

Controls are strange at first but other than that, everything about this game is beautifully done. If you haven't played a souls game yet I recommend playing the prior games first since the Quality of Life upgrades that come with Elden ring make it hard to go backwards.
This game is pretty good, i have some complaints like for example that the farming of runes gets repetitive after a while and once you discover all the maps the open world doesen't feel so open anymore, at least for me. Finding the bosses you need to defeat is also pretty hard as the only thing indicating where you need to go are the rays from lost graces, it doesen't help that the NPCs speak in riddles, may not be a problem if english is your first language. The combat is awesome, it feels great and it's smooth, some enemies make me want to bash my head against a wall though. Overall i think i would give it a solid 7/10. If this isn't your first time playing a souls game i would wait until a discount.

This is a very good starting game, it is very easy, the game helps you with a lot throughout the story so you never get stuck. The map is not too complicated and the combat system is very simple. If you want to start with a game that is not to hard to beat but is still enjoyable this is what I would recommend. In addition, I personally find this game very relaxing, I have never raged on this game even though I do often with some other titles.

Like most people who bought Elden Ring. this was basically my first souls-like (I dabbled in ds3). Having said that, this is one of the best games I have ever played. If you like being so mad not even rage quiting helps with the anger, then this is the game with you. 

Definitally not for the faint hearted. It's a difficult game, but the challange is what makes it so good! Make sure you have someone with a little knowledge of the game with you while you play, just so you know a little bit of what to do, or else it's going to be so confusing. 

Would recomend also playing on controller as there are so many different things you need to do that Keyboard and mouse makes it harder for you to get everything down. ( Play style, abilities etc )

All in all Elden ring is a fun and enjoyable game, takes hours of your time, and can cause some funny rage induced moments! Would recomend the buy
Behold, The Elden Ring! And now, wait for The Shadow Of The Erdtree
The most polished Souls game to date. Deep and detailed gameplay mechanics, the game will be challenging no matter playstyle you develop, and it allows a lot of those.

Expertly crafted Open World that greatly rewards curiosity and exploration and properly defies and also awes you, this is the best Open World experience in a video game to date, well placed and well timed events, secrets, hidden paths, new exciting enemies at every corner, and a lot of unique twists to its design.

Well developed and memorable NPCs, with awesome story arcs and a few emotional ones.

Main NPCs and the world has great and deep lore in the bit and pieces and environmental storytelling way that we always loved about the series. And of course the community around the game is amazing, from Fextralife to VaatiVidya and random sun bros you encounter on your journey online for jolly cooperation or fierce ivasions.

Until the moment I write this review, this is the best video game I have ever played. Period. And I have a few decades of video game playing.

If you love the Souls series you have to play Elden Ring, you have to. This is a unique experience and a work of art, it builds on top of everything FromSoftware created until now, clearly a labor of love from them.

This is FromSoftware's Magnum Opus.
There is SO MUCH CONTENT. You could play this game for 100 hours and not find everything (and I have...multiple times...). This game has depth and breadth like none other.
This game has already cost me 2 controllers and they plan to release a DLC? 

Excellent.
Buy it.

Hark! Lend thine ear to mine humble recount of an adventure most wondrous, known to the common folk as Elden Ring. 'Tis a tale of high valor, perilous quests, and a realm wrought with eldritch magicks and formidable beasts.

Upon mine first ingress into the Lands Betwixt, I, a humble knight sworn to the chivalric code, found myself ensorcelled by the vastness of this uncharted domain. The world sprawleth before mine eyes, rich in verdant fields, shadowed woods, and ancient ruins, each beckoning with secrets untold and dangers unforeseen. The very air hummeth with the whispers of bygone eras, and the stars themselves seem to chart the destiny of those brave enough to seek the Elden Ring.

The combat, verily, doth honor the skill of a knight. Each clash of steel upon steel ringeth true, demanding precision and valor. The foes one doth encounter, from lowly beasts to towering giants, are as cunning as they are fierce. Yet, with sword and shield, and the strength of thine arm, victory is attainable, though hard-won. The mastery of arms and the keen mind to study one's enemy art paramount to success.

Elders of this realm spake of mighty lords and ladies, once noble, now twisted by corruption. These formidable adversaries require not only brawn but the wit to unravel their mysteries and discern their weaknesses. Each encounter with these dread beings is a saga unto itself, etched in the annals of thine memory.

The lands are replete with sights to behold: castles towering against the azure sky, caverns deep and dark, where light doth fear to tread, and ethereal landscapes that stir the soul. The artistry of these environs is such that one might linger long in contemplation, were it not for the pressing duty to restore order and reclaim the Elden Ring.

Yet, not all is strife and battle. There be sanctuaries wherein one might find respite, commune with fellow wayfarers, and hone their skills. The camaraderie found in such moments is a balm to the weary heart and a reminder of the bonds that tie all who walk this perilous path.

In sooth, Elden Ring is a saga of grand proportions, a testament to the spirit of adventure and the pursuit of glory. To any knight, squire, or seeker of fortune, I commend this journey. Brace thyself, steel thy heart, and mayhap thou shalt emerge, not unscathed, but victorious, with tales to last a lifetime.

Godspeed, noble adventurer.

On a more serious note, Elden Ring was an absolute joy to play, especially if you're a Souls veteran. The game is essentially Dark Souls 4 with an open world map, and so many quality of life features that were completely missing in previous games. Summons and Ashes of War are great additions to the game, allowing players tons of flexibility both in playstyle and in difficulty. If you've never played a Souls game because it's too hard, this is the place to start. If you're a Souls veteran... What are you even doing here? Just go play the game.

Each NPC and boss have their own stories behind them. The deeper I delve into each questline, the more I understand why some NPCs and enemies have hostile attitudes towards each other or why they hide in different dungeons and areas. The world in Elden Ring doesn't just revolve around the player's story, many events occur simultaneously and they will continue to happen regardless of what you do in numerous ways. After all, it's the best Souls game by FromSoftware they have ever made!

This is an excellent game but not for the faint of heart. Please understand that dying over and over again is an important part of the game. It will help you to grow in skill, learn attacks from enemies and learn fight your desire to give up. I recommend that you play this game without outside noise (No music, podcasts or other distracting mediums). Please don't play this game if you have assessments, jobs, or other things to do. Don't play for too long (2 hours max) per day as this is a long game an is best enjoyed over a long period of time.

I love this game for the intense legendary battles and the open world experience. Ive played other games but the problem was that i was easily distracted and i adapted too quickly allowing me to mow those games. However Elden Ring has proposed a true bag of fine challenge(which needs no easy mode, since you have rivers of blood and other weapons to cheese) while dodging attack after attack until i see a punishable move. I even struggle at the endgame, with all the loot i can possibly obtain. They even have a feature unlike any other, which allows you to go through the entire game again, but with the bosses buffed up for a little more challange (im on my 8th one). Every weapon, including the starter weapons, can defeat all the bosses, which is perfect for elden ring. all in all i recommend this amazing master piece  (just ignore the rivers of blood haters) to anyone who loves a challenge

I don't write reviews at all but I did want to share my experience with Elden Ring/Fromsoft as a whole. This was the first soulslike I picked up after solely playing FPS for many years, and it genuinely raised my standards ridiculously. Every area in the open world feels lived in and packed full of depth, not a single place lacks importance or feels at all like filler. The versatility of your builds, armor, character design, weapons, all of it proves how much care the developers put into crafting such a beautiful experience. I don't play games very often, usually only hopping on with a few friends occasionally, but Elden Ring really caught my attention and re-lit a spark for story-driven single player games. I'm so very excited for the upcoming DLC

malenia can suck my dick
From Software's first modern open world game is quite impressive. I was surprised by how player friendly it is and how it avoids common pitfalls from other games. Yes the bosses are hard but the game gives you so many tools and options to develop there's an effective strategy for everyone. Fast travel is free to checkpoints, you have a horse you can instantly summon, it's agile and easy to control, highly effective in combat, and can double jump. Massive content and bueatiful world with interesting things to see everywhere you go. Respec is easily available and you're never locked into one build.

Worst thing you can say about it is the common Souls problem of your weapons all start at level 0 and require heavy investment to stay current, This makes it really expensive and grindy to change weapons the farther you get into the game.  The enemy variety is great in general but still feels stretched thin, especially with reused bosses in all the side dungeons. Eventually you'll have a set build of weapons and skills and it feels less fun to explore because you just find more weapons you won't use or spells that you don't need, etc.

Still, great fun, amazing game.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories. Thank you FromSoftware.

Visually? Game is 10/10. But Elden ring fans will way overhype the game beyond what its worth. It throws atleast 2-3 repeats of unironically 90-95% of the bosses. Occasional repeat bosses are fine in games, but not when its done to this degree. The whole "over a hundred bosses" Thing id deceptive because not including duplicates theres not even HALF remaining. Not to mention alot of bosses just dont give room to attack with the heavier weapons, you either end up having to damage trade or wait about 5 attack cycles to swing once. The game is wonderful, but its not worth the praise and price tag. Overall id give the game a 6.5 at best.

I platinum'd the game on PS at launch and it's a masterpiece in my eyes. The exploration, the universe and the combat are my favorite parts. Some dungeons are a bit meh and I think some bosses aren't perfectly designed for all builds (same as in DS3 for example).
The game runs amazing on my PC and it runs great on my deck (even though it decimates the battery as expected).
Gam gud maybe this game will be as popular as Crab Souls one day
Elden Ring has become my absolute favorite game of all time, and for good reason. From the moment I started playing, I was completely hooked. The world is incredibly vast and beautifully detailed, every inch begging to be explored. I found myself constantly in awe of the stunning landscapes and intricate designs. It felt like every corner of the map held some new secret or challenge waiting for me.

The combat in Elden Ring is something else entirely. It's tough, but that just makes every victory feel so much more rewarding. I had to really think about my strategy, timing, and approach for each enemy, especially the bosses. The feeling of finally taking down a tough opponent after numerous attempts is indescribable. Plus, with so many weapons, spells, and ways to build my character, each playthrough feels unique.

What really blew me away was the depth of the lore and storytelling. The narrative is rich and layered, and I loved piecing together the story from environmental clues, item descriptions, and character dialogues. It made every discovery feel significant and added a whole new level of immersion.

I also had a blast with the co-op and PvP elements. Teaming up with friends to tackle difficult areas or jumping into PvP battles kept the game exciting and unpredictable. It added a whole new layer of fun and replayability.

In short, Elden Ring is everything I could ever want in a game and more. It's beautiful, challenging, and deeply engaging. Whether you're a fan of FromSoftware's previous games or new to their style, this game is a must-play. It has rightfully earned its place as my number one game in the world.

i like the pot people
4/10.  BELOW Average.  The game is gorgeous, don't get me wrong.  Diverse enemies and environments.  But Elden Ring is a nightmare.  There is no difficulty setting, no introduction to the world (not really) or even much of a story (at least as I've been playing and running around).  "You are maidenless.  You need a "maiden."  "Why?"  "Because..."  OKAY!  

Here's a Giant Pumpkin Head boss in a new instance dungeon.  I wonder what his story is?  Oh, he just wants to kill you because.  He's the guardian of the instance.  Can you explore it?  No, because Giant Pumpkin Head kills you before you can progress. 

You don't know what you're supposed to do as there are no quests, except to kill everything, where you are, who the people you're fighting are, or WHY you're doing what you're doing.  A few hits from ANY enemy, and you're dead.  You're handed a stick, now go kill God.  And everyone is at war with you, short of a few NPCs and traders.  

Call me a clown.  Call me what you want, but I want options in my video games to make it enjoyable for EVERYONE.  Not a kid dropped in the deep end and expected to swim just because.  I can't kill a single boss, sub-boss, and even mobs are near impossible because as soon as you engage, the horns go off and half the map descends upon you.  Thus, I can't level up and become more powerful to get to where I need to go to progress the story in the most basic way.  

I've played six (6) hours, killed a few individual enemies; a lone warrior with good looking gear (yet had nothing) and spent 45 minutes individually killing a mob hauling a huge shiny carriage.  Was there any cool gear in there for my effort?  No.  Just a regular, gray axe I don't even use.  I still have the most basic of gear and spells.  I feel like I'm running around avoiding everything the game has to offer because of the fear of death.  No health or MANA regeneration, so there's also that added headache as well.  Enjoy your diverse, amazing abilities and powers!  But only a little bit.  

I even downloaded a mod  for "Very Easy" mode, with 25% more damage and 70% damage reduction.  Still too difficult.  WTF am I playing?  Dying against every enemy 50 times until I get lucky or figure out their routine isn't fun for me.  How am I supposed to continue if every encounter uses all of my potions?  I'm a casual player.  Dying over and over and over again isn't relaxing or fun in a video game.  It's ANNOYING.  And the game is BORING because I can't explore or fight anything.  Unless you're a masochist, don't buy this title.  The hype is just hype.  (I also don't like breaking open piles of dung for loot...)
No amazing chest ahead, only despair.

Masterpiece!!!!! The Best!!
WARNING: This is a heavy grind game from a "grind game" studio and fans like it for its ridiculous difficulty and full lack of player guidance and cherished by a niche fan group. IT IS NOT a good-looking Zelda-type open-world rpg. I suspect many others buy/bought this game in false expectations like me.
 If you haven't played any games in the Souls series, but you're curious, this may be the perfect entry for you. The open world allows you to bypass the "brickwall" bosses and levels Dark Souls is known for, and this game has more character build options than any other game in the series. The combat is the smoothest it's ever been (A lot of people say Bloodborne is the best for combat, but I haven't played it). 

You're given the option to respec your levels after one of the first bosses. You can change you're appearance at any point once you unlock the hub. This game has the best character customization. in the series. You don't need to create multiple characters to try out different builds. This game also has more story lines and endings than the other Dark Souls games. The quests are not super difficult to follow, but due to the size of the game and lack of any quest tracking system, it is very easy to miss them, or screw them up.
This game changed my life, and it runs really smooth on the steam deck 10/10 i would recommend this for anyone who just got a deck and doesn‚Äôt know what game to buy
As long as you are rich enough top replace broken controllers frequently or just dont break them good game

Im an Elden Lord now. So give me free awards i want to be RICHHHH!
Looking at my hours played on Elden Ring I'm shocked. I usually get bored with games within the first hour. I have multiple games where I play until the last boss and quit entirely. Something about Elden Ring is engaging from start to finish and it is a renewed experience every time you start over, keeping you hooked for hours and hours of entertainment. 

Elden Ring was my first souls game and I've loved it so much I went back and played all the other souls games (and big souls likes) but Elden Ring is by far the most fun I've ever had in gaming. One of the nice things about the game is even noobs to the genre can come in and play because of the integrated accessibility options. Can't beat a boss cuz u suck? Go somewhere else and come back when you're over leveled. Still can't beat it? Use a summon. Don't feel bad about cheesing a boss because you can always come back in future playthroughs and change the experience by doing the fight differently. Magic vs strength vs dex builds all play completely different. 

Very much looking forward to the expansion to add more depth and content to the game to push past 500 hours on my way to 1000. üòÇ

Highly recommend this !
Elden Ring is an immerse and powerful experience of a game that will put you through an absolute wringer of emotions. It will take you from anger to exhilaration as you confront hardship and overcome it, keeping you on the edge of your seat. 
This game has more to it than just "Dark Souls", with jaw-dropping vistas, the enormous world, and the frequently harrowing enemies that will leave you in awe. A fascinating and dense open world about freedom and exploration, Elden Ring is not a smooth-edged, one-size-fits-all kind of experience. It relishes in confronting players with unfavorable odds and delights in watching the ensuing struggle. 
Whether you‚Äôre wielding a sword, casting spells, or dodging attacks, every moment feels intense. Overall, Elden Ring will live on in our collective minds well after many other games are dead and buried, resonating with players who crave adventure, mystery, and the thrill of overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds. Prepare to be captivated by its dark beauty and immerse yourself in a world that demands both skill and determination.

Gameplay 10/10
Story 8/10
Graphics 9/10
Soundtrack 8/10

Overall 9/10

Similar games: Dark Souls, Witcher 3, Lords of the Fallen, Star Wars: Jedi Fallen/Survivor, Nioh, Sekiro

ü§°üí∏
One of the best games I have ever played, everything just looks beautiful.
I would be lying if I said this game was a 10/10. Some bosses feel forced, too difficult, badly placed, overpowered even. Sometimes the running around feels too weird, and the lack of the true Dark Souls run back is sometimes missed due to how beautiful the environments are. Sometimes I hate this game, as it just feels like there is no reason for things to be set up the way that they are, and overall it's just janky sometimes. 

But god damn if it isn't Elden Ring though. The most beautiful scenery of the entire franchise, perfectly sculpted environments and an overwhelming amount of mainline content, side content, secret content, it's just the content king. If you don't like something, chances are you don't have to do it. You can find any weapon/spell for any playstyle, and it feels like everything is viable. There's no boss that's too difficult in any bad reason, in this game you truly just have to get good to beat things. There is no other game like this game, FromSoft took everything that they had been building for decades and polished it into this masterpiece. Unfortunately, due to some slight letdowns (Some bosses as time went on got less and less epic-proportion-esque, probably due to Covid...) this game isn't truly perfect. But it's as close as anything will ever be... 9.5/10

FromSoftware found a formula over a decade ago that has stood to this day. Their latest iteration of that formula sees the player transverse the Lands Between to mend the Elden Ring, becoming the Elden Lord over a fresh, new Order.

Another challenge posed and conquered. Highly recommended, 5/5

+  3rd-person magic/sword combat has been well executed, quite close in style to previous games. Lots of skill overlap between this and previous entries. 
+  Building characters around weapons feels rewarding. Variety of scaling combinations among weapons opens build variety. 
+  Ashes of war are a great iteration of weapon skills, being able to mix & match lets comfort weapons become fresh.
+  Vistas everywhere. Taking time to see the scenery is a staple of the soulsborn franchise, it's just as rewarding here.
+  Lore galore. Several hundred item descriptions to sift through. Thick plot to sink any number of budding teeth into.
+  Spirits do so much damage and distracting, they are a favourite addition of mine. With the meta so tightly wound with spending time buffing its great to see a solution to relieve pressure. Good for the accessibility of the game as well.

-  Field/Catacomb bosses are repetitive.
-  Builds are almost too good, mobs in New Game get pulverized very quickly with most setups. New Game+ is the most viable its been in a few games, though.
-  Groups are invaded before solos, making invasions much harder overall.
-  High minimum system requirements, albeit not unexpectedly.

big sword
I might be terrible at this game, but this game is far from terrible...

This game is bloody amazing!

There's so much to do, so much to explore and the best part is, I don't just mean the open world itself. As a player you have so many different weapons to find, obtain and then choose from, some have unique skills tied to them whilst others you end up making unique through various ashes you can apply to them, which leads to there being plenty of ways to play the game and overcome the various challenges presented. So no matter what build you end up making, whether you're making something on your own or following a guide, it all boils down to how you do it and how well you can pull it off.

That's the number one thing I love about Elden Ring. There's multiple ways to beat the various enemies you'll encounter, be it a boss or a group of monsters in your way. Of course, there might be some methods that may take longer than others, whilst some might be more riskier in exchange to ending a fight sooner, whereas others may seem cheesier regardless of how safe or risky such a method might be to pull off, but the choice is yours and that's what matters.

I am excited to see what the DLC brings to the table, from the trailers I'm seeing? It looks like it's about to make an already big game, much bigger!

I command thee kneel
good
I was hesitant to buy this game at first since the developer has a reputation for making games which are very difficult, but I'm glad I gave Elden Ring a shot.  This is the best new game I have played in a very long time.

Pros:

1. Build variety: There's a surprising variety of weapons and playstyles available, which are all viable and are different from each other mechanically as well as graphically.  Even among the strongest, most overpowered ways of building the player character, there is a lot of variety, and it's debatable which is even the best.

2.  Choose your own difficulty: Although there's no easy mode, the game does an excellent job of allowing you to choose your own difficulty: grinding levels, getting certain powerful weapons, using stronger or weaker spirit ashes (or indeed none at all, as many players seem to prefer), or exploiting a the poor situational awareness of certain enemies to slowly poison them to death instead of facing them head on.  It really is impressive how wide a range of skill levels are supported by the game without using of a menu with discreet difficulty settings.

3. Polearms:  Some games which feature melee combat don't make much use of polearms despite their historical significance, but ER has 3 classes of polearm (Spear, Greatspear, Halberd), and they're pretty good, in part because they have more range than most other weapons (weirdly appropriate, right?).

4. It's massive, but somehow everything seems to work:  I've come to expect that large games are going to be filled with bugs and unintended mechanics, but I guess this game's developer didn't get the memo, because ER is a massive game that actually works.

Cons:

1.  Although the game offers a lot of difficulty options, easy isn't among them.  If you want the game to be truly easy, or you have an aversion to seeing your player character die (a lot), then this might not be your thing.

2.  It might ruin other games for you, because it's *that* good.

Conclusion:

Although this game isn't for everyone, It is an excellent version of itself; so if the game interests you at all, you probably won't regret buying it.

verigood calm story game

This has been my first Souls-like game. I wasnt really interested in the genre, "hard for the sake of hard" didnt really appeal to me. After playing through Armored Core 6, another supposedly hard FromSoft game, I decided to give ER a try. Ive found that while difficult, the bosses arent impossible. Ive one shot a decent amount of them so far, but Im not done yet. Still on my first playthrough at 250hrs. Theres a LOT of exploration to be done and secrets to be found. That unobtrusive bush against the side of the cliff? Yeah, its hiding an incredibly intricate cave system behind it. 

Do yourself a favor, get this game. Looking forward to running through all of the Souls games after this!

Playing Elden Ring is like embarking on a quest to find your lost sanity, only to realize it was hiding behind the next boss battle all along. from the exhilarating highs of defeating a monstrous foe to the frustrating lows of falling off a cliff for the umpteenth time, it's a rollercoaster ride through a medieval fever dream. Just when you think you've mastered the combat, a giant enemy wielding a toothpick sends you flying across the map. but hey, at least the scenery is beautiful. when you're not face-first in the mud. 10/10, would curse at my screen while simultaneously praising its brilliance again.

Elden RIng, the highly anticipated collaboration between FromSoftware and George R.R Martin, has enthralled players with its vast world, rich lore, and challenging gameplay. Amidst its expansive landscape and myriad of characters, one figure stands out --- Mommy Malenia. In this review, we delve into the enigmatic presence of Mommy Malenia within the Elden Ring universe and her impact on players' experiences.

Elden Ring's gameplay mechanics are renowned for their depth and difficulty, and Mommy Malenia's encounters are no exception. As a powerful swordswoman, Mommy Malenia presents formidable challenges to players who dare to confront her. Her waterfowl dance and unpredictable movements keep players on their toes, demanding precise timing and strategic thinking.Each encounter with Mommy Malenia is a test of skill and perseverance, rewarding players with a sense of accomplishment upon overcoming her trials.

Within Elden Ring's intricate narrative tapestry, Mommy Malenia emerges as a figure shrouded in mystery and intrigue. Players encounter fragments of story scattered throughout the lands between, piecing together clues to unravel her true nature and motivations. Mommy Malenia's backstory is woven into the fabric of Elden Ring's lore. offering glimpses into her past battle against Radahn and the role she played in the destruction of Caelid. Exploring her character adds layers of depth to the Elden Ring experience, inviting players to delve deeper into its lore and uncover its secrets.

Elden Ring's visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, and Mommy Malenia's domain is no exception. From her beautiful yet ruined haligtree her brother grew to the hauntingly beautiful landscapes that surround it, the games art direction brings Mommy Malenia's world to life in stunning detail. The atmosphere is imbued with a sense of foreboding and wonder, drawing players into Mommy Malenia's realm and immersing them into its other worldly ambiance. Every corner of her domain is infused with a sense of mystery and danger, enticing players to explore its depths and uncover its secrets.

In the vast and wondrous world of Elden RIng, Mommy Malenia stands as a captivating and unforgettable character.From her challenging gameplay encounters to her enigmatic backstory and hauntingly beautiful domain, Mommy Malenia leaves a lasting impression on players as they journey through the game's fantastical landscape. Whether facing her in battle or unraveling the mysteries of her past, encountering Mommy Malenia is a highlight of the Elden Ring experience, showcasing the depth and richness of FromSoftware's latest masterpiece.

I can't help myself.

big swords kill big boss
I've played all From Software games so far and by far Elden Ring is the most disappointing one. Open-world meant it lacks polishing in a lot of areas where in previous game the same things used to shine. Elden Ring has a lot of repetitive enemies, boring weapons, and mediocre soundtrack compared to past titles, plus a lot of empty space and boring procedural generated dungeons scattered around the world that feels the same.

Even though I love souls-like games, and I am playing Elden Ring at the moment, I can't give a positive review due to this game not being the best title From Software produced. Bloodborne and Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice still remain peak in terms of gameplay.

Also, terrible optimization, From Software treats PC players as peasants ever since the first Dark Souls port ever brought to PC in 2012. Elden Ring runs very poorly at locked 60 fps even in very powerful machines, unacceptable for a title released in 2023 and a game of the year contender (and ironically, winner).

I don't recommend purchasing Elden Ring at full price, or at all, unless you're a true From Software fan. Other From Software games deserves much more attention and praise than this one.

TL;DR:
If you've played all other From Software games, this is pretty much more of the same, but less polished. It's a fun game, but nothing more than that, it fails to impress and still has the very same problems all From Software games always had.
Not worth it for first-time From Software player, skip it and start with Dark Souls, Bloodborne and Sekiro: Shadows Dies Twice.
this game cured my future depression
   What do we have here? An outstanding game. I wanted another Dark Souls game, so I waited. And it really paid off. Huge open world, lots of weapons, spells and awesome bosses. Soundtrack? GOD-tier. This game is just magnificent. I would highly recommend this game to every gamer.

Gameplay: 5/5
