This game is a masterpiece of a game. It carries qualities of an action RPG, has adventuring, has a great difficulty curve (eventually, as you learn the game, you can dictate the difficulty by build selection and diversity, level capping, etc), has horror aspects, and overall can only be described as one of the greatest games you are likely to play regardless of the genre of gamer you are. 

I'm excited to dig in more and eventually 100% the game. Great build diversity is available to enable multiple play-throughs, providing nuance to the experience. Words cannot describe its greatness, one can only experience it. Also, don't give up; it will be hard, but it's arcade-like in that once you know how to maneuver your character and know the stage, you will be set to move forward. Good luck and enjoy.

10/10 but dont overlevel yourself
Yes absolutely I would recommend this game.  If you are at all curious about Souls games, In my opinion, this is the place to start.  It's a lot more forgiving in the early levels if you get stuck on a boss, as you can just go somewhere else and level up.  Mid game you even get access to an area specifically designed by the devs for you to be able to grind levels if you need a boost.

Ok boring part over.  This game is beautiful.  Everything about it screams the love that the developers have poured into it.  Yes they want you to fall down a hole and follow your nose, but the online community these games have fostered means that there's always help, and advice if you need it. 

You'll get lost, and confused, and you'll die. Over and over again.  But in these games death is the point.  The point is that anything you could choose to do might be beyond you now, but all you have to do is play more, practice more, and you'll be able to do anything.  

Life skills, man.  Disguised as a video game.

PS, when you're ready, BLOODBORNE IS THE G.O.A.T.

PPS, I'm playing this game on PC for the first time.  It's already platinumed on Playstation, but FUCK SONY. PC ALL THE WAY.

So my experience in the game and the bosses I've killed do not match with my hours in game, because I'm currently following a checklist to get as much done in game before Shadows of the Erdtree comes out.  It's a giant collectathon, not at all an ideal way to play the game, but what are you going to do?

It's a 50/50 if the game will work for you or not. The stuttering issue has not been fixed, and even though I had a blast defeating the first tutorial boss, the performance was unbearable. (For context, I can run Cyberpunk 2077 at max settings at a solid 90fps). 
Try the game, if you notice it's stuttering, refund it. There's a few things you can try (it's embarrassing that you have to in the first place)  that help the performance a bit, but none of the tricks will help enough.

roly poly

It's like snuggling up with a warm blanket on a freezing winter day.  Every time you play it, there's something new that you find you missed last time.  You come back a year later to do another playthrough, after something reminds of you of the game and you started wondering what different way you could play would be. 
 You struggle and rant and lose your mind against a boss until learn the nuances its attacks, and get the same rush after defeating it as you did in every From Software game from the last 10 years.  And then one day, you realize that jump attacks are OP as fuck and make the game too easy but there's no going back now because your brain is telling you this is the easiest path so just do it.  But it's still amazing.

noice

One of the greatest games of the decade, dare I say ever. I had never played a souls game before I tried to game on launch (console) and I immediately fell in love with the genre. The exploration, combat, the story all come together to create an absolute masterpiece of a game. This game will 100% teach you to be patient especially if youre like me where you tackle problems in games by butting your head against at a brickwall. The sense of triumph and accomplishment is beyond anything any other game ive played has ever made me feel, and it is truly satisfying and fulfilling. I would 100% recommend this game to anyone who is interested in the souls series but is not sure bc of the difficulty. There are so many different ways to tackle every problem in this game, and if youre stumped on a boss? just come back later. Best of luck ye Tarnished, see yall in the DLC...
Cant rebind all keybinds....
I've beaten this game twice on Xbox and just began my PC playthrough. There is nothing like this game. Genuinely one of the best experiences of all time. There is a learning curve for sure that a lot of people aren't willing to sit down and learn. Be patient with yourself and the game. While you learn, have fun and enjoy the beautiful world of the Lands Between. Interact with amazing NPCs. Learning the game will come the longer you play and before you know it you'll be an Elden Lord. 

Please do not deprive yourself of one of the best experiences in gaming history.
There are very few games nowadays that I can say are worth the price. 
Elden Ring is worth the price and always will be.

I wish to wipe my memory to experience this game again.
This game to me is my modern Skyrim. Love the themes, the combat, the music, and piecing the story of the land together one odd story and conversation at a time. I love playing this game solo, I love playing it with friends, I love playing it with mods. Honestly I could not recommend this game enough. Even if (especially if) you're not a hardcore soulsborne player, this game has lots of fun and accommodations to ease the struggle, but then surely challenges you even using them. Large build variety (still wish bows were a bit better vanilla), ranging from easy to intentionally difficult, and plenty of fun ways to create your own challenge runs (no summons, no magic, etc). Seamless co-op mod makes this a proper multiplayer game to play with a friend or a few even (a few bugs but nothing unmanagable) and cause chaos across the land. My favorite part about this game is that anyone with sufficient patience and willingness to understand can complete the game.

Where do I begin, A Journey into the Lands Between: My Love for Elden Ring

The world of video games is vast, diverse, and filled with countless adventures waiting to be experienced. Among these, one game stands tall, etching itself into the annals of gaming history: Elden Ring. This masterpiece, brought to life by the collaborative genius of Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R.R. Martin, is more than just a game‚Äîit's an odyssey, a testament to the power of storytelling, world-building, and the intricate dance of challenge and reward. My love for Elden Ring is not merely about the hours spent in gameplay; it is about the profound impact it has had on my understanding of what a game can truly be.

The World-Building: A Living, Breathing Fantasy

From the moment I first set foot in the Lands Between, I was ensnared by its breathtaking beauty and the haunting desolation that permeates every corner. The world of Elden Ring is a tapestry of interconnected realms, each with its own distinct atmosphere, history, and inhabitants. The attention to detail in the environmental storytelling is nothing short of remarkable. Ancient ruins whisper tales of forgotten civilizations, while towering castles and dense forests invite exploration and promise secrets hidden within.

What sets Elden Ring apart is its commitment to organic world-building. Unlike many games that hold the player's hand, Elden Ring trusts its audience to uncover its mysteries at their own pace. Every location feels meticulously crafted, from the sprawling fields of Limgrave to the eerie depths of Nokron, the Eternal City. The seamless integration of lore into the environment encourages a deeper engagement, prompting players to piece together the narrative puzzle through exploration and discovery.

The Lore: A Mythic Tapestry

A significant part of my love for Elden Ring stems from its rich and intricate lore. The collaboration with George R.R. Martin is evident in the depth and complexity of the game's mythology. The story of the shattered Elden Ring and the demigods vying for power is a compelling backdrop for the player's journey. The lore is not spoon-fed; rather, it is woven into item descriptions, dialogues, and environmental cues, rewarding those who seek to delve deeper.

Characters such as Ranni the Witch, Godrick the Grafted, and Malenia, Blade of Miquella, are not just bosses to be defeated but tragic figures with their own stories, motivations, and downfalls. Their tales add layers of emotional depth and complexity, making every encounter meaningful. The lore of Elden Ring invites endless speculation and interpretation, fostering a community of lore enthusiasts who share theories and discoveries, further enriching the experience.

The Challenge: A Symphony of Difficulty and Reward

At the heart of Elden Ring is its gameplay, which strikes a delicate balance between challenge and reward. The game's difficulty is infamous, yet it is this very aspect that makes it so deeply satisfying. Each death is a lesson, each defeat a stepping stone towards mastery. The combat system is nuanced and precise, requiring skill, strategy, and adaptability. The variety of weapons, spells, and playstyles allows for a personalized approach, ensuring that no two playthroughs are exactly alike.

The sense of accomplishment that comes from overcoming a particularly tough boss or navigating a treacherous area is unparalleled. Elden Ring respects its players, challenging them to rise to the occasion and rewarding perseverance with moments of triumph. This dynamic creates an emotional investment in the journey, transforming frustration into exhilaration.

The Community: A Fellowship of Tarnished

One of the most rewarding aspects of Elden Ring is its vibrant and passionate community. From shared experiences of hard-fought victories to the collective exploration of its lore, the community enhances the game in countless ways. Online multiplayer features, such as cooperative play and PvP invasions, add another layer of depth to the experience, fostering both camaraderie and competition.

Forums, social media groups, and fan sites buzz with discussions, theories, and fan art, reflecting the profound impact the game has on its players. This sense of community extends beyond the digital realm, creating a shared cultural experience that binds players together. The camaraderie felt when summoning a fellow Tarnished to tackle a challenging boss or the thrill of encountering another player in a duel adds a social dimension that enriches the solitary journey through the Lands Between.

The Art and Music: Aesthetic Brilliance

The visual and auditory artistry of Elden Ring is a feast for the senses. The game's art direction, with its gothic architecture, surreal landscapes, and grotesque creatures, creates a world that is as beautiful as it is unsettling. Each area is distinct, with its own palette and atmosphere, from the golden splendor of the Erdtree to the grim desolation of Caelid. The attention to visual detail enhances the immersion, making the world feel alive and immersive.

The music of Elden Ring, composed by Tsukasa Saitoh and Yuka Kitamura, is a hauntingly beautiful accompaniment to the game's epic scope. The orchestral score captures the grandeur and melancholy of the Lands Between, with themes that evoke both wonder and dread. The music enhances the emotional weight of key moments, from the quiet exploration of a forgotten ruin to the adrenaline-pumping intensity of a boss battle.

Personal Growth and Reflection

Beyond its technical and artistic achievements, Elden Ring has had a profound impact on me personally. The game's themes of perseverance, resilience, and the pursuit of knowledge resonate deeply. The journey through the Lands Between mirrors the struggles and triumphs of life, teaching valuable lessons about overcoming adversity and finding strength in the face of overwhelming odds.

Elden Ring has also sparked a deeper appreciation for the art of game design. The meticulous craftsmanship, the integration of narrative and gameplay, and the ability to evoke such a wide range of emotions are a testament to the medium's potential as a form of art. This appreciation extends to other games and has broadened my understanding of the creative possibilities within the world of gaming.

Conclusion: A Love Eternal

In conclusion, my love for Elden Ring is rooted in its masterful world-building, rich lore, challenging gameplay, vibrant community, and stunning artistic achievements. It is a game that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, offering an experience that is as intellectually stimulating as it is emotionally engaging. Elden Ring is not just a game; it is a journey, an adventure, and a work of art that will continue to inspire and captivate for years to come. As I traverse the Lands Between, battling foes and uncovering secrets, I am constantly reminded of the magic and wonder that drew me to this world, and my love for Elden Ring only grows deeper with each passing moment.

Title: A Majestic Journey Beyond Imagination

Rating: ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

As I sit by the fire, weary from the trials and triumphs of my journey through the Lands Between, I find myself compelled to share the wonder that is Elden Ring. FromSoftware has crafted a masterpiece that transcends mere entertainment; it's an odyssey into the depths of a world brimming with mystery, danger, and unparalleled beauty.

From the moment I stepped foot into this vast realm, I was entranced by its sheer scale and intricate design. Every corner of the map holds secrets waiting to be unearthed, whether it be the ruins of ancient civilizations or the lairs of fearsome beasts. The sense of discovery is intoxicating, driving me to explore every nook and cranny, eager to uncover the lore that binds this world together.

But Elden Ring is not merely about exploration; it's about the journey of self-discovery and growth. As I faced off against towering bosses and cunning adversaries, I felt myself growing stronger with each encounter. The combat is a delicate dance of strategy and skill, demanding precision and adaptability in equal measure. And yet, with perseverance and determination, even the most daunting foes can be vanquished.

What truly sets Elden Ring apart, however, is its storytelling. Through cryptic dialogue and environmental storytelling, FromSoftware weaves a narrative that is as enigmatic as it is captivating. Each character I meet, each lore snippet I uncover, adds another layer to the rich tapestry of the Lands Between. And though the plot may be shrouded in ambiguity, it only serves to deepen my intrigue, urging me ever onward in search of answers.

But perhaps the greatest triumph of Elden Ring lies in its sense of freedom. Unlike other games that confine players to a linear path, here I am free to forge my own destiny. Whether I choose to follow the main questline or wander off the beaten path in pursuit of adventure, the choice is mine alone. And in a world as vast and wondrous as this, the possibilities are truly endless.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a magnum opus that defies expectations at every turn. With its breathtaking world, exhilarating combat, and captivating storytelling, it stands as a testament to the boundless creativity of its developers. To anyone seeking an unforgettable adventure, look no further than Elden Ring. It is a journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll, a testament to the power of interactive storytelling.

9 / 10

Terrible compatibility problems trying to run this game in Linux.  I learned much to my dismay that the PC release has been malwared with EAC ("Easy Anti-Cheat").  Sickening when publishers do crap like this.  If you're going to bury this garbage in your game, you need to inform your playerbase CLEARLY before installation, and you need to put in an off switch.  I was not able to find either of those things.

Couldn't get it running under Windows 10 either.  I wish I hadn't played the 6ish hours on a struggling windows 7 machine, because then I'd be able to return this or sell it on.  Chalk up one more lose for digital distribution and AAA gaming.
it is good
good
if you don't get this game, you are maidenless.
I bought this game when it first came out but quit within the first hour because of the Tree Sentinel. Recently, I decided to give it another try, and after many hours of playing, I fell in love with it. This game is a true masterpiece. It tests your timing, skills, patience, and discipline. [h1] Nobody will read my review, so I'll just say fuck anyone who starts their comment like that (except me). This game deserves way better than cheap, lazy spam. [/h1]

I‚Äôve 100% completed Elden Ring on PS5, got the platinum trophy which was an absolute blast, and now I‚Äôm diving into it on PC. FromSoftware, you‚Äôve seriously outdone yourselves. Elden Ring is nothing short of phenomenal, and it's hard to imagine how you'll ever top this.

From the moment I stepped into this vast, mysterious world, I was hooked. The blend of deep lore, challenging combat, and stunning landscapes is just incredible. The gameplay is smoth and perfectly balanced, making every fight feel like a rewarding test of skill.

Exploring the world of Elden Ring is pure joy. It's packed with secrets, hidden paths, and lore that keeps you wanting more. The environmental storyteling is so rich that every corner of the map feels worth investigating. Each region has its own uniqie look and feel, so exploration never gets boring.

Now, let‚Äôs talk about the only thing that annoys me: the catacombs or dungeons. This has been a problem since Bloodborne (my favorite game of all time). Even though Elden Ring does it better than Bloodborne, every dungeon still feels a bit like an AI-generated copy-paste job. But hey, they‚Äôre still fun.

The character builds you can create in Elden Ring are better than in any Souls game before it. Whether you‚Äôre into melee combat, magic, or a mix of both, the depth here is just amazing.

In short, Elden Ring isn‚Äôt just a game; it‚Äôs an experience. FromSoftware has set a new standard for the genre and maybe created a new genre, and I can‚Äôt wait to see what they do with the DLC. If you haven‚Äôt played it yet, do yourself a favor and dive in. You won‚Äôt regret it.

GOOD GAME YEP
fire
dont get this game if your interested in leaving your home
DS1, 2 and 3: Boss attacks that conveys anticipation, buildup, momentum and follow through making bosses feel fluid and predictable enough for your eyes and brain to react to the animations while still challenging you.

ER: most boss attacks are so fast that you cant react to the animation of the attack, instead learning and understanding WHEN they are going to attack.  

Basically the Dark Souls franchise had really well conveyed attacks and momentum that can easily be dodged with human intuition. Elden Ring is the complete opposite because it makes the game way more difficult. 

I can't help but feel that the Dark Souls franchise was made to challenge you in a healthy way while Elden Ring was made just to be difficult. ironically enough falling into the same trap that Dark Souls 2 did (outside of the DS2 bosses)     

I can 1000% understand why people would love and adore this game but personally It challenges me in all the wrong ways

:))))

I had initially gotten the game Spring of 2023. For the last year, I only had about 2 hours in the game. For whatever reason, this last week I decided to try again. One of my friends who has a lot more hours in the game than me helped give a little bit of guidance. Just enough to not feel so overwhelmed with all that this game has to offer. Now that I've got a better understanding, I can absolutely say this is a phenomenal experience. I probably can't give great feedback on the mechanics and whatnot, and there are probably far better reviews for that. Eldne er rong
best art best bosses really good combat good story over all top 5 games in the wold
 In the vast expanse of gaming, few titles evoke the sense of anticipation and wonder quite like Elden Ring. Developed by FromSoftware in collaboration with George R.R. Martin, this open-world action RPG has been shrouded in mystery for years, with tantalizing glimpses leaving fans clamoring for more. Now, having traversed the lands of the Lands Between, I can confidently say that Elden Ring not only lives up to the hype but surpasses it in ways I never imagined.

At its core, Elden Ring is quintessentially FromSoftware. The punishing difficulty, intricate level design, and cryptic storytelling are all present and accounted for. Yet, within this familiar framework lies a world of unparalleled scope and ambition. The Lands Between is a sprawling, interconnected landscape teeming with secrets to uncover and challenges to overcome. From verdant forests to desolate ruins, each region is a testament to the game's meticulous attention to detail.

What truly sets Elden Ring apart, however, is its sense of freedom. Unlike FromSoftware's previous titles, which often felt claustrophobic and linear, Elden Ring offers players the freedom to explore at their own pace. Whether you're scaling a towering fortress or delving into a dark dungeon, the sense of discovery is palpable at every turn. This newfound freedom extends to the game's combat as well, with a wide array of weapons, spells, and abilities at your disposal. From visceral melee encounters to epic boss battles, every skirmish feels like a test of skill and strategy.

Of course, no discussion of Elden Ring would be complete without mentioning its enigmatic lore. Much like the works of George R.R. Martin, the game's narrative is rich with depth and complexity. From ancient prophecies to warring factions, the story of the Lands Between is as captivating as it is cryptic. Piecing together its various threads is a challenge in and of itself, but the rewards are well worth the effort.

Of course, Elden Ring is not without its flaws. The game's performance can be somewhat inconsistent at times, with occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-in marring an otherwise flawless experience. Likewise, the online multiplayer component feels somewhat tacked on, lacking the depth and polish of the single-player campaign.

Despite these minor shortcomings, however, Elden Ring stands as a towering achievement in the realm of gaming. It's a game that rewards patience and perseverance, challenging players to venture into the unknown and emerge victorious against all odds. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of FromSoftware's previous titles or a newcomer eager to experience something truly special, Elden Ring demands your attention. In the end, it's not just a game; it's an epic journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Elden Ring was my first soulslike.
It was kinda overwhelming when starting but I had tons of fun in my first blind run.
Like that's the great part of Elden Ring: you don't have to be this awesome Souls-Veteran to be able to enjoy the game.
You can just take your time with everything, explore the beautiful world, enjoy the view and smaller bosses.
The game doesn't push you to kill a certain difficult boss in order to get somewhere in-game. You're not forced to farm the same enemies for hours on until you're strong enough to continue your journey. You can just keep exploring & will eventually level up in the mean time. & if you're not getting any further with a specific boss, then you can just leave it be for now and do hundreds of other things instead.

For your information, I have played the game pirated before like 35h

Made by God.
awesome game
try but hole
Good and hard
It's Dark Souls but open world. This makes it way more approachable for new players because you can skip a lot of boss fights or more easily level up to overcome them--in addition to all of the other quality of life improvements compared to previous games. 

The world is also enormous and sprawling, and as a person who doesn't enjoy open worlds, it fatigued me really quickly sometimes. If you are looking to get into Souls games but share this concern, try out Dark Souls 3 or Sekiro. 

I also highly recommend the seamless multiplayer mod. Invasions have always been bullshit, and they only served to highten the fatigue I felt. The game did not need them, and I hope FromSoft considers removing this feature in the future.

This game has it faults mostly due to being a port over to PC, so expect your generic clunkyness in that regard. Game is capped at 60 FPS. Besides these faults, Elden Ring is a decently challenging game that offers you plenty of options to stray from a linear path. The open world allows for exploration and leveling with plenty of decent dungeons and bosses to get stuck into.

mhm
malenia feet
Simply put, this is a "must play" experience. 

The combat mechanics are so well designed it'll keep you playing for hundreds of hours. The landscapes, castles, dungeons, creature and boss designs are all artistic masterpieces. You will find yourself stopping to take in the vistas that the Lands Between offers. The game is a work of art all around and if you can embrace the challenge, you'll find one of the best gaming experiences ever created.
I'm not a die-hard souls-like fan, so this review is for people like me who are interested in the genre but never played one. Elden Ring is very likely a must-buy for folks who already enjoyed the previous FromSoftware games.It's hard for me to recommend this game, but in the end the positives outweigh the negatives. Most of my issues come from the fact that I don't like repetition very much. I do like roguelike/roguelites a lot, but there the repetition is not exactly the same every run. In souls-like games you have to go through the exact same areas with the exact same enemies over and over again.Let's start with the positives:[list][*]Exploring the open world is really fun and rewarding! There are a lot of hidden nooks and crannies with interesting gameplay.[*]Trying out the different weapons was fun.[*]For the most part the melee combat was fun and engaging, at least against small and medium sized enemies. I mostly blocked enemy attacks with my Greatshield and counter attacked, which staggers a lot of enemies directly or after a few successful counters.[*]The traditional souls-like death-and-progression-system works really well in this open world. If you are stuck at one point you can just go somewhere else most of the time. You have a lot of freedom where you want to go.[/list]Here are my negatives:[list][*]A lot of the bosses were not fun to fight against for me. Many are just big damage sponges and you have to roll out of their way constantly and chip away at their health one attack at a time before having to roll away again. This was tedious and not engaging for me.[*]Some boss fights appear quite sudden. If you have a lot of runes on you and get defeated (which for boss fights you will most likely lose your very first attempt), you have to go back to the boss fight, scramble to get your runes back and try to defeat the boss. This happened to me a few times and it's very frustrating. I know that Lies of P has solved this issue by simply putting the lost Runes/Ergo in front of the boss entrance, so you can choose if you want to continue or not.[*]I found it very tedious to get into the lore. Apparently you have to read item descriptions for that, which I did not expect was a requirement for exploring that part of the game.[*]I tried out some mage builds but that kind of gameplay was boring to me. You just stand at a distance and spam stuff. I got drawn to the game for the melee combat, so that's not that big of a let down.[*]There are some design decisions that could be way better imho, like the fact that Great Runes are kinda useless because you lose their effect upon death, and activating them costs items that you need to farm.[/list]But overall the game is very well crafted with interesting world building and mechanics. If you like challenging combat and open world exploration you should experience it for yourself! If you find constant repetition frustrating you should probably skip this.
Just died twice while holding 103454683 runes to a random albinauric.


Love this game.

What can I say about ELDEN RING other than it's a pure masterpiece. 

Whether that be the outright masterful music composed, to the overpowered bosses that take you several attempts (Personally that was Morgott), you will never know what to expect to miss on your first attempt or even your second.

If you're wanting a souls game to start with I would recommend ELDEN RING without a Shadow of (the Erdtree) a doubt. 100%ing this game took me a long time but I enjoyed every single attempt in getting there. 

Cannot wait for the DLC to come out (Also please bring bloodborne to PC)

yaya
[h1] In short, Elden Ring [/h1]
So, the latest [b] Souls Like [/b] game from Miyazaki.
The game is very good, really addictive, but only if you play without guides.
The game has an open world, a lot of quests and quest lines of characters, as well as a large number of bosses, namely more than 80, if you take into account mob bosses and just bosses.
The game has very beautiful graphics, all textures are well made, the picture is even on weak PCs [spoiler] I mean those PCs on which it can be played at all [/spoiler]
But there are also disadvantages, namely the traditional online, in which you can not normally play with friends.
Of course, this can also be fixed with [spoiler] Seameless Co-op [/spoiler]
The bosses are very diverse, from the usual soldier mob, to the well-known Malenia or, for example, other famous bosses.
There are several locations in the open world where you can find various things.
There are a large number of weapons that can be found, obtained and used.
Due to the variety of powerups, weapons and armor, builds are still appearing and stronger builds are appearing each time.
If you have already passed the game, and do not know what to do, there are several options that you can notice for yourself
1. Go fight with other players in the colosseum.
2. Install  mods on the game [spoiler] you can get banned [/spoiler]
3. Set yourself a complication in the form of, for example, passing the game by pumping only one characteristic, using only bows or crossbows, or without pumping.

Also, this game has an extensive community that can both support you and condemn you for playing or using something they don't like, for example.

The most important thing is to complete the game the way you want and like it the most, and not pay attention.

I hope my review helped you with the choice of the game.

Good luck and have a good game
Someone must extinguish thy flame. Let it be Morgott the Blade of Miquella

elden ring is a beautiful game with a lot of different weapons for different play styles you wil definitely find the weapon that suits you the most the map is huge and the bosses are fun an hard you can get mad but once you have beaten the boss you get the best feeling you will ever have if you are done with the game you can play hit again on new game plus in new game plus the enemys have more hp and do more dmg and if you are bored if the PVE what i don't think will happen you can also PVP with other real players there a a lot of story lines that you can follow to get some cool weapens i definitely will recommend this game for anyone who likes hard game.
[u]Recommended.[/u]
[list]
[*]The bosses are not as tightly designed and satisfying to fight against as in Dark Souls 3 or Bloodborne; 
[*]The world altogether is not as atmospheric, cohesive and balanced as Dark Souls 1 world; 
[*]The open world is beautiful to look at, but slightly too big;
[*]"Legacy Dungeons" (DS style areas) are expertly designed highlights of the game;
[*]PvP is not as varied as in Dark Souls 2 [i](very few "meta" builds - nearly half of Colosseum encounters are against the same 3 builds + no stamina management required whatsoever)[/i];
[*]Jump and crouch feel a bit better than in Sekiro;
[*]NPCs are still just teleporting vending machines, but this time in a much bigger world so they're easier to miss;
[*]The difficulty is all over the place. It will depend on the order in which you do things, and on your willingness to use all the tools at your disposal;
[*]The lore is not as dark fantasy as in previous games, it's more akin to a grotesque high fantasy soap opera;
[*]Art, soundtrack and voice acting are top notch, as usual;
[/list]

Whilst it doesn't bring anything new to the table for experienced DS players, it does have a lot of content, spectacle, and it's just more Dark Souls, which on the whole is a good thing.

10/10 game would play again
Best game. Very good.
goty every year
ta weno
It's alr ig
Elden ring is one of the very few games I would say is a perfect 10/10 for what it sets out to do. The bossfights are challenging and fun to learn, and the world feels like FromSoft wanted you to explore every single nook and cranny in the expansive map. As this is my first soulsborne game, I had a lot of problems learning the feel of how a bossfight is supposed to go, but once everything eventually clicked, the fights became more akin to a puzzle that requires a high level of execution to beat. And while I'm still not a pro at this game that has beaten the whole thing at level one, It has always been fun to go through playthrough after playthrough with different weapons to see how much I have improved. This game, while difficult, thoroughly rewards players who stick with it and are willing to learn from their mistakes. 

The only issue I have with this game is the multiplayer system, and I'm well aware the problems I have with it are a soulsborne staple. The mutiplayer system for pvp, while pvp isn't really my thing, is fine, but the co op multiplayer being based on only being at bosses is kinda annoying to me. I wanted to treat this game as a multiplayer game when I first bought it on PS4 (about 200 more hours), but Elden Ring really isnt set up that way, with exploration being mostly a singleplayer activity. BUT, with the help of the Elden Ring Co op mod, I've got exactly what I was looking for, which has lead to about half of the total Elden Ring played hours on my PC. 

So, all in all, phenomenal single player game, and if you don't mind mods, a phenomenal multiplayer game as well. Shadow of the Erdtree can't come soon enough.

I don't mind dying from skill issues. Getting killed by an instant kill room mechanic that changes it's function for no reason; that's just the game doing random things to kill you just because. Not my kind of fun. I'm also not a fan of having to go back to where you died to pick up your stuff in this game. Not because its tedious or a bad mechanic, but after dying from random out of combat stuff, its not really fun for me having to traverse back and forth avoiding it all again just to collect my shiz. I'd rather fight enemies. Not run away from giant rolling death machines that stick to a pattern; then for no reason they change direction because why not?

Also, is it supposed to be fun to get on your horse and run past just about every enemy in the game to go collect everything? Instead of fighting your way through enemies to earn your rewards... all you have to do is bypass everything with your horse to collect all sorts of loot/gear/keys/spells you name it. New area you just discovered full of enemies? no problem!, get on horse and run. Dragon just land out of nowhere on top of your head, no problem!, get on horse and run. 1/2 of all the weapons in this game you can get by avoiding all the enemies with your horse without having to engage in any combat. Yay! horse riding collecting simulator! Just look online on how to, "get OP early". You can spend hrs in this game getting stronger by just running all over the map avoiding everything to acquire end game lvl gear....No thanks.

I will acknowledge that just about everything else in this game is amazing. Content and character build theory crafting is super fun. The combat is ok. I'm not a huge fan of the dull music, but it does fit the atmosphere and feel of the game so i give it a pass. Being said; you won't be feeling, "epic" from the music anytime soon.

People say this game can be hard. I assume they must be confused on how to steer the horse.
1500 hours played (on different accounts) and I can't stop. Help me
tough love

If not the best, one of the best games I've ever played ngl
I love this game.

I am a huge Darksouls fan and can confidently say this is my favorite FromSoft souls game. I like this game so much that when I switched from PS5 to PC, I decided to break in Elden Ring on PC for the up and coming DLC. I platinum'd EVERY Souls game they made on Playstation, so its only natural to want to continue that trend on PC, too. (Currently still playing and enjoying, so I do not have all achievements yet.)

- That is a take away that separates this Souls game from others, however. Getting all achievement in this game is kinda hard to NOT do when all you have to do is play the game how you want. Hard to mess it up.
- The bosses in the game are arguably HARDER than other souls games, but they put in Ashes to help you with the fights (Mimic Tear, my love). And if that doesn't work, use a yellow pellet and call in some reinforcements from other Elden Ring nerds playing, which 9/10 times you'll end up beating the boss this way because there's a decent amount of good players that enjoy helping out.
- There's no upgrading armor in this game, some may not like that, but i like not having to put souls into upgrading MORE of my stuff when i can be using the souls to upgrade my stats.
- You do still upgrade your weapons, however. There's a vast sea of different options to choose from and I enjoy the versatility and variety. i always try to build my character a different way on each NG+
- New player friendly (lol). it's a souls game after all. they were kind enough to make a "tutorial" for you, which is nice. But that is only after you get spanked by a crazy looking creature that nightmares are made of. Extra arms for extra spanks. 
- For all the turtle bois that hide behind shields, you're in luck. They added a feature where you can essentially "counter" when something hits your shield. Does a fair amount of damage, it's like a fully charged heavy attack.
- Plus many other positive things I can say about the game, but i want to wrap this comment up.

So, whether you want to get into a souls game or you're a veteran souls player like me, I highly recommend this game to all gamers out there.

ranni
One of the greatest games you'll ever play. Even if you are not a fan of other Souls-like games, I highly recommend Elden Ring. Yes, the game is difficult, and you will die a lot, but there is no shame in it. The struggle in the early part of the game is a necessary, and satisfying one in the long run (keep in mind you only get stronger as the game progresses, though so do enemies). The lore of this game is incredible, and it is worth playing simply to learn about the history of the world and characters of this game, and all its mysteries. The game is about a lot of things, but ultimately it is the satisfying journey of starting as a weak character who can barley fight more than a few foot soldiers without dying and then eventually building up your skills, finding new weapons and armour in your travels across the world, uncovering secrets, and slaying not just the foes you used to struggle against, but literal Demi-Gods. 
the game is also super fun with friends. the PvE arena is a blast, and I highly recommend the Seemless Co-Op mod for playing with your friends (without having to summon each other in different boss areas, and no Invaders. a much more fluid multiplayer experience)
Bro i have no idea wht to do there is no tutorial i am refunding staright away
This game is genuinely incredible. It is amazing how massive this game is, and all the content and questlines you can explore and bosses waiting for you to defeat. The lore is incredibly interesting to, it's a very interesting story that shows itself more as you progress. It does have it's flaws, like poor balancing in the last half of the game and reused bosses as well as very strange design choices for some bosses; but ultimately I walked away genuinely satisfied and I do not regret a single hour I spent in this game.
The Foreskin Duo made me feel things that I never thought I would.

"Elden Ring" offers a stunning open world and challenging gameplay that rewards patience and strategy. Its graphics are impressive, and the combat system is complex, demanding careful thought and perseverance. The story is cryptic and engaging for those who enjoy piecing together lore. While its difficulty may deter some, "Elden Ring" is a rewarding experience for gamers seeking a deep and immersive adventure.

 [h1]Overall 9/10 for me. one of the best games of all time. [/h1]

-The incredible art style and world that has been created here is nothing short of mind blowing. On my first play through i was in awe at how the map just kept opening up over and over again.

-An insane variety of weapons and play styles, making for almost endless replayability

-more accessible than any other game in the franchise. If you are stuck there is almost always a way to make the situation easier.

Cons: 
-Game could have been 30 percent smaller and trimmed some of the fat. there are some bosses that are reused way too much
-Lacks drop in/drop out multiplayer (as all souls games do)
-some performance issues in certain game areas

Great game, one of the best I have ever played!
In a society where technology reigns supreme, I found myself navigating the complexities of parenthood as a 50-year-old corporate executive with a passion for classic literature. My daughter, a 16-year-old tech-savvy whiz, was always glued to her devices, immersed in a world that seemed light-years away from my own.
One day, she came home with a new game she had discovered online. As she dove headfirst into this virtual universe, I couldn't help but feel a pang of isolation, longing for a way to connect with her in a world dominated by screens and algorithms.
Determined to bridge the gap between us, I mustered the courage to explore this foreign terrain by creating my own gaming profile and immersing myself in the game that had captured my daughter's imagination. As I navigated the virtual landscapes, I felt like a fish out of water, struggling to grasp the mechanics and intricacies of the game.
Turning to my daughter for guidance, she eagerly offered to be my mentor, patiently teaching me the ropes and sharing her expertise. With her guidance, I slowly but surely began to find my footing in this digital realm, discovering a newfound sense of camaraderie and understanding with my daughter.
Our roles reversed as she became the teacher and I, the student. Through shared victories and defeats, we forged a bond that transcended generational barriers, finding common ground in the unlikeliest of places.
This game became our shared sanctuary, a place where words were unnecessary, and actions spoke volumes. It opened the door to conversations we had never thought to have, fostering a sense of closeness and mutual respect that had eluded us in the fast-paced world we inhabited.
As we ventured through virtual quests and conquered digital foes together, I realized that the true treasure lay not in the pixels on the screen but in the moments of connection and understanding we shared. This game became a bridge that spanned the divide between us, reminding me that in the vast expanse of the digital landscape, the most valuable treasures are the bonds we forge with those we love.

Soul like ‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏£‡∏Å‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏ä‡∏µ‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ï ‡∏™‡∏ô‡∏∏‡∏Å‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏Ñ‡∏≤‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏¢‡∏≠‡∏∞‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏•‡πà‡∏ô‡∏à‡∏ö‡πÑ‡∏õ 5 ‡∏£‡∏≠‡∏ö‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢ ‡πÉ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏á‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏°‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏°‡∏±‡πâ‡∏¢ ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏¢‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å ‡∏¢‡∏≤‡∏Å‡πÅ‡∏ô‡πà‡πÜ5555 ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡πÜ‡πÜ ‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏¥‡∏ô‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏Ç‡∏ô‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏ô‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô ‡∏ö‡∏≠‡∏™‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏Å‡πáEZ ‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏¢‡∏ß‡∏ô‡πÑ‡∏õ‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ö4‡∏ä‡∏±‡πà‡∏ß‡πÇ‡∏°‡∏á ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏°‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏∞‡πÅ‡∏ô‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏µ‡∏á‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö

üîõüîù
I have played and beaten all the souls games, including the original Demons' Souls on PS3. I love these games and I appreciate the devs for making these games. Now I know this isn't a *souls* game in name but it pretty much encompasses all the same gameplay that those games had plus some open world stuff.

Elden Ring is the worst of all the Souls games because of the open world. You'll end up destroying countless bosses because there is no way to balance this kind of game. Let's not forget all the copy and paste bosses you fight as well. This game may have the most spells, the biggest lineup of bosses and enemies, the largest world.... but it's all just padding on top of padding. I almost couldn't finish the game because I was getting so bored and I have absolutely no urge to do a NG+ either.

These types of games are meant to be first and foremost DUNGEON CRAWLERS. Getting through dungeons and figuring out traps is most of the fun in these games. The dungeons in this game are mostly half baked. The music is nowhere near as good as previous entries either.

Is this a bad game? No. But does it deserve a higher rating than DS1, DS2, DS3, Demons Souls? HELL NO.
Kai it took me 16 hours to beat elden ring, dumbass

This game FUCKS. I'm a firm believer now in the idea that you get what you earn. No hand holding, just fully dominating and winning against the truly skilled NPC. I've cheated, lied, and mirrored my way to an ending but by golly I made it happen.

I still feel blessed for the stuff I did beat, and now I'm going around the world again doing it for real. I'm losing all the time but at least I'm sticking to my principles!!!

This game is a serious net positive for everyone. Good job FROMSOFT!!
Es bueno
If you want to jump right into action, Elden Ring is the way to go.  Though it does have some story and cut scenes, much of the deeper lore is hidden in item description.  Though this game is not for the faint of heart, it will test your skills as a gamer.  No one way will always work for you, but finding what works best for you will give you good results.  Sometimes you have to be rash and quick, other times you have to be patient and still.  Up to you to decide when.  You can make the decision in the vast world with friend and foe alike.  Keep up your guard, for there are certainly more foes out there.  Many enemies big and small are ready to get in your way and change up the way they fight if you fail.  Solve puzzles in dungeons and craft items for restoration/buffs or throwables for combat.  Many weapons to choose from of different weapon types.  Find the one that suits you best(Katanas, Shortswords, Longswords, Greatswords, Axes, Bows, Bowguns, staves, knives, flails, etc.).  

Will you take on the adversity to crown yourself as Elden Lord?

PS
If you get easily offended because you are SINGLE, I wouldn't recommend this game for you.

EXPENSIVE,  As someone who has never played a souls game before and became instantly hooked from the just the game trailer, I must say that this game is expensive, not in the actual cost of the game, but in the replacement of my keyboards and mice that I have destroyed in the process of being absolutely spanked during game-play..........However after getting a controller and learning some tips from friends I cant get enough. The exploration of this game is so freaking awesome. The secrets, traps, and lore is beyond amazing. I have a love hate relationship with this game but I definitely recommend it. I also recommend the using the controller because it really seemed to help with the maneuvering.

asd
hehe big unga bunga go bonk
this is like playing those ds3 mods where they give bosses a way to cancel their recoveries into a combo extender or they port bloodborne and sekiro enemies, but you fight them using the ds3 roll instead of swapping to bb dash or using a modded block mechanic; it's technically very hard, but clearly something isn't right, but the overall experience is okay enough to offset it.
then you realize this game isn't a ds3 mod and it's actually a game by fromsoft, but then you find bloodhound/quickstep which is bb dash for 5 focus points; an optional skill equippable on any weapon. then you think back to other soulslikes or even bloodborne & sekiro themselves where enemies get expanded offensive options but the player gets expanded defensive options to compensate, and you wonder what the fuck actually happened with this game; this isn't sekiro or bloodborne, but the enemies herein are practically ripped out of these games and forced into a game lacking their contextual systems.
[list]
[*]gigantic enemies, but no camera adjustments like in sekiro - can't see fucking anything even though this is a completely solved issue in fromsoft's own games and every other soulslike
[*]souls' heavy input buffering and commitment on rolls and attacks despite having significantly faster pacing; if you misinput a roll and get hit, it gets queued into your hitstun, which makes you roll on recovery, and every single attack in the entire game is guaranteed to rollcatch these. 
[*]you have stamina which is expended by dodging, unlike sekiro, and the amount of damage negation done per point of stamina - either directly via iframes or passively via resulting roll spacing/sprint spacing is much lower than bb's. this results in even if you dodge literally everything, you've expended the same stamina bar you use on attacking.
[*]enemy attack strings are too fast for your slow souls roll or slow souls attacks to meaningfully allow you to weave damage unlike bb/sekiro.
[*]enemy's extremely long combos do not in any way contribute to your own aggression the way sekiro deflection or bb's movement does.
[*]enemy posture is a clearly indicated window played around to measure your own aggression - visual limb health in bb, the literal posture bar in sekiro; in elden ring you just stagger people sometimes and take your pity crit
[*]attacks can be jumped like sekiro, but without jump indicators, and inconsistent visual elements to these make them completely unidentifiable outside of testing i.e being hit or not by them while jumping
[/list] 
i've never felt this level of utter indifference over a fromsoft game ever; there's no accomplishment to be gleaned here because the game has been reduced to an onslaught of the most deliberately unintuitive and "videogame" feeling combat in the service of 'difficulty' that it loses its luster - you fight one enemy and you've fought them all, because they all rely on the exact same tricks as seen on something like tree sentinel: 
[list]
[*]one visual cue leading to multiple different attacks with varied dodge timings
[*]prolonged aggression in the form of long combos with recoveries that can be converted into combo starters depending on player proximity or pure RNG, to limit player aggression and make punish windows shorter
[*]comically long windup delayed attacks where the visual release does not coincide with its active frames or the attack 'falsely connects' with a vfx before deploying its active frames 
[*]'chained' attacks where a single iframe window is not enough to dodge both sequences and it requires your positioning to be perfect to both iframe the first part and physically displace you from the second during your roll recovery
[/list] 
while these aren't present in tree sentinel, they are present in the rest of the game's bosses;
[list]
[*]a gigantic dodge that resets all spacing, denies melee punishes and allows the boss to perform a variety of arena-spanning attacks with specific roll timings unique to this distance
[*]iframe-only aoe blast moves that have comically long windups but awkward release windows, sometimes paired with a fast attack that initially puts you into knockdown so you have to do this off of a doubly unique recovery roll timing 
[*]'passive' attacks where the boss is actively hitting you and forcing you to defend against a damaging thing, but still individually capable of performing all of its normal moves; lichdragon lightning buildup, rykard's skull storm, elden beast's falling stars
[*]'instant' attacks measured in less than 20 odd frames of startup that are basically undodgeable happening randomly throughout the fight; godrick's aoe wind, radagon's teleport, fat godskin's belly blast
[/list] 
the game's "superboss" is indifferent to everything before it outside of ONE attack that takes this to its logical extreme conclusion by outright killing you in a single move if you don't precisely dodge it... or you can bloodhound/quickstep it... or the boss can not do it throughout the entire fight... or the boss can do it like 10 times per phase

the series combat has always been defined by it's "turn based nature" and the learning of attack windows & how you may expand them with the tools available to you past iframing, which gets exacerbated by unskilled players as being "hard", but this is the only game ever published in this entire genre where i'd say that's a true assessment. 
you fight a guy and just wait for him to let you hit him, because attack Y has a recovery canceler, but attack X requires a combination of iframes and positioning that displaces you enough from the boss that you can't melee attack him on his recovery, and attack Z is a comically large and delayed aoe that requires you to run away really far. 
you go on youtube and find that some attacks can be jumped because some guy died like twenty thousand times testing jump on every single attack to glean out a scrap of the retaliation windows intuitively extractable in other souls & soulslike titles, plus the exact combination of AoW posture break or quick/blood dodge or weird sprinting that lets you counter this one attack having 280¬∞ tracking instead of the usual 360¬∞ and you can sneak a r1 in there as a result; he argues this knowledge, requiring 1000hs of failed hitless run scrimming to discover very selectively applicable tactics on some specific moves, justifies the game's overreliance on this one aspect of enemy attack design.

the end result is just me not caring - the experiential nature of souls is gone. i'm not fighting anyone, i'm staring at some videogame character's animations to coincide my iframes with his active frames, then i'm inputting my alloted attack before repeating the cycle. 
even the exploration and "feel" of the game falls by the wayside because i know the core of it will be fighting whoever is in that given area. this cynicism is unique to elden ring for its overreliance on this aspect of enemy design, which at most was an outlier hardly present in universally-agreed-upon goofy enemies rarely seen in bloodborne, any souls titles past, or soulslike greats like nioh.

all the visuals, content and barefoot women with individually rigged toes can't make up for the game twisting itself apart; a misguided effort to win this self-imposed arms race against players over the idea of being a hard game, not meaningfully earning it the way previous titles in the series or genre did.

anyways it's okay and goty and stuff

‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†à‚¢ª‚£ø‚£≠‚°á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢∏‚°è‚¢Æ‚£≥‚°Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢ª‚°ø‚£¶‚£ø‚°á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢ø‚†¢‚£Ω‚£Ö‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†∏‚°Ü‚¢§‚£ø‚°á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£∏‚°ü‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢∑‚†∏‚£û‚°á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚°è‚¢ß‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

elden
This game had a lot of good and a lot of bad, this review is balanced but skewed negative for specific reasons (skip ahead to see the negative before buying the game) I have never seen such glowing reviews to celebrate such mediocrity in my life.

THE GOOD: The scenery is beautiful and it makes exploration awesome. Combat is challenging but fun and super rewarding to overcome bosses. The world is huge and the story seems ok.

THE BAD: They sell this game as Co-op, but it is not. If you buy the game to play with a specific person like i did, prepare to be horribly disappointed. The co-op option is only available in specific areas and with specific conditions, those conditions are glitchy at best, and when you do play with a friend it is NOT co-op, it's PvPvE. The invader system is horrible, and the game encourages toxic behavior by throwing a random person in your game every 2-3 minutes to try to kill you and your buddy. You cannot turn this off, which is a terrible design decision. While you risk losing everything if you die, you get no rewards for winning, and the invader takes zero risk in doing so. Just an overall bad system. Hacking and cheating are rampant despite the supposed anti-cheat software (aptly named "easy cheat")

After 90 hours of playing with my buddy on and off, and numerous people cheating, a guy just broke my game by rocketing me to endgame at level 85, so no more co-op for me at all, and story ruined (why is EVERYTHING on fire? no idea)

Aside from the co-op, magic is available in the game and can be awesome and powerful, but every spell in the game feels like an afterthought, literally ZERO balance in spellcasting at all, the cost/damage ratio on late game spells is a joke.

AND MORE: No journal or quest tracker (good luck following the story to its fullest) No multiple loadout system. No ultrawide support. No cosmetic options. The parry system is notoriously horrible. It's 2024, these are game staples, i feel like the devs gave up halfway through making the game after they built the world, just so many ways they could have easily improved the system and chose not to. 

I had fun while it lasted, but overall it was a letdown. If you play solo, you can still have fun if you enjoyed dark souls, but if you are a social gamer don't waste your time.
Most fun I've had. I always keep coming back.
I bought this game to prove to my brother that I could beat it, and It's a real shame I didn't buy it earlier, In the start I didn't really feel it, but as time went on I absolutely fell in love, the Characters, story, gameplay and the art it's all so perfect, This was my second Souls game and I will definitely play it again.
this game is NOT Malenia, Blade of Miquella, and thats a good thing
The most immersive, challenging, yet fun game I've ever played

Wanna just thrust something so fast and hard that they die after a few hits? Absolutely! This game is amazing even after finishing it once, because that playthrough, is not done! In this game, there is an NG+ mode. With any CHARACTER, after beating the game you can continue with that one and make it harder for yourself, and more opportunities for other endings if you didn't like the one you got but don't want to get rid of all of your progress! You can also have MULTIPLE characters at the same time!

The Best Way to Get Your Butt Kicked While Enjoying a Gorgeous View

FromSoftware, you've done it again. Elden Ring is the game that perfectly balances the beauty of an open world with the relentless brutality of enemies who clearly don't understand the concept of personal space. If you‚Äôve ever wanted to spend hours wandering through a fantastical landscape only to be ruthlessly smacked down by a tree with anger management issues, then this is the game for you.

The graphics are stunning, the combat is intense, and the story is as deep as the pits I've fallen into repeatedly. Seriously, I've died more times than Sean Bean in his entire film career. If you‚Äôre looking for a game where victory feels like finding a $20 bill in your old winter coat, look no further.

Elden Ring has taught me many things: patience, perseverance, and a colorful vocabulary of expletives. Every triumph feels earned, every defeat is a lesson in humility, and every boss fight is a reminder that my reflexes aren't what they used to be.

So, if you enjoy breathtaking vistas, rich lore, and the thrill of yelling at your PC, Elden Ring is your game. Just remember: when life gives you Elden Ring, it‚Äôs probably going to give you a giant dragon to ruin your day too. Happy adventuring!

Such Elden... Much Ring...
Elden Ring: A Masterpiece of Dark Fantasy
Rating: 9.5/10 (nothing is perfect, but Elden Ring is close!)

Elden Ring, the collaborative effort between FromSoftware and George R. R. Martin, has taken the gaming world by storm. Set in a sprawling open world, it seamlessly blends challenging combat, intricate lore, and breathtaking visuals. Here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs a must-play:

1. World Design and Exploration
The land of the Elden Ring is vast, mysterious, and interconnected. From dense forests to crumbling ruins, every corner invites exploration. Hidden paths, secret bosses, and awe-inspiring vistas await those who dare to venture off the beaten track.

2. Challenging Combat
Prepare to die (a lot). The combat mechanics are punishing yet fair. Each swing of your sword, dodge, and parry requires precision. Victory feels hard-earned, and defeat pushes you to improve. The boss battles are epic, leaving you breathless and exhilarated.

3. Lore and Storytelling
The game‚Äôs lore is rich and enigmatic. Cryptic item descriptions, cryptic NPCs, and cryptic murals‚Äîall contribute to the sense of mystery. Piecing together the fragmented history of the Elden Ring keeps players engaged and hungry for more.

4. Visuals and Atmosphere
FromSoftware‚Äôs signature dark aesthetic shines here. The desolate landscapes, haunting dungeons, and eerie lighting create an unforgettable atmosphere. Whether you‚Äôre riding your steed across a moonlit plain or descending into a cursed castle, the visuals are stunning.

5. Customization and Builds
Choose your playstyle. Will you wield a massive greatsword, rely on magic, or prefer agile dual-wielding? Elden Ring offers diverse character builds, allowing players to tailor their experience. Experimentation is key.

Conclusion
Elden Ring isn‚Äôt just a game; it‚Äôs an odyssey. It challenges you, rewards your curiosity, and immerses you in a world where light battles darkness. If you‚Äôre up for the journey, grab your sword, mount your steed, and explore the fractured lands of the Elden Ring.

Remember, ‚ÄúFear not the dark, my friend. And let the feast begin.‚Äù
So much rings, so many Eldens!  All of the Souls!  Not enough Erdtrees
dakr souls
Elden Ring is an action role-playing game set in third-person perspective. It includes elements that are similar to those in other FromSoftware-developed games, such as the Dark Souls series, Bloodborne, and Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. The game is set in an open world; players can freely explore the Lands Between and its six main areas, which include Limgrave‚Äîan area of grassy plains and ancient ruins‚Äîand Caelid, a wasteland that is home to undead monsters.[1] The open world is explored using the character's mount Torrent as the main mode of transportation, though players may use fast travel outside combat. Throughout the game, players encounter non-player characters (NPCs) and enemies, including demigods who rule each main area and serve as the game's main bosses.[2][3] Aside from the main areas, Elden Ring has hidden dungeons, catacombs, tunnels, and caves where players can fight bosses and gather helpful items.[4]

At the game's start, the player chooses a character class, which determines their starting spells, equipment, and attributes.[5] Combat with enemies can be within melee, or from a distance using ranged weapons. Enemy attacks can be dodged or blocked using shields. Spells allow players to enhance their weapons, fight enemies from afar, and restore lost hit points. The player can memorize a limited amount of these spells, which can be cast using a staff or sacred seal item.[6][7] Weapons can be improved using ashes of war, which are obtainable "enchantments" that grant weapons new capabilities. Ashes of war can be applied to or removed from weapons, and each Ash adds a weapon art, a special ability that can be used during combat.[8] Aside from direct combat, stealth mechanics can be used to avoid enemies or allow the targeting of foes with critical hits while hidden.[9][10] Staggering enemies and parrying their attacks can also create opportunities for critical hits.[11][12]

Checkpoints called sites of grace are located throughout the game; in these places, characters can increase the power of their attributes, change memorized spells, swap ashes of war, or walk to using fast travel. Upon death, players respawn at the last site of grace they interacted with. Alternatively, they may choose to respawn at certain locations highlighted by "stakes of Marika" provided they died nearby.[8][13][14] To increase their attributes at sites of grace, the player must spend runes, an in-game currency that is acquired by defeating enemies.[15] Runes can be used to buy items, and improve weapons and armor. Dying in Elden Ring causes the player to lose all collected runes at the location of death; if the player dies again before retrieving the runes, they will be lost forever.[16]

Elden Ring contains crafting mechanics; the creation of items requires materials. Recipes, which are required for the crafting of items, can be found inside collectibles called cookbooks, which are scattered throughout the world. Materials can be collected by defeating enemies, exploring the game's world, or by trading with merchant NPCs. Crafted items include poison darts, exploding pots, and consumables that temporarily increase the player's combat strength.[17][18] Similar to the Dark Souls games, the player can summon friendly NPCs called spirits to fight enemies.[19] Summoning each type of spirit requires its equivalent Spirit Ash; different types of Spirit Ashes can be discovered as the player explores the game world. Spirits can only be summoned near structures called Rebirth Monuments, which are primarily found in large areas and inside boss fight arenas.[20]

Elden Ring has a multiplayer system that allows players to be summoned for both cooperative and player-versus-player (PvP) play over the Internet.[21] Cooperative play involves the placing of a summon sign on the ground, which causes the sign to become visible to online players who have used a corresponding item. If another player interacts with the sign, the player who placed the sign is summoned into their world. Cooperative players remain in the same world until the boss of the area is defeated or until a summoned player dies and is returned to their home world. In PvP combat, a summon sign is used to challenge another player to a duel, or the player can use additional items to invade the worlds of others. World hosts may use a "taunter's tongue" to increase the likelihood their world will be invaded by others and to decrease the time between invasions

I bought this 2 years ago when it released and put about 25 hours into it. I gave up. It was too difficult, work was crazy, my life was a little bit scattered, etc.

I picked it back up recently and decided that I could beat it and put my mind to that task. And I did it! It was equally frustrating as it was rewarding and I realized that was part of the allure of this game. I've never felt a sense of accomplishment quite like this in a game. Apart from that, the lore is so fascinating and this is probably the best open world execution of any game ever...and I love games like Witcher 3, Skyrim, etc.

Overall, this is one of the best games I've ever played once I learned to embrace the difficulty and learn how to play it.
Elden Ring is a masterpiece that solidifies itself as a timeless gem in the realm of gaming. 
As a devout fan who holds it in the upper echelons of all-time greats, it's an absolute pleasure to delve into its depths and share its wonders.

From the the exploration to the challenging bosses that you need to overcome in order to progress in the main story or side quests, i often found myself getting lost in various areas of the map trying to understand where i needed to go, word building and design in this game is S-tier.

Also this one the most beginner friendly FromSoftware tittle to come out yet it is possible to play the game easy mode with certain builds or if you¬¥re a veteran player you can still choose to play the game as raw as you can.

Overall this is one of my favorite tittles from the company.

I don't really like souls-likes in general, I had fun playing Elden Ring however with several caveats.

Do not get the game if you want to play on keyboard, the mouse and keyboard support is...technically there.
Do not get the game if you are unable to dedicate several hours a day to it.

I was willing to put up with the bad keyboard support, however when I got more busy with schoolwork I found that I couldn't consistently dedicate enough time to Elden Ring to keep progressing and was forced to quit. Its a fun game, but it has to be THE game you are going to play or you won't make much progress.
best game ive ever played
Best game of all time
While open world severely harms the souls formula, it would be wrong to not respect what was achieved here.

The views are phenomenal, but it was not worth bloating the game by dotting the same enemies and bosses around just to fill out the space. 90% of the extra dungeons and caves feel the same, have a repeated boss and lead nowhere. Your space is less limited in traversing around set pieces of enemies. It's not as harsh as you would expect a souls-like world to be, and therefore your interaction with it is reduced. You aren't gripped to engage with most of the challenges out there. It's clearly not an accident - the visuals are the focus in the open world areas and there are plenty of memorable and challenging exceptions - but it comes off sloppy and heavily diluted in quality.

Especially when you put bosses out in these open areas. They don't act like they know what they're doing in the space. They move over the landscape so awkwardly, and often they have attacks that reduce your engagement by stalling your advance. I couldn't be more bored of dragons. At least they don't tend to have the AOE-sphere-centred-on-themselves move that most other bosses seem to.

You should not play this game expecting Dark Souls (I'm talking about all 3). It is not worth exploring everything - I did it - it becomes stale. These areas look amazing, but mechanically there are few differences and therefore lack identity, and the space is reduced to filler between point of interest A and point of interest B. There are thousands of corners. Don't waste your time. They give you a magical horse, even, to reduce the time in filler. It even double jumps! Sounds great, how could this be problematic? But this horse highlights the greatest flaw with the game. With this one tool, all obstacles are trivialised. What does this add to the game? Platforming? Why? It doesn't fit. They wanted a world with huge scale, but the price was the immersive game loop that Dark Souls nailed. And then they can't apply the same scale to the cities as in Dark Souls. These are my main issues when comparing to FromSoft's previous work. I expected too much. Dark Souls is more purposeful, more intimate, more confident.

BUT

Just because it isn't Dark Souls doesn't mean it hasn't shifted focus in completely unwarranted ways. The main themes, the desire and corruption of the immortals and the resources that fuel them - there is so much incredible cohesive storytelling through every part of the world. The character design is insane, maybe even unmatched. You get the sense that despite the horror and the lengths these post-human beings have gone through to attain their stake, or their power or following, that you can climb to the same heights. They are falling apart. You feel born anew, ready to take the world by storm. Clear the stagnation. These aren't exactly different themes to Dark Souls, but for better or worse Elden Ring grants greater clarity and vision in your journey without being overbearing. And there's a lot more going on, so that's impressive.

The design philosophy of being able to reach any place you can see has to be respected. When you think you've seen it all, there is more. And as I mentioned above, there are memorable exceptions in the open world I love:
The forest of runebears, the haunting deathbird of prey, the accurate lobster missiles, and of course the chaos octopus. Iconic, unforgettable, simple.
Maybe it's the inconsequential dungeons and caves that are a result of the open world that I dislike more than the open world itself. I suppose part of the beauty of open world is you can find another way around. Still, I think they missed opportunities to add a lot of dynamics with this new approach.

I should probably talk a little bit about the boss fighting, though it actually doesn't feel necessary. I've explained my problems with repeated occurrences and a trend of AOE attacks. I did tell myself they had put Sekiro bosses in a Souls game on multiple occasions, eager to attempt parrying some 7, 8, 9, 10-attack combos. But while I would have loved that opportunity, it would probably have meant sacrificing the build customisation which has much more merit. It's a strength in Dark Souls, and Elden Ring takes it and flies. Anyway, the fights are of course great. They'll challenge you one way, allow you to change things up and then bring about a whole new problem to overcome. A beautiful back and forth struggle where the advantage is fluid. Just as it ever was, this is the bread-and-butter of these games. However, I do think the cinematic feeling was injected slightly too heavily over pure engaging gameplay. A boss will do a long chain of attacks, but to compensate they stagger much too easily. Again, it is no accident - it's supposed to feel like defying the odds, especially when these characters are built up so much. I wouldn't change what they did. But there is a beauty in simplicity: Godskin Apostle was a favourite. Also don't worry, there are still normal enemies that will kill you on their own just fine.

Now I have seen it all, I feel more ready to have fun in the Lands Between. The intention doesn't feel like it was to collect everything - use everything - in one playthrough (yeah, this was one long run). Choose a direction and go. Use what you find, don't be afraid to miss tiny things. Head to the most eye-catching places. Another strength of the open world is that every individual can have a different journey. No two paths will be the same. There's more joy to be had in the variation, and missing things is a part of that journey. Maybe this is a life lesson.
GAME OF THE DECADE

Greatest game of all time.
10/10 love this game worth every penny.
Before Elden Ring, I played just Mortal Shell, so no, I am not a Dark Souls veteran. But that doesn't mean I can't make a review. I spent 170 hours in the game, and after the first fantastic gameplay, I immediately started playing it again. But why is it still fantastic? Well, it has many reasons - the graphics are beautiful, the places like castles, wastelands, underground dungeons, and the capital near the Elden Tree are greatly designed. The lore is like a storybook, no doubts when it was helped written by George R. R. Martin. Yes, it is not the main reason for some, but I like it when what is happening in the game has its reasons, and you slowly discover them. That is a little about graphics and story. Now, something about gameplay. I don't see any serious problems there. The open world is a really nice way to give players free hands in where they want to go. Combat is smooth; there are many types of attacks and many types of weapons. The game will surprise you with different variants of enemies, and it will be necessary to adapt your combat strategy. For every mistake, you will be punished; your souls will be dropped, and if you die again on the way to retrieve them, they will be lost forever. Yes, that will happen to you... and many times... :) and you will sometimes want to stop playing because of it. Well, the game isn't for everyone, but hard work and iron nerves are key to victory. What more about gameplay? Well, of course, bosses with their super variable move set that will sometimes make you cry. I won't forget the words of the first one, every time I died: "Put your foolish ambitions to rest." But when you are looking for a Souls-like game, hard and variable bosses are what you want in it. And now the last perfect thing in this game. Elden Ring's soundtrack and in-game music are 10/10; people who play know what I am saying. That is all about my review. If you want an unforgettable experience from playing a game, this will be a good option. Let the journey begin.

So in this game you play a hollowed (no wait, tarnished, sorry) and have to defeat the lord souls (whoops, I mean the shardbearers) and then must cross the lands of lordran (NO I MEAN THE LANDS BETWEEN) while using campfires (SITES OF GRACE) to restore your estus flasks (FLASK OF CRIMSON TEARS) and gaining souls (RUNESSS) to level up.
