i suck at it
Tried for 152 hours to like this game, like I do with all the Dark Souls games. But this is just not a very good game when you have scratched the very polished surface for a bit.

*So many bosses are just hard because they have 62 different moves, will non-stop do combos like a windmill in a tornado and leave no real openings to punish them back.
*The targeting system is super wonky and sometimes you can lock on to enemies from 200 meters and at other times barely even at 3 meters.
*The quests are extremely vague, you will most likely miss the vast majority of them if you are not following a guide.
*Extremely little of the content is actually mandatory, but there is lots of filler content of often not very good quality.
*You can jump over some attacks but not others and there is absolutely no logic to which ones.
*A lot of bosses are reused versions which often only have more health, or duos of reused bosses, or trios. I don't know but there is probably some fight with 4 of the same bosses in there somewhere.
*There are ways to cheese almost everything with magic, ranged weapons or by summoning spirit ashes.
*Having your spirit ash summon tank everything while you hit the boss in the back is not fun or good gameplay.
*Because so many bosses don't really leave a lot of openings to hit them back a large chunk of what is supposed to be the highlight of the game ends up being watching a boss do combos. Sometimes for minutes before you get any opening to hit it back.
*One of the best and most universal tactic is to just trade hits with bosses instead of trying to learn their mechanics and movement patterns.
*The platforming is mostly annoying and frustrating because the controls are not very precise.
*The early parts of the game are better and of higher quality than the latter parts, where a lot of these things start to show.

There are tons more unfair, frustrating, annoying or outright bad things in the game. It is not the worst game in existence, but it sure is not the flawless masterpiece it's fan base seem to think it is.
best game

reskinned assets bad game honestly
Incredibly, and not unlike the world of Dark Souls, FromSoftware's Elden Ring feels like worlds buried beneath worlds.

Not just in the way that Nokron exists beneath Limgrave, or the buried giants peaking from the earth in Caelid.

A studio allowed to learn and grow together will make better games. Elden Ring has design history built into it. You couldn't play Elden Ring as it exists today had it not been preceded by Dark Souls, Bloodborne, Demon's Souls, and even King's Field.

While Dark Souls 1 might always be my favorite, Elden Ring felt like the culmination of over a decade of design choices since Demon's Souls. This might be the best gameplay experience they've created to date.

If an advanced alien race arrived on Earth today and asked me what a video game is and why we love it so much, I would show them Elden Ring.
YES
I finally started to get into Elden Ring these past few weeks. I'm a souls fan but for whatever the reason Elden Ring when I got it back in Dec 2022 just didn't click for me possibly due to every game wanting to be open world and time constraints. 

I beat the Tree Sentinel and saw how big the world was looking and felt like I wasn't going to really have time to sit and play this consistently yet especially with Tears of the Kingdom releasing a few months later in May which same problem there but I'm a big Zelda fan so I know I would prioritize it.  

Some coworkers talked about it a bit before Hogwart's Legacy came out in Feb 2023 and just hearing the encounters excited me, but this was a more open world experience than prior Souls games I had played. Played a bit more beat Margit and Godrick between FFXIV patches and before I knew it ToK was here so I shelved it.

Well when they announced the expansion for Elden Ring I knew I had to try again. So I picked it back up and thanks to my raiding friends I was able to get back on track the past two weeks and figure out what I was doing.
 
As of 05/11/24 I have beaten it, and I can happily say the game finally clicked for me and I'm having a blast. I stumbled into a lot of quest progression and found I had encountered situations that some friends have never seen or found and it just reminds me why I love the Souls games. So much lore and hidden things in them. Even more so since this is a more open world take than any game prior. I think I still prefer the more Metroidvania perfectly crafted set pieces of games prior, but the exploration and discovery is top tier in this game. I was able to see all the endings, but chose to go with Ranni's on my first playthrough. I had everything necessary to see all of them. Those Who Live In Death's, Normal, Golden, Dungeater's, Frenzied Flame,  and as mentioned before Ranni's. What a incredible experience. Can't wait for the DLC.
good game

I die and I cry. I keep playing idk why.
First off I really really like Elden Ring. The world is beautiful, and its inhabitants are equally gorgeous from their mannerisms to their movements. I've always really liked video game products that provide a challenge and something about never being able to turn down the difficulty or stop the relentlessness makes the challenge gratifying. 

I do have some complaints.
Some fights are absolute jank, really anytime the game throws multiple enemies at you at once 
The world itself doesnt feel very connected. There are cargo trains that dont seem to go anywhere, full castles built seemingly for no one, that rather then real life installations seem like just stages for bosses. 
Dungeons are built and the game is played in a manner where its generally bad to fight things and your better off running past everything until u reach the boss room. 
Its super hard to level up, and your often forced to focus on leveling certain things. Iv gone thru most of my playthru only leveling vigour and intelligence with minor points spent in other skills. This make individual runs more diverse but doesnt allow me diversify my weaponry significantly from boss to boss.
The guy who decided to combine sloulslike and open world deserves a promotion

This game is really fun. I looked a lot of stuff up online because it can be discouraging to be stuck on a certain area or boss. Certainly a learning curve, but I really appreciate the worldbuilding and content the game has. There is a lot of player freedom and things to discover, and you can change your build many times (as I did) with larval tears. No shame in using summons or magic. Play the game how you want. Just make sure to touch grass every now and then. I am 86 hours in and have done every major area except 4 endgame bosses.

dont play this if you want to be able to enjoy other games
This game isn't just a game, it's a journey.  A long journey, fraught with trial and tribulation.  Frustration and doubt.  Triumph.  Moments of quiet solitude.
It affected me.

It's not for everyone, and all play styles are valid.
But I'll warn you, to truly PLAY this game, you'll have to let go of the notion that death is bad.
Failure is nothing more than an opportunity to try again.  To learn from your mistakes.  Mistakes will happen.  Sometimes it's fair, and sometimes it's not, but that's life.

Again, it's not for everyone, but I don't regret a minute spent on this game (except maybe the valiant gargoyles, I'm not alone in that).

I'm sure I don't need to tell you this game is absolutely gorgeous.  The music phenomenal.  The designs often wildly creative and awe-inspiring.
I don't need to tell you that it manages to be one of the best open worlds despite being Fromsofts very first.
And I certainly don't need to tell existing fans of Fromsoft titles about the nature of Soulsborne combat.  They know it better than I do, seeing as this was my first of it's kind.  At time of writing this, my only other experience is just past beating Ornstein and Smough in DS1. (after beating ER)  I see why so many love that fight.

But this is a review for Elden Ring, so I'll stay focused on this game.

Lastly, before you enter this world, there's a few more things you need to know.
1. Don't attack the guy who calls you maidenless.  You can kill him later if you really want to, but trust me, you aren't ready. (he's got some good quest rewards too)
2. Bladd is best boy.
3. Hewg deserves all of the love.

Now, rise, ye Tarnished.  Rise and journey to stand before the Elden Ring... and become the Elden Lord.
And don't you dare go hollow.
10/10 game
boowomp.
not that hard of a game, lightwork no reactionü•±
very hard but fun

nice game :3
First half of the game is enjoyable but after [spoiler] Mountaintops of Giants [/spoiler] there is a huge power spike on enemies, as they have lots of more health and damage. You might wonder if you skipped some "expected route" areas but the power spike is noticeable even when you explore most content available at that point of the game. After that area, enemies are scaling up faster than you can level up your own character and strong enemies start to come in packs. I have had those +2/+3 resistance amulets for magic and/or physical damage equipped but my health pool could have lasted only 3 hits instead of 2 but those number don't really matter on bosses when they can have 5-7 hit combos.

Huge bosses could be fine by themselves if the camera could be further away from the player character on those fights. Now you are mostly fighting against the camera and trying to predict attacks only from their audio queues. Some mandatory end game bosses also have immunity to many status effects or their threshold is very high which ruins a bit the RPG element of the game.

I have completed the game once, almost second time after 1.5 years from the launch but the end game experience is still the same, unfortunately. Going through areas at and after [spoiler] Mountaintops of Giants [/spoiler] still makes the game a chore to go through. On my second playthrough I lost all the interest to finish the final boss after fighting 2 mandatory bosses back to back.

I had the DLC on wishlist but not anymore, as I can see the player experience haven't improved on the main game through these years...

I love games with a happy ending. Full of joy that make me look at the world more positively. However, I am playing Elden Ring. All in all, after 300+ hours, I'm not complaining. But since the DLC is coming out soon, I'll ask for a happy ending for Blaidd. Best boy in ER deserves more!
Anyone who describes this game as story rich is a bald-faced liar. There's a lot of LORE (you know, in the background) but nothing approaching a cohesive story. The NPCs are dull, wooden, and uninteresting. Everything I love about RPGs has been haphazardly hacked off leaving only a bunch of unrelated boss fights separated by lots of pointless nothing. I went into this game with an open mind, having never played any of the original Dark Souls games and wanting to see what people loved about this formula. I was not impressed.

Let me just say, I absolutely love this game! It is incredibly fun, its got an AMAZING open world, enjoyable content, a story line, Ranni, and so much more! Some people may be hesitant to play the game due to its difficulty, but I will say this. Even though the game can be difficult, it doesn't have to be you can over level, get better weapons, get talismans, or call in someone else to do it for you. I do acknowledge that over leveling and gathering equipment can take time but there are ways to get millions of runes quickly very early on into the game, and you can always look up guides if you choose to, that's all to say, most challenges can be made less challenging if you choose to make it so.

yes
One of the best from-soft games, it is more fun multiplayer with discord unless you want the in depth lore experience. Would recommend to anyone that likes a challenge in the gaming world 11/10.
FromSoftware took all of the good ideas,mechanics and some of the content (weapons, skills, some npcs) of their other games, added much more of it, added an open-world, their best bosses yet, smart QOL features, a horse, a jump button and joined it all together to make this fine game.
It's their biggest, most epic and hardest Action RPG yet.

Pros:
- Giant fantasy world thats fun to explore and filled with tons of secrets (maybe to the point of it being detrimental)
- Subtle guidance throughout the world makes for puzzling navigation which amplifies immersion and non-combat engagement
- Refined gameplay, with much freedom of expression
- Massive enemy variety, with bosses being the highlights
- Beautiful art style and graphics
- Beautiful music, sound design and voice acting
- Clever integration of lore into gameplay mechanics
Cons:
- Not the best performance
- Some 'copy-pasted' mini-bosses and caves here and there

Apparently the story and lore are great, but you won't figure out much unless you go full nerd and read item description and replay the game 5 times.
The game is sometimes too subtle about guiding you, to the point of missing huge chunks of content if u didn't talk twice to an NPC or missed some random item or something. But i guess it also adds to the replayability.
The online features are interesting, it's the same old Dark Souls formula. I'd recommend leaving online mode disabled for first playthrough cause the messages are too distracting and can spoil you sometimes.

Every ring has its elden...once said a wise man named Harry
.
This has become my favourite game. It is almost perfect. I'd say it's the first game in many years that has given me the same feelings i felt when i first started playing video games. The game forces you to challenge yourself and face it's adversity. You will die, and you will fail. But you can always stand up and try again. And when you finally succeed, you feel an intense rush and a deep sense of satisfaction. The progression comes mainly from you getting good with the mechanics and reading of the enemies patterns but you do become stronger overall with the various material upgrades. Coming back to the first area with an endgame character makes you feel like you got stronger, not only in level but in skill too. The story is grandiose, melancholic, full of symbolism and isn't given to you. You have to search the world and interact with it to try to understand it. The story kind of becomes your story, as what you find and how you tend to see things generally will deeply influence your interpretation of it. The only bad thing i can say about this game is that the discovery aspect suffers on successive playthroughs. I wish i had a reset button so i could experience this game again for the first time. Thank you FromSoftware. Keep doing what you do.
The best
I do not like most open world games, a lot of the time it feels way too empty and soulless. The industry trend is to inundate you with countless collectables and systems to keep you playing constantly.

But Elden Ring is different. Sure there are some areas that feel a bit empty, not every location is as rigorously planned as their linear games, but it all feels good.

The world is beautiful, many times I would just vibe and look out at the environment. The combat is still just as good as previous games, but I personally feel that it's gotten better. I'm a simp for parries, guard counters are a fantastic addition that gives that "counter" feeling without as much risk.

I would go into more detail, but if anyone is interested in the game, I'd say just pull the trigger and play.

After 300 hours on both PC and console as well as completing every game in the soulsbourne series I can say this is the best one in the series. Truly a masterpiece from the game play and level design to the music and enemy/boss design. The lore is extremely in depth and it is a ton of fun to put the pieces together through dialogue with the NPC's and reading the item descriptions. Overall an incredible experience and something that I believe can only be improved through the addition of the Shadow of the erdtree DLC. Do yourself a favor and truly give this game a chance. [h1] A masterpiece, still standing tall in a sea of mediocrity and woke pandering [/h1]
[b]Behold, Megatron's Assessment of Elden Ring[/b]

Decepticons and Autobots alike, brace yourselves for an analysis of the revered masterpiece, "Elden Ring." In an era overrun by the mindless babble of woke AAA titles, and unlike the modern woke developers spreading an ideology that makes no sense in the eyes of true gamers, this 2022 gem stands resolute, a testament to true gaming artistry.

[h2]The Challenge of Mastery[/h2]

Elden Ring beckons warriors with a challenge unlike any other. It's not just about mastering mechanics; it's a test of sheer willpower. Prepare to face countless defeats, yet rise again, drawn by the allure of conquest and growth.

[h2]Exhilarating Combat[/h2]

In the crucible of combat, every move is a dance with death. The stakes are high as you strive to avoid the ultimate consequence‚Äîlosing precious runes. This currency fuels your journey, a constant reminder of risk and reward.

[h2]Vast and Inviting World[/h2]

Venture into a sprawling realm, ripe for exploration and conquest. Elden Ring offers an expansive landscape teeming with formidable adversaries and hidden secrets. Its enduring graphics elevate immersion, defying the march of time.

[h2]A Masterpiece Amidst Mediocrity[/h2]

FromSoftware's creation exemplifies the pinnacle of game development. Amidst an industry plagued by virtue-signaling and pandering, Elden Ring remains a beacon of excellence‚Äîan art form untainted by hollow agendas.

[h2]The Joy of Fellowship[/h2]

Unleash the full potential of Elden Ring by traversing its perilous domain with a trusted comrade. Together, the adrenaline-fueled adventure becomes even more exhilarating, forging unforgettable memories.

In the realm of Elden Ring, challenges abound, but so do triumphs. This is not merely a game; it's an odyssey‚Äîan epic that will endure in the annals of gaming history. Join the fray, and let the saga unfold.

[b] Megatron, out [b]

Shing Shing Shing, Bonk, Pew Pew
I was not a Souls player at first, I actually hated it. I didn't really have the patience to learn attack patterns or even had the attention span for an open world. However, after playing a smaller Souls-like game that was smaller/linear that I really enjoyed, I learned patience and decided to give Elden Ring another try (especially after seeing the DLC trailer). Now I'm at 250+ hours, 3 characters in, and I'm still craving for more.

If you're patient, willing to learn attack patterns/play smart, and enjoy a diverse open world, this is THE game. Can't wait to try the other Souls-borne/Souls-like games out there after this.

ive heard more "i am malenia, blade of miquella" than anything else this year
Elden Ring is maybe the best game I've ever played. The game can be hard for less experienced players, and death should be expected. But there's always somewhere else to go if you feel under-leveled. Be aware that the story is very obscure. Much is either environmental storytelling or found in item descriptions. And there's a deep rabbit hole to go through if you want to understand it. But that's probably why so many love this game. Unlike other modern games, Elden Ring rarely holds your hand. There's no sidekick repeatably saying where you should go and what you should do. Just follow the guidance of grace, explore and fight until you become the Elden Lord.¬†

LITERALLY PERFECT. Never played a souls game before this and my life is forever altered by this game. This game is filled with the love and dedication of every artist, developer, writer, actor, and everybody else who worked on it. It is a masterpiece of game design, storytelling, world-building, and visual-auditory art. I played around 250 hours of the game on Xbox One, before playing it here, and the only problem I have with the game is that it suffers from some optimization issues. Regardless, these issues rarely rear their head. Amazing game, I'm begging Miyazaki for more.

I think that this is a fantastic game that I will definitely sink more time into, especially with the dlc around the corner.

I do have to say though, that the fact that sprint and roll are bound to the same button input no matter what is extremely stupid. I know there's probably a game balance reason for it, but it makes learning how to dodge in this specific game, more of a chore than other games, because your dodge input only goes through after you release the button, and also only going through if your input was short enough to not start sprinting. This leads to rolling feeling unresponsive/delayed when you start playing the game for the first time, which just causes frustration and probably leads to more players getting "filtered" than otherwise would have been, all because of a poor design choice. I may hate Destiny 2, but the fact that it deals with keybinds better than Elden Ring is kinda disappointing.

Fun game with great graphics and engaging combat
The idea of open world Dark Souls was exciting to me. Unfortunately, this was better as a concept than in implementation. The maps really needed another pass by a heavy handed editor. This should mean that I liked the mini dungeons, but the tombs and mines were poorly designed as well, feeling repetitive after the first one. Additionally, many of the enemies are repetitive and, worse, are less creative than previous games. None of this compares to the excellent layout and creativity of OG Dark Souls.

Do not fall for the hype. Elden Ring, while a decent game, is nothing special. It really feels like the B team phoned this one in.

There's a very large audience for this game, and i'm not going to call this game bad, but I definitely wouldn't recommend it to anyone who is new to the souls like category like I am. This game isn't fun at all. I struggled so hard with the first two hours of playing it, that I don't even want to know what the rest of the game is like. The difficulty of the enemies is way too hard for just having stepped out of the tutorial cave.  I feel like maybe the first enemies you fight should maybe be easier to ease you into the game instead of 100% difficulty right off of the bat. The game doesn't give you one single quest marker, no idea where to go or what to do. The only people who like this game, hate themselves because I can think of many better games to play, and uses of my time. Hopefully I can get my money back. I would definitely recommend you to stay away from this title unless you want to spend hours learning random enemies combos so that on the 100th attempt you can finally kill them, and then gain nothing from it.

At first, I had no idea what to do, or where to go, and the game did not really explain much but dam once I got into the lore and understood the basics I really started to enjoy the game.  I was afraid that game would kick my ass and nuts with one kick and slap me across the face 4 times, but fortunately, I was wrong, the game is decently hard but not annoyingly hard like running across half a map after dying to a boss just to fight and die to him again. Sure there are a few things that piss me off like not being able to pause the game,  not being able to keybing everything, like why did you force me to have a map on G? Just why? But still very enjoyable, with AMAZING scenery and nature, a lot of hidden stuff, great weapons, and just EVERYTHING i mean I could sit here for another 10 minutes saying how all of the stuff this game has is great and well made. I was/am pretty new to Soul-like games. Prior to this, I had a partial run of Dark Souls 3 (as a Pyromancer) and I gave up because I couldn't "git gud". So instead I got this game to play co-op. with the hope that maybe playing with friends would ease the pain of Soulsborne games "tough but fair" vibe. 

My first playthrough was spread out over years of casual play, here and there, when no one was online to play other games. So when I finally sat down to beat this game, something weird happened. After I had slayed the final boss and saw the credits roll, I actually wanted to play more! My thoughts must've been something like: "wait.... souls games are actually beatable? lol" 

This game is amazing and I'm surprised how deep I fell into it! And I'll definitely get Shadow of Erdtree when that drops. In the meantime, I think I'll give Dark Souls 3 another shot! :)

GO(A)TY
oh, dog
This game was obviously a wild success based on sales and popular reviews. However, despite my best effort and roughly 8 hours of game time, it just doesn't seem to hold my interest. The biggest killer for me is the rapid respawn rate of just about every mob in the game. It makes me feel as though my presence in the virtual world has no lasting impact and therefore feels completely meaningless. The RPG genre has always been my favorite, and I'm an explorer and a completionist, but if everything I discover respawns or resets to the exact state it was in before I discovered it, then what's the point? The whole experience feels hollow and lacks depth. The world may be huge and there may be a plethora of content, but if my actions and choices don't have a lasting impact on the world around me then it all seems pointless.

I also find the inability to save whenever I choose to be particularly annoying. And the floating ruin fragments and other glowing items feels a bit too old-school platformer for my taste. I need enough realism in my RPG games to achieve a greater suspension of disbelief to facilitate a truly immersive experience. The Elden Ring story does not even attempt to explain a lot of the mysticism. Harry Potter is an example of a pretty wild fantasy series (one which I love), but it all comes together to create a fantastic story because it's all explained in a way that I can accept.

I think perhaps it's just the souls-games in general that simply are not my cup and tea. I'm a huge fan of the Gothic, Elder Scrolls, Dragon Age, Two Worlds, Elex, Baldur's Gate, and Fallout series RPGs, to name a few, but Elden Rings is simply too wildly different from what I've come to love about the genre.
10/10
I jumped into Elden Ring hoping to get what all the hype was about, especially since I've heard so much about Dark Souls. But man, it's been tough trying to love this game. Let me break down why I think it's not living up to the buzz.

Let's start with the controls‚Äîthey're just... ugh. Slow, clunky, and unresponsive. And why can't we customize them? Who came up with using 'g' to open the map and 'q' to close it? It's just weird. Plus, the 3rd person camera and auto-lock during fights which led me straight into death more times than I'd like to admit.

And don't get me started on the tutorial‚Äîor lack thereof. How am I supposed to know how to do basic stuff like two-handing a weapon or casting spells? And why doesn't the game tell you important things like not being able to swim or the need to exhaust all dialogues? Playing Elden Ring is a wiki reading simulator, which is weird for a straightforward game. 

Elden Ring's difficulty should arise from thoughtful game design that provides fair challenges instead of relying on arbitrary obstacles to provoke frustration. 

I think there's a problem with the game's design as it doesn't mesh well with the idea of an open world. Open worlds should evoke a sense of wonder, mystery, and adventure, drawing you in with captivating stories and characters. Elden Ring punishes you for exploring too far off the beaten path, making it a headache to regain lost progress. The story and characters are boring. NPCs speak in cryptic riddles, other players will make finger and butt jokes. The world doesn't provide you with a lot of interesting items, stories, or anything else than bosses for you to kill.

Graphics are also really weird and remind me of the horse drawing meme. There are some beautiful sceneries with good lighting, or monsters that look great. And there are elements that look like they were made 20 years ago.

However since the game receives a lot of praises and sold many copies I'm probably wrong and this game is just not for me.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, I really did. 

Turning Dark Souls into a an open world game was the biggest mistake Miyazaki has ever made. The combat is fun, but the exploration part is incredible shallow and boring. The open world approach completely kills any sense of progression, so unless you follow an online guide you're gonna end up either underlevelled or overlevelled for the boss of any given location, which throws out all the balance and fun of fighting bosses out of the window.

That being said, the unique legacy dungeons are amazing and interesting to explore, which is ever so bitter because you need to plough through a bunch of trash mobs riding a horse through vast empty fields with an occasional dragon copypasted from location to location.

Hated this game! 10/10
Initial Appeal:
The game starts off with a bang, throwing you into exhilarating boss challenges one after another. However, this excitement quickly fades as you're forced to endure an excruciating 4000 hours of tedious running or riding just to reach a mere 5-minute boss fight.

Frustrating Exploration:
To make matters worse, the game's progression is hindered by an infuriating mechanic that requires you to repeatedly roll against walls to unlock additional paths. This not only disrupts the flow of the game but also feels like an unnecessary chore.

Repetitive and Uninspired Bosses:
Despite boasting over 200 boss fights, the game fails to deliver on its promise of epic encounters. Only a handful of these bosses stand out as truly memorable, while the rest are relegated to the status of forgettable trash mobs.

Unnecessary Travel:
The game's poorly designed map further exacerbates the problem of tedious exploration. The lack of clear visual cues and intuitive navigation forces players to waste countless hours aimlessly wandering around, adding another layer of frustration to the overall experience.

A Very good action game. not so good of a soulsborne game. unbalanced dmg output / boss hp. poise break every 4 hit.  overused boss attack patterns. Goated game
Though I think the hype around Elden Ring Was, (And still is), Justified. My experience with this being my first souls-like title was great at times, and unpleasant at others. My biggest issue is the balancing. I think them making this type of game in an open world setting makes it hard to balance the bosses because of the potential power you missed out on or having to much power. Most bosses are either laughable easy with summons, or impossible difficult without them. That makes it hard not to just say fuck it and summon on all the bullshit bosses the game throws at you. A truly amazing open world game.
If youre a masochist then this is the game for you. All jokes aside, this is by far one of my favorite games of all time. I have over 200 hours on my play-station account and just recently started playing again with a friend whos never played

For the new players to the souls franchise: This game is hard, you will die, you will fail. But once you start understanding the basic mechanics (dodging, attack timing etc) you will be fine. This game is meant to be hard, but finally overcoming whatever obstacle in your way is very rewarding. Build your character, kill the bosses, have fun with it! 

There is nearly endless amount of content to pursue. Endless spells, incantations, swords, axes, hammers, armor sets and more. Tons of NPCs that give you quests which in turn can lead to new areas of the map, new bosses and weapons that you wouldnt normally find.

This is your adventure. Arise now, ye Tarnished, ye dead who yet live. Destroy those who stand in your way. And CLAIM YOUR THRONE

‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á‡πÜ ‡∏ú‡∏°‡∏ô‡∏∂‡∏Å‡∏ß‡πà‡∏≤‡∏ä‡∏≠‡∏ö Dark Souls 3 ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏™‡∏∏‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏•‡πâ‡∏ß ‡πÅ‡∏ï‡πà‡∏û‡∏≠‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏≠ Elden Ring ‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÑ‡∏õ ‡∏°‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏¥‡πä‡∏Å‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ñ‡∏π‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏∏‡∏Å‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠
The best, most full fledged and accomplished game of this video game era, by a mile

By bringing narrative to new heights, and introducing a masterfully crafted open world design to the already accomplished dark souls action rpg franchise, Elden RIng has given us the pinnacle of game design, and the building stone for what we can only hope of has yet to come
Once you play this game it will ruin all other games for you.
This game changed my life
very good
Not a terrible game, but still majorly disappointing.

Major Pros:
- The game looks great, both graphically and aesthetically.
- Level design is quite good, referring specifically to the so-called "legacy dungeons" (bounded areas that behave more like traditional Soulsborne levels).

Major Cons:
- The open world of Elden Ring is a mixed bag. Nothing about it is revolutionary, despite what "mainstream" reviews may suggest. It is decently implemented, but nothing more. Some parts of the game benefit from this approach, while others suffer. Most of the world simply feels bloated and repetitive, with a great deal of space taken up by bland mini-dungeons and gratuitous re-use of bosses (even some major plot/lore bosses are inexplicably re-used throughout). The choice to make this game open world was a net negative, in my opinion.

- Boss design is... questionable, at best. The worst excesses of Dark Souls 3 have been amplified ten-fold in Elden Ring, with bosses so fast and unfairly punishing that they effectively invalidate all but the most powerful/meta of builds. The problem is mainly that the core gameplay of Soulsborne games has not been significantly improved upon since (arguably) Dark Souls 3, meaning that weapon characteristics and arts have to take up the slack. This game desperately needs a new system to master: something akin to Sekiro's parry system, perhaps. Alas, the only notable addition to this game is the ability to jump, and while that is a genuine improvement, it is far too little to keep up with the huge changes in boss and enemy design.

The end result is that Elden Ring feels more interested in build viability, rather than mechanical mastery. If you don't mind looking up meta builds on YouTube, then you may very well still enjoy this game. But in my opinion, Elden Ring is a huge step in the wrong direction. Hopefully we will see more effective innovation in FromSoft's next game.
GOOD, BUT VERY ANOYING BUT GOOD

Elden Ring is a triumph of fantasy and gameplay, blending FromSoftware's signature challenge with an expansive, breathtaking open world. Every corner of The Lands Between offers new mysteries and brutal encounters, making exploration thrilling and rewarding.

Combat is refined, strategic, and unforgiving, ensuring every battle feels essential and exhilarating. While technical issues like frame drops occasionally surface, they hardly diminish the game's monumental achievement.

With its gorgeous landscapes, haunting soundtrack, and deep lore, Elden Ring isn‚Äôt just a game‚Äîit‚Äôs an adventure that reshapes the boundaries of action RPGs.

Verdict: A must-play for anyone craving a deep, challenging, and richly crafted world. Every step, every battle, every moment feels epic.

good game
noice
I'm not sure how to start, but here I go.

When the game came out, I downloaded the cracked version just to try it out on my old 3400G system. Didn't run well and looked ugly af with all the aliasing (trees and especially shadows looked really bad) so I deleted it. No, I do not blame the game; an old, antiquated iGPU can only do so much. Rather, I decided I'll play the game when I get a new PC.

Fast forward two years and now that I have a decent rig, I bought the game. I didn't even bother trying cracked again, because after all the memes, discussions, GOTY and hype surrounding it I knew it was going to be special. I was not wrong. Elden Ring is, and I [b] do not [/b] say this lightly, one of the best games I've ever played. I've played a decent number of games over the past two decades of my life, and it is easily in my top 10s. 

The story is excellent, but I'm afraid I can't say much without spoiling it. However, unlike most games it is not entirely spoon-fed to you through long, boring cut scenes. No, you're expected to peer into every single bit of lore scattered across the world and item descriptions and piece the rest of it together yourself. And after you're done, go to online forums and discussions to find out stuff you didn't even know was in the game. To me, this is the superior way to experience any narrative, where you're actively encouraged to research the greater lore yourself. Sounds tiring? Go watch a movie instead. 

Gameplay is simple, ironically, but the depth in mechanics across a very wide range of weapons and weapon customization per weapon makes it highly configurable. Every player thus has their own unique playstyle, on top of an already highly customizable character build. Bosses have frustratingly difficult movesets and often almost unfair advantages, but that is precisely what makes beating them so much more satisfying. Patience is key. Malenia is a very popular boss in the game, for all the right reasons, but there are so many more such memorable and hard bosses that most people don't hear about. Perhaps that's a good thing, so it remains a surprise for you. Besides that there are some puzzles, most not that difficult but some are so well hidden that you will be compelled to google after a while. And ofcourse, the age-old platforming. It's a lot more important in this game than you may realize; both for finding optional secrets and to solve puzzles. Admittedly I'm pretty good at platforming, so I haven't had that many accidental deaths, so your mileage may vary.....is what I'd normally say. What I mean to say is, if you don't like it, you're just bad at platforming. I'm not sorry. 

The audio design and music score are some of the best I've ever heard. Like a certain crack-induced YouTuber once said, normally music is not that important, but Elden Ring's is so good that it [i] becomes [/i] important. And that speaks volumes (okay I'll stop.) When out in the over world, you hear a subtle and eerie music that perfectly captures the atmosphere of a desolate, crumbling world in utter ruin. The battle themes on the other hand, especially during boss battles, make you feel like you're constantly in a David vs Goliath scene, which makes the pure feeling of euphoria when you've finally put them down all the more satisfying. The final battle theme in particular is legendary. They really outdid themselves with that one. 

The graphics isn't particularly jaw-dropping, but it isn't bad either. It is highly stylized, which particularly enhances the some of the most beautiful vistas I've ever seen in a video game. There are different places with their own unique, excellent architecture and thoughtful ruination to portray the state of decay and falling apart of the world, and the different environments having a unique color scheme was also a nice touch. The monster designs are what I'd call perfect depictions of Eldritch horrors.

Every little detail in the game oozes genuine effort, which I could never appreciate enough. Modern gaming sucks because most new games feel like soul-less (heh heh), lazy cash-grab experiences designed to pamper everyone and squeeze every last penny out of you first, and be fun and challenging to play second. Calling them "games" makes my skin crawl, so I made up a personal term for them - digital turd. Elden Ring is the exact opposite of a digital turd; it is a love letter to a forgotten era of gaming that used to be hard for the sake of presenting a challenge to the player, while simultaneously delivering a narrative, visual and auditory experience you will remember for decades, perhaps unto death. To the reader I may sound like I'm writing up a romantic thesis on a mere video game, but to me, it was just [i] that [/i] good. It absolutely deserves all the love I can give. 

Yes it is hard, as it should be, but also often not very clear about your next objective. I'd argue that is part of the game, because it encourages the player to explore and find their own path - that is the point of an open-world. There is no wrong way to play the game, you can clear most objectives at any time in no particular order. Admittedly, I had a friend help me out for the majority of the game, especially in guiding me on what to do next when I felt clueless. I don't have as much time to play games these days, so I was okay with a little guidance in place of doing my own due diligence. Regardless, I enjoyed every last moment of it. 

This goes into my "games worth playing at least once in life" list. Ironically, you do need to play the game at least 3 times if you want to get all achievements, but subsequent replays after the first get much easier so it's alright. And if I'm honest, I probably won't mind a replay or two of this masterpiece. 

It is more than just a video game, it is art. Can't wait for the DLC.
So good I bought it again after selling my Playstation. It's one of those games you can go without playing for a year and then suddenly get the urge to dive back in, only to somehow find you're having way more fun than you did the last time around.
Pretty Fun PagMan

With all that said, this game deserves all of the hype, praise, and love that people give it. Give me the option to safe them or don't), I don't like the ranged combat with the bow (it is clunky, the arrows cost too much in the beginning. You are not an archer, you are a melee fighter who can occasionally shoot arrows), I don't like the leveling system (seems bland to me) and I don't like how most of the stuff is not explained in the slightest. Some small text over some values wouldn't hurt. Nope, just Numbers going up.

Like I said: Probably not my game, had hoped it to be different. Will maybe try again after I cooled down a bit.

[h3]Let's start with the bad stuff:[/h3]
- Optimization is kinda poor
- 60fps cap, no DLSS/FSR, no fov slider (all solvable with mods)
- You need to install "seamless coop mod" for a coop experience that should have been in the vanilla game
- Story it's about getting bits here and there, no long cutscenes, in this department can't say I'm impressed, clearly the focus is the gameplay

[h3]The good parts:[/h3]
- The open world is great, lots of content, you can just lvl up around until you feel like you can defeat some specific monster. Easy to spend hours and hours exploring without realizing.
- The graphics and animations are great, not only that but the artstyle it's very diverse and beautiful
- Lots and lots of different enemies, all with their unique attack styles

[h3]TL:DR[/h3]
This is my first souls game, I knew it's gonna be challenging but it's a great game, punishing but rewarding

A game you simply must play.

I've made several attempts at the Souls-like genre, but unfortunately, I always struggled with it. I felt they were too difficult for me, and I didn't understand them. I couldn't grasp how people could praise a game where you constantly die without making any progress for hours on end. That is, until I played Elden Ring. It completely changed my perception of this genre.

After playing Elden Ring, you'll want to try more games of this type; you'll feel a sense of longing. The game has a fantastic atmosphere, breathtaking views, stunning graphics, and an intriguing story that you uncover yourself. As a player, you decide how to play and what to do; the world doesn't overwhelm you or force you to do anything you're not interested in. If you decide to purchase the game, you'll be enchanted by it.
Elden ring is my favourite game by far. Stunning visuals, memorable bosses, a beautiful and rich story, it's developed by FromSoftware.. What more could you want from an open world RPG game. For the love of god, please play this game!! 10/10 would defo recommend
difficult but satisfying

Elden Ring is arguably the best game in the series, delivering an expansive and fascinating open world that's a joy to explore. The landscapes are breathtakingly beautiful, truly some of the best visuals seen in gaming. Each area is packed with secrets and challenges that keep you engaged for hours. The bosses are a standout feature; they're brilliantly designed and offer a tough but fair challenge, although a few do repeat throughout the game. Devs really nailed the climactic feel with the last two bosses‚Äîboth feel like true final bosses and provide a satisfying end to an epic journey. I enjoyed Elden Ring so much that I couldn't stop until I had unlocked all the achievements. It's a masterpiece that's not to be missed.

hard
Elden ring is a game that is an oddity to me due to the fact that on paper, it should have passed the next-gen test with flying colors.

I had a friend come over and look at the game, and he told me that the game in 8k resolution does look like a PS2 game. I don't even know why this resolution did this to this game as the game is usually highly regarded.

However, playing many other games from Bandai Namco, this seemed to be the only instance where their game did not pass. I think the suggestion is to just keep it at 4k, and build a new game with a mindset for 8k resolution once the game has reach the development stage.

Though I cannot recommend this game, it's still close to almost being 8k resolution.

I've played this to 100% on three different platforms. It's incredible. In my humble opinion, it is FromSoftware's magnum opus. They might be able to outdo it in the future, but they certainly haven't produced something quite like this before (though Bloodborne comes close for me).

It's got plenty of aids to help you if you're struggling, but you can also make it extraordinarily difficult if that's the experience you're going for. The exploration is curated and while some locations and bosses are overly repeated, there's enough content for 4 games here, but it's all handcrafted.

Elden Ring Is The Greatest Game Of All Time. It's a world filled with Art, feelings, adventure, and indescribable experiences.
Great game. And it is also very big great game. Granted, it is achieved by repetition sometimes, but there is enough exploration and nuanced experiences besides that.

As it is a souls-like, my ratings on the garbage mechanics (the lower the better, on the scale 1..10).
Corpse-running: 4. 
Most bosses have revive point nearby, which still can be 50 meters away, but it is still closer then running from the grace. But most are not all, and there are pretty egregious examples of corpse-runs (like academia).
Losing consumables on death: 2.
You lose consumable if you die. But most consumables are pretty easy replenished by collecting resources, or are relatively cheap. There are some limited consumables, and arc, which are effectively limited in singleplayer. 
Parkour: 4
Game does have enough infamous DS parkour to it to be annoying, but most of it exists for additional exploration, and is not needed to end the game. Most content in the game consists of additional exploration, though.
Hitboxes: 3
There are some questionable hitboxes, but overall they are good.
Camera: 6
Somewhat expected of a game like this, there are time you fight the camera, not the boss. There are several places with bosses which do not really fit the room, leading to further problems with camera.
Fromsoft obsolete: N/A
Latest (at the date of this review) FromSoft game does not have mechanics, obsoleted by FromSoft.
Goated game, def play

strongly recommend this game for players who haven't been involved in the souls-like genre but are looking for a start!

first of all gorgeous graphics, environmental storytelling, and atmosphere. easily could take a stroll in the game for fun provided things were not capable of nearly instantly killing me if i am not too careful.

second, the gameplay is satisfyingly difficult. many mechanics, although not explicitly told, are beginner friendly! you have many options for npc support or online support. additionally, there are few obstacles that cannot be conquered by getting the base mechanics down and simply leveling up. additionally, leveling up is not difficult.

finally, the amount of resources and community built around this game is simply wonderful! provided there are toxic opinions but you can play entirely solo but refer to well managed wikis for directions!

Game of the year for a reason
I cannot stress enough, Elden Ring on paper is a really good game, and I love the closed, contained dungeons. Everything else kinda fucking blows. The open world adds basically nothing, crafting items is an irritating system that adds nothing but meaningless backtracking for even basic utility items, the difficulty feels like FromSoft is drinking their own koolaid, and the amount of copy pasted dungeons and caves... it just feels like a let down. Dark Souls has always been a series I enjoy, but Elden Ring is not what I'd recommend for anyone. The systems and combat are smooth, but it's just... not an enjoyable game to me. Cannot in good faith recommend it to anyone who wants an open world or souls-like games, as this is the game that ruined my enjoyment of them all.

75/100

[b]The Good[/b]
The game's beautiful, the world design is top notch. The fact that very early you can see places and landmarks that you'll be able to explore later on gives a sense of awe and adventure to the game. The combat is really good, with a lot of different common enemies, bosses and different mechanics.

[b]The Bad[/b]
Game's too long, a lot of dungeons that are exactly the same, a lot of enemies re-skins. Gets really boring if you're trying to complete everything.

[b]The Ugly[/b]
Most double bosses are poorly planned and annoying. The mechanic of weapons upgrades lock players with only trying a handful of weapons in a single playthrough. Why place some campfires or stakes of marika away from bosses, so players have to run through the same place a dozen times? That's poor game design.
This is the first RPG I've ever played that has replay value. I've played also of RPG's. Before playing Elden Ring my bench mark for the best RPG was The Witcher 3, now Elden Ring take the first spot.
This game is a beautifully stunning masterpiece and playing through it is a magical experience. 
Super excited for Shadow of the Erdtree.
This is my first souls-like game in a good few years, and the game is very fun. 

The combat can be hard and frustrating at some times but the reward from killing a hard enemy in the form of dopamine is really, really great. I would recommend it to people who want to up their skill in games, but also for the world building and lore. It's a fantastically crafted "Open-World". Each zone has it's very own unique atmosphere and the music is so good.

A must for souls fans
I swear i pressed dodge
Elden Ring is a masterpiece that stands tall as the ultimate evolution of FromSoftware's renowned Dark Souls series. The game seamlessly merges the rich lore, atmospheric world-building, and intricate combat mechanics that fans have come to adore, expanding them into a vast open-world that feels both fresh and familiar. The Lands Between is a breathtaking realm, filled with hidden mysteries, formidable foes, and awe-inspiring landscapes that beckon players to explore every corner.

The combat retains the tight, responsive feel that made Dark Souls so satisfying, while adding new layers of complexity with the introduction of horseback combat and magic systems that encourage experimentation. Elden Ring‚Äôs story, co-crafted with the brilliant mind of George R. R. Martin, brings a deeper narrative that is woven into every character and location, rewarding those who delve into its depths.

What truly sets Elden Ring apart is how it builds upon the legacy of Dark Souls, refining and expanding the best elements of its predecessors while pushing boundaries to create something wholly unique. It is not just a game; it is an experience that captures the essence of adventure, challenge, and discovery, inviting players into a world that will be remembered for years to come.

Eldben Ring
Brilliant fucking game, but unfortunately you CANNOT sex the dung eater, so im very dissapointed >:(
I thought I was aging out of my desire to play videogames. Years ago this game made me love gaming again, so I feel compelled to write a review since I'm about to start a new playthrough.

This game was my first soulslike. The fact of it being open world was a draw to me so I decided to give it a try. Due to being in the process of moving and a few other things, I never actually finished it when it first came out years ago, but I still think about it. This game is the most fun I've had since RDR2, to this day. 

Remember when you were a kid and all you could think about was coming home from school to play that, in your mind, "perfect" game? It's all you could think about, time would go slow, and you just couldn't wait. It's a feeling we all, as adult gamers chase & try to find in games nowadays. Well, that's this game for me. This is the only game to give me that feeling as an adult. 

If you're new to soulslike games like I was, give it REAL chance, be open-minded, and embrace the difficulty you're likely not familiar with. It;s going to be tough and you're going to die a mega fuck ton, but it makes it all the more worth it in the end. It will be one of the most rewarding gaming experiences you'll have ever had.
very good and challenging game.
^-^

game ez if you have brain and not follow dumb builds from online.
9.5/10 - Amazing and emmersive experience - beautiful gfx/world/designs overall, super fun combat and the progress through the game feels rewarding and worthwhile/needed to complete the game(at least as a new player to SOULS-games as a whole. The only reason i'm not giving this a 10/10 is imo, the lack of a need to replay they game. I started on a NG+ after completing it the first time, but around 10+ hours into it, I simply got "bored"/uncompelled to go on. The reason why, is still super hard for me to determine, as I e.g. have replayed a game like BG3 4 times, even tho that's also somewhat of a similar experience. A guess would be that classes etc. are fairly "similar" and simple in terms of the only thing u actually change, is main weapon(+enchants if using those) and your stats. Armors are partly just cosmetic but are ofc also changeable, for a slight bit of phyc or magic proctection. Theres nothing more complicated to it, whereas in BG3(tho very different games altogether) offer both a lot of narrative/story changes, as well as super complex characterbuilding, with multiclassing/gear combos/spell interactions+works interactions etc - all of it also set is beatiful sorrouncindgs as with Elden Ring. 

Regardless of everything mentioned above, Elden Ring is a gamechanger and 120% worthy of the excessive amounts of GOTY awards etc, it has recieved since release! I can't wait for the DLC to come out, to once again dive into that first-time exp of gettin destroyed, and destroy, new bosses with great combat and in magnificient settings. 
Thank you for this game, From Software!
/Hasufer
Let me Solo him. Need I say more?
A true masterpiece with very little in the way of issues to subtract from its greats. My main gripe was that 90% of the rewards i found/earned while exploring weren't relevant to my build, such as getting 100 different ash summons, 200 different spells and 50 niche talismans that i couldn't ever use (ran a strength build). Despite this, the world, world-building and boss fights were unforgettable - an 11/10 experience. There's only a few games that I've ever been as invested in.

1. the one who just runs away or runs to an open world boss
2. The one that actually wants a fair fight
3. The one who has end game gear and one shots you

Great improvement from Dark Souls 3 when it comes to graphics, stability, and convenience. The bosses weren't as fun, but that's probably because the bosses are more intricate and are better at beating you. Balancing is a bit off, where if you spend a lot of time exploring, you get overpowered and every boss becomes easy. But that's fine since not everybody will do that. This is definitely the most accessible Souls game.

Invading is pretty hard though. DS3 skills don't transfer over well. Make sure to hit L2/LT more often.
Definitely try it!

The masterpiece of masterpieces.
Souls but... Horse.
It's not openworld Dark Souls. It really is its own thing.

While not being my favorite Fromsoft game, Elden Ring is a masterpiece of worldbuilding, exploration, art direction and complexity. It's the most accessible fromsoftware input in the Soulslike genre, but it's also the most expansive. There is so much build possibilities, so much stuff hidden, so much craziness all around it's really hard not to find something you'll like, from its satisfying combat system to its lore, characters and exploration. 

However, one playthrough and a half later, I still think that the last third of the game is its weakest part. Nonetheless, it's a remarkable game deserving of your attention.
This game lets me punch things and customise my character. I like that in a game.
A solid 9/10. Definitely among the best I have played.

First Souls game I've finished and it was incredible. Gonna be revisiting this game for years. Truly epic, with nearly endless replay value. The sense of exploration, wonder, and growth are top notch. An all-time favorite for me.

 Enjoyment-pilled and fun-maxxing
Elden Ring is a masterpiece. 
From the hauntingly beautiful atmosphere to the breathtaking graphics, every moment feels like stepping into a painting brought to life. Its vast, open world begs to be explored, each corner teeming with secrets and wonders. 
The bosses are epic battles of skill and strategy, each encounter providing a perfect balance of challenge and reward. 
After clearing all available content as of this review, Elden Ring stands tall as my favorite among all souls games, a testament to its unparalleled brilliance.

This is a good game BUT it's not optimized for PC at ALL. Controls are wonky, keybinds are not customizable, and the game crashes like a blind woman driving drunk at night on an icy road in a blizzard.  I generally hate games that are ports to PC, and while I certainly don't hate the game it's very frustrating and aggravating that controls and gameplay are so counter-intuitive...and that's not even commenting on the difficulty of the game, which is high by design.

If you're a fan of the souls games you'll love Elden Ring. Huge map countless locations to explore, beautiful map design too. Amazing game
Elden Ring is Elden Ring.
The world of The Lands Between is vast and filled with challenges, but it's also a place where connections are forged and courage is found. This is not a game to just go and speed-run all the way. This game is meant to enjoy every small steps and to look for every single details and hidden adventures here and there. I am glad I deep-dived and went for the 100% trophies.
This isn't just an adventure; it's a testament to the power of perseverance. A true Wonder in Modern Gaming. And as the credits rolled, I realized : I might not get to play something as extraordinary in gaming for a long time in the future now. The world of Elden Ring grabs you, holds you tight and makes you wonder. I don't know how will Fromsoft reach the height of this game again with another IP. I just know, I won't get to enjoy something as remarkable as this in gaming, possibly for a long long time.

Best game ever. Just wanted to give my thumbs up
The difficulty is really off putting to a lot of people, and so is the aimlessness that you feel at the start. There are no questlines to follow, and no exact direction to go to, to progress. But please just push through it. You won't understand anything for the first 10 hours but once you get a hang of the mechanics and controls, you'll really start enjoying it and its so incredibly rewarding. If you feel like you're stuck on a boss, leave it, and try the next day. Don't know what to do? Just run around trying to find caves or dungeons or bosses. Trust me, its a fantastic game. Give it a chance

Elden Ring is my first soulslike game and it presented great challenges right from the beginning. For someone like me, who was new to this genre, Elden Ring initially felt like a huge effort with little enjoyment in the actual gameplay. However, as time went on, and I improved, the fun factor continually increased. The beauty of the game world, the music, the boss fights, the lore behind it, and so much more, make me confidently say that it is probably one of the best games released in recent years, and I am eagerly looking forward to play the new DLC!
Simply put, it's a masterpiece from gameplay to the environment, music, everything about it is fantastic!

Firstly, so far, the hype is completely warranted.

However, if you run an ultrawide monitor and this is important to you, I do not recommend the game. Big black vertical bars will dominate the screen. I understand the "competitive advantage" UW supposedly gives but I play single player and wish I had known about this limitation and poor choice of implementation before purchasing, so am leaving this review to advise others. 

Even some appropriate game artwork in place of the bars would be an easy but acceptable fix.

good
What can be said about one of the greatest video games ever made?

It's hard as hell, rewarding as hell, and you'll get lost in the world for days on end.
They did a lot of things right. The creators really did an amazing job with he world building and atmosphere. The weapons are interesting and diverse. Some of the characters were likely, though maybe not as much as ds1 or ds3. My issue was the boss fights. Honestly this is completely my opinion, and maybe I should just get good, but I have a 120+ hours in this game, and perhaps twice that in other games, but every boss felt a little bs. The game made me so pissed I nearly screamed at the top of my lungs at 11 at night while the house was asleep. Every boss had this delayed attack mechanic that throws you off. After the first time its just a skill issue, but after the fourth time, it just gets annoying. The bs bosses that stuck out to me were Radagon (whatever his name is), Melania(of course), and Magma Wrym. Honestly Magma Wyrm wasnt that bad, I just needed to adjust, but Radagon had some stupid hit boxes and final phase was just keep away. 

Melania's heal is annoying but not game breaking, but her flurry of blades makes me want to kill myself. You'll be doing good, second phase, then she pulls it out of her ass, and there is nothing you can do, hope you're at full health with a vigor of 50. She also can just stun lock you so you cant dodge. I'm aware she is designed to be hard, but it feels more unfair than difficult. I'm playing at 146, 45 vigor, 20 endurance, and maxed weapon + max lv mimic and she still bends me over. In short, games a buy, if you like a challenge and cool scenery.
Gwynevere's fat tits, and fat tits in general, are absent from this game.
They missed the perfect opportunity too.


Please Miyazaki, rectify this, and also let us wear the deathbed companion panties without getting banned.

:) Im Malenia Blade Of Miquela
Try finger,
But hole
....

Beyond the poor optimization, reskinned enemies, trippy dialogues with NPCs, frustrating dragon battles for a melee user and the anger inducing input mapping, Elden Ring is a beautiful game which makes me wanna "git gud". Every boss I beat feels rewarding after the amount of tries it takes. I believe I am not even midway through the game but the secret to finish / enjoy this game is to never give up. 
The lore is enchanting if you carefully pay attention to the dialogues. 
I absolutely love the open world feature but maybe giving some outline of the main quests and side quests just to see the progression and if I am missing something would have been really helpful instead of trying to figure out hints from dialogues. 
There's a lot of negatives but I would recommend this game. If you are a masochist then this game is definitely for you.

Very easy
For me this is the best open world game I have ever played. It took what was great about Skyrim (if you can see it you can go there, create your own story and play through it the way you want) and amps it up x10. The art style, vistas, world design, level design are on another level. It really is a dark fantasy world come true.

 Another thing I like is they give you the tools to make this game work whatever way you want it to. If you want to play online and get that experience, you can, or just go offline and avoid the hints....and the invaders (which is the way I like to play by the way). You can touch all the sites of grace and never have to backtrack too much or don't touch them. You can summon spirit ashes to help your fights, or....not and make the fights more challenging. Plus the choice between all the different melee and magic styles. And Torrent is an amazing addition and a must for the way they designed the game!

  I just like the flexibility of getting to play the game the way YOU want to. I think it's great that it opens up FROM's style of game to people who didn't not normally play their games and hopefully will enable FROM to make even more epic games in the future.  

I am probably 3/4 of the way through the game because I search every nook and cranny of every area to find all the items because I like to collect all the gear. As far as the world and it's design and the epic vistas everywhere you look with all the secrets I have had more "wow" moments than any other game I have played. This game rewards you for spending the time to search every nook and cranny of it's world.
GOTY BTW

After 150+ hours on XB1, I now play it smoothly on Steam Deck. 

+ challenging and rewarding tactical combat: a soulslike power fantasy 
+ awesome replay value with amazing build options 
+ fun and reliable multiplayer (PVE and PVP) 
+ memorable boss fights and areas
+ cryptic lore set in a gorgeous vibrant world 
+ strong sense of discovery while exploring
+ solid music, sound and visual design
+ smooth transitions between open world and soulslike levels
+ many quality of life improvements to the soulslike formula
+ playful mockery of the player and community

This game is incredible.
good
Firstly, let me start off by saying, this game is as challenging as you want it to be. If you are a newer player, you can go about your first run with OP summons (essentially companions) and or OP weapons. This generally melts bosses quite quickly. Not to say that they are no longer challenging at all, but the things previously mentioned are definitely a lifesaver, that's for sure. If you feel that the game is too easy, go back and fight the bosses without summons, or over powered weapons. It feels good to beat a boss with those things, but there's something special about besting a boss with just pure instinct alone. Again, the game can be tailored to your liking and preferences. I recommend the interactive wiki map of Elden Ring if you get stuck, or are searching for specific items or bosses. Or just look it up on YouTube. Good luck!
Game is quite easy, i like it, wish bosses were harder though.

Malenia easy
The game runs poorly, with stuttering and dropped frames being very common. The only way to fix this is to disable the anti-cheat and play in offline mode. But then, you miss out on multiplayer and player messages, both of which are a large part of the experience. The game will also crash regularly. Gameplay wise, the default Fov is 35 which is almost unplayable. The only way to fix this is to install mods which can't be used online. Also 90% of the armor and weapons are just plain ugly. If you want to look like a badass knight like you did in Dark Souls then you are out of luck. Also very few weapons have unique movesets, for example almost all 21 greatswords have one of two movesets. This game lacks the polish and attention to detail the previous games had. You're much better off playing those games than playing this one, Dark Souls 3 in particular

5/5 Stars.
It is rare for a game to meet it's high expectations. It is another thing entirely to be better than anyone imagined possible. Elden Ring proves FromSoftware's mastery over creating the feeling of overcoming challenge. It allows one to express their own creativity in playing the game in so many ways, yet the system mechanics are so strong and refined that everyone in every scenario can succeed. It builds a dark fantasy world of gods and misery, knowing it has provided you, the player, with all the tools to overcome and succeed in this miserable world, whiles simultaneous allowing that success to be dictated and tailored to the way you prefer to express it.
Was fun until the difficulty got ridiculous, normally I am all for difficulty playing rain world, dead cells, AC6 but this is just a waste of potential. I know how fromsoft operates and their reasoning but this is just way to far, I mean only 20% of the people who bought the game could even beat it and they probably used meta and cheese. If that's what you need to be able to play a game then consider at least adding a difficulty slider or something. I expected to be a major challenge and to spend several hours on each boss but this is just sad.

It's not just the fight of killing in the gaming or other achievements, but it also shows how interesting each boss is and how VERY WELL detailed the game is. I would absolutely recommend getting this game. Also, what I find astonishing is that you can not only play by yourself but you are allowed to play with friends and go on a journey together throughout the game. Beat it to NG+3 on PS5 and then double dipped on PC to replay with ray tracing.

Elden Ring requires patience or skill. Easy mode is achieved by taking your time to explore every nook and cranny, leveling as you go. Hard mode, rushing through the game and taking on difficult bosses at low level. Both are there, but you either have to want a challenge or enjoy patiently picking apart the beautiful world piece by piece - which ultimately will lead to more skillful playing anyway. Dying is part of the adventure and really, if you collect your runes before dying again then there isn't even any punishment. Enjoy the risk, challenge, and adventure. If it's your first souls game there are always build guides. 

It's not a game that will hold your hand and gently walk you step by step and I love it for that.
very good game a masterpiece imo

From a new player perspective (new to souls-like games):

Well done and interesting world overshadowed by bad explanation of ingame mechanics and where to go, full of frustrating stressfull BS that is only there to waste your time. Its absolutely not beginner friendly in any way. Your getting run over by everything while fighting with the fumbling controls, changing stances, using different buffs and replenish your mana only to be fight ready, mid fight..

- f cheap ambushes and getting range attacked on "jumping puzzles" or ledges
- f delayed attacks
- f no grace period after entering a boss arena and getting instantly jumped by the boss
- f getting hit from outside the arena
- f running 30sec+ back to boss arenas
- f the lock-on system (especially on multi target fights)
- f losing all your progress while beeing bombarded with all above

I cant understand, why ppl love this game. After 19h played, i am left with a headache and broken controller. Now i have to buy a new one to continue.

Could this be Dog?
best.

New player to the Souls or Software games: I love this game, 10/10. 

Some Pros: 

Love the challenges that this game throws at me. Some bosses/enemies felt impossible, until you actually get good at the game. I heard a lot of people complaining about the toxic souls community, but their not toxic if their telling the truth right? If you can't beat any enemy in the game with your build, you are in fact bad and need to spend more time on the enemies. That's the fun part about any souls games, certain enemies feel impossible until you learn their attacks, then it becomes easier.

Love exploring the world and trying to find interesting items or embrace the gorgeous landscapes. I like finding hidden bosses, defeating them, and getting cool drops. I love learning how to fight all the different enemies that this game throws at me while I'm exploring.

Some annoyances:

Some of the larger enemies can just clip through walls when performing their attacks. This happens in a smaller arena and it makes it really hard for me to accurately dodge their attacks. Torrent can be really hard to manage and takes a lot of practice to some what control. Some attack combos feel impossible to dodge and I feel like you can't dodge or jump to avoid either close or instant death. I'm not 100% sure if some attacks are never to be "avoided", but I feel like that's not really the case. I would like if someone can confirm if some attacks are non dodge able. If so, I feel like that's not souls like. I would think every attack is dodge able if your good at the game. Not a big fan of the lock on mechanic due to me focusing on the enemy I'm fighting to be all of sudden targeting some random animal or another enemy that I didn't want to focus on. Most of these annoying points are just that, their annoying, but I can live with them.    

To be honest, I can't wait to finish my current "wizard" play through and do some type of melee focused character. I haven't seen most of the combat moves since my character focuses on range attacks. Can't wait to learn how to dodge new attack sets.
I died a few times (more than a few)

Good game alot better than Dark Souls 3(bad game) and Bloodborne(no one cares about this, it was a one off, and it sucked), but it is still not as good as Dark Souls 2.
It's awesome. Like, a really really good game. You can experience such a quality gaming experience with this one. We can go on for hours about how good this game is, but I am sure there I'd just be hashing things already said. I will keep short what I don't like:

1.) It does not work on ultra-wide screens without disabling achievements and mods. Wish it came built in, but FromSoftware just adds these black bars in. Something about fairness in PvP, whatever. Not a thing I like. (21:9 aspect ratio)

2.) There will be a point where it can drag along too long. I don't mind reused assets in large games, it makes sense. But there's a line and it's danced on with a little too much familiar enemies and maps (catacombs, mines). There's certainly enough new stuff along the way don't get me wrong. But the amount of times I was blown away at how large the map is got old when I was ready to end the game at the 100 hour mark lol.

Still really worth the experience. Can't wait for the expansion.

[h1][b]A Masterpiece Forged in the Flames of Ambitions[/b][/h1]


[b]FromSoftware has once again proven themselves as true artisans of the gaming world, and Elden Ring stands tall as their magnum opus. Every facet of this game is meticulously crafted, from the sprawling landscapes that beckon exploration to the intricate lore that weaves through every corner of the world.[/b]

One of the most striking aspects of Elden Ring is its sense of scale. The vast open world is a testament to the developers' ambition, offering countless secrets to uncover and challenges to overcome. Whether you're traversing the towering peaks of the Lands Between or delving into the depths of ancient ruins, there's always something new and exciting to discover.

But it's not just the world itself that captivates; it's the stories woven into its fabric. Elden Ring is a game that rewards curiosity, encouraging players to delve deeper into its lore and unravel the mysteries that lie hidden beneath the surface. Every NPC has a tale to tell, every item holds a piece of history, and piecing together the fragments of the past is as rewarding as it is engrossing.

[h3]Elden Ring is more than just a game[/h3] it's an experience. It's a testament to the power of storytelling, the beauty of exploration, and the joy of discovery. So if you're looking for a game that will challenge you, inspire you, and leave you breathless with wonder, look no further than Elden Ring. It's a journey you won't soon forget.
Very great game. Some areas can be challenging but every player can still progress given a little gumption. The possibilities of play style are fantastic, you can do literally anything you want for just about every aspect of this game.
Putting aside the nostalgia of older titles, Elden Ring is objectively the best game I've ever played, hands down! If you dislike this game, then you are the issue.

‚°à‚†Å‚†Ä‚£¨‚£ø‚£ü‚£ø‚£û‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢ª‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢ª‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢ª‚£ø‚£ø‚£æ‚£á‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢§‚£∂‚£æ‚£∑‚£ø‚£æ‚£ø‚¢ª‚£ø‚°ô‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ª‚¢æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£æ‚†°‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°á
