ELDEN RING: Where your worst enemy isn‚Äôt the bosses, but your own addiction to exploring every nook and cranny. It‚Äôs like Dark Souls and Breath of the Wild had a baby, and it‚Äôs a beautiful, chaotic mess of epic battles and getting lost in the woods. 10/10, would forget to eat dinner again.
Masterpiece
I could not even begin to describe how much this game made me cheer with triumph, scream with rage, stare in stunned silence, gasp in horror, grieve in despair, and more. . . This game is more to me than just another flawed FromSoftware masterpiece. It's quite possibly my most personal, and cherished Action Adventure Fantasy game I've EVER played in my life. Zelda was long dethroned by Dark Souls for me years ago, but this... THIS GAME has SO MANY uncanny coincidental personal overlaps with my life in allegorical form it gives me moments of sheer deja vu induced uncanny pause after pause. 

I don't know if anyone out there in the world has ever experienced anything so synchronous. . . 

I made a prophetess for my first character, and I pursued the flame of frenzy incantations because HOW the FUCK could I have passed up apocalyptic power fueled by the sheer madness and trauma of the collective suffering of not only myself but countless others?! AHHHHHHHH...MAY CHAOS TAKE THE WORLD! I thought... but then... I uncovered more things about this terribly tragically fucked up world... I discovered the duality of Marika/Radagon... I discovered Malenia and Millicent, I discovered Miquella... and their wretched state at the hands of Mohg... I realized VERY quickly I didn't want to burn it all away... that for the first time in FromSoftware history...that I could REALLY see myself in this game! Then Elphael... and the sheer pain and sadness of those losses... No... I cannot, and will not EVER burn all this away... no matter how painful it is to remember I will NEVER forget them... those who have came before, but are no longer with us... I WILL REMEMBER AS LONG AS I AM NOT HOLLOW! Also, there was nothing more epic in my life as who and what I am... and having so much of the world turn against you and people like you...only to discover that in this game one of the end bosses is like us too...but violently suppressing its fluid nature?! How fucking perfect that Radagon would be Marika, but obeying the oppressive greater will in the end... How perfect for someone like me that a Miracle Caster would be suppressing it's own female half violently... I had tried to do that... for far too long... Their self hate for their own red hair that I used to hate... that I would one day reclaim proudly and defiantly...

 I only wish I could have shown you these games in person when you were alive...but you're dead...and have been for a long time... no one remembers you but me...and I have no proof you ever even lived...but I know you did...I love you...and I miss you...forever.

It is a good game for those who are unfamiliar with the souls-like genre because it is not a very difficult game. There are many things to praise in the game, But here I will mention the missing parts of the game:
1-Story presentation is bad. It has a good story, but they didn't present the story well.
2-There is no quest log. It might seem as if NPCs don't give you quests, but in fact, they do provide quests and quest rewards. It's almost too difficult to complete NPC quests without using Google and Youtube. FromSoftware should pay attention to this now

I have a true love/hate relationship with Elden Ring. It's by far the most beautiful game I've ever played. I love the open world. As a PC gamer and used to MMO's like EQ where you basically  hit 'attack' and sit back, the combat learning curve for me was and still is difficult. I play on a keyboard but I feel like the game was designed to be played with a controller. Nearly all the video tutorials on YouTube give you the controller options when describing how to combat certain bosses or enemies. I've made it about 3/4 of the way through the game on multiple characters from pure magic user to tank to hybrid tank/incantation. I get to a point where the boss fights are just beyond my ability. My only chance is to out level the encounter by farming runes and watching cheese videos ad nauseam, and hope I get lucky. No matter how strong you are, many bosses can still one shot you. I get infuriated when I die because I'm stuck in an animation sequence and can't react. With all that being said I still enjoy the game immensely and will continue to play it, and recommend it to anyone looking for a beautiful but challenging game.

Sleep?

but Elden Ring!
good
The story for the game is excellent, the level design interesting.

The combat is terrible. You will regularly be killed through geometry, despite being unable to so much as damage through the same geometry. Sets of enemies will juggle you because their attack animations overlap in such a way that you can't roll away. Shields block damage, but ultimately are useless against boss fights. Most of the armor has no effect on your skills and minimal effect on your protection from damage, and the only real reason to change it is because you want to be able to medium roll. 

Having no quest log or real direction in the game is a stylistic choice, relatively unique, but having zero direction in where to go to finish side quests is more of a frustration than anything else. If someone is trying to avoid spoilers for how the game can end, looking things up on a wiki isn't useful.

Limiting the amount of times you can respec in a singular playthrough punishes buildcrafting, almost as much as the limited armor choices. So many weapons are useable, but only a handful are worth noting, and at a certain point they are prohibitively expensive to upgrade to try out.

Most of the later boss battles don't come down to your gear or skill with the game, they come down to taking advantage of the size of the boss and either doing as much damage as humanly possible in a short period of time, to cheese the encounter, or dying repeatedly trying to play defensively. The game gets boring when you realize there's approximately 10 builds capable of beating endgame content, and that you've invested 50 hours into a build that has stopped working entirely. Some bosses are so frustratingly strong that you're better off taking advantage of whatever broken mechanic there may be (as of time of writing, bleeding), going back to an earlier stage of the game, farming runes to upgrade the necessary equipment, and coming back to cheese the fight.

I kept going because I liked the story, and for a long time I was able to trudge through the combat- this is a Souls-like game right, it's supposed to be difficult. But this difficulty was and remains artificial, built into a combat system that doesn't work properly, gives unfair advantage to bosses, punishes innovation, all while often making you backtrack to boss battles, or run past enemies to find a site of grace so you don't have to run the whole section before you all over again. Is it better than simple bullet sponge enemies? Maybe. But it's kinda hard to hit something with a sword when it flips through the air 6 times and kills you through a pillar.
nice

Melania was a piece of cake. (ÔΩûÔø£‚ñΩÔø£)ÔΩû  (i got carried by random people)

first souls game i played, biggest psychological rollercoaster of my life
ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC GAME!
Elden Ring is an epic that redefines the boundaries of what an open-world RPG can be. It's a game that doesn't just captivate you with its story; it engulfs you in a world so vast and detailed that you can almost feel the grass beneath your feet and the chill of the wind as you traverse the Lands Between. The combat is fluid, challenging, and rewarding, with a depth that allows for a wide range of play styles. The lore is rich and woven into every aspect of the game, from the environment to the enemies and the cryptic dialogues with NPCs. Elden Ring is not just a game; it's a journey, an experience, and a masterpiece that deserves every bit of acclaim it receives. It's a game that stays with you long after you've put down the controller, and for that, it earns a resounding 10 stars out of 10.

hell yeA
Another Fromsoftwer masterpiece, up there with Bloodborne among some of the best games of all time.

I finished my first playthrough at around 80 hours, and they were some of the most fun, engaging and interesting I can recall in gaming. Elden ring takes the classic souls formula and improves upon it in every way, from the freedom of the open world to ashes of war, new magic and miracle mechanics, improved movement and more enemy and boss variety than ever.

The visual design in particular deserves to be spoken about. It is crazy how almost every single location looks gorgeous or straight up magical, not a single area of this game has bland artistic direction, it is percect.

The result is what can only be called a masterpiece. Does it have flaws? Yes, the camera is pretty bad (they still haven't figured out how to make the camera zoom out when fighting giant enemies) and the staggering is overdone. Worth noting that while the game is beautiful, the graphics could have been better, and the optimization is quite bad, with Ray Tracing tanking performance, as well as the lack of DLSS or widescreen support.

In the end, though, I'd rate it a 9.5/10, almost perfect.

Best Game Ever.
hatsune miku is in it
Elden Ring is GOAT in games to me. I never thought any game would beat Skyrim but Elden Ring did it. 
It's a masterpiece of a game. Elden Ring is a story that you're a part of, but not necessarily the "hero". The story was written by George R.R. Martin and then given to Hidetaka Miyazaki/FromSoftware to make the game. It was done exquisitely well. 

Then there's the weapon that is near and dear to my heart, The Darkmoon Great Sword, which is a derivative of the Moonlight Sword from another great collection of games I played many years ago, King's Field (1995). This sword is in every souls game, as a remembrance to FromSoftware's early beginnings. What has come to be known as a Soulsborne game, originated with King's Field. I loved those games, it's why I am super drawn in now. I guess I have this sentimental connection to Dark Souls/FromSoftware games, like Elden Ring. All I can say is I cannot wait for the DLC in June!
[h3]Elden Ring[/h3]

Miyazaki did it again. Elden Ring is an experience like no other. The world-building is exceptional and it really pulls you in. The bosses are memorable, even the gimmicky ones. Building your character feels better than souls games usually do to me. You have plenty of build options and plenty of weapons to choose from to fit your playstyle. The soundtrack is epic, kudos to the composers, they give that final touch to the already ambitious boss fights. I look forward to future content for this game. I also feel obligated to say that I was sorrowful when I finished it. Don't get me wrong, the game is filled to the brim with content, but as any good game should, it makes me want more and more of it.
,,,
cool
An amazing game with a really good story. The gameplay is also really emersive. It took me a week to finish this game and that week was one of the best experiences in gaming ive had. The bosses there are well made and each have their own lore/story behind them.

Overhyped game for nolifer masochists that requires constantly consulting a wiki and/or video tutorials. 

No sane person with a social life would find this game acceptable. I'm sure if they offered a demo version the reviews would be diametrically opposite. There is no quest log, quest givers, only asmr npcs spewing nonsensical crap. It's a game made to cause frustration. I guess that gives the devs a hard-on. I'm impressed how they managed to sell the lack of basic features as groundbreaking and genre redefining. There is so much more wrong with this game, but I don't feel like wasting more time on this than I already did.

Maidenless
When I first bought this game back when it first came out i hated it. It was my first souls game and i did not know what i was doing could t even tell you how many times i got lost or stuck on a boss of which i was way to underleved for. I thought it was to hard and challenging so quite shortly after deafening Mortgott. But early this year I heard that this will be getting a DLC in the summer so i proceeded to download this game once more and competently start from scratch with a new save file. But most importantly I walked in with a new mentally this time. Before i was scared and only relied on strength based weapons. I decided this time that i would play smarter not harder and that despite how many times i died that i would not give up and that i would get better and better throw every boss attempt. I think that is the best thing about souls games in my opinion is that it teachers you the lesson of life...FAILURE. Us humans fail again and again and sometimes just give up entirely. But failure it not a bad thing at all Failure is what makes us human it whats makes us learn and adapt and get good. Now that i have finished the game this is undoubtedly my favorite game of all time and i hope this  review can motive somebody to give this game another chance and experience this masterpiece.

I think its one of the absolute worst made games i have ever played. 2 years after the game is released and Torrent still has game ending glitches to where i'm walking off cliffs trying to get this shiny purple item and Torrent for some strange reason will not double jump here. Its the Malfactors evergroll right, had the same exact issue when i was playing through the first time, gave up and did not do it until i could ignore the cliff face around it. 

Why is that even what i have to do ? The riding mount i was given in the game will jump twice anywhere else on the HUGE map but will not jump twice here. its something so small but to me that makes the game unplayable. there has been countless occasions where after torrent gets killed and i land on the ground when the character is in the like " Oh no i cant get off the ground' and my PC will just be floating in the air flat like its surfing the air. 

Dont get me wrong ive put over 80 hours into this game and i own 3 dark souls games as disks and such, but these 20 plus year old games still have better basic mechanics than this sloppy game, and i mean its really sloppy. The multiplayer game modes are always glitching and the enemy invaders always seem to have either infinite invincibility frames, or can just walk through me and my other friends AoE ability's like the red lighting rain stuff. 


To bring the long rant to a close, if i would have known there would still be so many glitches and errors in this game 2 years after release i would have never bought it, its the biggest heartbreaking game ever. what a useless game

good
Qu√© decir, el MVP.
This is my first real dive into a Souls game.  I've attempted to get into others before and didn't.  The open world of this game is breath-taking.  After 3 start-to-finish runs I'm still finding amazing views I didn't notice the last time.  The surface lore is fine, the in-depth if you're paying attention is a pretty cool story of how everything ties together.  

I acknowledge that some of what I love about this game will be antithetical to hardcore Souls players but the fact that groups of enemies can replenish some flasks, there are bugs around that can replenish flasks and sometimes there are almost too many Sites of Grace made this game so much more enjoyable for me.  I think it could benefit from a hard mode where some of those are removed for hardcore players, but, I think its such a quality of life improvement.  

Lastly, there are S-Tier weapons and weapons that feel like cheat mode out there but just go have fun.  Find a weapon that speaks to you and I guarantee there is a way to build around it to get you to end-game.  That all being said, I'm off to start run 4 to get another ending done.  See you in game tarnished!
You should play this game
This is my 4th souls game that i plat trophied so i think i have a relatively credible opinion, so here goes:

This game is beautiful, there is a ridiculous amount of content and almost any build is viable, some boss fights are really enjoyable and the lore is pretty interesting.

As a souls fan there is no reason to not like this game, but there are also certain aspects which are unfit for soulslike game:

Most bosses are repetitive/boring and a lot of them are reused throughout the game,
Unless you pay perfect attention, the game is impossible to finish without any guides and being over/underleveled is something you come across regularly cause of the non-linear progression.

In my first playthrough, i got to the second sog (the one you talk to melina and get torrent) and rushed to margit cause in every other souls game you progress linearly. You can probably tell what happened; i got destroyed by margit multiple times, started to question my abilities then quit the game for like 2+ months.

I then came back, explored the entirety of Limgrave and almost 3 shotted margit on my first try. Bosses in this game are either too difficult cause you rushed to it without exploring or too easy cause you cleared every dungeon/cave in the area and are overleveled for the boss. 

As for actually finishing the game, i had to search multiple times to get to certain areas. If you miss a quest or a certain dialogue early on in the game, you can lock yourself out of progression and have to either backtrack significantly or use a guide to find out what you have missed. 

I still did very much like this game, but I cannot ignore certain problems in this game, I get why they went for the open world format; it is much more inviting for new players and i do think Fromsoft did a pretty good job of implementing it on the souls format. But these issues kill the replayability factor and a large part of souls games is that for me. 

I would definitely recommend this game, it is an experience every gamer should have, but i also hope they somehow fix some of the stuff i listed above in the dlc or the sequal.

Also fuck Fire Giant

MELINA PLEASE SIT ON MY FACE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
[i]Time of writing this review [2024/04/26] is before the release of the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC[/i]

[h1] TL;DR:[/h1]

[h2]This was a difficult game to really be sure how to rate, one of the times I wish a mixed score was an option. Ultimately I decided for negative since I'm not sure if I could recommend this game at full price to most players: I'd only suggest getting it on sale (probably 33% off or more); or if you are a die-hard FromSoftware fan who is more focused on experiencing all their games firsthand at some point.

It's a game that has some incredible highs and some miserable lows. I'm interested in the DLC, but at the same time I don't think I can in good faith recommend this game at full price. If you are playing it though, I suggest turning off ray-tracing; performance is better without it and fidelity isn't affected much. I had some crashes to desktop in my experience, usually when fast travelling, though thankfully save data remained intact. I don't recall many bugs barring some graphical oddities (like a gap in the world between textures in one or two places).[/h2]

[h3]Full review below, with some key stuff in bold.[/h3]

I originally tried this game when it came out, but bounced off it quickly; eventually got round to playing it in full this year (2024). I was predominantly playing melee and solo. In some ways it felt similar to other 'Souls games, in others pretty distinct. [b]I have not played Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, so most of my comparisons are relative to Dark Souls 3.[/b]

[b]Starting with the first thing that jumps out, the visual presentation:[/b] design-wise, the game does look pretty fantastic. The visual effects from spells and weapon skills are also great to look at. Many attacks, both friend and foe, are flashier than ever and really show what the game can do at points. And weather effects, particularly snow, really help to make this feel even more like a tangible world.

What's more noteworthy though is that, outside of fast travel, there is [i]almost no loading screens[/i]: having this detail is one thing, having it run this smoothly and seamlessly is another. It makes it so much easier to get lost in.

Bar none, the graphical presentation is the strongest point of this game.

[b]But the soundtrack is part 2 of exploration.[/b] It's overall very well done, and the ambient tracks when just exploring out of combat are some of the highlights in my opinion: it really makes the Lands Between somewhere you want to delve deeper into and get just that little bit more lost on your first playthrough. There's also distinct music during combat in each area of the game too, which transitions fairly smoothly back and forth between the ambience and fits the mood of each area well.

[b]Not since Skyrim have I felt this excited to explore. The only drawback is a lack of non-hostile NPCs to talk to in the world, it's still more action than RPG. But for me that's fine, gameplay is the main appeal in a Soulslike for me.[/b]

That being said, not all tracks compare: the soundtrack in side dungeons can be a bit disinteresting compared to the overworld; and most boss themes are pretty much what you'd imagine reading "soulslike latin choir" - they're still well made, just not as memorable as some Dark Souls series boss themes. YMMV though, I just only found myself remembering boss themes from how often they were overused (one boss theme gets used 6 different times throughout the game, for instance).

[b]The story...is a standard From Soulslike story:[/b] very cryptic lore that goes into a lot of depth, and a narrative so barebones that you couldn't make a broth out of it. The side quests are also similar to previous 'Souls games; mostly in how easy it can be to softlock yourself out of a questline or getting a particular weapon or armour set if you're not following a guide. I don't mind using guides, but it does diminish the wonder that comes from exploration a little bit.

[b]Then the gameplay: as far as character control and abilities go, this is a welcome upgrade compared to Dark Souls 3 for instance.[/b] There's now a dedicated jump button that doesn't require sprinting, and the addition of jump attacks; attacking after blocking an attack enables a "guard counter" which deals stance damage like a heavy attack but is much faster, making blocking more viable; powerstance (dual wield) makes a return from Dark Souls 2, albeit only for weapons of the same class (e.g: both katanas, or both colossal greatswords); skills are expanded into Ashes of War, which on basic weapons can be freely swapped out with other compatible AoWs you have acquired as items, and are much more bombastic moves you can pull off. From the perspective of player options and buildcrafting, the combat additions are really welcome improvements.

[b]From an enemy design perspective, however, is another story. Where 'Souls usually had a reputation of "tough, but fair", Elden Ring is "tough, except if you use this one thing".[/b] Enemies have generally much higher health, damage, and poise than their otherwise near-identical Dark Souls counterparts, and poise is much less effective to withstand weaker foes. Bosses in particular can also chain attacks together rather unpredictably, in that it's often unclear when a combo is finished or if it's just beginning - many different attacks can chain into each other, and I'm not wholly convinced there's a limit to how many can be done at once. Bosses can be staggered easier than in 'Souls, although outside of colossal weapons it can be difficult to really notice any difference versus most of them. Some bosses have attacks that are a flurry of blows where you either dodge all of them, or getting hit by one means getting hit by every subsequent blow. Others have a lot of AoE attacks where landing the dodge timing is more important than getting out of the way. And the camera is still not great against massive or highly mobile bosses.

[b]All of these issues get significantly worse in the last ~25-30% of the game. Combined with the fact that the number of side options to explore instead are shrinking, it makes the last stretch a pretty brutal slog.[/b] The fact that many late-game enemies and even some bosses are reskins or even identical versions of previous enemies with much higher stats doesn't help either. I don't blame From, it feels like they just couldn't get everything in.

The last 5-10% of the game is effectively just a boss rush, which means a lot of potential walls to progression. Some of the latter bosses are just miserable solo; by the end there was no satisfaction in overcoming the challenge, just wanting it to be over.

[b]Yet, enemy behaviour hasn't really improved since Dark Souls 1:[/b] I can still use a crossbow or throwing knife to lure them out one at a time; and bosses almost never go in for the kill versus invariably swapping to another target, if you're playing with summons or Spirit Ashes. It's not really that satisfying for fights, as much as it is punching a tree in Minecraft that will sometimes drop a Creeper on top of you. I don't want to approach a boss fight and have to choose between "tedious and with no margin of error", or "fun, but the boss rarely feels threatening if you attack from separate directions".

The enemy placement is also not great, for example ambushes feel too common to the point it diminishes their impact, but compared to how it feels to fighting them it's not as much of an issue.

Overall, compared to Dark Souls, particularly 3, combat feels like a net downgrade to play. Which is an issue when ~70% of the gameplay is combat. And you still can't bind dodge and sprint to separate keys.

All in all, this was a game I sometimes liked playing and sometimes hated playing. The midgame can be enjoyable, but sadly the endgame is what stuck with me. It was a memorable game, but I'm not sure how much for the right reasons.

...I still don't know why I'm eyeing the DLC...
finally beat the naked lady 100/10
Foul tarnished in search of the elden mogged by the flame someone must extinguish thy flame
Mogged by the flame of ambition
An ambitious FromSoft game taking the Souls formula of games and expanding it for an open world.

All the same controls you're familiar with from Dark Souls 3 is here alongside the game-changing jump button! Other features new and returning like horse riding and power stancing are all great additions too.

Despite the scale of the world, there are plenty of beautiful and unique areas for the player to explore, with an all-round great soundtrack. Not only is there some great boss music to listen to, but also atmospheric tunes to accompany the exploration of the open world.

The bosses can be quite hit or miss at times, with some of the best and worst bosses you'll face in a FromSoft Souls game. It can be fun to take them down nonetheless, but there are plenty of bosses that would be unfairly difficult or just a slog to get through.

Despite the open-world design and the fact I could get lost in it for hours with barely a sense of proper direction (NPCs can help to guide you however), a lot of familiar level design tropes harking back to even Dark Souls 1 and maybe Demon's Souls return here and make the individual setpieces a joy to explore.

Overall, Elden Ring is a great game, it can't be denied. From Software really put their all into this game and it's clear the effort that went into crafting this game. I wouldn't say that it's my favourite Souls game from them, nor is it such a highly ranked game for me since Dark Souls 3 and Bloodborne are still some of the best in my opinion. However, if you are in the need of some more Souls games and you haven't played this game yet, it's still very much worth it.

I think overall Elden Ring is great, but not as good as Dark Souls III baby!!!

Maybe it doesn't appeal to me as much, but I've never been the biggest fan of making every game an open world RPG unless theres a good way of filling it with "substance". I don't think Elden Ring has enough substance by its very essence of being a souls-like. In that I don't mean Items, but more story and interaction. An identical cave with a weapon or spell I likely won't use doesn't mean much to me. This is not to say there isn't quality in it. There is a LOT of great stuff in Elden Ring that I love, just more room than there feasibly can be stuff IMO. It makes replaying the game a lot of me just going towards the fastest way to get upgrade materials for whatever weapon I wanted and moving on. Even for a first playthrough, stuff is so spread out that I feel like as soon as I get enough for what I need it feels like a waste of time to explore. Like if I get too leveled, bosses won't get me enough runes to level so why bother? Oh boy, another ash I won't use. Etc. The quests are too far between and require too little actual exploring to force me to go places to be honest, though Ranni's and Fia's are good examples of a counterpoint. 

I honestly give it a strong 8/10, just Dark Souls 3 is like a 9.5/10 in comparison, I just want more weapons and powerstancing in it. But that's also my personal enjoyment out of a game a lot, is a nice directed experience where its tailored to have a lot of highs and not many luls from 'exploring'.

One of the best games of all time.
It's very challenging for a beginner, and you will die so many times, but that challenge is a rewarding part of the experience and what makes it, and all of Fromsoftware's games, so unique. The exploration and sights you can see are some of the best, with jaw dropping landscapes and so many nooks and crannies you can miss. The replayability is very high, with different playstyles and places and items to find that will keep you coming back and still discovering things. The level of discovery in Elden Ring is one that is unmatched, making the open world one that rivals the feeling Skyrim gave when it came out. I can't recommend this game enough, it's been with me through so much and has given me so much joy and fun. Just remember to keep trying and don't give up!

One of the best games I have ever played.
darnk souls
Elden Ring, to put it simply, is one of the best games that I've played in recent memory. It is a perfect blend of the tactical, timing-based combat of the Soulslike genre and rich and rewarding exploration of a massive open world.

At times that open world can certainly be overwhelming. I found that the game really shone in its more linear sections - the large and more traditional dungeons that served as funnels for the game's main story events and characters. The tighter level design in these dungeons just felt so much more satisfying to move and progress through. That being said, the larger world was still incredibly rewarding to explore - with some sort of upgrade or resource around practically every corner.

I played Elden Ring pretty thoroughly - I kept guides and Googling to a minimum for my first playthrough, but I still felt like I saw quite a bit of what the game had to offer. Towards the end of the game, but not during the "endgame", this made the game feel like it was dragging a bit, as there is just simply so much to do and explore. You never know if this mini-dungeon or that world boss will be the one to give you the exact upgrade that you've been looking for - so they can be hard to pass up. However, that is one fairly minor complaint in an otherwise stellar game.

The art style and visuals, the music and sound design, the typical fragmented and disjointed storytelling typical of a FromSoft game - they are all at their peak in Elden Ring, in my opinion. This is one of the most gorgeous and immersive games I've played, and the sheer variety in landscapes and environments is mind-boggling.

With a 100+ hour playthrough for my first time through the game, I probably will put Elden Ring on the shelf for a bit. But I know that someday I'll be returning to try out new builds, unlock new endings, and uncover new secrets in the Lands Between.

one of the best games i've played
[h1][b]Elden Ring[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 8/10 - Great[/b]

[b]Elden Ring[/b] is [b]great[/b], it truly is but there are multiple things that hold it back from being better than [b]Dark Souls III[/b] for example. The open world doesn't do the game too many favors, it's a little too big and filled with samey dungeons and copy and paste bosses. Fromsofts quest design also doesn't work too well with an open world, making it even more convoluted than in previous games. [b]Elden Ring[/b] also has some of the worst bosses Fromsoft has ever made, too many are so big that you're fighting the camera a lot more than the boss itself. 

On the other hand, the game is absolutely beautiful; some of the best art direction in all of gaming. Locations are beautiful and many of the castles and main dungeons are very well designed and fun to explore. The soundtrack is absolutely [b]Amazing[/b] as well, creating this vivid, palpable atmosphere - and then there is the lore, absolutely masterful. Some of [b]Elden Ring[/b]'s bosses are also [b]Great[/b], some of my favorite fights ever.

In conclusion, [b]Elden Ring[/b] is one of the best games I've played thus far. While it has some [b]Great[/b] bosses it also has some of the worst, the balancing is quite off due to the open world structure of the game but overall it is a [b]Great[/b] experience.

ranni is my wife
Was originally skeptical about purchasing as this would be my first FromSoft title and their reputation clearly precedes them. From the moment I stepped out into the vast open world I was thrust into an incredibly immersive gaming experience unlike any i've played before. Admittedly there was a learning curve as I was new to the mechanics, of which I can honestly say could use some improvement speaking as a PC player. Through trial & error, exploration & development, I was hooked beyond belief. The world-building is as intricate as can be, allowing for myself to discover entirely new areas, dungeons, items, etc. even after my 150+ hrs in the game. In the modern age of gaming its become increasingly more difficult to justify AAA price points and I went into this game thinking it would be no different, am I glad I was wrong. The replay-ability is insanely alluring and feels like I could continue my mission as a Tarnished scouring the Lands Between for an eternity without needing to enter NG+. I would highly recommend anyone with even an inkling of interest in this game and thank yourself later by making the investment that purchasing Elden Ring is. The return on investment with this game is without bounds as you will find yourself unable to pull away just as I have. Could not possibly give a more glowing recommendation. 100000000000/10!

[b]Score: 10+/10[/b]

[h2] Elden Ring is one of two games that can be declared a AAAA-title.[/h2]
(The other one beeing BG3, I havn't played it yet.)

[b]Story[/b]
This game here is not going to take your hand, bringig you to bead and reading you a good night-tale. 
Use your brain, the lore and story are so comlex that someone attempting to explain everything made a video that is 13h long 
(and that is only part one). But when you figure stuff out... wow.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

It is generally a good game, however there are things that are extremely disrespectful to the player's time. For example, running to the boss arena each time. Then they put an npc that will chase you to boss arena, so when you summon your spirit the spirit will sometimes attack the npc behind the invisible wall rather than the boss. They must have realized these, and these are all design choices. If it wasn't for these, I would give it a 10/10, but honestly towards the end, through all the chores you have to go through, the game stop being a game and just turns into a tiring mess. And even worse, some of the final bosses, I won't spoil, give you such poor frame rates... The fallen leaves tell a story.

The great Elden Ring was shattered.

In our home, across the fog, the Lands Between.

Now, Queen Marika the Eternal is nowhere to be found,

and in the Night of the Black Knives, Godwyn the Golden was the first to perish.

Soon, Marika's offspring, demigods all, claimed the shards of the Elden Ring.

The mad taint of their newfound strength triggered the Shattering.

A war from which no lord arose.

A war leading to abandonment by the Greater Will. Arise now, ye Tarnished.

Ye dead, who yet live.

The call of long-lost grace speaks to us all.

Hoarah Loux, chieftan of the badlands.

The ever-brilliant Goldmask.

Fia, the Deathbed Companion.

The loathsome Dung Eater.

And Sir Gideon Ofnir, the All-knowing.

And one other. Whom grace would again bless.

A Tarnished of no renown.

Cross the fog, to the Lands Between.

To stand before the Elden Ring.

And become the Elden Lord.

FromSoftware really does not disappoint with their Soulsborne games. The same can be said with Elden Ring. Elden Ring is a really large, open-world, soulsborne game and I'm not kidding when I say it is. In comparison to all the other Soulsborne titles (idk about Sekiro never played it yet), I'd say Elden Ring takes the cake. I've spent like hours and even stayed up on nights just exploring the lands between because it's so open world to the point where you're not gonna finish the game in just one sitting! And the best part, you aren't limited to what you want to do in this game. If you're having trouble getting past a boss, you HAVE the option to skip it and come back (I'd recommend looking up farming techniques). I first had it on the PS5 but because it's decommissioned at the moment, I resorted to PC for now.

The only main problem I have about this game (on the PC) is that because the file size is really big, I think it's contributing to the amount of lag spikes while playing the game. My PC is an New Alienware Aurora R10 so maybe I need a stronger PC. That being said, you also aren't able to play the game very well if you have many other applications open in your desktop (which most of the time I just open one browser to look at the Elden Wiki for tips).

Besides that though, 10/10 I recommend playing it but 8/10 because it may require you to have a stronger PC to handle this game.

Even if you don't really like hard games, you may still really enjoy this, as there are so many built-in tools and features that make this one of the most accessible From Software games out there. You don't need to be a great gamer to finish this game, but you can also make it very difficult if that is what you are in to.

it epic
Elden Ring is quite simply a modern classic, a game that will one day stand toe to toe with Mario brothers, The Legend of Zelda, Metal Gear Solid, Final Fantasy VII, and every other game that has endured for decades. This is one of the best games ever made and you can't go wrong playing it. There's a very high chance you will end up sinking dozens of hours into several playthroughs. Play this game
Truly an amazing piece of work. The boss designs and lore are incredible. The world is simply breathtaking. Combat is very smooth and feels great. The game is very rewarding to those who like to explore and you can really feel the progression when you've put in the time and effort. The game is hard, (as expected from a souls game) however, it is extremely fulfilling once you've figured out what you're doing.

The only complaints I have are in relation to the targeting system (which can be a little annoying at times) and the weird positioning of some sites of grace in certain dungeons. The lack of a journal to track quests is also a little a bit of a nuisance but I wouldn't say it's a major design flaw. I also wish there was a civilian population of some sort that you could speak to or even find because who are we meant to be ruling over after we become the Elden Lord? Who are we fighting for exactly?

Overall though, Elden Ring is very solid and has been a joy to play. I could honestly play this game forever and I cannot wait for the DLC!

Elden Ring came to me in a time in life that I very much needed what it had brought me, and I didn‚Äôt even know what that was when I bought it! 

I was in a bad situation for a long while and happened to be watching Jacksepticeye videos on YouTube when I was in a safe and healthy space. I used to play video games all the time when I was younger, but prior to my partner getting me a steam deck last year I hadn‚Äôt played games in 11 years.

Well one day I watched an older upload of Jacksepticeye playing through Bloodborne, was completely enamored by it and had never seen a game quite like that. So on my deck I had already been playing Doom 2016 and the older Doom titles that I grew up with. And I looked up From Software.

I had no idea what I was getting into, I bought Elden Ring on a whim and I absolutely love all the souls games now. This game affected my life in a positive way. It challenged me, pushed me, hell I went in blind and got stomped! I had no idea what I was doing for the first 120 hrs! There are so many mechanics that now I‚Äôm still learning how to be more efficient and effective with my character and weapon builds. The story and lore are awesome and I am excited to see what everyones experiences are in the DLC coming up!

While I know these games aren‚Äôt for everyone, if you are curious I would give it a go. You will die, you will learn and you will become better! The game is beautiful and fun, good luck out there fellow Tarnished!

haha funy gaem
So, all I really have to say is that pve and open world is okay, lots nice areas with interesting enemies, cool weapons, and armor sets. Lore is weird especially if you're trying to understand it through your play through. Bosses in this game are repetitive af, lots of copy paste mini bosses, but there are some cool main ones. Don't get me wrong I loves souls games but where I personally found this games fails is through pvp, I guess coming from ds3 pontiff shi**er invasions my opinion may be too harsh on the game but I really think there's a lot that needs to be done with the current state of the pvp aspect, starting with invasions. To put it simple they are very unbalanced and all odds are usually against the invader, from getting bad spawns, immediately getting ganked and spammed to getting taunter tongue cancelled as soon as you join another world with the host and 2 other phantoms and worst of all never getting a teammate. Maybe somewhere to start would be make a game with 2 phantoms automatically open the doors to allowing 2 invaders at once without taunters.. Additionally, the network on pc for this game is absolute trash, im not 100% sure its because of the anti-cheat but it really doesn't help pvp at all, you should expect to get phantom hits from a mile away and also expect to see other players in arena floating around, I have good internet and have not had any issues on any other games including the previous souls games. I have a few different characters ranging between lvls 125 to 200 and its safe to say that ive only seen the same thing across all of them in regards to invasions at least. Over leveled phantoms and the game encouraging players to spam, especially wizards lol. I don't really have much else to say but I hope at least some changes are made to the online aspect in the future lol.

game is great, shutup and buy it
I think it's a quality game as many people before me have stated. If you're looking for darksouls, then this isn't it though. A lot of the late game bosses will deal a lot more damage than you expect and the lack of openings in bosses especially late game can be infuriating. In general the replayability of this game is top notch, and the gameplay itself is incredible. With a stunning world to look at and an open world bigger than almost any other I've played, this game is easily worth the price it's asking for. Though I don't agree with how fast some of the bosses go, or how much damage is dealt late game, I can appreciate this game for what it is. That being a masterpiece.
I watched you slowly grab me by my waist, pull me in and whisper " I am Malenia. Blade Of Miquella. And i have never know defeat. "
This was my first soulslike game and I was not disappointed!

Loved every moment of the game down to the boss fights, the scenery, the different builds you can choose from, the weapons and spells. Its truly a masterpiece and has been one of the most memorable games I've played.

Replayed through it around 10 times now and that number will 100% grow once the DLC comes out : )

I've had trouble accommodating to FromSoft games in the past. I figured this one would be no different: I try, I die, I quit.

For whatever reason, I've yet to introspect too much on it, I can't stop playing.

It's still fairly difficult to play for a newbie like me, but it's still the more approachable experience.

I now wish to give DS1 & DS3 another shot with this newfound appreciation at hand.

Its fun
In my first run of this game, I found myself in love. Of course I used the stupid dex/int build that everyone uses, but that's besides the point. The game is beautiful. The story is lovely. The fights are tense and the victories are rewarding (except Malenia, fuck Malenia). This game is a fantastic way to introduce someone to the soulslike genre.

That being said, as a modding nut, I think I wouldn't be playing this game nearly as much as I do if the modding community around this game wasn't as massive as it was. I can imagine myself doing a dozen runs due to the sheer number of weapons, classes, and mods at my disposal.

Thank you Miyazaki for this masterpiece

Great game.You could play for 1000 hours and still not use every weapon.You WILL die a lot,THAT IS THE POINT,every single time you die you get a little more knowledgeable on that boss.And if you think Malenia is too hard...fair point BUT waterfowl dance is quite easy to dodge,bro just search up a tutorial...or use mimic tear.So yeah you can spend probably hundreds of hours into the game and have no IDEA certain areas exist and using mods like the convergence mod it prolongs the amount of time you can enjoy game by a huge amount and you can find pretty much everything you need on sites like nexus mods and more mod sites.so overall its an amazing game,but people get mad when its too hard but if anything its too easy if you know what your doing,Example:Mohg's great spear (if you are mad about PVP just download seamless co-op or just dont play PVP at all)

fricking amazing
HELL YEAHH

After 200 hours of gameplay, I can say that I finished every corner of this masterpiece, every land, every boss, every site of grace found,  was like peace in the middle of a war, damn, I don't know how to explain how I dedicated so much time to learning  the lore of this game, I can say that I am not a soulslike player nor do I have experience in the area with these games, but I cannot remain indifferent to what I call a piece of art, the fascinating story/lore combined with an extraordinary game detail of the character makes the experience absolutely insane, I can't count how many times I got lost exploring this map, cuz the game doesn't really tell you what to do but was really challenging but at the same time rewarding. It was an amazing time that I spent  just contemplating the beauty of different areas, and I can say that the effort made to create this game was worth 100% it. Big props to fromsoftware for bringing the DLC. LETS GO!

8/10. This game needs fishing in it, and maybe an expansive cooking mini game.
My only problem with the game is its concept of difficulty for the last few bosses in the main story. I think difficulty only makes sense when there are things you get a grasp of and they help you get through the whole game, if you master them well enough. But the last few bosses, actually just Godfrey and Maliketh, is just constant spam of attacks that barely give you any time to fight back, 90% of the time you are just trying to evade attacks, it is no fun. But other than that it is a great game, definitely worth the money and the time.

However, the idea that I could take things at my own pace and immerse myself in the beautifully designed world encouraged me to give it a shot. Mohg:
Elden Ring was my first soulslike.
It was kinda overwhelming when starting but I had tons of fun in my first blind run.
Like that's the great part of Elden Ring: you don't have to be this awesome Souls-Veteran to be able to enjoy the game.
You can just take your time with everything, explore the beautiful world, enjoy the view and smaller bosses.
The game doesn't push you to kill a certain difficult boss in order to get somewhere in-game. You're not forced to farm the same enemies for hours on until you're strong enough to continue your journey. You can just keep exploring & will eventually level up in the mean time. & if you're not getting any further with a specific boss, then you can just leave it be for now and do hundreds of other things instead.

Gosh, the game is boring.

The first playthrough was entertaining, the open world looked nice, the plot... well, what could you expect from FromSoft? It's complicated. Finished the game in around 100h or so. But NG+ is a way different [spoiler]Elden[/spoiler] beast...

Exploring got boring and repetitive, the game is literally too big and the open world became a major drawback. I couldn't really form an emotional connection with the NPCs, the plot is overly complicated even for FS standard and after sometime I did not care about the world and my role as a Tarnished in it. Maxed all the achievements, uninstalled Elden Ring, won't return nor buy the DLC. 3/10

IT WAS SO TO FUN PLAY WITH FRIENDS.SEAMLESS CO-OP MOD I LOVE YOU.CAN NOT WAIT FOR THE DLC TO COME OUT
Absolute beast of an RPG for anyone who likes the souls series. The world vast and fascinating, and you constantly discover new things. The game also has around 230 bosses which some are quite challenging and exciting. Of course some of them are not. The game is very welcoming to new players but for veterans it is quite easy (so far) but one can always amp the difficulty artificially by investing stats differently or not using certain skills. You make the difficulty. The only downside is that there are too many "bonfires" in this game. There also appears to be quite a lot of replayability since some quests lock some areas which one may or may not discover on first playthrough. 

For newcomers, it may take some time to adjust to game mechanics and such but once you do, you will love it like everyone else who doubted souls series but ended up loving them. 

9.5/10
Very good you can all kind of challenges an it's so expansive

good game
good game
It is my first souls game and it is amazing! The simplicity of their menu and items description makes it a bit complicated at first consider how game companies babysit their users in today's age. 
I can spend hours playing and never get bored as there is always a new mistery, new bossess, quests I forgot I accepted and grinding. 
The game is HARD, if you have no problem grinding you should be fine, you'll die a lot slowly.
If you want to charge at everything at once, it is possible but, you'll die ... lot and faster.
It gets you thinking, frustrated, inmersed and completely fascinated about their story.

One thing I have to mention, if you skip dialoge, prepare to spend hours searching on how to do things or searching for information on the internet. 
If you like to read, there is a change that you might need to read one thing or two if you are getting desperate. 

I would give this game 9.9/10. I'd like to upgrage my armor or perhaps, choose how my character looks like if I had discovered new equipment(looks only). I know it would go against the nature of the game but, it'd be a cool detail.

The samurai is the way to go if you are new, at least from my experience.

I am John Elden
There is a solid foundation and a lot of potential, but the multiplayer aspect has been completely scuffed.

Reading past interviews with Hidetaka Miyazaki, such as Eurogamer's Soul Survivor, makes me sad because I feel like his vision of multiplayer was truly stupendous, but the execution was very lackluster.

Co-op makes the game too easy, breaking the intended experience of overcoming hardship, as the enemy AI are just not designed around dealing with multiple players, and the advantages of cooperation are so great that being invaded is more like a minor inconvenience than an actual threat.

Invading can be fun, it can be tedious. What sucks though is that you cannot co-invade with friends. The second password summoning was made a thing back in Dark Souls 3, co-invasions should have also existed. If players can progress with friends, they should also be able to invade with them. Having to host and gank for co-op PvP or using the lackluster arena is just. . . boring.

Arena is lackluster. It somehow has less variety than the arena in Dark Souls 2 and 3. Three flat maps, one with pillars. . . excuse me?! Rather than using the password system, we need to be able to host lobbies and fine-tune rules so we don't just have one elimination mode and a bunch of timed death-match modes. Where is my 2v2 or 3v3 elimination?

Due to how multiplayer works in this game, the lack of natural solo invasions, inability to be invaded in areas where the boss is cleared, lack of covenants, amongst other features missing from previous titles, Elden Ring does not really have a post end-game for those that fall in love with its mechanics but want to do something other than progress the story with the same enemy placement for the millionth time. Dark Souls 2 has some neat features that this game could really make use of ranging from multiplayer mechanics such as post-game invasions to new game plus features such as new enemy placement.

It sucks because I really like this game, but I really do not like the overall direction FromSoft/Bandai have been taking multiplayer where it has been started to feel more like a half-baked afterthought rather than an integral part to the core experience.
fun and ez

Also Make sure you understand how spirit ashes and multiplayer work. This will also help your enjoyment of the game if you are a new player.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 40 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching Faide montages on YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

A true master piece and flawless game. I could not recommend this game enough to anyone who has not played it.
This just wasn't for me.  I was never attracted to any other FromSoftware games.  I only decided to purchase and play this because of all the positive reviews.  To use the genre name applied to this game, it feels soulless.  There are scant few NPCs in this open world game.  You have to do a lot of work to figure out the story.  Though, in fairness, the plot is straightforward: become Elden Lord.  But I can't say I cared for any of the NPCs or the story.  The bosses had a threadbare backstory, and it didn't make them interesting nor did it make them sympathetic.  Honestly, why were these people fighting over the Lands Between which are just various flavors of depressing wastelands?

The open world is simply littered with monsters.  There are not any long pauses in fighting.  You better not stand around looking at the wasteland scenery lest you are attacked by roving monstrosities.  I didn't like that my character never felt particularly powerful.  It seems absurd that this peon could become Elden Lord, whatever that means anyway.  After awhile, things became repetitive.

I do give this game credit for an option to exit to the desktop.  That is always appreciated.  But there were scant few accessibility options.  I want to still play games and not experience repetitive stress.  It doesn't seem that hard to offer this accommodation.
Can't say I jived with it as much as I did with DS3, but it is still a rather solid game based on having seen others play through it. As you can see by my hours so far as of this review I didn't play much of it myself but that doesn't stop me from recommending it.

Most immersive RPG ever. Truly the easiest souls game IMO, but 0 restrictions let you do truly whatever you want, basically whenever you want, with whatever build. The questing and storylines are vague until you get to the middle or end of a quest, but that's to be expected in a real rpg like this. 
Honestly, I can so easily soak hours into this game so greatly immersed without even thinking about it. For the price, it's so easily worth it. The Seamless co-op mod at nexus games is a MUSTTTT (since the co op in normal Eldin Ring isn't very fluid) Truly one of the best RPG's of all time.

7/10, good game but needs modifications to be truly great.

Other reviews probably have reviewed this to the Deeproot Depths so I just go through some basics for co-operative play.

Here we have "action-fighting" PC game which loses to kids' Hogwarts Legacy what comes to control customization. Nuff' said.

Here we have PC game which competes with Skyrim which one has more arrow blocking meshes.

Here we have PC game from 2022 which looks like something which crawled out of  PlayStation 4.

Here we have game which forces you to play PvP with hikikomori wiki-crafters if you want to play only co-operative mode unless you install modifications.

So, to for all new players I'd recommend before you even start playing:
Install Elden Ring Mod Loader.
Install Seamless Coop.
Install 2K or 4K textures.
Lock PvP hikikomori nerds to colosseum, throw away the key and get VERY LARGE cup to collect all salty hikky-tears. xD
Invite your newbie friends.
Start your playthrough.

After [b]500+ hours[/b] in the game and with [b]all the achievements unlocked[/b], I can confidently say this is [b]one of the best games I've ever played![/b]

[i]As I'm writing my thesis on gamer culture, I've been really interested in playing, getting to know the community around the theme and theorizing along with fellow players. The environmental storytelling is amazing, the plot is rich - provided by both known information and the lack of it - and integrates the many aspect of jobs and niches of people outside the world of video games (e.g. Tarnished Archeologist). 
While this is unmistakably a FromSoft game, I'd say it's a balanced gateway piece for more casual players, allowing them to discover their own play style while offering help in form of co-op and spirit summons. Also, the struggles and preferences in exploring the world allows one to delve inside their own psyche, finding out more about their inner struggles they've been suppressing IRL, as I've seen in the case of many of my friends and myself. 
It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I'd highly recommend giving it a try![/i]

Can't wait for the DLC to drop!

[i][b]MAY CHAOS TAKE THE WORLD![/b][/i]
:3 ewden wing

I‚Äôve played a lot of Dark Souls 3 across many systems so when I‚Äôd heard Elden Ring was coming out I thought ‚ÄúHell yea! A new Souls game! aaaand its open world‚Ä¶‚Äù I'm not a fan of open world games. To me, when a non open world game goes OW its about to die. Like a last ditch effort from big game companies. Either way though I pre-ordered it because why not.

Now its been like 2 years since then so I cant tell you what my inital thoughts were other than ‚ÄúHoly fuck this place is beautiful.‚Äù I CAN tell you what I thought by the end of my first play through though. I wanted to go back to Ds3 but every time I did, my mind drifted back to ER and well, I came crawling back. ER has lots to offer. The series would be WILDLY different without it but, it can be improved. At Least for the DLC and mod makers out there.

One thing I think ER has that the other SoulsBornes don't have is deadspace. No not the game. Areas that dont have much other than minor enemies for population and meaningless items for the same reason. There were plenty of times on my first play through where I was exploring places and never gained anything. These places tend to lose my attention and take up my time. They‚Äôre perfect for streamers by giving them chances to talk to chat but they‚Äôre quite useless for the average player.

	As a Ds3 lover, my fav place was the Shaded Castle. Felt like they took a scrapped Ds3 area, boss and all, and put it in ER. The Haligtree was similar but built for ER. Not exactly ‚Äòdeadspace‚Äô but space for a story and items that aren't required but could be useful. Space that you don‚Äôt HAVE to deal with unless you want items which, well that speaks right to a lot of soulsborne players.


So if you're into Soulsborne games, It‚Äôs a must have for your library and it has plenty of challenges so you won't be disappointed.
If you saw the gameplay and became interested, you should 100% give it a try because you‚Äôll love the various builds you can create. My first one was a ‚ÄúDragon Lord‚Äù
If you saw the beautiful world, theres plenty of time for you to embrace it and try to understand the convoluted story of it all. Just dont forget how the other games play in.
Or if you saw its open world, well, you might be disapointed, but im not about to let you leave without trying it. Just throw it on your wishlist for when it gets a discount a few decades from now.


AS FOR PVP. Its been a hot minute for me. I played when it came out and it kinda sucked hard. Like maybe the damage values needed some editing/balancing. As if they were more geared towards PvE. I've been playing Convergence mod+Seamless Co-Op with my buddy and we do some PvP here and there and it feels pretty balanced. Those are Genuine 1v1s though where as invasions will, AS FAR AS I'M AWARE, always be 2v1.
Tread carefully with your PvP experience and report any improvements you can think of. The DLC is supposed to be coming soon so they might be more likely to implement or at least test stuff.

Elden Ring is a **masterpiece** that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its expansive, beautifully crafted world is a joy to explore, filled with intricate details and stunning vistas. The game's combat system is both challenging and rewarding, offering a depth of strategy that is rarely seen in the genre. The narrative is rich and immersive, with complex characters and a lore that keeps you engaged throughout your journey. Elden Ring is not just a game, it's an experience that leaves a lasting impression. It's a testament to the power of creative storytelling and innovative game design. A must-play for any gaming enthusiast!

So, my very late review for Elden Ring: I wish I could reccomend this game to everyone, but I can't. That said, I can't not recommend it either. Is there a neutral review option? My view of this game is that it is great, but it needs refinement. The pros: The boss fights are (mostly) fantastic, the enemy design is great, the ambience is good, the music is good, everything feels (mostly) tough but fair (fuck you raygun lobsters and scarlet rot), and in general the worldbuilding and gameplay in general is amazing. That all said, you might wonder why I don't recommend it? Well, put simply, the quests. I'm sure this has been said to death: this game NEEDS A QUEST LOG. Also, the controller support is stupid.

For controller support: I don't understand why PC games don't have Playstation Controller support. Ridiculous that I need to install a mod just to see playstation glyphs or inputs, so I actually learn the proper controls. Especially when the game is made by a big, rich publisher, THAT ALSO PUT OUT THE GAME ON PLAYSTATION WITH THE CORRECT DISPLAY. You literally made the correct display, for a different platform, why can't you have the playstation controller glyphs as an option for PC???

For those of you that say, "no it doesn't dark souls has never had a quest log!" True. It's also never been open world and had so many questlines that could be broken without warning. The fact that simply heading to Liurnia or killing a specific boss early could end 2, 3, even 4 questlines for people I might not have even met yet, and cut off multiple different endings, is absurd. Also, when you speak to people, they give no indication, many times, where they are going! Good luck finding them again (Hyetta). Even more absurd, there is no warning. We saw this in The Witcher 3, when you collect Ciri, the game will warn you that some quests may be unable to complete. Why is this not a thing in Elden Ring? And the fact that some NPC's (Ranni) will lie about their real name (says she is Renna I believe), tell you that you won't meet again, and then proceed to be one of the most important ones in the game, is fucking baffling. Not only that, but with other questlines (Rya) unless you reload the game, she may not spawn, which also pisses me off. How can you lock her entire quest because "I had a long play session without logging off so she didn't spawn and I missed her quest". I didn't buy this game to spend more time on the damn wiki than in The Lands Between, thank you very much. 

So, will I play this game again? Probably not. Like I said, I won't spend more time on the wiki, reading shit, than playing a game. I also won't buy the DLC, because I have a hard time believing it will be different.

And for those about to "clown emote" my review, here is my suggestion to FromSoft and Bandai: for those of you that don't want a quest log, make it optional. We kind of saw this in AC Odyssey - you could have fully guided quests (markers, you knew where to go the minute you got/progressed a quest), or more vague ones - "go to this location and look around, here's some hints and we recorded them for you in the quest log, then use your cool bird to find stuff." A system like that would work great in this game, in my opinion, and also make it more accessible to newbies.

Elden King!!
Absolutely one of my favorite games of all time. It wonderfully combines the basic souls-formula with a gorgeous (partially) open world, giving the player a choice in how long the experience will be. 
One might only focus on the main story, and have an experience roughly the same length as Dark Souls 3, while an explorer or quest enthusiast might spend up to 100 hours on a single run. 

The world is absolutely beautiful, and the game runs quite smoothly on a worse than average setup. The story is pretty good, and if one pays a little extra attention to dialogue (and item texts, and does multiple quest-lines, and explores, and...) I'd say the story is REALLY good. Excellent even.

However the biggest flaw in this game is in the way that story is told. As in most soulsborne-games, it can be a bit tedious to piece the whole lore-puzzle together. Especially for players who might play this as their first souls like game. 
Some bosses are repeats with a twist, but most bosses are quite epic & memorable. I'd say this game has probably the best boss fights in the series, together with Sekiro.

Nevertheless, small flaws in a huge machine. Elden Ring really took me by surprise, and I'd honestly say it's my favourite fromsoft game so far! Big up.

Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece, blending intricate world-building, captivating storytelling, and challenging gameplay into a seamless experience. FromSoftware has once again raised the bar for immersive open-world RPGs, offering players a breathtaking landscape to explore, filled with rich lore and jaw-dropping visuals. The freedom to forge your own path, coupled with the deep, rewarding combat system, keeps you engaged for hours on end. And let's not forget the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that elevates every moment of the adventure. Elden Ring isn't just a game; it's an unforgettable journey that sets a new standard for the genre.

dank dank.
Another masterpiece from the originators of the SoulsBourne genre!

This game takes the best, most well-developed, aspects of Dark Souls 3 and refines them even further while adding a whole new dynamic of an open world. This is the best curated and most populated world map I have seen and every corner has something to find, both small and large. The open world contrasts against the dungeon-like areas that follow the more classic Dark Souls gauntlet.

New or returning player, you will enjoy this one.
Its elden ring.
Let's get the negative out of the way first.  The mini-dungeons (caves/mines/catacombs/etc) are of dubious quality.  There are a few very good ones, but many that feel very repetitive.  Cutting most of them would've made the game even better, by playing to its strengths.

But that's about it.  I love everything else.  The world design is wonderful in fromsoft fashion.  They've adapted to the open world well - I always preferred the DS1-style world, that's still their best work, but this is great.  It's got the haunting/beautiful combination down pat, though the overall tone is a bit lighter.

I'm not very good at these games, but I've played them to death anyway, because the gameplay/combat is just so fun, even if you kinda suck.  There are a few new mechanics to help out a bit - you can always summon help for bosses or certain other encounters, even offline; invasions are way toned down; and there's something you can access early on to gain levels quickly when you're underpowered [discover it on your own, I was shocked/thrilled when I did!  but by now it's in guides if you need em].  All this combined makes it a bit more accessible, but it's still very satisfying and challenging.

And no, I still haven't beaten malenia.
big bongo bum
As of writing this I have played 161 hours,but haven't actually beaten the game yet. Not for the reasons you probably think I could have beaten the game a long time ago,but I keep getting distracted cause I'll sometimes find a item that has a cool ability,and want to make a whole build around it. I keep restarting to try out new classes, or new special weapons that give me some idea to make a cool build around. Theory crafting,and exploration are probably the two biggest selling points of this game.

One reason why I keep coming back to Elden Ring,and this is probably my biggest selling point. Elden Ring is the only game I know of so far that tells the story the way it does. What I'm saying is it has a unique way of telling the story of elden ring. It does so by the environment itself. The world of elden ring will tell its story in a very unique way that no other game provides as far as I've seen.
Even though I haven't beaten the game,and know the ending there multiple endings,but I have put in this many hours into a game I haven't even beaten yet, so I got my moneys worth. Plus the characters,and world of elden ring are pretty amazing,and I'm not a Dark Souls fan, I didn't enjoy the Dark Souls games,but Elden Ring is good imo.
