IAMMELANIABLADEOFMIQUELLA
fun game to play and grind
This is possibly the best game I have ever played. There is a steep learning curve to the game and if this is your first Fromsoft game you will have a rough time until you become comfortable with the mechanics. If you try this game the best advice I can give is to explore and if something is to hard, mark it on your map and come back later. I have gone from dying to simple soldier enemies all the time to being able to kill major bosses with ease by my second playthrough. I keep restarting and coming back to this game and making new characters, It's such a thrill to play.
One of the best games I've ever played. I can't recommend it enough.
What a game !!

This is the first FromSoft game i managed to beat, after struggling to get hooked to Dark Souls (especially #1). 
I think it's a great starting point, because it keeps some From Soft things (the demanding gameplay, be willing to learn from mistakes, some boss design rules etc ...) but with a more accessible gameplay (summons, rune farming, sneak, craft ...)  (Tho i should wait until i beat previous Dark Souls before saying that ... I will)
So if you never managed to play a FromSoft game but always wanted to, i recommand starting with this one
With some precautions tho - the game is big, really big. I spent 80h, but i'm sure i could have spend 30 more hours, there's plenty of dungeons i didn't explore etc ... 

There's obviously some flaws coming with such a ambitious wide design, some (a lot) of bosses are reused, which isn't too much of an issue imho, but it's something to be aware of. A lot of dungeons are pretty much copy pasted, but once again, you don't have to do them all, except if you want every piece of loot. 

Some boss fight are frustrating : duo boss fights sucks imho, and there's a few of them. Some attacks seem a bit unfair etc ..., but overall, it's really an enjoyable journey. Just be ready to use everything the game gives you, because the game won't hold back, for the best and the worst. 
There's a lot of different builds available, and the game makes respecing quite accessible, which is great, because you can respec for one boss if you struggle too much. Some boss also suffer from awful camera placement (most dragons for instance). But overall, they are good, some are trully great.

A lot of weapons, but every cool weapons is locked behind magic stats, which kinda sucks if you want to play with a pure melee fighter, because you won't get to use 90% of the loot. 
Armour is mostly for fashion, which isn't a bad thing imho (there's already plenty of things to manage), except that a lot of armours really don't match together, especially because of very different metal tints. 
 
The biggest strenght of the game is the world design. Gorgeous ! Some places are simply breathtaking, and it shows that a lot of care was put into it. If you enjoy fantasy worlds, this one is great ! A lot of inspiration from different things (Berserk obviously, this is a From Soft game) but other things too !

The story is kinda cryptic like From Soft usually does, but i enjoyed it. I'll be watching lore videos about it so i can get the whole picture ! NPCs writting is a bit lazy tho. Like, i don't mind having cryptic things and etc, but a lot of them seems almost parodic. Sidequests kinda share the same flaws, you will probably need to read a guide to finish them, but some are great !

Overall i think Elden Ring is a great experience, i think their goal was to make a more accessible game without making too much compromise, and i think they achieved that in a very impressive way. If you are a knowledgable player of previous From Soft games, you might get rebuted by the flaws i mentionned ; because of the size of the game, it can't be such a polished experience as previous games. The size is a strenght and a flaw.
I'm definitely looking forward the DLC which seem to be massive !
GREAT GAME

Game is darn expensive for sure but it is worth your time and buck still waiting on the dlc but when it does comes out will purchase it without hesitation. 100/10
My beloved <3
My most played game on steam and probably my favorite game of all time.
eglenring
Try finger
EDIT: is a game worth playing, very fun mechanics, has some internal coherence issues and suffers from a copypasted style. Being fully honest I only felt invested half my first playthrough, then I just went through the motions for the sake of completion, but the story in itself boasts of grandiousness while being kind of shallow at the same time. My main issues are: 1- I don't care about the Lands Between and the explanations about why its conflicts haven't been solved until we arrive feel very flimsy, I mean a VERY big stretch. 2- The open world is beautiful but is a diservice to the classic progression system the Souls games have (and viceversa).

A very good game, excellent in the areas Fromsoft always is, but I won't blame you if you feel is overhyped.

The long rant:


[h1] YES - but with caution [/h1]

[h3] PROS: [/h3]
[list]
    [*]It is [b] BY FAR [/b] the most forgiving Fromsoft game ever. Ashes of war, cooperative open world, cheese locations, explore get stronger and come back. Yes, it is unforgiving, but it gives you tons of tools to get over tough spots.
    [*]The open world is gorgeous.
    [*]Weapons variety with their movesets is very good, but suffers for it though.
    [*]Ashes of war (equippable weapon abilities) is by far the part I most enjoy, they keep the combat feeling fresh.
    [*]Sinergy between temporary effects, statuses, attack types, buffs and debuffs is deep and expertly crafted, but it also suffers from this.
    [*]Armors. They're beatiful as always, and there's variety as always.
    [*]Varied enemy gallery that keeps you on your toes with their different movesets, elemental affinities and weaknesses.
    [*]Incantations are varied and feel super satisfying to cast.
[/list]


[h3] CONS: [/h3]
[list]
    [*]The lock-on targeting system really, I mean [b] REALLY [/b] needs a rework. It is super inconsistent to the point it will [b] NOT [/b] target a guy that's directly in front of you but will target a guy that's behind a wall and a flight of stairs 30+ mts away from you. The lock-on system has killed me more than enemies by straight on deviating a precise hit or making me walk to a precipice (Dragon's Dogma would never do that to me).
    [*]Stamina management is very good and I enjoy it, but considering special moves also consume FP, would you Fromsoft [b] AT LEAST [/b] not give me that much delay between attach chains?? I mean animations look cool but damage is only registered in a segment of it, rest of the time I'm open for attacks (that have way more reach than me even using the same weapon btw) so 0.2sec is [b] A LOT [/b] of time, enough to get rekt. Also, why can't I chain an attack with a roll if I have stamina?
    [*]Boss weapons, some are awesome but most are... Disappointingly lame. Gargoyle weapons suck 4$$, Crystal weapons are extremely lame. I can undertsnd not being able to apply Ashes of War, but why can't I infuse the non-affinity types with some with an element?
    [*]Sorceries are a tricky point: power does not outweight the fact that they're all some variation of "blue light goes *bling*".  Sorry Fromsoft but terribly uninspired and not satisfying at all.
    [*]Crystallian gear and sorceries do what again???? Oh never mind, they're sligtly cooler looking than some other armaments/sorceries. For real??? What a terribly missed oportunity.
    [*]Flame Monk Curved Sword is so dificcult to farm and has 0 special traits that is a complete disappointment, alongside Black/Flame Monk attire, like why the heck do they not give you a slight boost maybe in casting fire/black fire incantations? Or have the black flame incantation effect last longer in Flame Monk's armaments, or make Black Flame stronger with the full set and weapon but weaken your Magick/Holy damage output/resistance..??? Not the only case in which there are missed opportunities: Hoslow's full set should give you a slight higher evade window (since Juno is so mobile), Diallos' mask should give you decreased DEX but increase damage resist while using the Noble shield (since Diallos is weaker than Juno which makes him dependent on his shield). Marais mask shouls give you a slightly faster attack rate with Regalia of Eochaid or Marais Executioner Sword (ok I'm stretching it but you get my point: we have to farm specifically for things that are not specially rewarding).
    [*]Why the horrible downgrade to the Serpent Hunter greatspear outside the Rykard arena????????? Yeah yeah, don't give me the super bombastic wind blasting spear ability but man... that super slow SHORT RANGE attack??? Of course is very effective if you level STR but it for sure does not feel satisfying to use. At all. Horrible downgrade.
    [*]Weapon range unbalanced AF. Enemies using your same weapon and ability will have longer reach than you. Some enemies have their damage dealing window last longer than the attack itself: I can roll and avoid the first imapct and then roll again to avoid the explosion/AOE but for some reason I'm getting rekt even when enemy attack is over..? Why? Because otherwise you'll be OP..? Bro, strong enemies can still pretty much one shot me and I still can beat the crap out of weaker enemies, no need for the reach to be that unbalanced. Weak point here.
    [*]Overly repeated boss reuse. The only situation in which is ok to do it is Margit/Morgott, Mohg the Omen/Lord of Blood, the Crucible Knights, and the Ancient Hero of Zamor because is a piece of storytelling. I'm not talking about field bosses, but actual Bosses.
    [*]I understand the "dead world" scenario Fromsoft always depicts but this isn't supposed to be one as the story goes, but a world in the *process* of dying. Melina herself would ask you (if you accept the Frenzied Flame) why destroy everything if life keeps on being born, which makes no sense since everyone is either a raging zombie, a zombie soldier, a sad-sits-in-its-place zombie, a zombie boss, a demigod, a quest giver or a tarnished; no life being born at all. It is a dead world, but is inconsistent with what NPCs tell us. Love you Fromsoft but weak point here.
    [*]Weird framerate drops even at ultra low resolution (thought it was that but apparently nope)
    [*]Weird crashes while trying to connect to multiplayer (mostly collosseum but open world too
    [*]Music is good but not particularly inspired. Only one memorable song and that's the main theme.
    [*]I don't care about any of the main characters or main points of conflict, they are "cool" but I really don'r care about being the Elden Lord or feel any satisfaction about having a hand in the Lands Between's "destiny" because the story itself lets you know very clearly that the outer gods and all of the other gods just switch supremacy every milennia or so. That with the fact that I am super weak and only lucky to win any combat makes me doubt on the mental capacity of any of the main characters and that is because, sadly, Fromsoft has fallen in the formula spamming coil. It is a game with an overall expert craftmanship, but lacks the depth and coherence the Dark Souls series has.
[/list]


[h2] CONCLUSION: [/h2]

As someone who is not a fan of single player games, this is one of my favorite games. I'm glad I gave it a try. This game grabs your interest and makes it hard to leave. You encounter a boss or enemy that is hard and you won't leave until you beat it. Once you beat it, the feeling you get keeps you playing. The graphics are beautiful and I have only encountered a single bug which is amazing to think about. Don't let the difficulty keep you from playing, once you understand the game and its mechanics, it is not too bad!
Solid game but be ready to get sucked in for long playing time!

I am only saying yes as Peru might sink into the ocean if I don't. Now I consider myself an avid fan of difficult games (If I do say so myself). Fallout 2? A breeze. Wow Classic, no sweat. However, Elden Ring was found on the ninth floor of Dante's Inferno, chained to the pulsating nut sack of Satan himself. The amount of pure, unbridled punishment this game puts you through for the hairy snatch of a medieval peasant woman is unprecedented.

Smashed to death by giant falling from sky. 

I have returned on multiple occasions as I have always felt like I just never gave the game the good ol' college try, just to have my dick so firmly placed inside my ass by every mob I come across that unless I have some sweaty no-lifer dragging me through the game, I don't stand a chance.

I first started Elden Ring in 2022 and just finally finished this game to completion ahead of the DLC dropping and all of the time spent playing this has been enjoyed. Highly recommend, game is a masterpiece and after hundreds of hours of playing you will still find new things. 10/10
As an avid gamer who revels in immersive worlds and challenging gameplay, Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece. FromSoftware has once again proven their mastery in crafting captivating experiences that transcend mere gaming.

From the moment I stepped into the Lands Between, I was entranced by its sprawling landscapes, rich lore, and haunting beauty. The sense of discovery is unparalleled; every corner holds secrets waiting to be unearthed, every vista a breathtaking testament to the game's meticulous design.

The gameplay mechanics are both familiar and innovative, seamlessly blending the punishing difficulty of Soulsborne titles with the freedom and exploration of an open-world RPG. Combat is a delicate dance of strategy and skill, rewarding patience and precision while punishing recklessness. Mastering each encounter feels like a triumph of both intellect and reflexes.

But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its narrative depth and world-building. FromSoftware has crafted a mythos so intricately woven that every character, every piece of dialogue, every item holds significance. The lore is not spoon-fed; it's there for those willing to delve deep, adding layers of meaning to every action and decision.

And let's not forget the mounted combat ‚Äì a game-changer that adds a new dimension to exploration and combat. Galloping across the vast expanse of the Lands Between, engaging in epic battles atop majestic steeds, is an experience that will stay with me long after the credits roll.
Big Sword Good Game
everythings good only fire giant this absolute mf is the flaw of the games by himself
One of my favorite games of all time; played for hours on Xbox and just got the PC version for Shadow of the Erdtree. I never thought I would enjoy a Souls-type game and frequently stayed away. It was after my friends convinced me to play I realized I could play so much more than just FPS. If you are hesitant, I would say give it 10 hours, it is a slow starting game. Just enjoy the atmosphere and try to find cool things. 
For those who might be curious since I ask everyone else, my builds have been:
- Poison/Scarlet Rot dual spears (I know, I know...)
- Madness
- executioner sword (I know, another meta...)
- Celebrant's rib rake
- Crossbow/Black bow
and am currently trying a thorn build on PC

best Lords of the Fallen copy I have ever played
The lack of any ability besides actually getting banned and ending up on a server for the banished to play without anti cheat is truly disappointing and it is a lazy design choice at this point that it has not been addressed. If you don't want to play with mods and potential cheaters then don't, if you don't care then you should be able to just turn it off. It's all about consent and choice lmao. Anyways, besides that negative disclaimer everything else here is golden, it's a supersized Dark Souls with it's own unique identity that sets it apart from the rest. It really does feel like they took every lesson learned from previous titles, scrubbed most of the bad and kept most of the good and then improved upon it as a whole. Did you perhaps really appreciate the consumable and environment based system from Demon's Souls? That's a completely viable play style here or you could ignore it completely and go for the more predictable (in terms of PVP) Dark Souls model. You can even go ham on an aggression build, and while you won't fully get something as satisfying as Bloodborne it's more than you can pull off in any of the other like titles. The lore is going to take you a long time to wrap your head around even if you are an avid reader. This game does not give you a story that makes sense until you speak to everyone and read every item description and even then it's based on the context of your choices and individual perceptions. You almost have to collaborate with other peoples experiences to get a full picture, much like Dark Souls but bigger. It scratches that itch, being a massive game, one of the largest ever successfully developed but filled with zero fetch quests or pointless content, it's all interesting and not at all repetitive. Everything has a point and a purpose and it is astonishingly impressive that they pulled that off within a semi non linear world. The Witcher 3 did this 2nd best and it's still full of time wasting errands that are just there to inflate the amount of time you spend with the game. The graphics are top notch, the game play is great if you like souls games, the magic system is very much expanded but not at all required, the story is an enigma and it's your job to decipher it and share your findings, the sound design and music are in my opinion 2nd only to Bloodborne, the replayability is an art itself and it's perfect here. Need I say more? In a world where supposed AAA devs are ripping people off left and right this game is worth way more than the listed price. You'll be at it for years and you won't regret a minute, well except for mistakes that you can only really blame on yourself.
Elden ring is as good as hitting a fent cart. 1 2 buckly my shoe, skibidi rizz
The game is absolutely insane aye
Yes 10/10 Everything, recommend this
GOOD GAME RECCOMEND HIGHLY
GOAT

good
I recommend this for everyone who has the time to explore this game to the fullest and spend the time needed to make the game worth buying. As a big fan of the DS franchise aswell as BB and in general Souls-like games i was very disappointed about the greater game design but specially the boss design. There are a few bosses that seem like they received the same love every DS boss received. But then there is a ton  of bosses who seem to be made with the idea "from software games must be hard so the bosses must be annoying and just spamming attacks because we dont have the time to spend the time needed to make a challenging boss." If this game would have had two more years in development and world building it could have been what it seemingly wanted to be, a darksouls similar game but with an open world. But it was released with bad bosses who are very repetitive, have no complexity in their move set and just spam their attacks. Nothing to learn about, no way to get into most of their move sets because their are no gaps to find its just dodge dodge dodge hit  and so on. The open world is incredibly empty but the dungeons and castles you do find are fun to play through and the bosses you find are fun if you find and fight one of them for the first time. My personal problem with the game is the strong push towards playing magic builds. As someone who loves it to wield a big sword or axe and wear cool looking armor this game is less enjoyable. The run i have where i build strength was very exhausting and no fun at all. The magic focused run was way easier especially with the bosses but still not what i look for in a souls-like. If you like open world games with a lot to explore and fun challenging areas this is a game you might have fun with but be warned about the boss fights they are less fun than most other games from this genre.

Im bad at this game
This is a "Dark Souls" kind of game aka you die a lot. The multiplayer is clunky, but it was a design choice to get you thinking about the "fingers" in the lore more. There is no way to compare a merchant's equipment to the (up to three sets at the same time) equipped gear. 

I stuck with it enough to make it through a cave and travel across a large section of the map (Spoiler: I got to the "roundtable" map location). I am not sure if it is worth playing based on the QOL approach that the devs have taken to this thing.

There isn't much that I am spoiling if you have gone through the tutorial, so I am going to just say "Things I wish I knew when I started":
1) "runes" are coins that enemies drop when killed and they are auto collected. "XXX runes" are items that you collect where XXX is any adjective. Note that the coins you have drop when you die and despawn if you die again before picking them up. Note that items stay with you forever. This was explained like 3 times but the fact that the exact same word is the noun between those two made me still think I was going to lose my "golden rune", "smithing rune", etc. whenever I died.
2) the way to make any in-game progression is to either
 - grind to get "good" by dying several times memorizing boss and creature "tells" on what they will do next
 - grind to get "overleveled" by rune-coin farming and spending the coins on levels. (you kill stuff, auto collect rune-coins, touch "respawn point" to revive all enemies, rinse repeat) then buy level stat upgrades.
 - partially cheese any boss by using either "summon spirit ashes" or "multiplayer summon online player" to help you defeat the local boss then your helper despawns
 - get better gear, but all the merchants have "tutorial level gear", so make due and progress the game in other ways via grinding THEN access areas with better gear?
3) You need to "touch grass" often. Substantially all enemies respawn when you "touch grass" aka the respawn "touch grace light" locations. Also substantially all enemies respawn when you die and respawn. Unless you "fast travel" to a "touch grass" point, you will spend your time "grinding" to just travel unless you get the horse.
4) Spoiler: you get the horse by touching 3 unique grasses (not in dungeon) then [EDIT] visit the first location (a church's grass) at night or by dying and respawning at that first church's grass.
Spoiler: you get the spirit bell to summon "spirit ashes" by [EDIT] having the horse and wating at least 1 day where you ride the horse then visiting the first church's grass at night or dying and respawning at the first church's ashes.
5) Multiplayer messages and "blood stains" showing deaths are the only predictable interactions with players. This gives info about "be cautious" or secrets.

Based on all the info i have gotten from the game, Its UX is going to be clunkier regarding QOL and I don't want to spend my time doing grinding to be able to hit "bigger things" with my tutorial sword.
Difficult at first, many secrets, deep gameplay. I recommend to play online. Amazing mood, lore and exquisite crafted world.
this game wildin
Makes me incredibly irate, my blood pressure and heart rate definitely rise while playing. Good game design and beautiful boss fights and scenery. 10/10 waiting for DLC while I finish a play through.

didn't have fun 10/10
Alright, gather round, fellow casual gamers, for the epic tale of my journey through Elden Ring. Spoiler alert: it was like trying to juggle flaming swords while riding a unicycle on a tightrope. In other words, it was an absolute circus.

First off, let's talk about character creation. I spent a good hour tweaking my avatar's nose length, only to realise later that in the grand scheme of things, it didn't matter because my face was going to be hidden behind a helmet 99% of the time. Thanks for letting me agonise over nostril size, FromSoftware.

Then there's the combat. Oh boy, the combat. I swung my sword like a toddler flailing at a pi√±ata, hoping for some sweet loot to fall out. But instead, I got a swift kick in the teeth from a skeletal knight who probably chuckled at my feeble attempts. And don't even get me started on the dodge mechanic‚ÄîI dodged right into more trouble than I dodged out of. It's like my character had a death wish.

Exploration? Yeah, that was a laugh. I set out to conquer the vast open world of Elden Ring, only to find myself lost in the woods faster than Hansel and Gretel on a sugar rush. Every time I thought I was making progress, a giant monster or a gang of bandits would pop out of nowhere and remind me that I was just a puny mortal in a world of pain.

Oh, and let's not forget the story. I'm sure it's deep and meaningful, with layers upon layers of lore waiting to be uncovered. But honestly, I was too busy trying not to get skewered by a dragon to pay attention to the intricacies of the plot. Call me when there's a "Casual Gamer" difficulty setting that comes with a CliffsNotes version of the storyline.

But you know what? Despite all the frustration, Elden Ring somehow managed to keep me coming back for more punishment. Maybe it's the gorgeous landscapes, or the adrenaline rush of finally taking down a boss after a hundred failed attempts. Or maybe I'm just a glutton for punishment. Either way, Elden Ring gets a solid 10 out of 10 for making me feel simultaneously triumphant and utterly incompetent. It's a special kind of masochism, and I can't get enough of it.
Elden Ring was a great game to play through. Plenty of fun all round, good combat system. Only thing I would complain about is the game not being cross platform but besides that Fromsoftware delivered an amazing game and I can't wait to play the other souls games.
√â o melhor jogo que eu j√° joguei. :D
I have 150 hours on my main character and I still haven't finished the game
My friend got me this as a gift and let me say that he very well may know me better than i do becuase i thought i would not enjoy Elden Ring. Boy, was i wrong.
Good game to co op at the start when learning the ropes.
Malenia my beloved

Pretty good - 8/10

Best open world exploration game I've ever played. It's challenging but extremely rewarding.
Dodge and weave then wail on something a bit while dying 100 times isn't exactly a fun, engaging combat cycle, nor does it lend itself to emergent combat mechanics; neither does the flat, entirely damage-scaling leveling system which clearly would do Dark Souls games better if it didn't exist in the first place and they just put more capacities into armor and weapons based on what I've seen and heard of other Souls games.

Those who say this game is amazing, for everything I've encountered, are delusional if they think this game is perfect, or even worthy of high praise. I've gone as far as Stormveil. The encounters and stealth are by far the only both good and fun design here, and the encounters so far are done nearly perfectly if not perfectly, but that's certainly an aspect low in priority over the base of the game itself.

Don't praise something just because you personally enjoyed it. Praise what is worthy of praise, and boo what is worthy of booing. Or do you care so little about creator's welfare that you'd rather tell them a lie so they can go on to make mediocre creations, let alone your own when you tell lazy megacorporations "I'll pay 60 USD full price for garbage, and praise it too!"

Am making a mod to fix the combat. Enjoy the pointless grinding and lifewasting without it with unfulfilling skill that doesn't transfer between different enemies and bosses. Was fun dying a million times to Tree Sentinel until I realized it's just pointless grinding and lifewasting with unfulfilling and unsatisfying skill that doesn't transfer between different enemies and bosses. Game is irredeemable without mods, but even the mods fall short of perfect, so I'll do it myself.
yes

i mean, what a game.
The open world is feels bland and repetitive, with barely any incentive to stray off the path, because there's not much to see. There are also many enemies with attacks that seem cheesy and unavoidable, which leads to some deaths feeling cheap and not deserved. Still, awesome music and awesome combat. The build variety is insane, so very replayable. Start with Dark Souls, then Sekiro, then this.

good game fun if you have the mod with friends
This game is a jank mess and a perfect example of why open world games are the worst thing gaming ever came up with. You're presented with the option to explore everything, but that's not what they want you to do, they have a clearly defined path they want you to follow. The game is gated behind mechanics you aren't told about till you progress through these railroaded paths, even after they go out of their way to create a tutorial area to highlight how the game works. That this game is lauded so highly while being so sub par in presentation, and the fact that you can't suggest these are bad without people who bashed their head against a wall to figure out how the game operated and then the subsequent hoard of people that read their guide and will act haughty about how they didn't have a problem with figuring it out will bury you for suggesting that this game hallmarks the declining interest in quality of a game over how the community needs something to rally around and anything that has a large budget and doesn't have Ubisoft/EA/etc. stamped on it has to be better.

Eldemn Rimng
This is, without a shadow of a doubt, the greatest game I have ever played and I can genuinely say that this is a game that almost anyone can find a way to enjoy. 

For context, I'm usually a big FPS, BR, racing, and sports game person (anything with sustained action has me locked in). I had heard of and looked slightly into Elden Ring when it first released and even watched my sister play some of it, but it didn't seem like my taste. About a year later, my girlfriend and our mutual friend started playing it and suggested that I give it a try. I told them bluntly, "I don't know if I'm going to play it. It looks kinda boring in my opinion." They urged me to buy it and if I didn't like it, to return it and get my money back. Elden Ring then proceeded to death grip me and became the only game I played consistently since. 

In almost every conceivable way, Elden Ring is nearly the textbook definition of perfection. The story, albeit very difficult to grasp without looking up a breakdown of it online, is deep and rich. The open worldness of the game lets you pick your own progression path, and generally allows you to get any items you want at any time (except for progression locked areas like Mountaintop of the Giants, Consecrated Snowfield, Crumbling Farum Azula, and the Haligtree). There is a massive number of different types of items to utilize throughout the game, and creates an amazing opportunity to try different character builds across different playthroughs. 
Most importantly, the game play itself is a chef's kiss. I went into Elden Ring thinking I could beat the ever living piss out of everything and tank most hits with minimal consequence, and I was dead wrong. This game challenges and forces you learn how to play it, and its learning curve is steep at times, but is largely enjoyable and engaging from early game through to end game. But at every single point, it is satisfying to look back on the bosses and sections of the game that seemed impossible but now are a cake walk.

From being a person who thought they were going to hate Elden Ring to someone who considers it their favorite game of all time, I highly suggest everyone to give Elden Ring a try. You could always return it within two hours if you end up not liking it... (but in some way, I guarantee you will)
oh its the boat man again

‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£Ä‚£§‚°∂‚†ñ‚†õ‚†õ‚†â‚†â‚£Å‚£§‚†Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚†â‚†Å‚¢∏‚†â‚†â‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

‚†ü‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†É‚¢Ä‚†à‚†â‚¢Å‚£®‚£≠‚£ø‚°ø‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢∫‚°á‚†Ä‚£Ä‚£ø‚£ø‚°è‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£ø‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

‚†¥‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ò‚†≥‚£Ñ‚†Ä‚¢∏‚£ø‚£ø‚°Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚¢ø‚£ø‚£¶‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†à‚†ª

‚†§‚†Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£Ä‚°Ä‚¢Ä‚°Ä‚†§‚†Ä‚†â‚¢Ä‚£Ä‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ü‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚£ø‚£¶‚†à‚†õ‚¢∑‚£Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

pretty good
This was my first experience with a souls-like game and I think I started from the top. So, when I started the game for the first time, they showed me a short cutscene and just put me into the game with no specific missions, no journal, no characters around me except for one dude who literally told me to get some maidens. There is no indication on where to go and what to do. So, you know, you just start walking around and in front of you is a knight that is 5 times bigger than you and if he notices you, he one shots you. 

Anyway, after walking around and exploring I started to get some weapons, runes etc. but still have no idea what to do. So, I did the only thing I could do, just started riding the horse around the place and found myself in Caelid, which is the Australia of Elden Ring. And that wasn't a fun experience because, again, there is no indication on where you can go and where you should go-avoid. So you only know where you shouldn't be after getting eaten by dogs that are 4x your size.

Jokes aside, I usually try to go everywhere in games, explore every detail so that I don't miss out on stuff but in Elden Ring, that is very hard to do. So I always had this feeling that I am missing content. After playing for about 35-40 hours I started watching-reading some guides so that I don't completely miss out on important stuff and this being my first souls-like game, it helped. So, if you like souls-like games, just go on this journey without looking at anything but for me, playing with a guide was actually really fun. I played the game on a 1440p monitor with max settings with a 4090 and graphics are out of this world, so often, I stopped to take pictures or just look at the views because the game is looking gorgeous. I mean, what else to say, one of the best games ever created both gameplay and graphics wise. Story is also good but not having journals or mission descriptions can make you forget some of the parts of the story but I suppose that's just how these games are. What a great journey this was
gud game
Embrace the pain. Become Elden lord. There's a magic Lady with four arms what more could you ask for?
YES
Elden Ring is currently by far the best souls-like in almost any way. I'll spare the praise as many others already did and just mention the only complains I have to not call it a perfect game. But this is complaining on a very high level.

1. There are way too many caves and catacombs. I mean that this feels repetitive from level design to boss variety. It feels like the department for items, ash of war and spells was outperforming the level design department and they just said, " screw this, we copy and paste from now on to include all that crap". fewer but better caves and catacombs would have been the much better choice in my opinion.
2. ER is lacking the dense atmosphere of former Fromsoft games. I know I shouldn‚Äôt compare it to Dark Souls as ER is its own thing. But I miss the thrill of desperately looking for the next bonfire and feeling the relief when finally activating it. This mostly only applies to the open world and is caused by design.

I still would say 10/10 (or 9.9/10 if you want)

.
There is not much to say besides that this is easily one of the greatest games of ALL time, and that's coming from someone who's never played a souls game until now. They do not make games like this anymore. This is 100% a generational title. DO NOT MISS OUT!
Has crab and prawn. Never met someone who likes crab and prawn that I cant trust
gang
This game is not good, but it's not bad either. I still had good times playing it.

The combat is similar to the Dark Souls series, which is fine, but there are still some clunky controls present, such as input queueing, input delays, and certain unnecessary animations that can't be canceled to roll.

Camera still suck, it's nightmare when you fight the big bosses or in tight room, your camera will be your biggest enemy because you can't see things. The lock-on feature can maybe worse, if it lock-on legs or hand of big bosses when they attacking, the camera will spin a lot and made me dizzy.

The world in Elden Ring is beautiful and has great world-building. The graphics may not be good, but the game has a great art style that makes the world look stunning. They have created a large map, but it lacks enough content. There are many similar dungeons with slightly different layouts, filled with enemies that we have already encountered countless times. At the end of these dungeons, we often encounter the same bosses with fewer movesets and your reward most of the times is shit-tier items you never use. 

They don't even bother adding a journal for players to keep track of their next moves. You will find yourself looking for a wiki or YouTube a lot to find out your next move, which is bad. The side quests are even worse. The NPC who gives you the quest may give you a hint about where they're going or which item you'll need, but most of the time they just don't. It's not a big problem in previous titles because the map is small or even linear, so you can just play the game and still stumble upon them by chance. But in ER, the map is so large, it's very hard to keep track on quest, it's very to miss or ruined the entire quest.

FromSoftware is the best when it comes to creating boss fights. There are 238 bosses in this game, which is quite unbelievable. However, most of them are either copy-pasted or trash mobs that appear later in the game. I can only count about 20 bosses that are worth mentioning. They have very good designs but BS because their spamming of AOE moves, infinite stamina, huge hitboxes, absurd damage and long combos. 

The final boss is the worst final boss FS has ever made. Radagon is fine; he's challenging but still fair. However, the Elden Beast is an extremely frustrating fight. It unnecessarily long the battle because most of the time I can't even touch the creature. Whenever I get close, it teleports to another side of the map and relentlessly spams homing spells at you. What makes it even worse is that you don't even have Torrent with you, which is BS. And if you die, you have to find Radagon all over again. Have fun with that. 

It may seem like I really hate this game because I've complained a lot. But to be honest, it's a great game to play, and I still recommend everyone to at least try it once. This is the first time FromSoftware has made an open-world game, and they did a very good job. However, it still has a lot of flaws. I hope they will take a look at them and fix them if they decide to make another game like Elden Ring.
Miyazaki you've done it again

Ok, so I never played a souls-like game until Elden Ring. But I'm sure glad I got it. The graphics are up their with the best, the gameplay is fairly intuitive, the difficulty is hard enough to provide a challenge, but easy enough to enjoy. It runs pretty well, I have a fairly old PC by modern standards (RTX 2060). It's probably the best game for beginning your journey onto the souls-like genre. You can absolutely sink hours into it, making it, in my opinion, absolutely worth the asking price, and more.

good
The absolute best option for an into to the soulsborne genre, with phenomenal combat, exploration, story, and a beautiful world to explore. The difficulty is far more forgiving than any other fromsoft game, and the game is incredibly well polished. 

Some of the late game bosses feel blatantly unfair and bullshit,  but the sheer number of easy ways to cheese them if they get too annoying cuts back on that pretty quick. The game is balanced around the idea of using summons and calling other players to help you,  By the time they become a problem you have to deal with, you'll be able to manage well enough.
"Elden Ring" is not just a game; it's an odyssey, a journey into a meticulously crafted world that challenges and captivates in equal measure. From the visionary minds at FromSoftware, creators of the acclaimed Souls series, and the masterful storytelling of Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R.R. Martin comes a gaming experience that sets new standards for the medium.

At its heart, "Elden Ring" is about exploration and discovery. The Lands Between, a vast and interconnected realm, invites players to chart their own course through its sprawling landscapes, each more breathtaking and perilous than the last. Whether traversing dense forests, scaling treacherous mountains, or delving into the depths of forgotten ruins, every step is a testament to the game's unparalleled world design.

But it's not just the world itself that mesmerizes; it's the stories it holds. "Elden Ring" weaves a rich tapestry of lore and mythology, drawing players into a narrative that is as enigmatic as it is compelling. From ancient legends to tragic histories, every character, every location, every encounter is steeped in significance, waiting to be uncovered by those brave enough to seek them out.

Of course, no discussion of "Elden Ring" would be complete without mentioning its challenging yet deeply satisfying gameplay. Combat is a ballet of steel and sorcery, demanding precision, timing, and strategy. From epic clashes against towering bosses to tense skirmishes with cunning adversaries, every encounter is a test of skill and perseverance, rewarding those who dare to face its trials head-on.

Yet perhaps what truly sets "Elden Ring" apart is its sense of freedom. Unlike many open-world games, it doesn't just give players a vast playground to explore; it gives them agency, allowing them to shape their own destiny within its world. Whether forging alliances with powerful factions, uncovering hidden secrets, or forging legendary weapons, every choice carries weight, every action has consequences.

In the end, "Elden Ring" is more than just a video game; it's an experience, a testament to the power of storytelling, world-building, and interactive entertainment. It challenges, it inspires, it enraptures, leaving an indelible mark on all who dare to venture into its world. For anyone seeking an adventure unlike any other, "Elden Ring" is a must-play masterpiece that will be remembered for years to come.
its elden ring

Best Fromsoftware game to date.
I played this modded and was cheating. The only thought I had was *This must suck playing legitimately*

Late to the party, was my first Soulslike but got me hooked really quick. BotW open world and dungeons vibes. Looking forward to the DLC!
An amazing game that exceeded all of my expectations. Building off the DNA of their previous games (not Dark souls 2, everyone knows and agrees that that game is utter putrid garbage) Miyazaki integrated an open-world aspect to make an enormous world that I found myself lost in. The design for the art, combat, and enemies were also incredible as all of Miyazaki's games are (with the exception of the cheap imitation of a Miyazaki game known as Darksouls 2, which was made without him).  

TLDR: Dark souls 3 meets Skyrim, amazing game, 10/10.
godskin duo and waterfowl dance.
flasks are somewhat outdated, as in the souls game you had a shit ton of time to use them. Now? it's a risk even glancing at your R key.
other than that? yeah, get it if you're into soulsborne/soulslike. (the difference is staggering, surely) Probably the best souls game to start with, as it's (in my opinion) easier than the rest. Whole lot of area to explore, with a ton of lore, and plenty of weapons/spells/incantations. Plenty of replayability. Also, some advice: Don't use YouTube build guides. By all means, use YouTube or the fan wiki to find where to go, or where to find things. But your build should be your own.

Very nice not hard at all..
In short: A major improvement over Dark Souls 1 and 2 in terms of gameplay (haven't played the rest). The open world aspect is kind of boring, but not enough to make me mad. Story is still mostly whatever but at least respects your time which I can appreciate as usual. The post-processing is a fucking abomination.

In more details:
Gameplay:
+faster everything, less of a snooze-fest
+a lot of efforts made to break away from the series' well-known monotone roll-stab-roll-stab, shield-stab-shield-stab one-on-one is-it-my-turn-yet fights
.....a strong focus on group fights, both one-vs-many and many-vs-many, naturally bringing variety and tension in fights and rewarding agressivity
.....lots of enemies now designed to make you use a variety of defensive maneuvers in a single fight, trying to make you switch between dodging, running away, ducking, jumping, circling around, blocking, parrying, or stunning the opponent
.....more meaningful variety in attacks too, with guard counters to spice up sword-and-board gameplay and jumping attacks or charged attacks as high-risk high-reward moves to stun enemies and open them up for further punishment
.....very interesting ashes of war system that allows the customization of one attack as well as the stats of every basic weapon and creates an incentive for switching between one-handed and two-handed weapon handling mid-battle
.....mounted battle
+pvp truly optional
+monsters' physical and elemental resistances actually somewhat important, yet another incentive to switch up your gameplay
+much more difficult, but still very reasonable difficulty

-still impossible to pause the game, even with multiplayer being now optional
-still long-ass useless 'you died' screen to waste your time, especially during pseudo-multiplayer when you're invading npcs
-a lot of damage sponges

World:
The open world nature of the game creates a lot of downtime during exploration that you may or may not like. It also features some of the most blatant copy-pasting that I've ever seen in my life in big productions. I don't particularly mind it, but it is certainly noteworthy. You'll see the same rooms, the same rock formations, the same elevator shafts... dozens of times each.

Graphics:
I honestly think that the artists that have worked on this game must be mad about their art director. The decors, characters and animations aren't outstanding, but they're certainly very nice. Miles better than anything I could produce of course, and well worth the probable dozens of millions invested to make them. So where was the need to throw it all down the drain with all that unbearable post-processing? If you were to play it vanilla, you'd see the game's beautiful artwork through the lens of: at least four layers of blurring (anti-aliasing, motion blur, depth of field, chromatic aberration), at least three ways of fucking up the lighting (vignette, auto-exposure, lens flare), ridiculously strong color filters and a thick layer of volumetric fog. It makes me think of those face-blurring filters that you have on tv to protect people's anonymity. Trying one's hardest to turn a normal image into an incomprehensible smudge on the screen. Obviously one's hardest is a bit of an exaggeration here since it's just enabling a few checkboxes on your game engine, but still, I can't play this game vanilla for more than ten minutes without hurting my eyes. I'm not joking. A blurry mess, flashes of blinding lights and deep darkness randomly alternating every few seconds and a view distance of ten meters. That is the shocking reality of vanilla Elden Ring graphics.
I suppose all modern AAA games are like that by default, but I wouldn't know because 1. I don't play that many AAA games, 2. In the vast majority of those games, you can disable those stupid effects. But here you can't. Or well, you can't except for depth of field and motion blur, which is already something I guess. I couldn't bear it so I played the game modded to remove whatever effect I could, and you certainly should do the same. Honestly, if I didn't know that you can alleviate that problem through mods, I wouldn't recommend the game based on that point alone as it is absolutely unacceptable.
1st of all, I have beaten this game on PS side (all bosses) so don't mind the gameplay time.

ELDEN R√ñNG. Been playing this since beta test and gotta say this is a mixed bag if something. It's beautiful to watch and listen to (I was mesmerized of the main theme for a long time) but sadly, the gameplay - or the way this game makes you play is a letdown. I mean the diversity of player builds, There are a few builds that absolutely bulldozer the whole game, so the so-called freedom is not there; literally you take a spear, infuse it with bleed, take a shield and that's it. - you are nigh-invincible. Congrats, feel free to kill everything. The game even MAKES you do this, because some of the bosses are full of one-shot killing gimmicks, especially that one.... you know, THE one. I played over 100 hours and then I had to change my whole build to beat her. Yes, I  know it's a SKILL issue also, because I kinda suck at souls-likes, even though I have beaten DARK SOULS 3 several times and some others I won't list here. 

After changing my build the little rest of the game was easy-peasy and so on.. the point being it's an OK game to beat - ONCE.

Later, I bought this game again (momentary lapse of reason), this time for PC. It was kinda nice at first, looks better than on PS and yadda-yadda... then I realized, after ten or so hours... this is absolute crock. This game is an absolute Bore after the first "round". Co-op is boring, bosses are boring, everything feels like a chore and the list goes on and on...

I won't be buying the DLC, I won't be playing this anymore. so guess I just don't like ER. I understand people who love this game, the lore is interesting, and like I said it's a beautiful game to watch and listen to. Sadly the most important thing, the actual game, is just hollow. DARK SOULS 3 is a masterpiece, ER is: Put a ring on it - and divorce after the honeymoon. That is the ELDEN R√ñNG. Thank you, waiting for ELDEN Shop.

fun :D
Beat the game for the first time after about 113 h of playtime and only this "soon", because I felt like I shouldn't continue searching every nook and cranny to see everything and find every hidden item or place this game has to offer. And there is a lot this game has to offer besides the main story path.

Elden Ring is my first Fromsoft game, and it got me hooked, even though I usually don't like dying over and over again. 
But this game isn't unfair. It offers so many possibilities to play it and make it easier for yourself, if you do wish so. 
And even if you die a lot, you probably learned something from it. I still remember how it made me feel to finally beat the Tree Sentinel at the start of the game, after dying to it over and over again and almost losing hope, but not quite wanting to give up. It was truly exciting and invigorating to finally defeat it.

If that doesn't sound like an experience you want to go through, then maybe the game really just isn't for you. It doesn't hold your hand, platforming can get incredibly annoying at times, NPC questlines can be easily screwed up and sometimes there's this moment, when you stand in front of a certain lake of rot and just wish to go home. 
But there are also those moments, when your heart is loudly beating in your chest, as you see the sliver of health left on one of the bosses, you died to quite a lot already. And then you finally beat it. 

I love the freedom this game provides. There are so many places to discover, so many builds to choose from, so many enemies you can confront, but most of the time don't even have to, if you don't feel like it. 
The world of Elden Ring is vast, beautiful and cruel, harboring interesting characters, be it NPCs or Bosses.

This game was made to be fun and it shows.

elden ring!!!
TL;DR: great solo experience, and 1v1 PVP. Co-op is lacking (at least unmodded - big up Seamless Coop person/ team) and forget about team PVP with friends VS other teams.

Everything you would expect from a FromSoftware game. Engaging boss fights, breathtaking vistas, cryptic lore, satisfying combat mechanics. 
Add to that the dissapointing afterthought that has historically been multiplayer in these games. We get an arena, but no clear way to team up vs others. As a result anything but dueling is dead. Great.

One point:
There are many ways to simplify/trivialize PvE by a significant amount (broken builds, bleed everything, npc phantoms, the comet). It is up to the player to create their difficulty setting. Would be nice to have more options that make the game harder as well (there is only currently a talisman that increases damage taken by the player afaik)
Literally the best RPG I've ever played. At first I couldn't get into it because it was too hard and frustrating and I hadn't played a souls-like before. After coming back to it and persisting I'm blown away by the amount of effort and polish in this game.

Top 3 favorite game of all-time. Don't hesitate, just buy it and enjoy!
Elden Ring is an achievement in game development. Among FromSoft's catalog of excellent games, it stands as the pinnacle of everything they've done thus far. Few games come close to Elden Ring in the value that it provides: a sprawling open world to explore, some of the most creative enemy and boss designs ever put in a game, engaging combat, intriguing lore and unique worldbuilding, and so, so much replay value. There's so many different builds you can create that fundamentally change how combat feels and you approach the game. For example, here's a quick rundown of how different my builds have been between playthroughs: 

1st. Colossal Sword & Greatshield - A Strength heavy build meant to tank damage and hit hard. This is basically the character I've been playing since Dark Souls 1. Looking back, it's a slow and cautious way to play the game, and I was missing out on so much by sticking with that build. 
2nd. Sorceries & Cold - My first Magic build. Create distance, and use spells to deal damage and buff yourself. This was the first time I truly melted a boss. Comet Azur and Terra Magica is a brutal combo. While you can hit enemies from far away, you're more fragile without the strong defense of a shield. 
3rd. Dexterity & Bleed - Getting close and cutting quickly with katanas is everything. Unlike my strength build, I have no shield to protect me; I have only my dodge to rely on. This has been my favorite playthrough so far because the fights feel more intense, but I've been blasting through the game like never before.

I already have plans for at least two more builds I want to play through the game with (Faith build, then Dragon Knight). With each time through the game, I've found more and more things I've missed each time. It makes me realize how truly massive Elden Ring is, and I still enjoy the game as much after 220 hours as I did after just 5. You will get your money's worth out of this game. In a market saturated with unoriginal and boring products, this is a wise purchase indeed.
when the dlc was announced I had child support due, and I had to chose one or the other... I will let you guess which one I got

best game ever
GOAT Nuff Said
     1,000 hours later, I think it's finally time I gave my thoughts on this game. I've been meaning to do this for a long, long time but my opinions on the game kept changing, not changing, and everything in between. I've done dozens upon dozens of playthroughs for the other souls game and this one is no different in that regard but it's also been by far the most polarizing to me out of all them. To tell you the truth, another reason why I held off on doing this was because I know how much people love this game, how much hype there is surrounding it, and I didn't want to be seen as that guy that just wants to rain on someone's parade. I also didn't feel like getting spammed with the usual "git gud" garbage but I guess you could say my playtime has given me the confidence I needed to finally put my thoughts out there. You could also say that this is just as much my own personal story with Elden Ring as it is a review of it.

     I played Elden Ring a month after it came out and I'm gonna be blunt, I was not impressed by the end of my first playthrough. I didn't hate it but it was definitely my least favorite out of all the other games. I was so disappointed with my enjoyment of the game that I replayed the other games to see if I was missing something or being too harsh on the game or anything like that. I played Sekiro for the first time and fell in love with it almost immediately. I did SL1 runs of the whole trilogy to see the bosses were really as well designed as I remembered (they were). Once I was done with all that, I went back and tried a couple of different builds in Elden Ring. I really tried to break down what it was that didn't click with me. I was trying really hard to understand why I was replaying every boss in Sekiro multiple times just for fun while I couldn't be bothered to fight half of the bosses in Elden Ring again after beating them the first time.

     If I were to sit here and talk about every single problem I have with this game, this shit would damn near turn into a novel so I'm gonna try to condense it as best I can. I didn't have any problems with the open world mechanics but I found the world, the lore, and the story to be far less interesting then it's predecessors. I loved the wide variety of builds with the spells and ashes of war but hated the balancing and how many of the magic types were so barebones to the point of being nonexistent (I can feel my blood pressure rising just thinking about bubble spells). I didn't like how the game felt too easy with spirit ashes but also didn't like how annoying the game was without them. I was frustrated with the performance of the game and how it always kinda ran like shit despite never being outright unplayable. I absolutely despised that no matter how good I got at fighting the bosses (getting into no hit territory), they never reached the fun level of Bloodborne, Sekiro, or DS3. Like I said, I could on and on about all the little shit for hours but I doubt anyone would care that much.

     I need to make this clear, I never hated Elden Ring. I would never have gone through 1,000 hours if I outright hated it. In fact, I think one of the biggest reasons why I kept playing it so damn much was because I was trying to find that magic that everyone else was experiencing without even trying. I eventually resorted to mods (some of them even made by me) to try and just fix the problems myself. Some were more fun then others but I eventually realized that I was just setting myself up for disappointment. It's around this time that I started to change my philosophy a little. If the other games were As to high Bs for me in terms of enjoyment then I wanted to try get Elden Ring up to a B- as opposed to the C- it currently sat at with me. I accepted that Elden Ring's just never going to be my favorite but I still wanted to at least be comfortable where I stand with the game.

     I wish I could describe some magical moment where everything just clicked and it instantly became my favorite game but the truth is that it was more of a soft click then a hard click. Over time, I either made my peace with or found workarounds for a lot of the things that bugged me, I grew to appreciate some of improvements Elden Ring made from it's predecessors, and I kept making more and more memories with the game. I was able to do so many things in Elden Ring with my OCs (ones that I've had as far back as Demon Souls) that I just straight up could not do in any of the other games. I lost my dad, almost lost my mom, and went through the darkest period of depression and anxiety I've ever felt and there's no denying that Elden Ring helped pull me through that time period. My opinion of the game has come a long way since my first playthrough and I think I'm finally up to that B- I mentioned earlier. It's not even close to being my favorite souls game, I still stand by all of the problems I have with the game, but I'd be lying if I told you that I regretted all the hours I spent on this game.

Oh my god, this game is a giant emotional roller coaster and I know that sounds bad, but the game is really rewarding has some of the best graphics I've ever seen. Most of the game is about trial and error, you walk into a boss you will probably loss pretty hard but either after awhile of trying or coming back later the boss feels less like a unbeatable powerhouse and more like a equal. The games characters, level design, spells/weapons, boss design, aptmisphere ect are all amazing. Never in a game have I walked into a room see a giant hand shooting magic orbs from his middle finger and stun locked him into oblivion with a oversized pizza cutter. Even with this in mind the game still has alot of problems their are alot of repeated bosses and content, the game is super overwelming for newcomers, alot of stuff you worked hard on doesnt give a good reward, and some stuff is just plainly unfair. Overall I still think this game is a master piece after overcoming the overwelming parts but could still have improvements which i'm hoping to see in the DLC

This game is a masterpiece. I can't begin to explain and detail as to how much the game does a great job than ever before trying to tell you a story, while the sense of wonder and mystery is still there just like in the previous Soulsborne titles, but this time around, they are offering a bit more. The world tells a story even more so than ever before, and you will feel like exploring every nook and cranny as there may be something that escaped your view the first time you went that path. And there's so much to explore, the world really opens up and absorbs you in. Don't  expect to feel too challenged in this game compared to previous titles, as it's not focusing on that, and yes, there are some reused models, just like in other games.

I definitely recommend this game to long-time fans of the series and genre, and even if you didn't play the other games, but you would like to try something in this genre, do yourself a favor and try out this game. You won't be disappointed.

haha boss hp go bye bye
I have never played any From Software games but I've heard great things about Elden Ring and decided to try it out. It was great indeed! Not sure if anyone wants to actually read all this, but I want to share it anyway.

From reviews I knew that it has amazing worldbuilding that is provided in cryptic small pieces. And that the best way to play the game is to go in blind and try to figure things out by myself without any spoilers. So I did.  Played in offline mode. Did not look any information on the Internet aside from few technical things. 

What i enjoyed:  


[h1] Non-combat [/h1]


1. Open world freedom. After Stormveil I realized that pretty much all  of the game is optional. Do what you  want in whatever order you want. Your journey, your rules. Which is awesome as I love my games to be as non-linear as possible.    

2. Cryptic exposition. I spent hours wandering around the world, trying to learn its properties and its history, so I can understand what's going on. As of now I formed my own theory about what happened and read no external theories, so it would be nice to see other perspectives. It is the first game I played where there is so little exposition, it is an incredible way to project one's own views and think hard on the themes the game offers.   

3. Worldbuilding is exceptional, creative and huge. It is not just about how cryptic things are but also about how interesting the world is. And it is very interesting and full of variety. For example, it is rare to see developers to commit to weird ideas, but they did and it worked.   

4. Visual design is beautiful. The game invites screenshots, and I made a ton.   

5. One of the best videogames soundtracks ever. Not much to add.   

6. Also it is my first From Software game, so I had the first time experience with "lose XP on death and try to get it back". Ingenious design that makes even high-level play tense when you carry a lot of XP on you.


[h1] Combat [/h1]


1. I love how you don't exactly need to level up to beat the game. With enough mastery, stamina and will you can push and beat any boss you want with pretty much no skills and no gear. It is very very hard and I personally am not ready to try it. But it is possible. And, on the other hand, if you strategize and stack odds in your favor by exploring, finding and crafting items, designing a build, you are  rewarded.   

2. Ended the game on level 181, started as Astrologer, over time developed my character in a more or less well-rounded Sorceror who does not die from one hit. After finishing the game I realized it more and more that my build is awesome, but there are so many more to try out.   

3. And now that I finished exploring, I can try multiplayer. Looking forward to it.  

4. Beat every single boss there was to find. Boss battles in this game are great. You need to think and tailor your strategy for each one. And each has its own strong and weak sides, which may or may not correspond to strengths and weaknesses of your character. So some enemies, even supposedly tough ones, are a breeze for your build, while some, that may be considered weak, can give you a lot of trouble even on high level. 
  

[h1] Criticism [/h1]


One strong critcism I have for Elden Ring is the design of side-quests. Just hated it. For three reasons:
   
1. Most quests are linear and for me it does not mesh well with an otherwise open-world, "do what you want" design of the overall game. You have your journey and then it all stops so a writer can push an idea he had in mind. Sure, there is a choice to not complete the quest at all, but decision on whether to lock yourself out of content or not is not exactly a good choice to make. Aside from that a player has little impact on how to complete the quest, which sucks, because I really wanted to complete some quests very differently. And had no idea why my character acts so weird.   

2. Quests are cryptic. Sure, the whole game is cryptic, but when the quests are both linear and cryptic it turns completion into a search for needle in a haystack, which rubs me the wrong way. Riding all over the map, mowing down tons of enemies just to find one obscure character mentioned by another obscure character many hours ago is not fun for me personally. With a guide it would've been far easier, I guess.

3. Some quests are just disagreeable and weird. I tried to roleplay as a generally benevolent character, so I saw no reason whatsoever to help obviously shady or downright evil characters to complete their quests. Especially, since the quests are mostly linear and there is usually no way to trick the NPC like you can in Fallout games, for example.


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

best geam
A Sprawling Adventure with Minor Gripes: 

Elden Ring is a mesmerizing journey through a vast and intricately crafted world, where every corner holds secrets waiting to be discovered. As a player who have played a few of the other titles of FromSoftware, I found myself drawn into the rich game, with a challenging gameplay, and breathtaking landscapes that define this epic adventure.

Visually, Elden Ring is a masterpiece. While the graphics may not be the focal point of the experience, they serve as a stunning backdrop to the game's immersive world. The open-world design is nothing short of awe-inspiring, inviting players to explore every nook and cranny at their own pace. The addition of the jumping mechanic adds a new layer of verticality to exploration, making traversing the vast landscapes feel more fluid and dynamic than ever before.

One of the standout features of Elden Ring is its horseback traversal. The ability to summon and customize your steed adds a sense of freedom to the game, allowing players to roam the open plains with ease. It's a welcome addition that complements the game's open-world design perfectly.

However, Elden Ring is not without its flaws. While I personally enjoyed the challenge of facing off against formidable bosses, I can understand how some players might find the difficulty frustrating. Boss battles require patience, skill, and perseverance, which may not be to everyone's taste.

Another minor issue I encountered for the PC version, was with the controller support. While I recommend playing Elden Ring with a controller for the best experience, I was disappointed to find that there was no option to display PlayStation buttons for those using a PlayStation controller. Instead, Xbox buttons were shown, which could be confusing for some players.

Despite these minor grievances, Elden Ring is a triumph of game design. From its stunning visuals to its deep and engaging gameplay, it offers a truly unforgettable experience for fans of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned Soulsborne veteran or a newcomer looking for a challenge, Elden Ring is an adventure well worth embarking on.

‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°Ä‚¢†‚£æ‚£ø‚†è‚†Ä‚††‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†õ‚†â‚†Ä‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ß‚†à‚¢π‚°á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£∞‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°Ñ‚†à‚†É‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£†‚£¥‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø

bad game i dislike this very much
it's aight
I don't know what to tell you that you probably haven't heard already.

For me, this is the absolute perfect game. The difficulty scales inversely with how much effort you put in to exploration and learning. It's a hard game, for sure. There are tons of ways you can make it harder as well, but it's very easy to explore and get stronger and overcome those difficult fights. The game is non-linear, so you can skip to whatever parts you wish to explore as well, without fear of too many consequences. Of course, there are a few quest lines you can lock yourself out of if you jump too far ahead, but you're not likely worried about those quests if you're fighting bosses that far ahead.

The combat is smooth, the controls make sense. In a very combat-centric game such as this, that is very important. It feels good fighting and learning just when to dodge, how to attack to the best effect, and when you can pause for a breath. It's very satisfying taking down a more difficult boss with some well timed attacks and rolls, rather than beefing yourself to godlike levels.

The environments are beautifully rendered, each location being very different from the next. The scenery is gorgeous, and the sheer size of the map means there are so many beautiful vistas to find.

The characters are very colorful, and the richness of the lore is also found through exploration. You aren't spoon fed the game lore like in most RPG's, you have to look for it yourself. Flavor text in items, an off meeting with an NPC giving you hints, and even reflections of real world historical events can give context to the in-game lore. There are hundreds of hours of explanations and theories surrounding the Lands Between.

In short, didn't expect message.
If you enjoy the Dark Souls games or soul type games in general, I would definitely recommend giving Elden Ring a try!! The design of the game is stunning with a free to explore world with a well developed story line and side quests! Sure there are times where I want to uninstall the game xD but it does feel very rewarding when you defeat the small bosses and especially the big boss monsters. Highly recommend getting into the before the DLC drops!!
10/10 GREAT GAME
this games has almost endless ways to play it which makes each playthrough after ur first exciting even if you have explored everything because you get to play it again in a new special way plus you can also do some of the sidequests you missed on your first playthrough to get really good items

wang lao ju
best game ever made
good
game sucks
.
I wanted to wait to write a review until I was a good ways into this, and at 185 hours I'm only just getting into the endgame on my first playthrough. And with a game of this size and scope I think you really need to get pretty far into it before offering an opinion.

I've played all the Souls and Soulslikes and I went into Elden Ring with expectations based on those experiences. But what I've found is that it's not really a Souls game, it's Dark Souls 3 meets Skyrim, and necessarily more Skyrim than Souls but with less structure than either of them. That's not necessarily a bad thing, there's nothing wrong with mixing genres, but I think that a lot of players will find their expectations challenged no matter which direction they're approaching it from. You could be an RPG gamer looking for an edgier Skyrim or a Souls player looking for something similar but a little less demanding. So it takes some time to get used to the unique feel of the game but beyond that initial learning curve it's a game with very broad appeal. 

It's a huge open world game, and coming at it from the "I want Dark Souls 4" direction, I've found progression to be slow and a little confusing. I've gotten bogged down at times exploring, doing side stuff, but then that's not really any different than what I did in Witcher 3, a game I loved,  and other RPG's. I've also found that when you focus on progression the difficulty ramps up a lot, you're clearly expected to take your time poking around, killing birds for arrow feathers, checking out dungeons, and so on.

It's this mixing of genres that's the essential concept of this game. In terms of other aspects of the game like combat mechanics Elden Ring doesn't reinvent the wheel, the combat is pretty similar to what Souls players are used to going back to the first Dark Souls. It has a plot very similar to Dark Souls 3, requiring you to kill a list of bosses in a series of different areas in order to unlock the final area and final boss. What's different here is that in Dark Souls 3 the vagueness of your goal isn't problematic because you're going to be channelled along in a linear manner. But here you're just presented with a huge world and told to figure out how to accomplish your overarching goal on your own, without any direction. 

So if you're a big fan of open world games and you just want to have a lot of fun roaming around, exploring, fighting a few bosses, without being pressured to get to specific goals, then Elden Ring works beautifully, And particularly if you have limited time for gaming you could happily spend months exploring the Lands Between. And players looking for a more structured experience can also have a good time here, provided you keep an overarching goal in mind and stay focused on that and as long as you have some sort of a plan for how you're going to get there. So one player may spend a lot of time dungeon crawling to get the runes(souls) needed to keep levelling and another player may just skip all of that and go farm for a while. Works both ways. 

And that's the beauty of it, it's intended to appeal to a lot of different gamers,  and it's done a very good job with that, particularly in drawing in a lot of players who haven't played a Souls game but are looking for something similar but more approachable. They clearly put a lot of thought and creativity into it and you have to admire them for what they've accomplished here. It's not a perfect game, there are problems , the various pieces don't always mesh well, but it's a unique experience, full of interesting content, and after a lot of thought I very highly recommend it.

A Masterpiece of Exploration and Challenge - Elden Ring Review

Elden Ring stands as a testament to FromSoftware's unparalleled ability to craft immersive worlds and challenging gameplay experiences. As a long-time fan of the Soulsborne series, I eagerly dove into the lands of the Lands Between, and I was not disappointed.

From the moment I stepped foot into the vast and beautifully crafted world of Elden Ring, I was captivated by its sheer scale and attention to detail. The landscapes are breathtakingly diverse, from lush forests to barren deserts, each area teeming with secrets waiting to be discovered. The sense of exploration is unparalleled, with every corner of the map beckoning me to venture forth and uncover its mysteries.

Of course, exploration would be nothing without the looming threat of danger, and Elden Ring delivers in spades. The combat is as challenging and satisfying as ever, requiring precision, patience, and a keen understanding of enemy patterns. Every encounter feels like a test of skill, with each victory bringing a sense of accomplishment unlike any other.

But perhaps what sets Elden Ring apart from its predecessors is its seamless integration of open-world mechanics. The addition of horseback riding and the ability to traverse the world at will adds a new layer of depth to the experience, allowing for greater freedom and immersion than ever before.

Of course, no game is without its flaws, and Elden Ring is no exception. Some may find the difficulty to be off-putting, and the sheer size of the world can be overwhelming at times. However, for those willing to embrace the challenge, Elden Ring offers an experience unlike any other, one that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece. From its breathtaking world design to its challenging gameplay, it represents everything that makes FromSoftware's games so beloved by fans. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the Soulsborne series or a newcomer looking for a challenge, Elden Ring is an adventure that should not be missed.

Elden Ring is a thrilling journey where death isn't just an end, but a lesson. As you navigate its unforgiving landscape, every demise teaches, every discovery unfolds a new layer of beauty. The true essence lies not just in survival, but in the exhilarating pursuit of uncovering the world's secrets and conquering its formidable bosses.
