tarnished
This was my first Fromsoftware game. I'd always heard wonderful things. I'd also heard a lot about the challenge, the inaccessibility, and the learning curve. I went into Elden Ring with very little in the way of expectations. The aesthetic grabbed me. If I didn't like it, at least I could say I tried. Shortly after starting the story I was hooked. The challenge felt difficult but also fair. I got the sense from the very beginning that you are rewarded for effort. Now 100 hours in, the game continues to blow me away, to keep me playing, to make me want to progress. The design is blisteringly cool. The combat is fair, challenging, and rewarding. The specs and possibilities feel endless. This quickly became the best game I've ever played. It's not for everyone, but I HIGHLY recommend giving it a shot. You may have the same experience. If you don't, at least you can say you tried.

cum
"Elden Ring" epitomizes the essence of the Soulsborne genre, offering a complex and rewarding journey that evolves from daunting to exhilarating. My personal voyage through this epic landscape was initially overshadowed by its notorious difficulty, but the game opened up significantly after navigating past the central castle area and especially once I discovered the right character build for my playstyle.

The turning point in enhancing my gameplay experience came with a strategic shift in character development‚Äîparticularly, allocating more stats to vitality. This adjustment made the game considerably more forgiving, allowing for extended exploration and combat endurance. The profound impact of such a simple change highlights an area where "Elden Ring" could improve: player guidance. For newcomers, the game's steep learning curve can be intimidating, and more accessible tutorials or resources to help players understand character building could greatly enhance the early game experience.

Graphically, "Elden Ring" is breathtaking, with each environment and panorama painstakingly crafted. However, performance issues in the later stages suggest a need for better optimization to maintain immersion without technical distractions.

The mythos of rising from a peasant to an Elden Lord is compelling, brilliantly integrating the theme of ascending to godhood as you grow in power. This narrative framework provides a rich backdrop that makes each player's progression feel significant and earned. Despite this, the game's conclusion can feel somewhat underwhelming, as it doesn't radically alter the world or reflect the monumental journey that led to it‚Äîa common critique in many open-world games.

Additionally, my experience was significantly enhanced by modifications I implemented myself, such as adjusting the game to run at 120 fps and enabling unlimited respec options. These modifications suggest that such features would be beneficial if included natively within the game, as they address fundamental aspects of gameplay fluidity and flexibility that can enhance player satisfaction.

As I anticipate the expansion "Shadow of the Erdtree," I reflect on "Elden Ring" as a landmark in gaming. It's a title that offers a profound, if sometimes perplexing, adventure that challenges players to explore, adapt, and conquer. The game stands as a pillar of the genre, offering a journey that is as rewarding as it is demanding, and continues to captivate with its promise of further expansions and enhancements.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

onion ring
Highly recommend, especially if you have open world game fatigue and if you're okay failing alot before improving.

Over 2 years since its release, I can see why it won game of the year in 2022. I have never played a souls game. I've always been deterred by the very vocal souls players with how much they brag and obsess about difficulty. 

However, I originally got this game because of I was looking for an open world game that didn't have the ubisoft gps tracker., minimap and objectives where it spoon feeds you everything. Another reason was I got a taste of souls combat from Code Vein because its frequently on sale and cheap and thought had nothing to lose. I did enjoy souls combat but felt it was too linear and pigeonholed me into playing a certain way. 

Elden Ring is a great game to durdle with. I often joke with my friend call the game Durdle Ring. The first 50 hours was me durdling around finding random cool gear or finding cool settings and taking in the atmosphere. The set design of the game is really well done. It was a breath of fresh area compared to open world games which handhold you in exploration.

Durdling also included exploring which playstyle fit me. I learned early on Im bad at melee combat, I panic too much and struggle to be close enough to an enemy to hit itwith a sword. But there are several ranged playstyles I found that fit my tendency to panic when being attacked and was viable enough to bring me to completing a playthrough. 

Whats great is that there are enough tools to help the player overcome bosses from weapons, skills, gear, summons, and co-op which helped relieve how daunting the game felt. 

Fia best girl
it was perfect. Perfect. Everything, down to the last minute details.
GOOD
There are no words to appropriately describe the immense joy and fun I have while playing this game. Elden Ring takes concepts from other Soulsborne titles, improves upon them, and goes beyond expectation. The open world is beautiful with a lot of locations to explore and goodies to grab. The bosses are fun, challenging, and always satisfying to beat. With such a wide variety of content to explore, it is very difficult to run out of things to do. It's why I have so many hours in this game: I never got bored of it.

My main criticism come more from personal experience rather than concepts the game has. Notably, the world feels smaller when you learn where everything is and avoid places to fight bosses or get items you don't need. This is to be expected as with other entries to the franchise, the experience feels linear and shorter with each playthrough. Despite this, I am still amazed at this beautiful world each time I ride through it.

Please do yourself a favor and try this game. It is difficult, punishing at times, but the immense satisfaction and relief from beating a boss you've been stuck on for 5 hours never fails to make the mood better. Who knows, you may just find a personal favorite encounter.
Yeah it's pretty good
Awesome game, if a bit difficult at first. Persevere !
9/10. A brilliantly crafted dark fantasy world with endless options on how you want to tackle the games many complex bosses. 
The progression system is one of the fairest and best feeling that I've experienced. 
The lands between while it may feel huge as some detailed intricacies to it and lots of secrets to explore. 
The soundtrack is built perfectly to not be overwhelming during exploration but instead really shine through the big battles. 
The game may sometimes struggle with performance and not be the best visually looking games out there but who am I to really care when I'm swinging a huge badass sword against some massive boss with instruments and a choir blasting through my ears.

This is my favorite game in the world.
this game is the most anticipating of the century i look forward to the dlc :)
So if you're not new to Soulsborne games and somehow haven't played this, play it.

If you're new to them, imagine the following: You're in a dark medieval fantasy world, armed with some basic gear, and 95% of the world wants to kill you on sight. You're not the protagonist who is destined to save the world, you're just some nameless NPC. 
Now imagine you go out and try to defeat those enemies. Maybe you get a few of them, but inevitably, you die to something. A boss, or an unexpected powerful enemy, or fall damage.
And you get up, and try again. But this time, you're a bit better.
You still fail again, but now you've learned something new about one of the enemies.
On the third try, you make it further. A terrible monster destroys you.
You get back up again. And this time, you succeed. 
You find a safe place, and take a breather. Bit by bit, you find new items. You level up. 
You're stronger now. But not only that, your timing has gotten better. 
Three days later.
You're in a new place, one filled with even worse enemies, and a swamp that poisons you. There's a message on the ground from a fellow player. "I want to go home," it reads. You sympathize. Me too, buddy. You cross the swamp and see another message from some poor soul. "Be wary of right," it says. You creep toward the next corner, and spot an enemy waiting in ambush. You defeat it easily and give kudos to the other player's message.
The other player is in the middle of a heated boss battle, and they're out of heals. They're dodging frantically, and suddenly, your kudos gives them a free heal. They go on to defeat the boss, thanks to your anonymous help.

These are the kinds of moments that await you in this game. It's full of struggle, tragedy and triumph. If you're new, use everything at your disposal, because the game doesn't pull punches. Look up guides, find useful weapons on the wiki. Do whatever it takes to win. Don't let anyone tell you that you're playing it wrong.

Elden Ring was the first time I fell in love with a Soulsborne game, and it has since convinced me to go back and play others, especially Dark Souls 3.

Good luck. Be safe, friend. Don't you dare go hollow.
fought Margit while listening to Black by Pearl jam. very cinematic. 10/10

game good
It's  FromSoft game. Its HARD, you're going to die, repeatedly, even when you think you've gotten good, you'll die anyway. That being said, I'm on NG+4 and having an absolute blast, the world is huge, and multidimensional. Every time I run through a NG I find new things, new story lines and quests, new areas, new bosses, new items and interactions. It's an amazingly deep and well built story and world with secrets and lore and alternate endings and replay-ability rarely found in games nowadays. I 100% recommend this game to anyone who likes, or wants to get into, Souls-like games. I'm really excited for the DLC this summer, and I'm that by then, I'll have racked up a good 100 more hours into it. 10/10

Praise the sun!
I've beaten a couple of the other Dark Souls games (+ their DLC), and I think Elden Ring is a better game but I prefer the Dark Souls lore in many aspects.  I agree with most people who say that Elden Ring is much easier than the other games, but I think that actually makes it a generally better game.  Elden Ring finds a better balance between feeling challenging and feeling fun.  There were plenty of times in the Dark Souls games where I was just frustrated by how unnecessarily punishing they were... Like when I first played Dark Souls II and I couldn't summon any co-op allies because I died too many times and was locked out of multiplayer by soul memory... Or in Dark Souls III when I had to run through Lothric castle over and over again to get back to the second boss fight after each time dying...  Those kinds of clunky difficulty just made the Dark Souls games more frustrating, not more fun.
One of the best games of all time. No exaggeration.

w game
I am going say that I don't like a lot of the game design choices for  this game. A lot of them are straight up garbage. Most of the boss mechanics are beyond trash and frustating. The things that I love about this game is the story, the world building, and level design of this game. I love it a lot and that is the only reason why am giving it thumbs up.


The bosses in this game are some of the most frustrating bosses I have ever dealt with compared to something like WoW, FFXIV, and even DS3 (first 13 hours). I don't have I single boss that I actually liked in this entire game because you have to redo the entire battle knowing that it may be few attempts or you just summon someone to help you. Especially the last boss Elden Beast was the only boss I had to actually summon someone to help me with due to mimic not being good enough to make it second phase. I will say I got the Elden Beast to 12% and that I was why I summon a player.

The world design is just amazing. I loved every second of exploring the world. It the only reason why I put this many hours into this game. I love going everywhere and looking at things. The problem is that it was never rewarding, but seeing lore I guess was sort of rewarding. I only two weapon this entire game the starter weapon for samurai and River of Blood. I loved the River of Blood since it was my type of play style of just messing up the mobs.

The story is was decent and I enjoy it a lot. I personally went with Ranni Age of Star since was the only ending that I liked personally. I just wish there was more world building and world changing element, but that just not a Fromsoftware type of thing since they care more about combat and game design which isn't a bad thing until they completely screw it up in Elden Ring.

6/10 is my final score. Cannot wait to rage at more fromsoftware game.

insane game
Elden Ring isn't just a game, it's an adventure of the highest order.
FromSoftware has once again proven themselves as masters of their craft, forging an experience that transcends mere entertainment and ascends to the realm of artistry.
At its core, Elden Ring is a testament to meticulous world-building. The Lands Between sprawls before you, a vast and intricate artifact of lore, history, and mystery waiting to be unraveled. Every crumbling ruin, every tangled forest, every desolate battlefield is infused with a sense of place and purpose, inviting exploration and discovery at every turn.
But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its unparalleled sense of freedom. In a genre often plagued by linear storytelling and rigid progression,  FromSoftware has shattered the mold, offering players an open world of staggering scope and depth. Whether scaling towering mountains or delving into the darkest depths of underground catacombs, the sense of agency is palpable, empowering players to forge their own path and shape their own destiny.
Of course, such freedom would be meaningless without meaningful gameplay to accompany it, and Elden Ring delivers in spades. Combat is a symphony of steel and sorcery, demanding precision, timing, and strategy. Every encounter is a test of skill, pushing players to their limits and rewarding mastery with a sense of satisfaction unlike any other.
But perhaps most remarkable of all is Elden Ring's ability to weave its gameplay and narrative together into a seamless tapestry. Every boss slain, every quest completed, every secret uncovered feels like a piece of a larger puzzle, driving the story forward and deepening the player's connection to the world and its inhabitants.
In the end, Elden Ring isn't just a game; it's a masterpiece. A towering achievement that sets a new standard for all of gaming, and reaffirms FromSoftware's status as one of the greatest developers of our time. Whether you're a fan of action RPGs or simply appreciate storytelling and lore in games, Elden Ring is an experience not to be missed.

Amazing game could play it for thousands of hours and never get bored of it.
Let's be honest here - for a "classical" mouse&keyboard PC gamer, the UI is prehistoric and atrocious, camera behaviour and controls leave a lot to be desired, and developers (or people who ported the game to PC) certainly never touched a PC in their life.

But if you manage to see past those issues, the game is fantastic. Huge open world, wonderful landscapes and music. You feel your skills challenged all the time, but if you want to just roam the land without challenge - you certainly can. The lore... is there. It doesn't jump in your face, you don't feel burdened with "profound dialogues", but if you want a story, it'll be there for you too. Solid boss fights, mysterious characters, lots of things to explore and discover.
Buy The game

amazing game, but the optimisation is HORRIFIC! the constant crashes, and I have done everything to mitigate it, run as admin, barely any background activities. I have an RTX 4090 and Ryzen 9 7950X 64GB RAM and the frames drop constantly even if I drop down to low settings and 1080p. it performs the same at low res low settings as it does at 4K Ultra...

full clean install with no bloat, not one single other game has issues running at 4K 60+ Ultra... except this one. I REALLY hope the DLC is coming with some improvements to the game as its just awful crashing, usually when you're about to kill a hard boss.
Open world Soul game with exceptional setting, imagery and vision.  The structure and game play tread a well worn path, but a very well built and engineered path indeed.  All the typical hall marks are here, including many challenging bosses, no hand holding (there are online guides if you don't like this approach) and a difficultly that demands focus and patience, without being unfair.  Some frustrating idiosyncrasies carry on from previous games, albeit minor and to some extent do add to the macabre and unforgiving tone.  

While the game benefits from the open world, it is hard to distinguish between how much value this adds or if it is the setting and visual imagery.  The artistic style with stunning visual setting at every turn is worth admission alone.

If you enjoy Soul games, this is special.  I can't say enough how stunning The Lands Between is to traverse and how majestic the various lands are behold.  For those few how haven't tried a Soul game before, patience is a virtue.

Boy oh boy where do I even begin. Lebron... honey, my pookie bear. I have loved you ever since I first laid eyes on you. The way you drive into the paint and strike fear into your enemies eyes. Your silky smooth touch around the rim, and that gorgeous jumpshot. I would do anything for you. I wish it were possible to freeze time so I would never have to watch you retire. You had a rough childhood, but you never gave up hope. You are even amazing off the court, you're a great husband and father, sometimes I even call you dad. I forvever dread and weep, thinking of the day you will one day retire. I would sacrifice my own life it were the only thing that could put a smile on your beautiful face. You have given me so much joy, and heartbreak over the years. I remember when you first left clevenland and its like my heart got broken into a million pieces. But a tear still fell from my right eye when I watched you win your first ring in miami, because deep down, my glorious king deserved it. I just wanted you to return home. Then allas, you did, my sweet baby boy came home and I rejoiced. 2015 was a hard year for us baby, but in 2016 you made history happen. You came back from 3-1 and I couldn't believe it. I was crying, bawling even, and I heard my glorious king exclaim these words, "CLEVELAND, THIS IS FOR YOU!" Not only have you changed the game of basketball and the world forever, but you've eternally changed my world. And now you're getting older, but still the goat, my goat. I love you pookie bear, my glorious king, Lebron James.ü´∂

its good
Absolutely stunning visuals, excellent voice acting, immersive world design, some interesting boss fights, and amazing lore. A plethora of combat options to go for that means the game will never really get repetitive. It'll be as difficult as you wish it to be, according to weapon and build of choice.

It's a game that is impossible to fully enjoy without extensive use of a wiki, so be aware of that. Bear in mind also that it's very easy to hit a wall around mid-game where you are too underleveled to proceed and you might not know where to go next - some grinding is absolutely necessary. Would absolutely recommend prioritising vigor.

Note also that a few fights (Malenia?!?!) are straight up unfair and cumbersome - don't ever be afraid to summon your ashes throughout the game.

From a technical perspective the game is acceptable, although FromSoftware could've done a better job porting to PC - my computer crashed quite a few times. A few frame drops in busy areas despite beefy PC specs being used.

One of if not the best game I have ever played. Ive never had a game intrigue me so much with its story and world. The two tie into one another so perfectly, the exploration naturally promotes finding bits of lore out as they help you explore the world's secrets. The game is not perfect by any means, but for what was made and presented its one of the best experiences one can have within media and literature. I have not experienced a game like this since Hollow Knight. I put 120 hours into my first playthrough and I cannot imagine how many more I'll put into this game on future runs. I cannot recommend this game enough if you somehow haven't played it.

I don't think I need to really sell this one. By now, you probably know if you like souls-like combat, and that'll always be the crux of this game. It's insanely pretty, I think the dungeon crawls are engaging, the bosses are largely very cool, and the lore is fun.

Edit Edit: I AM ELDEN LORD
One of the best games ever made, screw the fire giant though.
Something incredible ahead.

My favorite game of all time from childhood was Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time. I still watch content about that game today and have gone back and played it a couple times. No game has ever made me feel the same way I do about Ocarina of TIme, but then Elden Ring came along. This is easily one of the best games ever made to date in my opinion. So many countless playthroughs always differing and finding new things you didn't find before. There is a seamless coop mod that makes playing with friends much more enjoyable but playing this game alone is a wonderful time as well. You find yourself getting sucked in and immersed in the scenery and enviorments. This is one of those games that you say youll just sit down and play for an hour or so but then you realize you played the entire day away and had a blast doing it. Even when you are stuck at some frustrating ass boss theres something about it that doesnt make you feel like youve hit a major wall. Maybe its that its open world and if your stuck you can go explore and get stronger and come back later. Torrent is a little sensitive when trying to turn back and forth on him but other than that he controls amazingly. So many different armor sets and weapons and the armor sets can even offer their own buffs to you for wearing it. You can even choose to have summons on your side to help and they do help tremendously. However if your a souls vet played and beat dark souls 3, bloodborne, sekiro etc any of the other soulsborne games than more than likely having summons with you will make the game to easy. Without summons this game is quite difficult honestly, even with summons some fights can just be made 
harder by them. However you want to play this game has a build for you with an adventure curated just for you on that playthrough. Its time to prepare for the Shadows to overcome the Erdtree we must be ready fellow Tarnished.

I have never played a Souls game before. I was afraid I would rage quit and wouldn't enjoy it but the more I played the more it grew on me. I was fascinated by the world sure the enemies were hard and sure I died plenty of times but something kept pushing me forward to not give up. There were moments of anger, frustration but also moments of beauty, and grace. Every boss has its challenges. I kept going with every new area I explored I got stronger with every defeat I learned and adapted. It's not an easy game but if you have patience, determination, and will you can learn to be great. A friend once told me "The game is only as hard as you make it." I couldn't have put it better myself. I loved this game a lot and I highly enjoyed covering it on YouTube with my community. I had no idea what to expect and that's what made it awesome. If anyone is afraid to cover this game or has no previous Souls experience like me this is one experience that will truly change your life. It will challenge the way you think, the way you usually play, and the way you experience games forever. Thank you FromSoftware for making such an amazing game and I look forward to the Shadow of the Erdtree expansion.
i love you elden ring. please have my kids.

[h1]Is Elden Ring any good?[/h1]

Short answer... [b]YES[/b]

The game though is at times to big and open, and gives people like me decision-paralysation, and unlike all other [i]From Software[/i] games I weren't able to blindly play through the game with no guides or any "[i]builds[/i]" to go for.

The game also suffers from a poor iteration of having "coop" in it, and a friend of mine really wanted me to play this game. So we ended up playing on the "[i]Seamless COOP[/i]" mod, and while the bosses got a lot harder with a bunch of health the challenge was awesome!

[hr][/hr]

The game is good, it's great too. But in my opinion not the best of the "[i]From Software[/i]" games, that title goes to "[i]Sekiro[/i]".
[h2]My Score: 9/10[/h2]
[h3]The game is good, and I'm looking forward to the DLC![/h3]
This Margit guy keeps defeating me...
Aside from not knowing if I'm drinking a potion or riding my horse, I feel like some of the animations could be curtailed a bit to improve immersion. I use an Xbox controller though, so maybe it's just me. Visually the game is unparalleled aside from a competently modded SSE. Hands down some of the coolest boss fights ever.
True gamer game.
Beating bosses felt underwhelming. Too many repeated bosses; I was excited when I read the game had over 100 bosses only to find most of them are either repeated or simply bad (ridiculous spam or crap like dragons where if you're fighting with a sword you see the dragon's bum for 70% of the fight). 

Open world is not only confusing but also a waste of time.

I found myself using a guide for most of the game which made the experience less enjoyable to figure out where everything is.

Good as a first souls-like game for someone maybe. But as someone who played DS1 and DS3 (casually), boss design other than Margit is horrible (still yet to fight Melania and Radagon but I'm nearly finished w the game so even if they turn out to be good, not enough to change my view). The game pushes you to use summons and magic against bosses in many instances through either spawning some difficult NPCs or spamming attacks/abilities (i.e Commander Niall, Draconic Tree Sentinel, Mirriam).

Fall damage is bad: it feels like one jump kills you and torrent while another only takes away a bit. There is no consistency.
i am guts

10/10 game
ruff
IF YOU HAVE A LOT OF TIME, then I suggest this game. It is substantially longer than any other souls game I've ever played and any plot significance or map exploration is aimless. There is a tiny bit of a contrived plot, but honestly, I hate the fact that From Software doesn't do any storytelling outside of their basic world building and expendable NPC's. Nothing feels like I'm supposed to care and I just summoned folks to fight stuff for me. 

Aesthetically, I enjoyed the game. I would not have completed it without using the guides on the internet. As such, I really felt like the only true way to play the game is with the mentality you're going to 100% it at least during one playthrough. Then, like BOTW, you may never touch it again.

I have not even played this for 10 hours and immediately got addicted. This game offers so much exploration, fighting, looting, literally anything that it is insane. This is good especially for people that like hard and LONG story and open world games. It even has multiplayer! I would honestly recommend this for everyone to check out.
Really enjoyed this game. It's like a game version of a Tim Burton Movie, same artistic style and vibe. The beginning can be quite tough, and you definetely need a controller to enjoy it. But when you learned most mechanics and how the game works with it's quests and so on, I would recommend you to throw away your first character and start a new one, after reaching Farum Azula is a good point, as you've probably missed alot of quests. Then you will definetely enjoy it, and get addicted to the exploration and stuff. It has some Bizarre open world, where you have to thiink outside the box in terms of movement, because it's not on a 2d plane like other RPG as for example Skyrim, but has a more vertikal 3d exploration, where you go up and down, and end up in places, which normally are not accessible in other open world games. Very creative and unique. Death becomes a part of the game, rather than an obstacle. For example if you die in Skyrim, you have to reload a save, and if that save was 1 hour ago, you will have to go and grab all items and stuff, you've collected before again. Here you keep all previous collected stuff, and just respawn at a nearest site of grace. It makes the game more fluent, even when dying.
I don't like this game. I've tried it again, again and again and it just never clicks for me. 
I've tried to validate my feelings by watching lots of review content and replaying older FromSoftware games. 

For the games defense, it got lots of good in it.  It looks great, the world design and monsters etc. are spot on.
The weapons and combat mechanics and different items you can collect to aid you in combat keep the game interesting. I had lots of fun exploring some of the side content in the game.

My major issue with the game is the bosses. Most of the time they are not fun. Most of them punish you too hard from one mistake and barely give you any time to counter attacks. I didn't like cheese bosses from previous FromSoftware titles but this time I feel like they've overdone it. 

Another thing I don't like is that this game isn't great for going in "blind". You'll have bad time without meta builds or guides to find "the good stuff". The game is way too big to not give any directions at all and it's easy to feel just exhausted and not wanting to explore at all. It doesn't really help that lots of content (including mini bosses) are copy-paste content. 

If you are not a speed runner and know all the tricks beforehand, you'll find yourself quite fast being stuck on boss that keeps one-shotting you for hours, days, weeks. 

I'm at that point of the game where I've explored the game enough and I want to "wrap it up" but I can't finish it because I'm stuck on a stupid anime style boss that is way too fast for the player character. 

Why I did give it thumbs up? I guess I've had my moneys worth. But if there will be Elden Ring II with similar traits I won't be as generous.
This is the best game, period.

Strongly recommend. If you are new to these types of games stick through the beginning. It seems pretty pointless when you have no idea what to do and encounter some kind of max level boss around every corner but once you figure out where to go and what to do it‚Äôs a really satisfying experience.

Dog ahead!
Sadly, Elden Ring has a terrible mechanic; the soul fanatics will say it's fantastic, but it's not. 

All Souls games, Dark Souls 1-2-3, Demon Souls, and Elden Ring, have a delayed dodge mechanic. Your character will react 0.25 seconds after you press the dodge button, even if you push it quickly.

This lousy mechanic will destroy all your reactions in other games. You think you become better in other games when you play Souls games, but in reality, you become worse. 

Souls games like Elden Ring give you stupid reactions, like having to roll into a monster instead of rolling from it.

Elden Ring has invincibility frames, which only exist in Souls games. So you will only be good at this kind of game with a messed up controller, and if you do not become crazy about the clunky bad controller like me, then go ahead.

People who say git gud defend a terrible control. No action games except Souls games have this kind of delay, and that is because the devs have done this on purpose to make the game harder. In reality, you trick yourself into believing you will be better at games playing this crap. Every time I play Dragon's Dogma or a game where the controller works and return to these crappy genres called Souls games, I have to learn EVERYTHING again from scratch. Just skip these bad games and focus on games where the controller works.


For those who do not believe this, search YouTube for Elden Ring delayed dodge and see for yourself. This review is not a lie like the Souls fans does.


So why have I given this a thumbs-up? It's because of a YouTuber named 
Thingfishy "How To Dodge-Roll - In-Depth Beginner Guide - Elden Ring"
That is the search words to find his guide.

The delayed dodge can be worked around, but it demands a different view. It is still a bad design; you can make it way better, but Fromsoft seems to be not that good at programming. 

If you learn the mechanic he teaches, you can enjoy the game even with the delayed dodge.
A truly amazing game like its predecessors (Dark Souls). The graphics and animations are vivid and the landscapes as if taken out of a child's fairy tale. The boss difficulty is expected but also fun since the game makes you devise strategies to win and when you actually do the dopamine rush is crazy. Would definitely recommend this to someone who enjoys fantasy oriented games that also pose a challenge for the players ingenuity and skill.

The game that tried too hard to be the "hardest one". Wasn't balanced from start to finish. You spend most of the game being spammed, one-shot, etc. And if you're going in for the co-op experience; the game actively punishes you for summoning your buddies. This game is not for everyone but for anyone who clicks with this game's combat will get hours upon hours of enjoyment. 

Fromsoft really knocked this one of out the park. (it's not perfect, but that's okay)

At worst this game is a little mobs spam heavy some rooms can have up to 20 dudes waiting to touch your butt. As well as a fair share of repeat bosses assuming you're trying to explore and do as much as possible before beating the game. (Playing co-op with a group of 3 will prove tough in the late game due to the co-op modifier that inflates the boss stats)

At it's best Elden Ring is an expansive open world RPG, filled with amazing scenic views which are packed with nooks and crannies that have goodies to find.There are a multitude of weapons ranging from long-swords, short-swords, great-swords, katanas, hammers, spears, whips, pole-arms, bows, crossbows, staffs, seals, etc. which all can provide an engaging combat experience. Not to mention the other fair share of tools such as armour, shields, talismans, magic, incantations(holy magic), weapon skills, spirit summons, co-op summons all in an effort to make you stronger to get you  through your journey in the lands between.

(I've played & Platinum-ed this game on both Steam and PS5)

[h1]A brutally honest "Elden Ring" Review: [/h1]

https://store.steampowered.com/app/1245620/ELDEN_RING/

[u]!!! Disclaimer: !!![/u]
This Review is written before the completion of my first ever playthrough of Elden Ring, so I might edit it later and/ or add a few things that were relevant enough for me to add them as I play through the game a few different ways.

This Review will be divided into several categories and rated on ?/10.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

First up, we got [b][u]The world and its design[/u][/b] (8/10):

The world is beautifully designed, theres many different areas with a wide variety of enemies and minibosses for extra bossitems and/ or useable spells. Many different merchants can be found, caves with bosses to face after finishing exploring them and so called "Churches of Merika" with inhabiting NPCs or items to upgrade ur Estus. The whole map itself is gigantic and must be diclosed by finding map items, which can be found in the associated area. 

For me personally, it was very easy to get lost in the open world, especially since I was used to the Dark Souls games and its rather linear progression system, which lead me to miss out on quite a few minibosses and talismans, not to mention NPCs and their associated questline. So taking all of that into account, I rate the overall world design an 8/10!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Next, we will take a look at [b][u]The Lore [/u][/b] (7/10?):

I wont get too much into The Lore as to not give away too much about the game, but I was rather intrigued by the cinematic intro. Since I am not a person that gets into the Lore of every game and reads every single item description in order to find out more about whats going on in the game, I can't say for sure what I would rate the lore in context of the other [i]Soulsborne Games [/i]. So I would go with a 7/10(?). 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The next and final section of my review with revolve around [b][u]The Bosses and their design[/u][/b], aswell as [b][u]The combat system in general[/u][/b] (10/10, second best I have ever gotten to experience in a [i]Soulsborne game[/i], right after the Bloodborne combat system!): 

Okay, I have [b]alot[/b] to say about [i]Elden Ring's [/i] combat system, so bare with me please! First off, the bosses, their movesets and [b]MOST OF ALL! [/b] their voicelines far surpassed the expectations I had towards this game and are EASILY the single best designed in the entire franchise! 

There are bosses that use [i]Dexterity focused weapons[/i], leading to a moveset that consists of combos that can lead into a flurry of attacks, simply melting your HP down to 0, whereas there are other foes, that have delayed attacks that require you to adapt to their timing. They are quite slow and do not have many tools in their arsenal to dispose of you [u]Lowly tarnished[/u], but they hit like a truck, should you be too slow to get out of their way and dodge effectively! That type of boss trusts in their [i]Strength[/i], in order to hinder you to progress through the lands between. 

The arenas, some bosses can be located and challenged in, may take your breat away simply by how beautifully and fitting they are designed, complimenting their respective boss snd/or area they are located in. BUT FOCUS ON THE TARGET INFRONT OF YOU!

You yourself have many different tools at your disposal in order to reach your goal, with many different paths and classes to choose from. Crafting is a mechanic that debuts in this game, with crafting materias scattered about for you to collect and use to your advantage and give you a slightly bigger chance of beating the opponent you might get stuck on along your journey. 

As I mentioned above, I NEED to give the combat system a perfect rating! But I also said, it was the second best combat system I have experienced so far, right after Bloodborne's. Elden ring is a masterpiece, but I can simply not find the strength to push Bloodborne off of the throne, that is my heart and let Elden Ring take its spot...! I am howeveer curious, wether the DLC might change that fact, so stay tuned, maybe I will upate my Review after playing through the DLC.

Until then, I higly recommend this game as an entrypoint to the [i]Soulsborne Series[/i]. 

Pay the maiden your respects after rating my review, thank you and have a nice day/ night

[h2]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3207137551[/h2]
I hadn't played a souls-borne game before this. I knew I would like the aesthetic, but I didn't know if I would like the actual difficulty and gameplay. There are games you always wish you could go back and experience for the first time again, and this one definitely already is. The game can be confusing on how to progress, which is my biggest gripe with these games, but that's part of what makes the story and game so mystifying. I highly recommend this game.

thumbs up
.
I have never played a souls like game before which made the game really hard and frustrating at first, but after getting killed 1000 times and finally learning the mechanics and game play I have absolutely loved Elden Ring, it is definitely one of my top games I've played and it is well worth the price.
This game scratches that itch that everyone has whether they know it or not. The open world exploring is S tier and the story ingrained into each character is amazing. 634 hours into this game and I am still finding new things. Let's get down to the specifics though

1. SOUNDS:
     The soundtrack is, of course, amazing and fits perfectly with any boss fight or combat in the open world.
     Breaking an enemy's stance is so satisfying.
     Critical striking an enemy feels so powerful. The list goes on because this game is thoroughly fleshed out.
2. BOSS FIGHTS
     "BLADE OF MIQUELLA" tough... but wonderful if you are a masochist.
     These boss fights are some of the most fun and challenging boss fights I have had in a long time.
     As I said earlier, the soundtrack to each boss is amazing and made to fit the lore of each boss.
     When you finally kill a boss you feel so powerful! All up until the easiest npc in the game kills you. 
     The move sets of almost all of the bosses are really cool in my opinion. 
3. GENERAL COMBAT
    Melee combat is at it's peak here. Strategy is a must for the whole game. One mistimed dodge or swing of your weapon could erase the souls your Tarnished vessel tried so valiantly to retrieve. 
    The weapon designs and skills are so much fun. The variety of weapon designs and skills allow for not just overpowering some enemies, but they are also easy to cosplay with. 
4. MAGIC
    I am mostly a tank, damage, and support kind of player so I get some could use out of the support/ buffing spells and incantations. 
    One critique I have is, I do not get nearly the same satisfaction from using damage spells as I  do with a melee weapon. I just feel that the spells are lacking in someway and that could very well just be a me problem.
5. TERRAIN: 
     The locations in and around the Lands Between are beautifully depicted. The trees in Leyndell, the different cultures ingrained into the buildings around the map, the star lit sky of Siofra River and Nokron, everything in this game has so much passion placed into it. 
 6. SUMMARY
     I love this game! I suggest it to anyone I know that has an interest in video games. Currently I am cosplaying Varre. Two Great Knives in hand and plenty of bleed and the blood spells of Mohg. This is probably my favorite cosplay so far. Extremely fun. The variety in ways you can tackle this game really makes it my favorite game by a large margin. 

    BECOME A TARNISHED! JOIN US AND COMMIT THE CARDINAL SIN! OR BETTER YET, BRING CHAOS TO CONSUME THE WORLD!

I'm new to souls-like games and I've been avoiding Elden Ring all this time, until one day I decided I wanted to give it a try...
100+ hours later, playing this game everyday, and dreaming about it at nights instead of sleeping like a normal human being, it's safe to say it got me hooked, duh.
I've never seen a world THIS rich, with so many places to explore (both seen & hidden), so many different enemies to fight in each location you go. 
The Lands Between are gorgeous and disturbing at the same time, some enemies & NPCs I've met, gave me chills down my spine. 
The boss fights are absolutely insane, I loved almost every single one of them! 
The story has left me in ruins, it broke my heart into pieces, but it was absolutely worth it.
Elden Ring is an absolute masterpiece and the best game of this decade, no one can convince me otherwise.

yipi
You've heard it before, right? If you're going to play a Fromsoft game, be prepared to die, and die often.
The challenge in playing these games isn't about how to stay alive, but in making sure that you're learning from each death. Understanding the enemies' different attacks, understanding the movements of your own character, learning exactly how to move and where to stand so that you can both stay alive and pressure the opponent--none of these skills will come in a day. But it will be incredibly satisfying when it comes.

The game is hard and may be frustating. But there are work arounds for that. You may either play with some friends to help you with bosses, or give up the great online experience and install the Easy (or the very easy version) mod. Despite the name, it still won't make the game easy, but at least way less frustrating...

Elden Ring is notoriously difficult. Enemies hit hard, and bosses are punishing tests of skill. However, the game respects your time, offering multiple paths to progression and rewarding exploration. Difficulty never feels unfair, and overcoming a seemingly insurmountable foe is incredibly satisfying.

You can probably already tell what I think of this game by my playtime, but regardless, the game has an amazing amount of content, easily 120 hours per playthrough if not more depending on your own speed.

Elden Ring is a game that, despite its open world nature, strips out much of the bullshit found in other open world games and delivers a great, tightly-controlled and combat-focused experience. In addition, many weapons in the game possess their own unique identities with things such as move-sets, weapon ranges, special moves, etc. to consider; there are very few pure stat upgrades to be found between weapons and armor, and only a few for talismans, just about every item in the game is viable for a playthrough. Would highly recommend, especially with the DLC on its way.

I haven't played a lot of Elden Ring so far and I also am kinda late to the game but with all things considered I am BEYOND! impressed with this game, I have never played a souls game and I'm still confused on certain things but I think that's also the joy of the game. You don't instantly know what to do, you have to take your time, explore and learn which adds to the open world adventure feel. The bosses so far vary, from being quite easy to seeming impossible (AT FIRST) but then after dying over and over and trying to remember their attack patterns, timing etc you finally master them and beat it like a piece of cake and you find yourself shaking in relief but also achievement after completion on the mini milestone. With that being said the game is 100% not for everyone and if you aren't up for a challenge then DO NOT! get this game. The visuals are also outstanding and I've enjoyed every bit of it! :)

the game is great, but it seems to me that after this experience I have forgotten how to have normal and healthy communication with real people.
After 200+ hours I think I can safely say I really don't like this game anywhere close to the older souls games. Not that I hate it, only that it fails to make me want to play it more. I would recommend literally any of the other Souls games over this one 90% of the time. I am not saying this game is bad, only that I would recommend playing literally all the other souls games first. Leaving this one as the "I have no other Soulsborn games left to play" option. I feel like those games are more cohesive experiences that are far more focused in their design than Elden Ring.

I can play the older games any time I want without feeling lost or frustrated. If I want to play Elden Ring I am stuck playing the same handful of meta builds or risk making the game pure frustration. If I want to not lose track of what I was doing, I can't go to long without playing or I forget what I was doing or where I was in a quest line. There is a reason the open worlds this game is supposedly better than, use checklists and quest logs. Because there is to much stuff that without them you would lose track of it all. Checklists are not inherently a bad thing. But I'm not a smart enough person to fully elaborate on the nuance of that statement. No. Sadly I'm a dummy.

But a big part of what I think the problem is comes down to the game's big open world. Outside of a few exceptions it is very forgettable. A blending of the typical environments you expect to see in a souls game, only with the endless repetition of a generic open world. The best areas of the game are the ones with a much smaller scale. Like the legacy dungeons or the smaller open sections like Siofra River or Nokron. Open, but more structured like the classic games. These places make all the repetitive little side activities feel so out of place. They feel straight out of the generic open world playbook. Just because they are not marked on your map as a checklist doesn't mean they aren't generic copy paste busy work. These side activities designed to pad out playtime and create the illusion of extra content. 

What is the difference between fighting a unique boss, enjoying it, and fighting it again either by putting down a summon sign to help another player, or just fighting it again NG+  compared to fighting the same boss 3 times in 2 different dungeons and 1 time in an evergaol? Some trinkets at the end of each dungeon? Some trinkets that could have just as easily been sprinkled through the legacy dungeons in more densely packed interconnected secrets. You know, like the souls games were well loved for in the first place?

Half the, crypts, evergaols and mines could have been cut with no loss to the game's feel. Removing them might have even made the game feel better instead of padded with pointless busy work. They look the same, they feel the same, and all their bosses are copy pasted the same. None of it feels special anymore. Worse than that they rob other moments that might have been special of the chance to be special. I'm certain I'm not alone in seeing a boss in a crypt or evergaol, or even just as an open world boss. Then fighting them thinking that was a pretty mid boss, then seeing where I was supposed to encounter that boss for the first time and the "Wow factor" of that moment was ruined by previously encountering them as a generic boss. Open world doesn't mean better. It just means a lot of empty connecting space, with a need to fill it somehow. And what they filled that space with is copy pasted and generic. 

Moving from one topic to another, as I don't want to get hung up on one point for to long; I haven't even begun to talk about some of the games most notorious difficulty spikes. Though honestly I don't plan to. People smarter than me with more skill than me have made far more compelling arguments for and against the difficulty than I ever could. To the point that my voice wont lend anything constructive to the conversation. All I will say is that I never could beat Melenia. And at this point, I don't care. I don't need to give myself the headache trying when the reward for beating her isn't worth it. Especially since half the game's community seems to mock katana weapons as noob crutches. Despite us having had over a decade with this format of game some still can't seem to just let people play the way they want to without having to make a fuss about it. And yes I know mimic tear bends her over its knee. But I want to beat the boss. Not watch the AI do it. If you want to just call it a "skill issue"? Fine, I don't care. My sanity is worth far more than an imaginary video gamer e-peen, that no matter how big you think yours is, still wont get you any maidens.

All in all I am left feeling very much confused. Because on the surface I should love this game for being just "Bigger Dark Souls." But I don't. Maybe if they removed all the copy paste boss encounters that rob each unique fight of their memorability. Maybe if they focused more on the legacy dungeons that felt like fun and worthwhile challenges of exploration rather than just big open space, each location would feel more memorable. Maybe if they spent less time worrying about making the game hard for experienced players and just made it on par with previous titles, the meta wouldn't be so restrictive. Maybe if all these things had come to be I wouldn't have ever even cared enough to try and put my thoughts to text, and I would have just put another 200+ hours in without a second thought to the YES/NO recommendation button.

I wanted to love this game. I wanted to love it so much. But I am left disappointed. I see Elden ring as a good game. But one that had it just a little more restraint would have been infinitely more enjoyable for me. But it seems like it has lost focus on what originally drew players like me to these games in the first place. All in favor of the mass appeal that the open world tag seems to draw in. So with that we get to the ultimate YES/NO decision I had to make. I don't like the generic "YES/NO" review system on steam. So I try to answer it with an entirely personal question. Since I know I can only ever speak for myself. 

I ask myself, "If I were talking to my past self would I recommend the game to me? Or would I just like my time back?". Then hit YES or NO based on that. Not as some objective statement to the game's quality. It wasn't an easy decision to come to. I didn't enjoy my time with this game. No matter how many hours I sat through trying to tell myself that I did. Or that it just wasn't clicking with me yet. If you loved it, than all I can say is that I wish I felt the way you did. Maybe someday, I'll come back to it and my thoughts will be different. But until then. Have fun playing the games you love. And never let anyone tell you that they way you feel about a game is "Wrong".
This is currently the greatest game of all time. I previously held Bloodborne as my best game but Elden Ring has improved on every aspect of their previous games. It added everything fans wanted, better bosses, more interesting settings, beautiful visuals, hard as balls boss fights and build flexibility that is rarely seen in games. 

I love this game and wish I could go back and play it again blind that's how good the experience was. I mourn for anyone who does not give this game a fair shot, once you get past the difficulty its the most enjoyable experience I've ever had gaming. 

Also.... Malenia f* you that boss is so hard
Destroy Bird. Absorb power. Rule Ring.
Elden Ring is a fun, beautiful game that's not for the easily infuriated, and it's even more so with the Seamless Co-op mod, but a significant chunk of its masterfully created hours upon hours of content are easy to miss by failing to find some random portal tucked into a corner or some random wall that's for some reason secret. 
Its class system is similar to most class systems found in videos games: it adds replayability by locking content behind class walls.
In addition, the unbalanced nature of certain weapons as compared to others makes most of the loot even within any given class worthless, as the damage of any given weapon most likely pales in comparison to the damage of the weapon you currently have. This holds true for incantations and sorceries, as although this incantation looks really cool, it still only does 90% of the damage of this other spell that functions in the exact same way.
The keyboard and mouse support feels horrid as the player is forced to rapidly press buttons to get to incantations or items, as compared to hotbars or hotkeys found in other games. Furthermore, the unoptimized nature of the game leaves users of high resolution or high refresh rate monitors with a sub par experience.

Overall it's a good 8.25/10. It's a bad port of a brilliant game that feels just barely underpolished.

Easily as strong recommend. The standard Soulsbourne difficulty combined with the open world format give the game almost endless replay value. You easily get your money's worth with a single playthrough. The environmental storytelling of this game is out of this world, and there are plenty of deep, nuanced and complex characters. A few criticisms that I have would be the fact that the game repeats bosses too often, in a few cases recycling repeat bosses as basic minions in later dungeons. There's too often a reliance on using multi-boss fights and it feels to me like a cheap trick to artificially inflate the difficulty.

Elden Ring: Where Death is a Learning Experience!

Prepare to embark on an epic journey through a sprawling world filled with danger, mystery, and more deaths than you can shake a sword at ‚Äì welcome to "Elden Ring," where every demise is just another opportunity to laugh in the face of danger!

FromSoftware has done it again, delivering a game that's equal parts challenging and ridiculously entertaining. As you step into the shoes of the Tarnished, a lowly outcast with a knack for getting into trouble, you'll quickly discover that the world of "Elden Ring" is not for the faint of heart. But fear not, brave adventurer, for every defeat brings with it a valuable lesson ‚Äì or at least a hilarious anecdote to share with your friends.

The gameplay in "Elden Ring" is as addictive as it is punishing, with tight controls and precise combat that will put your skills to the test. But don't let the constant barrage of enemies and environmental hazards get you down ‚Äì after all, what's the point of slaying a giant dragon if you can't do it in style while wearing a ridiculous hat?

Speaking of style, "Elden Ring" offers a staggering amount of customization options for your character, allowing you to create a truly unique hero who's as fashionable as they are formidable. Want to wear a suit of armor made entirely out of cheese? Go for it! Prefer to wield a weapon that's actually just a rubber chicken in disguise? The choice is yours!

But perhaps the true beauty of "Elden Ring" lies in its world-building, with a rich and immersive lore that's just waiting to be discovered. From ancient ruins shrouded in mystery to quirky NPCs with stories to tell, there's always something new and exciting to uncover around every corner ‚Äì assuming you can survive long enough to find it, that is.

In conclusion, "Elden Ring" is a challenging adventure that will keep you coming back for more, even when you're face-down in a puddle of your own defeat. So grab your sword, polish your sense of humor, and prepare to laugh in the face of danger ‚Äì because in the world of "Elden Ring," death is just another opportunity to respawn and try again!

Masterpiece
Great trials produce great satisfaction when overcome through hard work and dedication. 

Except in Elden Ring. here beating a boss has you panting with relief just to die to the new enemies in the area you just unlocked because you're probably under-leveled and have no idea where to go next (unless you use an online guide because honestly, in Elden Ring, even a straightforward path sometimes has quite a few loops and secrets to it that you have to figure out otherwise you'll spend an hour just trying to figure out how to exit or bypass an area only to find out your only way back or forward is a single doorway that you've passed 4-5 times while constantly being attacked by, and dying to, the area's inhabitants.

10/10 would recommend (but be sure to bring your big boy pants because even an endgame build can be quickly overwhelmed by basic enemies)

Did you ever hear the Tragedy of Darth Plagueis the Wise? I thought not. It's not a story the Jedi would tell you. It's a Sith legend.
Darth Plagueis... was a Dark Lord of the Sith so powerful and so wise, he could use the Force to influence the midi-chlorians... to create... life. He had such a knowledge of the dark side, he could even keep the ones he cared about... from dying.
He became so powerful, the only thing he was afraid of was... losing his power. Which eventually, of course, he did. Unfortunately, he taught his apprentice everything he knew. Then his apprentice killed him in his sleep. It's ironic. He could save others from death, but not himself.

This is my first souls game, fell in love with it immediately. Bought this game during sale, never regretted it. My best game purchase so far.
Arguably one of, if not, the best game Souls game FromSoftware has ever created. For those who are hesitant to get into the Dark Souls/Sekiro/Bloodborne-like games, I would recommend starting here. The game has SO MUCH content its actually shocking. The world of Elden Ring is vast and diverse with various different enemy and boss types. The game is difficult, like all souls games, but its by no means unfair. One of the positives this game offers that many souls games do not is the opportunity to level yourself through mini-bosses and dungeons which also grant you opportunities to get valuable weapons, skills, or items to fight major boses. On my first playthrough alone it took me almost 70 hours to beat and thats not accounting for all the character missions or secret endings you can choose to do. While the lore can be a little hard to grasp, the game offers a amazing and immersive atmosphere that sucks you in and has you craving to play.
I loved this game as a solo playthrough when it first came out. Now my friend and I played coop style through 3 different playthroughs. This game is incredible.

The world is big enough to have finished the game a coupe of times and I know for sure that I'm still missing many quests, items and even complete characters arcs.
Loved it. Can't wait for the DLC.

11/10 one of the best games of our age
This may be the last open-world game that I will play. Side quests are seemingly endless, and expansiveness is insane. If you like point A -> point B games like me (ie: Dark Souls 1,2,3, FF, etc.), this may not be your ideal experience. However if you have persistence and a desire to challenge incredibly difficult foes, you will most certainly enjoy the game. Those who like open world games will find this one less empty than many others, with foes coming out only during set times and roaming around. If you haven't played any dark souls games, this one is a fine place to start.
This is the most artistically inspired game from a large studio I've seen in a while. FromSoft consistently outperforms every AAA studio by a huge margin. Even the most annoying bosses outperform most fights from any other game.
One of the most beautiful and amazing games ever created!

is good game
Amazing game overall, from beautiful graphics to polished and fun game mechanics. Haven't played other souls-like games except for Dark Souls 2 so can't really compare it to those but as a souls-like beginner I'd highly recommend it. Only issue I had was open world, but after my first walk-trough I've learnt most of it even tho it's huge. It's just so good that every location just stuck with me. For beginners I'd recommend using wiki to navigate trough the game but I'd highly recommend trying to avoid spoilers on bosses and such, just use the map for "level progression" so you don't enter locations where enemies will shred you cuz of your low level. I'm pretty sure one walk-trough will be enough to memorize most of the game and for new builds you will more then likely know where to go when without any big issues. Also, if you are not satisfied with your build and you find a new more interesting weapon, DO NOT BE AFRAID TO RESPEC. You can respec and redo your build mid game without any repercussions so if you wanna try out new stuff, then do it!
Love this game and can't wait for the new DLC, I've got nothing to complain about! <3

Most incredible not optimised shit in my life, that can't be fixed any of thousand guides
Since I'm not following a step-by-step walk-through, I have literally no idea where to go, or if my level is appropriate to the location I'm in.
Very hard to tell if a Boss is just insanely hard because I'm not ready for it yet, or if I just suck.
- But then I went back to Limgrave and I suddenly one-shot everything. So at the moment I am over-powered for the starting area, but under-powered for the place I'm at now. It really feels like a drag trying to get runes enough to 'catch up'.

Other than that, it's a great game.
Can't recommend based solely off of things like 

- Requires V-sync on in Nvidia settings just to not have terrible screen tearing
- 60fps locked
- Terrible performance/optimisation
- Terrible hit boxes (From soft fans will disagree, but there are tons of times enemies miss by MILES and you get hit anyway)
- Enemies can still hit you through walls (embarrassing game design)
- Terrible AI, especially for spirit summons
- Terrible physics (we all know Torrent making you die from fall damage after double jumping is pure horse shit, and some times you die from fall damage if you fall off of a ledge that isn't considered solid ground)
- Still has freezing issues for the first 20 minutes of play
- Mid combat (Senua Sacrifice and God of War? Far superior combat and games overall. Note the differences.) 
- Barely any story. Pretty much nonexistent. 

I can write a book on everything wrong with this game. 

It's cool going on an adventure, but god damn is this NOT a AAA game. It's just factually not up to that level of polish and optimisation. Goated art direction, dog shit coding/game design. It's 2024, and a ton of these issues are not only not fixed, but not even ADDRESSED. It's pathetic, tbh. 

Fromsoft fanboyss are some the THE WORST fandoms on the planet. This game is so far from being a masterpiece. Play better games like God of War or Hellblade instead. There are AA games with better gameplay, stories, scores and combat than this. But keep drinking your cult koolaid, sheeple lol. The game could barely meet the requirements for an argument to say it's GOOD. Let alone a masterpiece. Stop being delusional. You're embarrassing yourself.

In the heart of a quaint countryside town, there lived a young boy named Tommy whose world revolved around one obsession: trains. From the rhythmic chug of the locomotives to the distant wail of the whistle, there was nothing Tommy loved more than the sleek metal beasts that raced along the tracks.

However, Tommy harbored a deep-seated fear, one that lurked in the shadows of his otherwise joyful existence ‚Äî spiders. Ever since he was a child, the sight of their hairy legs and beady eyes sent shivers down his spine, filling him with an unshakeable sense of dread.

One fateful evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and darkness descended upon the town, Tommy's parents left him alone in their cozy cottage while they attended to urgent matters in the neighboring village. Despite his unease at being left alone, Tommy found solace in the familiar sound of the distant train whistle echoing through the night.

As he sat by the window, his gaze fixed upon the tracks that snaked through the countryside, Tommy's heart leaped with excitement at the approaching train. But as the familiar rumble grew louder, his joy turned to terror as he spotted something unsettling lurking in the shadows.

A dark figure, with eight spindly legs and glistening eyes, scuttled along the tracks, its presence sending a chill down Tommy's spine. Paralyzed with fear, he watched in horror as the creature drew closer, its movements fluid and sinister in the moonlight.

Desperate to escape the nightmare unfolding before him, Tommy frantically searched for a place to hide. With trembling hands, he barricaded himself in the attic, his heart pounding in his chest as the sounds of the approaching train mingled with the haunting echo of the creature's footsteps.

As the train thundered past, its blaring whistle drowning out the cacophony of Tommy's racing thoughts, he dared to peek through the dusty windowpane, hoping against hope that the nightmare had passed.

But to his horror, the creature remained, its malevolent gaze fixed upon him with a hunger that sent shivers down his spine. With each passing moment, it drew closer, its shadowy form growing larger and more menacing with every step.

Just as all hope seemed lost, a blinding light pierced the darkness, illuminating the attic with a brilliance that banished the creature back into the night. And there, standing in the doorway, was Tommy's father, his worried expression softened by relief as he gathered his trembling son in his arms.

In the safety of his father's embrace, Tommy's fear slowly began to fade, replaced by a sense of gratitude for the love and protection that surrounded him. And though the memory of that fateful night would linger in his nightmares for years to come, Tommy found solace in the knowledge that no matter how terrifying the darkness may seem, the light of love would always guide him home.
It's a great game to play with a friend, that forces the play to be a of a set skill level individually to progress past certain points which I respect. The fights are fun, quests have depth, magic expansive, weapons various.... It's a bomb game. Watch out for invaders if just starting. Games better with a friend and overall a delight. Sometimes crash collision is plain wrong on a puzzle or a boss has a move trigger after already being killed so you die. Overall entirely worth it despite any minor/rare peculiarities and it's beautiful AF too. Great co-op I love to play with my partner.

Unlike previous soul-like games (such as Sekiro, Darksouls, or Bloodborne), Elden Ring is the first within the series to have an explorable open world.

 I'm a big fan of souls-like games, and not only does the game match the standards of its predecessors, but IMHO surpasses them. On top of this, after having completed every side-quest and main boss fight within the game, I felt very in touch and immersed in the lore of this beautifully crafted universe. 

The combat is challenging and feels very rewarding upon completion. I'd highly recommend playing this game.

[h2] A great game suffering from various issues. [/h2]

- Many of Elden Ring's locations aren't worth exploring if the current build you're running doesn't require the items/equipment you'd find at those locations.
- Late game enemies/bosses do an absurd amount of damage.
- (If you're planning on doing co-op) Near constant Invasions by other players get tiresome after so many hours of just trying to play with your friends. (You only really get invaded while engaging in co-op)
- It feels like you're a normal human fighting [b] FINAL EPISODE LEVEL [/b] anime antagonists as you watch them perform amazing feats meanwhile you're just trying to land a jab or two in between their bouts of wild flailing.

At some point it may stop being fun and you may continue playing out of pure spite.
Other than that, [i] it's just Dark Souls 4. [/i]

the best game ever played
Good!
gud
So much copy and paste, this is worse than all the copy and paste in Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion. FromSoftware clearly absolutely hates doing work, this is a $19.99 rehash of DarkSouls-3 in a bigger map that gaslights into believing it doesn't copy and paste the same shack model 5 times before you get out of the starting zone.

I'm likely seeing it even worse since I just came off a binge through Dark Souls 1, 2, and 3 - but the only original content is the boss fights. Every single animation is from one of the older games, every single weapon art is just a remap of an enemy attack to the player. Bosses like Leonine Misbegotten are also mostly just Bloodborne animations reused.

Up to Liurnia I've seen only 2 different shack models and have counted 16 unique ruin wall pieces and only 2 different kinds of towers. Every Tunnels dungeon map uses the same handful of pieces and all have the same boss-room. Only one of the caves uses a different boss room, but that's because it's a thru cave to the dragon covenant isle.

Sure, the gameplay is mostly fine but it's impossible to overlook how puffed and inflated the content is. Liurnia doesn't need to be even a quarter the size it is, it's literally just flat puff. 

The game relies too much on some sudden burst damage coming out of combos so you're doing a pittance of damage and then all of sudden BAM! 1/3rd the enemy's HP goes away and it dies. That makes it difficult to judge if you should even be engaging an enemy or not as you cannot tell how hard you actually hit until the burst occurs (praise optimal level maps on wikis). Usual souls' game issues that disengagement is an RNG chance affair, so don't get roped into melee if you don't want to start a damage cheese race as you can roll some dice on whether you can get disengage or just get killed for trying. Attack tracking and variable length holding has been reasonable, I haven't actually noticed any enemies doing DS3 nonsense of holding their chambered swings for varying lengths of time.

TL;DR: only buy this on sale, it's not worth $59.99 usd, not even close.

Do not feel bad about murdering innocent birds. You will come to the conclusion that birds must be erased from the world.
