[h2]An Unremarkably Detailed Examination of Elden Ring on PC[/h2]

Elden Ring, a title that has found a home on the PC platform, introduces itself with a sense of ambition that is, frankly, just there. Amidst a sea of games clamoring for attention, it exists, steadfastly occupying its own space, I suppose. This review endeavors to dissect the game in a manner as colorlessly precise as possible, without swaying too far towards any form of excitement or disapproval.

[h2]Gameplay Mechanics[/h2]

The core gameplay of Elden Ring, as one might expect, involves a series of actions, quests, and battles. There is a certain level of complexity to the combat system, offering a variety of weapons and spells for players to use. Movement through the game world is facilitated by walking, running, and the use of a mount. These elements function in a way that allows you to interact with the game, which is about as much as one can say on the matter. The mechanics are there, they work, and I suppose that's an important aspect of being a game.

[h2]Visual and Auditory Experience[/h2]

Visually, Elden Ring presents a vast world filled with diverse landscapes, characters, and creatures. The graphics do their job, rendering the game's environment in a manner that can be seen with the eyes. The sound design accompanies these visuals, providing auditory cues and a soundtrack that exists alongside the visual components. It's all very much a part of the game, and to be frank, it doesn't evoke much beyond that basic acknowledgment.

[h2]Narrative and World Building[/h2]

The narrative of Elden Ring, along with its world-building, is present. There's a story being told within a universe that has been crafted with a certain level of detail. Characters and lore fill the game, offering information and context for those inclined to explore it. Whether these elements are compelling or merely exist as part of the game's structure is a matter of perspective, I guess. They're there if you want to delve into them, but I'm not sure how much they'll impact your overall experience.

[h2]Overall Impression[/h2]

To encapsulate the experience of playing Elden Ring on PC in a few words, one might describe it as 'playing a game.' It's an experience that, while functional and comprehensive in its scope, maintains a steadfast commitment to neutrality in its execution. The game does what it sets out to do, offering a gameplay experience that exists and continues to exist as long as you choose to engage with it. In conclusion, Elden Ring is a game available for play on the PC, offering a mixture of combat, exploration, and story that collectively forms a cohesive gaming experience. It is a title that will occupy time and, perhaps, space on your hard drive. To those considering whether to embark on this journey, it may be wise to abstain, safeguarding oneself from the risk of encountering an overwhelmingly average experience that could potentially unsettle one's commitment to polar rating systems.
As someone completely new to the Souls-like genre, delving into Elden Ring was an experience beyond expectations. Without any prior exposure to similar games or even a glance at gameplay trailers, I was immediately captivated by its world design and combat system. Every facet of the game seemed meticulously crafted, drawing me in with its immersive environments and challenging yet rewarding gameplay. Elden Ring surpassed any preconceptions I had, delivering an experience that felt nothing short of perfect.
One of the best if not the best games ever!
At this rate I'll finish the game in 2040, still great tho just getting stuck a lot. *(skill issue on my side)*
[h1]PROS[/h1]
This game is amazing! If you like games like Bloodborne, Sekiro, Dark Souls, then you are going to love this one. Keep in mind that it can be difficult. The map is HUGE, huge variety of things to loot and craft, a ton of unique weapons, and a HUGE variety of dark twisted mind blowing enemies to slay. I also like writing and reading messages that other players left, seeing players in the world every once in awhile, and seeing bloodstains where other players have previously died which warns me of the dangers. I always thought these were unique mechanics.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
My only complaint is the way Co-op is handled. Co-Op is the same as in Bloodborne. You would think this would be fixed after all of the complaints after Bloodborne. The issue with this, is that it is sometime hard to call people in to help you with a boss. Sometimes you will be sitting there waiting ten minutes for a gold mark to pop up on the floor. When it finally does, you sometimes get invaded by a player. Sometimes that player is a OP try hard and they completely destroy you and the person you summoned and the session ends. Now you have to go and wait for the gold mark again, when all you wanted was help with the boss. There should be an option that allows you to turn off invasions altogether instead of forcing players to play PVP every time you ask other players for help. To make matters worse, you have to craft something called a "Furlcalling Finger Remedy" in order to play with friends or get help from other players. So if you die, you not only have to wait for another gold seal to pop up, but you have to craft these every single time. They are easy to craft but it is still a headache. Especially when you want to play with your friends and it kicks them every time you die and forces you to go through this entire process again. The Co-Op is just a little bit of a nuisance and needs work. 


[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
These cons don't break the game in anyway! Its still an amazing game overall. I would still give it 10/10 even with these flaws! I would definitely buy it again for full price. Don't think about it, just buy it. It's well worth the $60 price tag. You won't be disappointed. I have 129 hours into this game and I am not near close to being done. I am blown away by how long it is. (That's what she said)

meh/10 

"open world dark souls" for me is more tedious than fun.  Rmb how you searched every nook and cranny in Dark souls? now try an entire map. By the end I just wanted to finished the game and stop playing. 

Npc quests are still extremely obscure and inconsequential. 

Repeat enemies make new areas feel uninspired. 

Bosses seems to be designed with the use of summons in mind.  Extremely wide move set with long combos that make it hard to read moves and small attack windows. Bosses hit really hard. 

Personally, even after completing the game, I do not feel like I am very good at PvE. Certain enemies will still rape my ass easily. Making the idea of 'getting gud' not very rewarding. 

I personally hope Fromsoft just makes a new IP with Sekiro's combat. Enough dark souls man D:

[h1] Elden Ring is the best Fromsoft game I have ever played, but the flaws that it has are really highlighted because of how good it is.[/h1]

Elden Ring as an open-world RPG game is overwhelmingly good. The location and enemy variety kept me excited, looking forward to what the next area will look like and what type of fucked-up enemy Miyazaki has concocted. There are major secret areas and mini dungeons that can be found just by exploring in the open world, and once you get hooked on finding them, six hours will have passed and the deadline for your schoolwork will have already passed too. I spent 20 hours just exploring the whole of Limgrave (the starting area) because I found a dungeon somewhere. This game will really make you say, "What the hell is that?" throughout your journey, then get you distracted by seven different things on the way, and I freaking love it that the world holds secrets and really feels alive and breathing.

The highlight of this game for me, though, as an action RPG and Souls fan, is the combat and bosses, and I'm really happy with the quality of the Remembrance bosses. All of them have really interesting design, voice acting, music, lore, and movesets, that I really wish for Elden Ring to have a system where you can fight bosses again, similar to the Reflection of Strength from Sekiro. All of the Remembrance bosses feel and fight like final bosses in other games but in a cinematic way especially the last few gauntlet of bosses in the endgame. Of course, they're not perfect, and some have attacks that really feel unfair [spoiler](most notably Maliketh's Edgelord attacks and Elden Beast's Elden Stars and the ring around the rosey attacks), [/spoiler] but overall, the bosses fight fair and square. I also really like that some boss attacks can only be dodged by jumping, which adds a layer of fun to a fight. Couple that layer of fun with the number of weapons, ash of war, incantations, and spells that you can use, and you can see how much depth the combat mechanic of Elden Ring has.

The NPC quest this time around, though, has really improved in flexibility and quality. Unlike in previous Souls games, where you talk to some NPC and progress their questline to a certain extent, then forget about them for some time only to find them in a ditch somewhere because you didn't do a certain thing or progressed through the game too much, all of that is somewhat fixed. NPCs in Elden Ring stay still in the last spot you saw them unless you progress through the game, which causes some part of their questline to be skipped, or if you progress their questline by exhausting their dialogue or giving them a specific item. You can even do some quests after you've beaten the game, unless, of course, that specific NPC questline is tied to a boss or some other things that became inaccessible after some time. I really recommend a spoiler-free guide if you want to experience these questlines on your own.

Let's now move on to the flaws that I have mentioned in the title. After a certain point in the game, you can feel that enemy variety and level design have been thrown out the window (if you played the game, then you would know the part I'm describing). Enemies that have no reason to be there are there, and the amount of damage they deal is on par with some of the early-game optional bosses. I didn't really mind the repetitive and reskin-optional bosses because, "Eh, whatever that still makes sense," but if you start placing enemies at a location where it doesn't really make sense to be, then that's just lazy. This dip in quality is clearly noticeable, and I just slugged through that specific section as fast as I could, but I'm really glad that the quality picked up again right at the end of the game because that would have left a scar in an otherwise really great game.

Overall, Elden Ring really exceeded my expectations of what an open-world game could be, and it really deserves the Game of the Year title it has. Let yourself be cast into an unknown world and explore it, finding every secret or taking your own pace. No matter what suits you, you will have a great time. You will experience Insomia for weeks, but in exchange, you will experience one of the best games of all time. I'm really excited to play the DLC once it comes out, and also, [b]where is the Bloodborne PC port [/b]?
¬†

mind blowing game
Having played through this game multiple times, with 356 hours played at the time of this review, I can not suggest others to buy it at all.

This game has made a lot of advancements for the "open-world" (more on why open-world is in quotes later) genre, but I just absolutely despise the gameplay.
The best way I can describe the gameplay is that it's the same shit as always. Spell spam (when a boss/enemy spams spells over and over instead of actually doing anything unique or fun), AoE spam (Same thing as spell spam but instead of spamming spells they're spamming attacks that deal damage in an Area of Effect), combo spam (Same thing as above but instead of whatever it's high damage fast attacking combos), or spamming roll catchers (moves that have delayed attacks designed to trick you into rolling early). Sometimes, you may even get a "new" thing where they combine the things I mentioned into one singular enemy!
Oh, there's also damage over difficulty (which imo is the worst offender here), which basically just when they decide to make something deal a ludicrous amount of damage instead of actually making it a difficult fight, which leads me into why I don't consider this game to be "open-world". The damage/health scaling for this game is... abysmal? Yeah, abysmal. Nearly every area you enter until over half way through the game you just feel so weak. Either because you don't have enough health to survive the attacks, or you don't have enough damage to not take an eternity just to kill the one enemy/boss so you CAN level up and try to get more HP/damage, leading to the game not really being "open-world" but a linear game with a strong suggestion on where to go. Like, I don't want to spend hours farming, I want to spend hours PLAYING. Farming runes is not playing, it's just mindlessly repeating the same exact movements over and over and over and over and over and over again just so that you CAN actually play the game! IT'S NOT FUN!

Truly and honestly, I think this game has some of the best features of all the soulsborne games, but the combat is just so horrible to me that I grit my teeth and wonder "why am I even playing this?" every single time I launch it, because it's just amplified every problem I had with the old soulsborne games in an attempt to make things more "DiFfIcUlT", leading to the game just feeling annoying to me rather than challenging. I sunk nearly a thousand hours into DS3 because whenever I died I felt like there was something to learn on my end to do better. Passed my first playthrough of this game, it's rarely ever felt like my fault for dying, it just feels like the game's trying to be as annoying as possible. From the combo spam, combo's which have roll catchers for every attack in the combo, the endless FP they gave NPC's because... well just because, the auto parry they gave some NPC's because... well because, to the endless stamina they gave NPC's, well... you get my point, making every fight with them a game of waiting for an opportunity to attack (which is also the problem with many of the bosses in this game as well, but I'll get onto that in a bit). I play games to have fun. Expecting me to be perfect isn't fun, it's exhausting and annoying.

My biggest gripe with the bosses is that they just don't make sense. Why give a boss an extremely high damage combo that homes onto you? Because it's "DiFfIcUlT". Why let a boss like the big red fox just keep jumping every half second while spamming spells non stop that home onto you? "DiFfIcUlTy". Why make a boss fight like Maliketh who just jumps away from you, spams combos that drain HP on hit as well as limit HP on hit (You know, that system of limiting HP like they did in DS2? That thing everyone loved :| )? "DiFfIcUlTy". Why throw the same bosses in stupid places over and over and over and over again? "DiFfIcUlTy". Like, the dual godskin duo bossfight is literally just the same "bosses" (let's be real with ourselves, these aren't bosses when you fight them as much as this, they're just large enemies, like the dogs in Caelid), except here's the kicker, THERE'S MORE HP THAN THE TWO OF THEM COMBINED! Meaning you have to kill them, have them respawn, so you cna kill them AGAIN! SO MUCH FUCKING FUN! HAHAHAHA! Piss off.

By pushing themselves to the point they have, they have begun to show the cracks in the armor of Soulsborne, showing us the problems they've had from the start, the only difference is that they're in full view now. Enjoy looking up meta guides, because that's about the only way you'll have fun playing it.

"Elden Ring," the latest masterpiece from FromSoftware, delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that pushes the boundaries of open-world exploration and immersive storytelling. From the moment you step foot into the expansive realm of the Lands Between, you're engulfed in a breathtaking world teeming with rich lore, dynamic landscapes, and formidable adversaries. The game's open-world design seamlessly blends exploration with intense combat encounters, offering players an unprecedented level of freedom to chart their own path and uncover hidden secrets.

One of the most striking aspects of "Elden Ring" is its intricate world-building. FromSoftware has crafted a meticulously detailed universe filled with diverse regions, each with its own distinct atmosphere and challenges. Whether you're traversing lush forests, scaling towering mountains, or delving into dark dungeons, every corner of the Lands Between feels meticulously crafted and ripe for exploration. The sense of discovery is unparalleled, as players stumble upon ancient ruins, enigmatic NPCs, and cryptic lore that deepen the mystery of the world.

Combat in "Elden Ring" is a thrilling dance of strategy and skill, offering a variety of weapons, spells, and abilities for players to master. From visceral melee combat to exhilarating mounted battles, each encounter feels dynamic and satisfying. The game's challenging difficulty encourages players to adapt and learn from their mistakes, rewarding perseverance with a sense of accomplishment unlike any other. Boss fights, in particular, are epic spectacles that push players to their limits, testing their reflexes and tactics in intense showdowns against larger-than-life foes.

Beyond its gameplay mechanics, "Elden Ring" excels in its storytelling and atmosphere. The game's narrative unfolds organically through cryptic dialogue, environmental storytelling, and haunting imagery. Every NPC, no matter how minor, has a story to tell, adding layers of depth and intrigue to the world. Meanwhile, the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack sets the mood perfectly, evoking a sense of wonder, danger, and melancholy as you journey through the Lands Between.

In conclusion, "Elden Ring" stands as a triumph of game design, seamlessly blending innovative gameplay, captivating world-building, and immersive storytelling into a truly unforgettable experience. FromSoftware has once again raised the bar for open-world RPGs, delivering a game that will undoubtedly leave a lasting impact on players for years to come. Whether you're a seasoned Soulsborne veteran or a newcomer to the genre, "Elden Ring" is an absolute must-play that showcases the best of what video games have to offer.

These are the kinds of video games I live for. I am nowhere NEAR done with Elden Ring. I see myself playing this over and over and over and over again, and I don't expect to keep finding new things with every playthrough. I'm stoked.

I usually HATE open world games. I despise them, frankly, but ELDEN RING is truly something special, they turned a genre which I dislike, into something I love. FromSoftware really did their homework and made an awesome experience that anyone can enjoy.

stuck on solider of godrick
Elden RIng is not a game without imperfections. It contains multiple extremely flawed main bosses, such as the[spoiler]Godskin duo and the Elden Beast.[/spoiler]. That said, Elden Ring is as close to perfect as a game may ever get. It has well in excess of 100 hours worth of actual worthwhile content. The artwork is some of the best to ever appear in a video game. The soundtrack is incredible. The open world is better than that of any other game I've played. It doesn't rely on meaningless checkbox-based exploration. The bosses, although not perfect, are, as a whole, quite fun to fight, especially [spoiler]Morgott, Radagon, and Godfrey[/spoiler]. The legacy dungeons are amazing. Overall, Elden Ring is probably the best game I've played to date, and I'm excited to see what Fromsoft has in store for us with Shadow of the Erdtree.

Elden Ring is a great game, nothing can really come close to it in terms of open world design and exploration (mostly, the only thing that does a better job in the exploration department would be Metro Exodus) and the gameplay (enemy design, character move-sets, etc. etc.) is incredible fun. 
Now I don't have much to say about the good things, this is Dark Souls 4, if that sounds good, have fun.
now the bad. 
I'm gonna sound like i'm going hard on it here but you criticise what you love the most.

What I have a problem with and this harms the gameplay too, is the sheer amount of repetition, The enemies and bosses you fight at the beginning of the game are unironically the same bosses you'll be fighting at the end. there are only 8~ish truly unique, un-repeated bosses in the game and it being an around 50+ hour experience means you'll spend a lot of time before encountering new enemies.

Now I'm not saying that the bosses that are copy pasted all over the place aren't good, it's just that it makes any subsequent encounters with them completely boring. By complete chance I ended up encountering almost every single boss in the game through their 'duplicate' versions first, so whenever I found the originals any sense of tension or challenge eats dirt.

Also another big problem I have with the game is the completely schizophrenic progression, If you listen to the game and 'follow the grace' without going full Skyrim and exploring then by the time you get around to what the game doesn't tell you is the first area everything will die incredibly quickly. Not to mention that the directly intended route will be several magnitudes more difficult until your level catches up.

There are also some problems with enemies occasionally having attacks that feel straight out of Sekiro but that's a whole other topic I don't want to get into here, this isn't the first time I've just said 'go watch this review' in a steam review but go watch Joseph Anderson's review of Elden Ring, It'll cover everything.
easy it not just in danile
I don't need to tell you why this game is good, its fromsoftware, everything miyazaki touches turns to gold
Girl talk to me :)
GOATED
Easily one of my top 10 games this decade for sure! Enjoyable, teaches you a lot of things (patience, problem solving etc), amazing art style and overall atmosphere!

Everything I hoped for in an Open World From game.

Came out around, 2 years ago, and honestly was not that hyped about this game.
got it couple of months ago, played it few hours, and dropped - thought to my self that im sick of souls games.
after arguing with my friends, i decided to give it a go once more - ONE OF MY BEST DECISIONS FOR GAMING.

As im approaching the end of my first run, i can say for sure that FromSoftware made a game of the decade here, they took many good aspects of souls games and just improved on them to create a captivating game that makes you just bash your head until you beat every boss.

The game it self feels a bit "lesser" in terms of hardcore souls games like the others in the series (dark souls 1 + 3), but for sure there are some crazy ass bosses i was grinding my teeth to beat.

putting the combat aside, lets talk about the game visuals... they are just breath taking.
Every time i'm reaching a new area, i just cant hold my self from stopping for a minute or two just to glare at the beautiful scenery.. 

With all that in mind ye tarnished, GO and be the ELDEN LORD! 

FromSoftware - Thanks you.

Elden ring is the greatest game of all time. It's not for everyone, but if it's for you, it is THE game for you. It's the type of game you beat once and instead of putting it down, you want to play again for like 2000 more hours. It's the G.O.A.T.

Big thumbs up personally.

Pros.
- tons of bosses to test new weapons u find on.
- tons of build variety and potential.
- nice weapon list with some pretty good ashes of wars to put on weapons.
- very enjoyable as a first play-through to explore the map and find new things.
- pretty good questlines.
- beautiful game depending on graphics settings or mods.
- enjoyable mods, seemless coop, convergeance, things like that.
- main bosses have pretty fun movesets if you're patient enough to learn.
- spirit ashes r helpful for ppl who want to play it more casually ( although controversial )
- amazing world building, most places when u enter u can see the end of the area to or where u end up going.
- cool enemy/boss/character design
- very good boss ost's ( not as good as bloodborne though zzz )
- interesting enough characters and lore in the world, although not clear enough, ( seek youtube )
- try fingers, but hole.

Cons. 
- Replaying the game and going through the map can be boring depending on yourself. for me knowing the game inside out and the locations of stuff makes it difficult to play again since i know to look for, first playthrough was a go explore now its a go from A to B to get this then kill boss and repeat. 
- good luck without fextra life interactive map in some situations. 
- not enough in the open world to keep you interested in replaying, the only good places r the main areas.
- the bosses aside from main ones are pretty poor considering there is 165 and most of them arent single unique ones. im not mad was just a bit disappointing considering there are stuff like 2 astels?
- no 40 vigor no fun
- endgame scaling goes crazy considering morgott can be really easy with scaling and then all of a sudden it feels double the difficulty when going to fire giant.
- summons can ruin the game on a first playthrough and sour the game for you.


Still though, i love the game. just have some issues with it.
DLC will be goated though.

Ranni is feet Goddess
You've most likely already heard the trite expression "Elden Ring isn't Dark Souls 4, its 4, 5 and 6 in one" and I'm tempted to say that might even be a bit of an understatement. I'm not massive on open worlds and even for this one there was a good 10 or 20 hours in the middle that I was bored to tears tempted to just look up where to head next, I believe the main thing to consider if you have prior experience with especially the metroidvania esque souls games, you have to abandon some of the mindset with those games in regards to exploration and combat, this game is a masterclass of an open world games but it still comes with many of the fallings of the genre - hard to balance areas with some being far to easy or far to difficult depending on when you choose to tackle them, a lot of liminal moments (joke intended) between that you may find boring with an open world by design never ever being able to be as dense as a more linear game etc. If you look past your own biases however, you will most likely find Elden Ring an incredibly fulfilling experience, nigh on the best combat present in an open world game, an incredible story and lore even for the very very high bar other from games set, and goes without saying but drop down gorgeous, not only from a graphical point of view(beware there are some performance issues due to this) but from an awe inspiring art direction. Lastly, accessibility options are to use per taste, something is only cheating (summons, "cheese" load outs) if you believe you've cheated yourself, if not, go wild the options are in the game for a reason, it is a video game not a test.
10/10 would let ranni have my mushroom
I loooooove this gaaaame but it makes me maaaaad sometimes
This game is brilliant in many ways, but not for the gameplay. 

First lets start of with whats genuinely good about the game right now:
- amazing soundtracks
- a lot of weapon diversity and playstyle chosing
- lots of route finding
- a LOT of random stuff in the overworld giving rewards (its also a con cause of missing semi important items for builds is VERY probable)
-  well written story and Lore for everything in the verse right now
- good ending choices that have a deeper meaning for the players decision


Now lets go to the bad aspects that I found out from my gameplay so far (started Farum Azula  and completed everything else before it + Haligtree) :

- Middle and Endgame have LOTS of tedious stuff not out of difficulty but out of pure frustration => less fun in the endgame with the most amazing bosses in the game (Malenia, Morgott, ect.)
-  The scaling for the different areas is inconsistent. You're supposed to do Calid before Altus and Leyndell, yet the enemies there are a LOT stronger than the ones in Altus
- build options are hidden throughout the game and thus make respec-ing into another more favorable built of yours a necessity, which is not a good design with limited respecs
- the Arenas are genuinely the worst ones in any Fromsoft game like genuinely
- movement feels clunky due to target locking, making the rather weird option of free camming the better feel, but also significantly more harder for the average player who doesnt play claw
-  player level scaling is not intuitive. "What level am I supposed to be?" in areas with Vigor checks and also high density of enemies happenes countless times throughout the gameplay and the fact that you HAVE to be at a point in Vig. where 2 Flasks dont even full heal you... lets just say that doesnt help the feeling a player has
- broken weapons and limited uses till Farum Azula due to limited (somber) smith stones => cant pivot to other weapons for a LONG time 
- parrys feel awful on some enemies, especially Malenia. I genuinely enjoy parrys in general, but when the timing for parrys isnt the same across the board, why am I even supposed to play with shields in this game and not just go a dex/strength build or mega prepare a Intellligence built, it just doesnt make any sense to have a skill expression like that in the game when it isnt across the board and you need to literally relearn it for a majority of enemies
- a lot of repetitiveness in Bosses, Catacombs/graves, normal enemies, heck even weapons and spells
- unnecessary pacouring with the worst movement controls of any game I have played


In short: I am not a fan of how this game feels to play, how it makes the play have to REALLY think on what build to go, how to prepare (if at all) for bigger Bosses and what to expect from enemies around the boss. Very unfun and useless parts keep appearing in this game as is and give the player a miniscule reward in most cases and at best 15min of wandering in an area trying to figure out a "puzzle" (hint: its a dark tunnel or an invisible wall).

Love everything else about the game BESIDES the gameplay and thats why I cannot recommend this game for majority of players who want a good time, want to enjoy a chill game where they have a challenge but get rewarded. This game is none of these and is just a pure headache for anyone not taking it seriously.
No clue how this won GOTY honestly, I do have high hopes for the DLC though in terms of fixing problems.
la mujer del proceso

what is this elders rings I've heard all about?
FromSoftware's formula makes for a unique experience when combined with a truly open world. While the end result is imperfect (the second half of the game is noticeably worse than the first in terms of enemy variety, rewarding exploration, and difficulty that inspires a sense of accomplishment instead of just relief when you overcome it), this might still be one of the overall best action RPGs in recent memory.

Elden Ring is also by far the most accessible game FromSoftware has ever made on account of things like spirit summons that can trivialize most bosses and the ability to overlevel a lot of content you find difficult by simply exploring instead of grinding. So, if you're looking for an entry point into soulslikes, look no further. If all else fails, you can always fall back on multiplayer co-op to overcome the game's most ludicrous challenges.

Great game, but steep learning curve
good game
While clearly not the worst From Software game, it's by far the most overrated. You can ignore the fact that most dungeons are the same dungeon copy-pasted or, in general, how much the same assets are re-used over and over. That is nearly inevitable in an open-world game.
But you cannot ignore the fact that you are not free to explore the world without risking of soft-locking most of the sub-quests (which the game gives no indication whatsoever) or without risking of overleveling.
But the worst offender in this game are the boss fights: really bad designed. They are hard but not challenging; it does not matter how good you are, if your character is not one of the meta builds you cannot defeat most of the main bosses. And no, being forced to follow a meta is not good game design (yes, even Let Me Solo Her is a meta build). Another very big problem with boss (and mid boss) fights is the spectacularization over gameplay. Most of the time you are forced to watch the boss doing all its acrobatics maneuvers while rolling away (yeah, shields don't really matters anymore), waiting, waiting and waiting for a split second window of opportunity to strike back, all while fighting against a camera view not intended for such choreography.
We are far away from the tactical and metodical fighting mechanic of Dark Souls. This is an extremely disappointing game.
If only I could be so grossly incandescent..

The gameplay is amazing. I think everyone can agree on that. Highly recommend this game even if you hate dying and losing all your runes...

However,
The quality of life UI/UX in the menus is "E" tier at best.
Press G to open your map.. but Esc to close it again, because NOW G opens a help dialog in map. 
This is one of many examples of the thought that went into the menu/features. 
Also - This game has secret controller/keyboard configs you CANNOT change and DO NOT show up in anywhere but maybe the tutorial. only to be forgotten later. 
I have had to look up so many hidden controls or try and figure out WHY oh WHY can I not use my cool ash of war on my one-handed sword while also wielding a shield, just because it also has the parry skill...

anyway. I do love the game. But if you are going to really be bothered by a bad UI/UX experience in a game. Maybe hold onto your $$$.

no, you're maiden-less >:(
ELDEN RIIIING OH ELDEN RIIIIING
 To keep it short, this game is basically the culmination of Fromsoft's experience with "Soulsborne" as a whole, particularly improving on Dark Souls 3. 
It's easily the most accessible souls game thus far, with it being open world, and having a "play it at your own pace" attitude, as well providing tons of get out of jail free cards for newbies; from spirit ash summons to weapons that are broken OP in PvE, such as the "Rivers of Blood" Katana or the "Blasphemous Blade" greatsword, or even assistance in the form of online co-op with a buddy. As such, ER can simultaneously be the most difficult souls game ever, OR the easiest souls game ever, depending on how much you want to take advantage of these tools. At the very least, I'm proud of myself for managing to beat the main story as a STR build without using any spirit ashes as per me being a souls veteran, but again, it was purely my choice; mimic tear and Banished Knight Oleg can bail you out if it's too hard for ya. I'm still feeling torn in some aspects about the game though; no dragon in the game can match Midir from DS3 and I still think that balancing the game around spirit ashes make it preposterously difficult times, particularly against the likes of the infamous Malenia; but I guess there's already plenty of youtubers and and "letmesoloher" that have beaten her without any cheap tricks as well. All in all, a fantastic game, and well worth the money at $40-60. Can't wait for shadow of the erdtree
Get good.    easiest of the souls games, but best story in my opinion

Edit: I got banned??

I was playing offline Elden Ring modded after I completed the game for a few runs, I turned off anti cheat, created a new character and went at it for about 2 weeks. I got bored and wanted to go back online to play some coop. I deleted my mods, deleted my modded character and verified game files before opening and got the message "Prohibited Alterations detected". But this seems to be a common issue and seeing as I deleted all my files I should be fine. The message also said the warning would not go away for a while so I thought I was in the clear. I played for about 2 weeks and got the message "Your account has been penalized" for 180 days

huh?? I rarely play online anyway so it dont matter too much for me, but that's ridiculous. To this day I still dont know what I got flagged for. 

It would make everyone's lives easier if the warning actually told you what you got flagged for, so you can get rid of said items if you have them. I thought I was in the clear after deleting everything except my vanilla characters. (which I havent touched in the mod)

All this and there are still blatant cheaters roaming about in the game without being banned.

Customer support is also ridiculously slow. I don't think I'm getting unbanned anytime soon

Never bothered reviewing a game before, but FromSoftware went above and beyond to craft a game that towers above the rest in scope, theme, mechanics, music, story and everything in (the lands) between.  This game single-handedly pulled me back into single players games, having not completed one since Resident Evil 7, and before that, Dragon Age Origins.  What a joy to play and experience for the first time.  

As frustratingly hard as some encounters may be, the prospect of discovering a new piece of lore, the flavor text on a dope item, a valuable upgrade, or parkour-ing your way to another hidden quest or boss, made me never waver in determination to see what was around the next corner.

Bravo.  This is one that will be remembered fondly for a long, long time. I Haven't felt like this about a game since the golden age of SquareSoft games.

More content per square foot of game map than any game I have ever played. Hard and frustrating at times, you get such a sense of satisfaction after learning a boss, or mobs mechanics and finally defeating them after many tries. Some things can be clunky, jumping puzzles sometimes suck due to the games physics, and the camera can be special at times, but not enough to not suggest Elden Ring to anyone. My favorite of the souls game to date by far. I hope From Software keeps the game going in the same direction in the future. 9.5/10

The Soulsborne evolution!
What can I say about Elden Ring that hasn't been said already? So many different areas to explore, and things to discover in the open world, especially the weapons, there's many unique weapons and builds to test out which offers this game some insane replay value. On top of that you have some of the best level design and bosses that the souls games have to offer. Elden Ring is basically a culmination of all the things the fans of the souls franchise love, but with so much more. This being FromSoftware's biggest game, the ambitions definitely make up for one hell of an experience. This is not only one of my favorite from the franchise, but one of the best games I've ever played.

Hey, I'm not sure it entirely has the flow/balance of the other games, you can't really perfectly outskill it.

But it's also good enemies are more realistic, don't wait for you to fight one enemy, attack like relentless other people would, don't give you any pattern to really counter a lot of the time, but that imo is a new thing and good, cause it's realistic, like fighting real people.

So you gotta be smart, unfair, like you are surviving in a real world, D&D style, and research stuff you can use/get to give yourself the edge and win, it's quite fun, and the world is really expansive and lovely, if a little of a pain to navigate sometimes.

Replaying this game years after launch, and I gotta say, it's just a 10/10.

ring elden
Try Fingers But Hole
Obviously still very early impressions for how long of a game this is meant to be. I have explored a decent chunk of the starting area and have faced quite a few dungeon bosses now.

I have become a from software fan in the past couple of years, Having played first bloodborne and then sekiro - and now understand the joy that these games bring to many, including myself. I think Sekiro is one of the few 10/10 games I have ever played, and I could see myself potentially enjoying Elden Ring to that same level.

The worlds that from software are able to create never cease to amaze me. The atmosphere in this game immediately makes itself known with the big glowing tree you can see in the horizon pretty much all the time. The lore begs for you to learn more, and piece together the bits of information available. As for gameplay, fighting tree sentinel at level 1 was fun. Struck memories of gyobu in Sekiro. I can see why so many were upset at launch now, which makes it even funnier knowing I had to actively seek out his attention so he would start fighting me. The core of these games are all the same, Fight big bad over and over, learning everything about him until you know what he is going to do before even he knows. And using that information to punish them. Spirit ashes are a great optional addition to the game that are there for most optional bosses I've come across, although some boss are restricted in their use. These give you summons to help if you are new. This makes the game pretty newbie friendly, even if the boss move sets are sometimes annoying to deal with. Would recommend to anyone like me as a relatively new fan of these types of games that is still considering whether or not to buy, and would cautiously recommend to anyone looking to get into the franchise. I still think bloodborne is the easier game, but I can see the larger mass appeal in Elden Ring.

Greatest game of all time

bonk

It's actually amazing how many QoL things this game has that make it much more enjoyable than any other previous Souls-likes.

I'm not saying this is the best Souls-like, that is very much debatable, but things such as instant fast-travel (no item needed, nor it is unlocked late game or anything), Statues of Marika (no painful runbacks to bosses), clearing groups of enemies gives you back some healing flasks (just play the game aka beat enemies and explore), Spirit Ashes, the gentle guidance of grace, the map and NPCs being showed in, all of these things make the game more enjoyable so that you don't have to suffer through rather questionable design decision and just, you know, explore and beat bosses. And there's plenty more that I can't think of right now, and probably much more that need to be added. 

The game definitely doesn't need a traditional "difficulty slider" as the game mechanics can influence how hard or easy the game can be. Have a tough time with a boss or an area? Go somewhere else and level up a bit on easier enemies. Need just a bit more damage or something that can take aggro or tank? Summon spirit ashes. There's plenty of mechanics like this that you can opt in or out of in order to modify your experience to your liking.

Excellent bosses, impeccable lore and storytelling, various weaponry and armor (can't wait to check out new weapon types in the DLC), amazing locations, just a great game overall!
The game is only as hard as you let it be.

The game is really good if you put time into it, of course not an easy game but just find how you want to play and then build that way. You can always switch your build later so no worries, after a lot of amazing bosses and annoying deaths, i did beat the main game. There was a moment in the game i was really frustrated because my build i had the whole game was no longer good enough or i was not good with the build, so i stopped playing a while and eventually came back and switched builds to beat the game. This game isn't 100 perfect and a few flaws but i got the game for 40 bucks and have 90 hours or so and id say it was well spent. If you are not a patient person i would not recommend the game, but if you got some time like 2 to 3 hours a day i think it would suit you well. It is really rewarding to win so go for it and enjoy. amazing game

Elden Ring, a collaboration between FromSoftware and George R.R. Martin, is a masterclass in modern gaming. Set in the vast and meticulously crafted Lands Between, players are immersed in a world brimming with rich lore and stunning landscapes. Combat is challenging yet deeply rewarding, demanding strategy and skill in every encounter. The narrative, influenced by Martin's expertise, is intricate and captivating, driving players forward with mysteries waiting to be unraveled. Multiplayer elements add further depth, offering opportunities for both cooperation and competition. Visually, Elden Ring is breathtaking, with each environment boasting its own distinct aesthetic. It stands as a masterpiece of artistry and creativity, honed to perfection in every aspect. Elden Ring is an essential experience for any gamer, a shining example of gaming excellence in the modern era.

It feels like Guantanamo all over again but with a mix of Vietnam. Sadly the developers haven't landed in a Chinese Reeducation Camp
This game (and honestly all other Souls games) change you. That sounds cheesy or whatever, but there is SOMETHING about these games that just cannot be compared to anything else. For anyone intimidated because you've heard these games are tough and brutal, the real experience is overcoming the hard stuff and finally achieving victory. Not only that but the world, the music, the tragic characters, are all captivating and I think there's something to love here for everybody. It's worth an honest shot. This stands to be my favourite game possibly ever. I've played 130 hours and will continue to play, have pre-ordered the deluxe DLC and still listen to hours upon hours of lore deep dive content. Just... yeah. This game absolutely slaps.
shall be one of the best games of the year
A Masterpiece of the Decade

Elden Ring is, in my opinion, one of the best games of the last decade. The open world of this game is simply incredible, inspiring a desire to explore every corner, unlike some other open-world games that fail to captivate. The game's art direction is astounding, and the music is of exceptional quality. Every element of Elden Ring has been crafted with care and attention to detail, making it a standout title in the gaming world. This game is a must-play for anyone who appreciates the artistry and immersive experience of a well-designed open world.

‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚°ü‚°ø‚¢ø‚°ø‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚†Ä‚†ª‚¢Ø‚¢∑‚£º‚†Å‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚¢ø‚°Ñ‚°à‚¢Ü‚†Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚°á‚£ø‚°Ö‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚†¶‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚°á‚¢π‚¢ø‚°Ä
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Å‚†õ‚†ì‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†º‚†á‚†Å

Elden Ring is objectively the greatest video game of all time and my personal second favorite, next to Bloodborne. There's just no other game like it or better than it. I've completed all of FromSoftware's Soulsborne games, and I would say this is the culmination of all of them.

I platinumed/100% completed this game in just one week on PlayStation 5 during its release week, and my run was in the top 0.6% completion overall at that time. I found a game-boosting side job and earned a few bucks from it. It ruined every RPG that came out and that I played after it to this day. What else can I say? That's how great it is!

I wish I could put it as my top game of all time, but Bloodborne holds a special place in my heart, so it won't happen anytime soon. I've spent hundreds of hours on PlayStation 5 and will still spend more on Steam PC as I'm preparing a new character for the next DLC (Shadow of the Erdtree).

The only downside to this game is that it will ruin your fun and experience with other RPGs that come out afterward. You haven't played it yet? What are you playing other than this? Stop whatever mediocre games you're playing right now! Don't sleep on it! Go grab it NOW!
You get better till you quit

STRENGHT IS COOL, DEX IS COOL, ARCANE IS COOL

Finger but whole
played it on my PS5 goated game pls get if you wanna play one of the best games of all time!
wooooow
It's a good game it just has too much garbage to filter through. If you're experienced at these games you're also going to have to gimp yourself a lot to find any enjoyment out of it otherwise its going to be too easy. The modifier stacking in this game is insane, its practically Nioh levels of insanity where you can basically bypass the combat system with diablo power stacking through buffs, rings, consumables ect. The ashes of war are also far too powerful and are easily spammed without consequence. Most of your power is defined by them where neutral play matters far less.

Most of the open world is forgettable and redundant only there to pad the game time and appeal to a different audience that enjoys that kind of experience. Liurnia of the Lakes is by far the worse example of this and its always a slog to go through even when you're skipping through 90% of it. The underground areas are also vapid derivative empty spaces of time wasting. The worst is Nokstella, a complete waste of time that you cant even use the horse to trudge through. Most of these areas only serve to plod along the plot of the most self indulgent unlikeable character in the game. It's all extremely disappointing.

The pacing also suffers as well. Most of the game feels too samey in terms of enemy power level where the player starts to outscale them until you get to mountaintops of the giants and then the enemy power curve leaps exponentially.  Caelid, Luiurina, Altus, Leyndell Capital all feel very similar in terms of enemy power. The bridge between them and Mountaintops is supposed to be Volcano Manor/Mt Gelmir but even that feels way undertuned compared to mountaintops. My issue with this is that it really feels like the game doesn't start until you get to mountaintops as the stuff you did beforehand feels irrelevant. Playing through NG+ cycles only makes the gap wider and its a real problem I have with this game. 

With all that being said this game is still worth it despite all of these problems. The boss design is solid and the movement options like crouching and jumping feel good and don't overly oppress the core dark souls combat. Legacy dungeons are by far the best this game offers, areas like Stormveil Castle, Farum Azula, Miquella's Haligtree, Leyndell Capital are very well designed and are worth trudging through the open world to get to. 

The core combat is still dark souls and the formula is very addicting where you can spend hours of fulfillment killing hordes of enemies. Although the game does prod you into abusing cheesy mechanics or diablo power stacking, you never have to and there is a level of satisfaction gained after achieving a certain level of mastery over the challenges the game puts you through. I think this is what keeps me hooked to this game above all else.

Absolutly Incredible art piece as well as video game 9.6/10
Fun game and fantastic world.  Exploration is definitely rewarded.
Difficulty is on the high side but not horribly unfair.
For those who don't want the challenge but would like to try the game mods are just a google search away and there are some that lower the difficulty or nearly eliminate it if you just want closer to tourist mode.  If you go this route I do recommend trying the game later on with mods off once you have some experience with the mechanics.
While some starting classes are more powerful out the gate than others I recommend going with whichever catches your fancy or fits what you believe to be your style.  All starting classes ultimately become whatever you make them through gear and leveling.
With the DLC around the corner it is a good time to get started.  Though waiting for a deal once the DLC hits is also an option.

Overall definitely recommend for any gamer who likes swords, sorcery, and exploration.
Elden Ring? Oh, please. That so-called "challenge" was child's play for someone of my caliber. Every achievement in that game was practically handed to me on a silver platter. From conquering bosses with my eyes closed to navigating the open world with one hand tied behind my back, it was all too easy. I finished the game before most players even figured out how to swing a sword properly. Maybe next time they'll make a game worthy of my skills, but until then, I'll bask in the glory of effortlessly conquering Elden Ring.

I have beat this game before, but I missed it so much that I bought it again at full price to get ready for the upcoming DLC as I'm never going back to console.  This game is a masterpiece that deserves all the praise and sales it has received.  

Is this game going to be for everyone? NO, It is not a game that everyone will find fun and rewarding. It can be challenging in some areas but if you stick with it and give it an actual effort you might find a game you can sink hundreds of hours in.

:)
[h1]Jaw-dropping experience. [/h1]
Not the best combat out there, you will die, and i mean, a lot. Elden Ring is so rewarding, so fulfilling.
You will have to go back and forth multiple times, because you are probably under-level, but that's why this game is so unique and special. I never thought i would like souls-like games, but exploring this open-world is something i have never seen in any other videogame ever before. it is truly remarkable.
Every location you explore is incredibly built and designed, with tons of secrets, hidden places and doors, multiple precious items, and incredible views to see.
I truly think everyone should play this game, atleast once, in his life, it is simply incredible, something taken from fantasy books.

Just have in mind that you're most of the times, the victim. You will have to farm EXP, kill a lot of mobs, get good gear and upgrade it, until you get stronger, in order to go into new areas of the map, search a lot online, you will probably need it, as zones have level caps, but this game wont tell you anything, literally, anything, but well... i guess that's the beauty of it.
[b]
Be patient, do not rush enemies, study their moves and patterns first, then take your move and kill them, dodge or parry exactly in the last second, remember, this is Elden Ring, exploration is key, if you cant beat an enemy, do not worry, come back later.
For 3 times i thought to myself, i m not ever playing this again, but i was wrong.[/b][h1]TRY. IT. best love-hate relationship there could ever be[/h1]

Overall this is a really fun game that I think people should try at least once. The combat both in and out of boss fights is engaging and rewarding and you get a true sense of accomplishment for every victory you take. The only thing that I wasn't too much of a fan of is how disjointed and awkward some of the npc quests are. Often times they change locations (sometimes as far as the opposite side of the map) without so much as a clue as to where they might be going, making it so that its very easy to miss, sequence break or outright ruin entire quest-lines. However, this gripe is minor compared to everything else I loved about the game. Overall I'd give this title a 9/10 and i'm very excited to see where the dlc takes the series next.

Could this be the greatest game to ever exist? It easily could be. From amazing level design to outstanding and breathtaking landscapes, this game offers anything and everything you wish for in a open-world game. On top of all that it drops you into an intriguing lore-filled story that offers hours of mystery and world-building. The side-quests add even more hours of depth to a game already so rich with narrative. I cannot recommend it enough.

Amazing game, 10/10 and im not even finished yet. 

There are slight issues, First of all, knowing the next place you are supposed to go for the main story is quite difficult, most of my time is spent running around trying to figure out where im supposed to be. I guess this is intentional? its kind of fun to explore and find side quests. 

The main quests are sooo much fun tho, the main bosses in this game are truly incredible... 

The combat is so much fun really. but the most stand out thing about this game is the incredible game design visually (genius art styles). The atmosphere and legendary boss battles are sooooo stunning. 

This game punches so far beyond any game ive seen. Its in a whole class of its own really. 

I think im CPU limited on a ryzen 5600 at 4k so im probably not getting full 120 fps, but its worth it for better visuals. It also stutters a bit, again I think thats cuz my cpu is a bit slow for this massive game. 

I cant wait to finish it and play the DLC later this year!

yes
[h1]It does not matter how slowly you go as long as you do not stop.[/h1]

One of the greatest games ever released this generation, even for someone like me who typically don't play Souls-type games. The staggering amount of content, the sense of scale, and the world design/world-building, gives the player a sense of exploration unlike any other game. The art style, enemy variety, boss design are incredible, and the soundtracks are amazing.

The combat and build variety are great, and the bosses are some of the hardest in the series to solo unless using an OP build or by cheesing (looking at you, Malenia), but you never feel frustrated, and instead try to get better. However, game balancing is an issue. Some of the enemies deal absurd damage for how common they are.

The game is designed in a way that the player can make the game as difficult as he wants or as easy he wants, using the summons and tools given, making this game very accessible to any new players to Soulslike games.

If you're wondering about the hype and whether it truly is a great game, let me tell you as a newcomer to Soulslikes in general, yes, this game is a must-play and I'm so glad I've experienced it. 9/10

Before playing the Elden Ring, I had full head of hair, a healthy sleeping schedule and a lifestyle and a sense of personal accomplishment. After many nights filled with my own screams echoing throught my home, all of those things have vanished.....I have been kicked out of the house, in the very dark place of my heart full of depression and anxiety and my ADHD has been kicking in non-stop ever since playing the game. I am slowly getting my life back together, once i start living a normal life again me and this game shall meet again!

morning star >
good game for starters. If too hard just summon or go mage. If too easy go strength build with guts sword. Overall, let chaos take the world.
Elden Ring is one of my favorite games of all time. originally I was skeptical on weather I would enjoy Elden Ring or not simply because I had never played a souls game before and they have a certain reputation of being difficult games so I waited a year before I ended up saying to myself "ehhh it looks cool and it's on sale so why not?". However I ended up enjoying this game way more than I thought and for anyone who is skeptical because it's a souls game then I would suggest buying Elden Ring because 1: it is the easiest souls game because of the open world and 2nd: There are multiple difficulty sliders such as: Leveling Vigor, Using Magic, Using Summons, and Farming Souls. So with that said my favorite parts of Elden Ring are as follows: The rich, vast open world that feels amazing to explore, The insane amount of weapons, armor, and spells included to make it easy to create many cool builds, and the weird part for me is I never beat the game or even went to the Mountaintops of the Giants because for some reason I had so much fun doing Limgrave over and over again 40-70 times. 11/10. GOTY 2022 for good reason. deserves 1000 hours.

‚£ø‚†è‚†Ä‚£∞‚£ø‚†Ø‚£Ω‚¢è‚£º‚†ª‚£ø‚¢≥‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚†Å‚†ô‚†õ‚†∑‚£§‚£ô‚†≤‚†ß‚†ü‚°õ‚†ª‚†Ö‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚°Ä‚£¥‚°ø‚†ø‚†Ω‚£ø‚£∂‚£¶‚¢§‚£º‚£∂‚£ü‚°ò‚£ß‚°ô‚£Ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚°∏‚°±‚£Æ‚£ø‚£Ø‚¢Ω‚°ü‚£æ‚£ø‚£ü‚°º‚¢π
‚¢ã‚†Ñ‚¢∞‚£ø‚†è‚¢ò‚£ø‚£Ø‚£º‚†Ä‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†â‚†â‚†â‚†â‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†õ‚†ª‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£¶‚£§‚£à‚°â‚£ø‚£Ø‚°Ω‚°ü‚†Ü‚¢ø‚††‚¢ø‚£ª‚£ß‚£ª‚£ß‚†ó‚°º‚£ø‚£ø‚°ù‚£ñ‚¢ª‚£ø‚£û‚†∑
‚†ã‚¢∞‚£ø‚†ã‚£†‚£æ‚¢ü‚£Å‚¢æ‚£µ‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ô‚†ª‚†∫‚†ª‚¢ø‚°ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚†ß‚£∑‚£º‚°ø‚£ò‚£ø‚°ó‚£ø‚°ú‚°ß‚¢é‚£π‚£ø‚°è‚£æ‚¢£‚£ø‚£ø‚£Æ
‚£∂‚†ü‚££‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚°ñ‚£¥‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£π‚£ø‚°Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£ª‚†ü‚£ø‚†Ä‚£ø‚°ø‚£ø‚£º‚£ø‚¢π‚£ø‚£ø‚°ó‚°®‚£ú‚£ø‚£ü‚°î‚££‚¢ª‚£∑‚£ª
‚£Ø‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ª‚£¥‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£á‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚††‚£§‚£ø‚†ü‚†ª‚£∑‚£ø‚£á‚£ø‚£ø‚°ò‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚°±‚£å‚¢≥‚°≠‚£ø‚°Ñ‚¢ª‚°ú‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°è‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚£ø‚°ü‚£ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ê‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£†‚†ü‚†Å‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£á‚¢∫‚£ø‚£ø‚£ü‚£ø‚£ø‚°Ü‚£è‚¢î‚†ª‚°å‚†∑‚°∞‚¢õ
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ó‚¢∏‚¢ª‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ò‚¢∑‚°ù‚£∑‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£∏‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°á‚£æ‚°û‚£ø‚¢≠‚£ø‚£∑‚¢ü‚†ß‚£æ‚£∑‚£∂‚£π‚£∂‚£ç
‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£æ‚£Ω‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ª‚¢∑‚£ô‚£∑‚°ú‚£ø‚£Ü‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£†‚£ø‚£ü‚£Ω‚£ø‚£ü‚£ß‚£ª‚°á‚°õ‚¢¶‚£ø‚£ø‚¢∫‚£ü‚¢∑‚£ª‚£Ø‚¢≥‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£∏‚¢ø‚£Ω‚£∑‚°ø‚£ø‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£¥‚£ø‚°ø‚¢π‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£è‚£ø‚£É‚¢£‚£æ‚£ø‚£è‚£æ‚£ü‚£º‚°ª‚£Ø‚¢æ‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£û‚¢ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£∑‚£Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ë‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£†‚£ø‚£ø‚†è‚°î‚£ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∫‚£∑‚°ø‚£ø‚†ü‚£Ω‚£≥‚£ø‚°≤‚£ø‚°¥‚£ª‚£ø‚£Ω
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ø‚¢∑‚†ª‚£ø‚£∑‚£ß‚£ø‚£¶‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£†‚£∂‚£ø‚£ø‚†õ‚††‚¢ò‚£º‚†ã‚£º‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ü‚£æ‚£ø‚£ü‚£ø‚£∑‚¢´‚£∑‚£ø‚£ª‚¢ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ü‚£Ø‚†π‚£ø‚°∑‚£ª‚£ø‚£ø‚£¶‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£Ä‚£¥‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚†ã‚†Ä‚°å‚£¥‚°ø‚¢°‚†Ç‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ω‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ü‚°æ‚£ø‚£Ω‚£æ‚£Ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ω‚°ß‚£π‚£∑‚£π‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£Ñ‚°Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚£Ä‚£§‚£∂‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚†ü‚†Ä‚¢Ä‚°∂‚¢ø‚°ø‚¢Å‚¢¶‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£∑‚£ø‚£•‚°π‚£ø‚£æ‚°π‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚†ø‚¢°‚††‚†í‚†Ä‚£º‚°ü‚£±‚¢Ø‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£æ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ß‚†ú‚°π‚£∑‚°ù‚£é‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ω‚£ø‚£ó‚£´‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚°ø‚†õ‚†Å‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚¢†‚£æ‚†è‚†ú‚£±‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£è‚†Ñ‚†ë‚¢û‚†ª‚¢¨‚¢ç‚†ª‚¢ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ü‚°ø‚†ü‚†Å‚††‚†Ä‚†ä‚†Å‚¢Ä‚£∞‚†ü‚¢Å‚††‚†ö‚£µ‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø
‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ü‚†Ä‚†à‚¢£‚†Ñ‚†Ç‚†°‚†Ä‚†π‚£ø‚£ø‚£Ñ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚£†‚°û‚†Å‚†à‚†Ä‚£†‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø‚£ø

Dog pope! üê¢

It's fantastic. Even for people unfamiliar with FromSoft's other games, this game is accessible in spite of its lineage of difficulty. There are multiple things you can do to gain strength, and also multiple strategies you can employ within combat itself.

The addition of the open world and crafting system is a huge boon to the formula. The open world encourages exploration, which has always been a strong point in FromSoft games, and also opens up tons of opportunities to power up through side activities and explore quests through the various characters you can find and talk to. The crafting system also functions as a way to ease exploration by creating useful tools, as well as make combat more manageable through crafting throwables, ammo, status inflicting items and buffs.

The moment to moment gameplay is vastly improved as well. You still have your light and heavy attacks, your guarding and parrying, and your magical spells in two different flavors. But all of these features have improved in a number of ways, including new ways to interact in combat. Combat Arts can be a fundamental part of the way you play, opening up lots of new moves and abilities, the new guard counter allows for a much more defensive playstyle to punish opponents after they attack, and heavy (especially charged heavy) attacks can break your opponents stance to open them up to critical hits. If you're struggling with a fight, changing your strategy can be a viable option, and if that fails then opening up the crafting menu can also give you the edge you need. If all else fails, you can rely on your fellow Tarnished and summon a friend (or stranger) to help you out in multiplayer.

This game is the best version released of FromSoft's formula that they've been refining for years. As someone who's played every game in the Souls series, including Bloodborne and Sekiro, this one is my favorite. And here's to hoping the DLC improves on this already great game even more!

Remember a time when you're dad would come home after a long day at work?
He would walk in all tired, have a shower maybe sit infront of the TV and watch a WWE, and both of you would have a blast watching Rey Mysterio 619 the Big Show. All was right in the world.
But sometimes father, he'd have a few beers, and maybe he'd get a little mad at mum for cooking Meatloaf (Again) and you'd sit all quiet while he yells at her, and she hits him and then he looks at you, with that same look he just had for your mother. He grabs you by the arm and punches you in your 8 year old mouth. You sit there stunned, helpless because father always hits you when he and mother yell at each other.
Years this goes on until one day you've had enough. You move out of home and go out into the world keen to never look back on these dark times again. Not long after, you've started a family of your own, and you've vowed to never be like your father, you'd always treat your child better then he ever did.
Until one day, a messages comes by, "Hi son. I was hoping we could catch up? Maybe go see a movie sometime?" Your eyes tear up, he's trying to get into your life again, to do better. "Yeah dad, I'd love that".
You arrive at the cinema together, you've hugged made up, times are great again. 

That's this game.

Everything is fine, except for the lazy attitude of the developers towards PvP, fixing exploits, lags due to easy anti-heat, which does not help, missing clicks (i.e. situations from the category: ‚ÄúBut I clicked!‚Äù is a given here.), and so lags of keystrokes, when actions do not occur by pressing or releasing keys, but with a delay.
1/3 of the invasions end before they begin, because the player entered the bossroom while you were loading to him or because you are spawned not closer to the player, but on a ‚Äúconvenient slope nearby‚Äù, from where you can clearly see through binoculars (and more often, even not visible) as your goal runs beautifully in the rays of the setting sun, unattainable for you.
the other third ends when you are connected to an open field, where 3 ‚Äúgood soldiers‚Äù shoot you with 3-6 guns.
In total, the last third remains, of this third only a third is not overshadowed by the reasons described in the first sentence.
There is something in this game, but the mediocre attitude towards the PvP interaction part (which is the MAIN one in the Souls series) negates many of the successes. As a final example, you will come to the realization that there is no meaningful in-game reward for a character for PVP (or even PvE).

hard af
fenzy flame O-O
The Game is mediocre at best. While the story and the content are marvelous, the design, music and scenery is some to really behold. IT all falls apart in the gameplay mechanic. 
Early game you have to really grind to get somewhere and progress and rewarding is measured with a strict hand. You better stick 1 specific weapon and sink all the upgrades in it or the bosses will become even more grinding than they are at some point. 
Midgame the pace picks up and until you get to the endgame content, you can fare pretty good and the rewards upscale a lot. This is the part where most fun is to be had.
Endgame content is typical, every enemy is overscaled, overpoised, overboosted in every way. In some cases some simple regular enemies have more hitpoints than some midgame bosses. Technically your HP is irrelevant as you are 1-3 hits, depending on your vitality. In some cases, some simpel field mobs are pvp worthy, the invader NPC-s have nothing compared to them. Even bosses can be hardly compared to some. Also, mediocre weapons are hidden in endgame which would be useful in earlier stages, grabbing them simply adds nothing to the gameplay.
In many cases the best tactic to use: dash from 1 SG to another, you have your progress saved. Farming is done via boss assisting, item acquisition can be postponed. You won't use most of them anyway in bossfights. 
Also when a game has pixelperfect platforming integrated instantly looses 3 points in my eyes.
All in all not a bad game but the endgame technically kills the part to which try to aim.

This game offers so much in terms of world, items, bosses, side-content, interconnected story-lines, etc, that even players seasoned to this type of game can still get bogged down.
That being said, I had to come back to prepare for the DLC in June.

ELDEN RING's take on an open-world was very well-executed, dense with points of interest, and varied in terms of environment and enemy type. Even though not perfect when compared to other FROMSOFT games, mainly in its tendency to reuse bosses somewhat heavy-handedly, the sense of exploration and achievement you can get from this title is amazing

I don't play souls games usually. But I got this game as gift from my friend to try it out and I totally like and am addicted to it.
I would smash Radahn
Elden Ring was my first souls game and I have to say I was not disappointed at all. The style of gameplay was new to me because I've known nothing besides first person shooter games; nonetheless I was able to adjust fast. If you're looking for something new, fun, rewarding, and intense I suggest this game highly. Not only is the game amazing in terms of graphics, but it prevails in other areas where developers seem to be struggling right now as of 2024. For instance: Story/lore, gameplay mechanics, level design, voice acting, in-game rewards, no micro transactions, helpful/funny/dedicated community, graphics again, creativity, etc. I can go on and on about how great Elden Ring is but this is actually that one game where you must play it for yourself to find out. If you get stuck there's plenty of guides and videos online to help you. This is one investment you will not regret. Have fun Tarnished!

10/10 ranis feet

Can't defeat the bosses? Git gud
I get it, another Elden Ring review that is negative that is unfounded but just giving my feedback.
 
The mandatory, I have played Demon Souls, all of the Dark Souls games, Sekiro  Armored Core 6 (I know its not Souls but its awesome!).

I like the tighter experience of previous titles, smaller, interconnected, filled with purpose. 
I felt Elden Ring was just a big world with dumb mobs placed every where, dungeons that felt so samey, reskinned bosses, and just crap tons of stuff to get into. For me it was a grind to just get through it. 

I guess I have gotten older and want to play whats fun not whats trendy, it just wasnt for me. I am not a combat efficientato by any means and the options, spells, ashes of war, summons were all good systems. At its core though, for ME, its just tiresome. Why or how can poison go through a wall? Why can a bad guy plunge his axe through rock and hit you on the other side? Why do bosses have unlimited stamina? Elden Ring had some of the most aggressive boss battles I have ever played through in a From Software game. Hands down. The last section of the game is littered with them back to back to back, its insane. Granted the open world gives opportunities to gain some flasks back but thats so you dont have to go back to a spot to heal again, it didnt make it more accepting in terms of difficulty. The dungeons generally are filled with the same wolves, pots, and gremlins, with a few traps and a boss or two at the end of it. Once you get the goodies in the dungeon or cave you usually find yourself dead at the bosses door or near death with no flasks forcing you to death with the boss so that you can just run all the way to the door again if there was no stake to bring you back to near the door. Fighting on the horse was fun although, the farther you get into the game, the more you realize the horse is just another piece of armor that most enemies are going to be able to kill. Its fast but they are faster. 

I think for people who love this genre and the Souls franchise this is a dream come true. Its a big expansive world with enough variety for people who want to see it, and lots of things to explore. More mini bosses, more dungeons, more exploration, more armor/weapons, summons, just more more more. But its also just more frustration, cheap boss battles and the ever present git gud mantra of some really just becomes icing on the cake, yeah, I dont need to do this anymore.
I love how creative you can get with all the different kinds of builds, makes for tons of replayability. Don't be afraid to run passed enemies or come back to fight a boss later. You'll likely need a guide for NPC storylines though, no shame in that. Music is peak.
Well, what can I say - This game is Masterpiece, 10 out of 10.
It took 300 hours for me to beat the game, with all side quests and exploring every corner of the map.
And guess what - I was never bored playing Elden Ring!
Waiting for DLC with great impatience

I'm really bad at souls-like games but still enjoy them. 
Can't dump 1000 hours into any of these games to "git gud", so I thought I would give Elden Ring a try. 
I've read that it's a bit more forgiving than Dark Souls or Bloodborne, still challenging but not in a "git gud"-kinda way.

These articles and comments were right.
While I still struggled at a few points, it never felt unfair and I was never "stuck" cause of Elden Ring's open world. Whenever a boss turned me into tomato paste 30 times in a row, I turned around and progressed on a different route. Fighting a different boss, defeating him, getting stronger and returning to the other boss again.

I really enjoyed the game and I am looking forward to the DLC.
Without the coop mod, I likely would have never tried this game. It ended up being literally the best gaming experience of my life. I will never forget this unbelievable adventure.

THIS IS NOT A GAME FOR PC
It's like they decided to punish the player if he plays with a mouse and keyboard instead of a controller
Or they just didn't care about the PC gamers
I'm not sure which is worse
disappointing
Probably the most fun I ever had in a video game. Exploration feels really fun and rewarding. Not just for the loot but the sight you get is a reward in itself. Combat is typical souls combat but with new skills and spells. The danger you feel while exploring the world really makes you feel like you are on a adventure which a game very rarely manages to get right in my opinion.

The things I dislike are rather minor like the copy pasted catacombs with copy/pasted enemies and interior. You may also get to other low level zones later which means you'll completely obliterate a boss, that could be fun to learn. The biggest problem I have with this game is the reuse of enemies and bosses. There are MANY unique enemies and bosses but some bosses appear like 6 times which takes some of the excitement away. Especially when a big story boss reappears as a random optional boss with a misspelled name.
waiting for the dlc

Wow amazing game a little late to the party becasue I just got a pc this holiday but this game is great, im only like 22 hours in and like 2 main bosses down and im still loving every second of this game! Im sure you all heard it by now but this game is a must buy 10/10 for me.
This game is incredible. Have played it from start to finish at least a dozen times now, including (1) play-through that is at NG+6. It's difficult, and certainly has a learning curve, being my first souls-type game, but it was probably the most rewarding game to complete I've ever played. Gladly will be paying for the DLC to extend this gameplay.

One warning, is that once you learn the combat system of this game, it will make all others feel stale, boring, or easy in comparison. That is the only down-side I had found, and I'm not entirely sure it's a bad thing to have high standards for gaming studios moving forward.

One of the best games I have played. I have over 100 hours on console and now enjoying the PC version
The accumulation of all From Software's best ideas and fantastic combat put into a huge open world with over 80 bosses. There's so many random encounters and dungeons to explore and endless weapons to try it feels like an adventure that never ends, every new location discovered better than the last. Not to mention the jaw dropping visuals with a level of detail that is a true feat for a game of this size.

masterpiece
Very rarely do I wish that a game never ended, but this one felt like a magnificent dream that looked to have no end in sight. When it finally did it was a bitter sweet moment. Every area is so detailed, so beautiful, so rich in character and atmosphere that its almost unreal. The combat is fluid, weapons/spells are all interesting and feel fresh whenever you use something new, build diversity is there. The enemies offer challenge level from easy to hard to b.s but that's all part of this mountain that you must climb, b.s and all. Some of the best designed bosses in all souls games including sekiro. Jumping is a simple yet refreshing game mechanic that makes the game play feel more free. The MUSIC needs to praise because it goes without saying. 10/10

Elden Ring made me stop playing halfway because towards the late game it was getting a little too brutal, BUT WE DONT BACK DOWN AND WE NEVER GIVE UP AND WE BEAT IT 2 MORE TIMES BECAUSE THIS IS GOTY. I always say the souls games get better the more you replay them. So if you read this, get a new character and your dragon smithing stones ready the the shadow of the erdtree.
I be Mohging all the way to the erdtree, first play through was a grim reaper black flame scythe build (made for a strength play-style but with a focus on dexterity). The frenzied flame incantations are the best edition to the souls magic system and was the core of my NG+ play through. Lazers shooting out your eyes and morgotts cursed sword were stat hungry tools but lvl 155 allowed for a hybrid build that leaves scorched earth in a wake. The 3rd play through I finally got around to using my favorite archetype of weapon, the colossal swords. Worked in most of them to deal with different areas and bosses but the real hero was actually working the grafted dragon first to the off hand to roll catch and get safe hits on bosses. The mimic tear spirit ashes is for noobs. So I used the Jellyfish and the stormhawk.  Intelligence and the way of fists are gonna be the next play through.
