I haven't finish my playthrough yet, but this is easily one of the best games I have ever played hands down. Very highly recommend for anyone who likes large exploratory worlds and fighting unique and tough enemies.
- Absolutely god-tier artwork/art style/art direction and music
- Jaw-dropping landscapes and visuals inspire awe at every turn
- The combat is challenging and unforgiving, yet incredibly rewarding with plenty of ways to become overpowered and switch to 'easy mode'
- Extremely deep and fascinating lore (for those willing to explore it)
- A staggering amount of content - it just almost never stops giving
- Pay once and enjoy a full-fledged game and much more
- Very good replay value
- Absolutely worth much more than you pay for it
- 101/10 recommended

its good

[b]This game is a masterpiece.[/b] I know this review is incredibly late and we all know it won GotY, but seriously, I love this game with all my heart. The lore, gameplay, and design all come together to make a game that I seriously have to recommend. I truly could spend hours talking about this game but I'll try to keep it within reason (Though it'll still be a bit).

[b]Is this game for everyone?[/b] No. Combat is very punishing and balance can be a bit off for some boss fights. Sometimes fights leave you feeling like you were fighting the game itself rather than a boss, which can be very discouraging.

But if you think you can get past that, this game is a wonderful project that can make you feel like a god when you finally overcome the obstacles in your way. The story feels impactful the more you begin to piece it together and you should never find yourself feeling as if the world is empty, exploration is almost always rewarded, and even if not by items or story, it's by the messages left by other players. And as mentioned before, combat is so incredibly satisfying when overcome. All weapons feel fun and unique to handle and the variety of builds you can play with is amazing, and when you gain access to respecing, the opportunities for changing your strategies with bosses is second to none.

I truly could keep talking about this game, its impact on me as a person and truly just how fun it is to pick up and play. But I'll leave that for another platform. But take it from me, as I've spent 190 hours finding as many facets of this game as possible, please at least give it a go. It's so wonderful and I think anyone can find the enjoyment in it.

Also the DLC is right around the corner so no better time to play this game and prepare to take on the challenges in the Shadow of the Erdtree!

Magnum Opus
mommylenia.
Good game, go buy
Elden Ring has the worst combat system out of all of Myazaki's games. Most of the bosses are impossible to kill if you are by yourself or are not over-leveled for that encounter. The golden knights are impossible to fight on your own, especially the draconic variants, the main bosses are almost all horrible and frustrating to fight against unless you are some kind of demi-god or have memorized all the moves they do. The bosses have inhuman reactions, constantly spam 15 move combos, and spam a variety of distance attacks if you stay away from them. If you try to fight a draconic golden knight by yourself, you will be there for weeks if you want to do it all on your own with no summons and also without grinding and finding moonveil katanas. It would have been great if the combat was like Sekiro but better and the bosses were not so insane. It doesn't feel like a fight, it feels like you when you were a kid and you were defending yourself against daddy with the belt. Having to dodge 99% of the attacks and wait for a small opening to hit once and run away is not fun or intense, I learned nothing. Its just one big slog, one big mess where you push through everything in the most tiring and nerve-wracking way possible, in the end you have to resort to summoning bots in the fight. But you quickly find out the bots suck, so you go even further, just summoning other players to fight for you as you stay away mostly and hope that you are not the only one left in the end. And if you are, then you have very little chance because the end phases of the bosses will destroy you without you even getting near them, whether it is in the form of a fireball ·õãhitspam, or lighting strikes which you cant even dodge because they track your character's rolls. If you didn't have Estus to chuck every five seconds, you would be ·ö†ucked, in that case might as well summon a whole army of players, just make the game an open MMO. 
    By the way, most fights in this game are useless because the enemies just respawn after you kill them, whats the point of fighting them if not for drops or runes or whatever. You never have the satisfaction of clearing out an area of enemies, you just have to run past them over and over. The open world is empty, vast majority of items you pick up will be some sort of materials or some useless junk, you kill a massive knight in armor and you pick up a ·ö†ucking crusty mushroom off his body... You go off exploring an area you think contains something cool, only to find its empty or has a corpse/chest which has a "sliver of meat" on it. At the early game you are basically depressed because you can't find sensible equipment to use, you are forced to open the wiki online to manually look up where the hell the damn armor is located. Same thing with the quests, you have no idea which character goes where and what the quests are, you can even miss quests just by playing the game, so you have to look at the wiki. Not only is the armor hard to find, most of it is hideous, the designes are just fantasy garbage, more than half of it doesn't even make sense nor does it look good. Only a handful of the plate armors look somewhat historically inspired, the banished knight's armor looks the coolest but still has issues like the horn on the shoulder and the fuzzy hair on the back.

I give this a 5/10

EDIT: After finishing the game proper, I want to revise the final score to a 2/10 for the absolutely disgusting final bosses of this game, Fire Giant, Horah Loux, Radagon, Elden Beast, Malekith, Godskin duo. Those bosses are THE worst bosses I have ever had the displeasure of facing, alone they are unbeatable, you need to summon someone else to fight for you for all of them.

So nice, I bought it twice! If you like Souls-like games, you'll like Elden Ring. There are additional features like spirit ashes that can make this game significantly easier than previous fromsoft titles, but they're optional so it allows for a good amount of difficulty scaling without having an actual option to change it.

If it's your first souls game, it will humble you. This game is tough but it's also very rewarding.
Online pvp on pc is a cesspit with chainsawers, cheaters and 350 ping lightrollers from the other side of the world who have never heard of an ethernet cable. Playstation is a lot better in this regard and has allowed me to actually enjoy the multiplayer. If you dont give a shit about the mp, the game is pretty good on pc, arguably a must play. (((I MUST NOTE BEFORE HAND: I am not dogging on the community or the game, it is a great game but it just too many flaws for a "normal games" Player and a huge waste of money. So don't take my post with hatred as i don't hate the game, just simply don't like it. )))

I was bored with every game I had. and I wanted to try something completely new. So I asked around probably 20~ people about a game that would last me hours, maybe even days to enjoy and about 60%~ recommended Elden ring. I told them "I've never played any Souls game in my life" and they all said "It doesn't matter since this is nothing like a Souls game" so I took their word for it as they also told me "it fun" "challenging" and "has a lot to offer", and ill state that they weren't wrong. but it isn't "Fun", it's more than "Challenging" and there is no damn story. I have given it 5 hours of playtime just to see if I can give it a chance and after 5 hours, I was just so damn bored. It's a time waste. and I would love for a refund back so I can use my money for a fun game...

CONS:
- Boring
- Tedious
- Time Wasting
- More than "Challenging" (if anything, EXTREMELY DIFFICULT)
- Can't stay alive for more than 10 Minutes
- Weak Weapons
- Too many LVL Ups needed to use a different weapon
- It's just Overall Boring and a time waste due to no Plot or Path to follow

PROS:
- Extremely Difficult
- Time Waster for those who have enough time to waste
- uhhhhhh.... Idk what else

Please, PLEASE! Dont rec this game to anyone who never played a Souls Game (Or anything familiar since this isn't a souls game) Since it is just too much and too little...

Elden Ring: A Masterpiece of Modern Art in Video Games

As a long-time fan of video games, I've experienced many adventures, but few have captivated me as deeply as Elden Ring. From the moment I started playing, I was drawn into the epic world that FromSoftware has crafted with this game.

The music of Elden Ring is nothing short of breathtaking. Every note, every chord contributes to amplifying the emotional depth of the game world. The compositions seamlessly adapt to the mood of the scenery, enhancing the gaming experience in a way that few games achieve.

The voice actors also do an outstanding job, breathing life into the characters and infusing their stories with authenticity and depth. Each voice adds to the atmosphere of the game, making it an immersive experience.

The atmosphere of Elden Ring is simply unparalleled. The dark yet captivating world is full of secrets and dangers. You can practically feel the story lurking in the abandoned ruins and majestic landscapes.

The character design is another highlight of the game. Every NPC, every enemy, and every boss is meticulously crafted with attention to detail. Their designs are not only visually impressive but also contribute to the storytelling of the world.

The various regions of Elden Ring are so diverse and well-designed that you never get bored exploring them. From gloomy swamps to majestic mountains, the game offers a wealth of landscapes to discover.

And of course, the story cannot go unmentioned. Elden Ring tells a profound and captivating tale full of intrigue, betrayal, and heroic deeds. Every detail of the world contributes to unfolding the story, and it's a true pleasure to uncover each mystery.

Overall, Elden Ring is undoubtedly a masterpiece of the modern art form of video games. From the music to the voice acting to the character design and the regions, everything is perfectly balanced, creating a gaming experience that will not be forgotten anytime soon. This game is an absolute must-play for any video game enthusiast.
I'm going to be honest I have enjoyed fromsoft's games since the release of dark souls, I remember being a young kid hyped up and ready for a grueling sadomasochistic enjoyment of a never onslaught of death.

With Elden Ring I've been disappointed.. the Bossfights and gameplay of half the game are copy pasted repeats of the content you first encounter in the game. With the speed and pace of boss battles being a frenzy of 5-7 hit combos, frequent unnatural delays meant to trip up a player, combine this with the half second input lag that frequently occurs on rolls, it's a recipe for disaster.

This game took away from the experience of intuition that most souls games forced you to adapt yourself to, and instead require rote memorization of a boss' 20-30 possible moves and attacks to carefully dodge often requiring you to die a multitude times more than predecessors of the genre.

Fights and combat are either overly difficult and needlessly long due to the abundance of flying and hyper-mobile enemies the size of 4 school busses, often needing to wait a full minute before you can get a single hit in. Or in the case of the elden beast, the final boss of the game running 10 football fields away requiring you to make a beeline 10-20 good times becoming an exhausting boring marathon of wacking a pinata with a stick on a treadmill. The late-game was a slew of lazy boss design and attack motions such as in the case of godfrey spamming a ground pound with the same animation 100 times in a row.

The dungeons of the game are a boring slog, copy pasted over and over again with the same layout and bricks that put Skyrim to shame, filled with the same enemies you've fought the past half dozen times.

While this is a good game, it's not the 10/10 GOTY everyone calls it, I'd dare anyone to venture beyond using mimic tear, spells, and rivers of blood to attempt a fight with a shortsword or club. Melee feels like crippling your knees with a bat before a 5k, whereas ranged builds are given an immense advantage that had not existed in prior iterations of the souls series. 

In essence I feel Fromsoft balanced their game around a multiplayer and coop experience which is even harder to find due to the endless amounts of cheats and mods, throughout the last 70 hours of playing I was never able to invade, find an invader, or even play a single match in the coliseum. Which makes me suspicious regarding the supposedly high player counts boasted of on steam.

The art style is excellent, the lore and various questlines are intriguing, but the gameplay of the game bounces back and forth from being either far too easy, or punishing the player for using anything slower than a katana in melee combat, and at times making it NIGH impossible to score hits on certain enemies such as the fallingstar beast.

I've never once wanted to speedrun a Dark Souls game, and with Elden Ring it couldn't be finished fast enough.
git gud

(10/10)

very good game but needs bigger map in multiplayer

Shit ass Game
‚Ä¢ Dark Souls 3 combat pretty much. Enemies and bosses seem to be faster, while on your end everything feels slow and clunky. I am a little tired of this cadence, I want more Sekiro or Bloodborne combat. Still really good though.

‚Ä¢ The addition of a dedicated jump button is welcome. I'd be impressed if they added a climbing mechanic like the one in Sekiro.

‚Ä¢ Torrent is useless outside of the speed boost when exploring. If it dies from fall damage, you die as well. The double jump feature is obsolete outside of sequence breaking platforming as it doesn't negate fall damage, found that out the hard way.

‚Ä¢ Enemies are inconsequential for the most part, some exceptions that stand out REALLY stand out though, for better or worse. Revenants, Runebears, Lobsters, Birds and Hand Creepers all feel very fresh and unique in design but can feel kind of awful to fight. I still enjoy their designs very much however, they feel very fresh.

‚Ä¢ The majority of the main bosses are some of the best that From games have to offer. The gimmick bosses are From's best gimmick bosses to date as well. A personal disappointment was Godfrey, all that hype and marketing only for him to have a glorified Chained Ogre for a 2nd phase... Zangief looking ass.

‚Ä¢ As for minibosses, the sword and shield Crucible Knights, Erdtree Sentinels and the Bell Bearing Hunters are AMAZING minibosses, classic Fromsoft knight badassery. The Godskin bosses are pretty memorable as well. Every other miniboss felt either inconsequential or very unenjoyable to fight, like the Deathrite Birds and the Magma Wyrms.

‚Ä¢ In terms of content, the game is extremely front packed. When you finish Limgrave and one underground area, you've seen like 50% of the game, add Liurnia and Caelid, and you've pretty much seen about 95% of the content the game has to offer in terms of enemies, minibosses and items. That leaves you with 4 more main areas, 4 legacy dungeons and several underground areas and so many dungeons that are pretty much copy pasted content. I expected it following my experience with the CNT (Closed Network Test), but I can't pretend it didn't disappoint me when it turned out to be the case.

‚Ä¢ They marketed ER NPCs as having rich stories and their own agendas. They are literally the same 10 or so obtuse NPCs you can find in previous From games that wait for you in fuck knows where to chat so their quests can progress. Melina, the icon of "deep character" (during marketing), is absent for 99% of the game. She has like 7 completely optional and random interactions scattered throughout the world, throughout this 100-200h experience, that have literally nothing to do with her. Other levelup ladies and the Sculptor in Sekiro had WAY more character development. The game is consistent to older From games when it comes to NPCs; the issue here is, the scope of the game is like x10 of any of their previous games, so there's a clear mismatch. You get neither quantity nor enough quality to keep up with Elden Ring's huge scale.

‚Ä¢ The world is gorgeous and the level design is impeccable, always. The views are picturesque, the art direction is unreal.

‚Ä¢ Stability, Bugs, Multiplayer: the game ran terribly at launch and still has stutters in several areas after several patches, mostly due to EasyAntiCheat. Optimization was bad and has even gotten worse after the RTX update, I don't know what they messed up but the poor performance persists even if you turn it off for some reason... For good co-op/ multiplayer, use the Seamless Co-op mod - it does away with the archaic limitations and annoyances that From like to cripple their games with like disconnects, no summons unless the area boss is alive, invasions and whatnot.

‚Ä¢ As for the soundtrack, the main bosses have great themes. Some of the minibosses as well, especially Erdtree Sentinels. Unfortunately, despite Bandai Namco's and Sony's (false) advertisting, ER clearly doesn't use live orchestra. But lacking sound fidelity aside (cause they aren't live recordings), still a really strong soundtrack.

Conclusion: The game started as a 10/10 for me and then as I played more of it, the weak parts stood out more and more and it tumbled down to a solid 8.5 or maybe 9/10 if I really stretch it. As an overall package, it's definitely their most ambitious game to date. Bloodborne, Sekiro and Dark Souls 3 however are kind of more consistent in quality, although significantly shorter experiences. Still, what ER does well, it does better than any of the previous games (mainly, the world and level design). Hopefully the DLC will bump the game up a couple digits for me, I can't wait for Messmer to impale me. Also I really, genuinely hope they move on from the slow Souls combat for their next game. Give us more Bloodborne or Sekiro combat speed and difficulty please, the Souls combat feels so overdone at this point...

Buy the game at full price if you can afford it, it is worth every penny and Fromsoft really do deserve the support.
awesome
After playing ER I do not believe the souls formula works in an open world environment. Everything about this game made me think "I liked how this was done better in Dark Souls or Sekiro". 
The world in ER is not coherent, it's just a map for a game to happen in, things are just scattered around to fill the world with content without much meaning behind it. 

In Dark Souls everything felt like it had a place, a story and a meaning for being there. The fact, that a lot of assets are re-used in ER from DS3 doesn't help either. 

In short, everything about this game pales in comparison to older titles in the series - world building, story, characters, enemies, bosses and level designs, music etc.  Bigger is not always better. A more linear, hand crafted experience where everything is meticulously designed therefore has a bigger impact in the game is a much better approach for souls like games imo.
best game ever

Elden Ring is FromSoftWare's attempt to keep the Soulsborne Formula the same but with minor additions that impact the game in amazing ways i.e jumping as an example. Now I enjoy this game and it's a well made game (Though not that well optimized I will admit) It's FromSoftWare's biggest game to date and the mass amount of people getting into FromSoftWare games just because of this game speaks volumes. Now I have been playing FromSoftWare games for a long time and as much as I like this game and all the praise it's getting is warranted I don't think Open World DS type games are personally my cup of tea. It's great they tried something different but for me it misses the mark by a hair, do I still recommend the game? Yes especially if you're new to FromSoftWare as a company as Elden Ring is the easiest of the FromSoftWare games so if you can beat this and get used to how it's played you will exceed and know how Miyazaki (The creator of this game and many others) brain works and outsmart his creativity but there is two games from FromSoftWare that you will fail no matter how much experience you will rack up from this game those being Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice and Armored Core these two play drastically different than most of their line up of games so don't play with a DS mindset is what I'm trying to get at.

Art
This is a review from a non-soulslike player.

At first when this game was released i was on the negative side where i was like another dark souls, an annoying hard game that i don't want to try, amazed that it even won Game Of The Year. Talked with some of my friends how the game is all about a single community of soulslike had negative view points to be honest.

3 Months back one of my close friend(as he also not a soulslike player it was his first soulslike game and he's playing in coop) recommended me to play the elden ring, i was like no somehow he convinced me by showing some of lore of Malenia and Miquella and i loved the story so i thought of lets give it a try. Bought the game with dlc as my friend said get the dlc too so here we go.

so in my first play through i picked Vagabond class and i was playing with shield trying to parry and dying a lot my friend suggested leave the shield and just learn to dodge turn out this was much better for my playstyle. 1 week of playing the game understanding about stats/items/weapons/levelling/world/quest etc, i got hooked to the game. Killed the first boss after soo many tries. complained to one my friend who already finished elden ring he said "yes, the first boss is unfair for new players as the 2nd boss is much easier". Beat the second boss then after beating Rennala i changed my build and started using Sword of Night and Flame. Got to the best boss fight i ever had Radahn. soo many tries but in the end i won and from here i got deep into the lore Started watching VaatiVidya on YT for lore GOT HOOKED.

For a month had to leave home for work means no gaming for a month and i never felt like that i want to go back play the game and complete it. But somehow this game is truly different. Got back home started playing again changed my build again to Greatsword with all strength enjoyed a lot. At fire gaint got stuck so changed my build again to moonveil with Nagakiba. This new build was more fun for me as its more agile. Now i'm at final boss waiting for dlc to drop so i can once again enjoy this game. Achieved almost every achievement on steam only game ending achievement remains that will be done after dlc.

This game is new player friendly only if you give this a game time to understand its mechanics or else you'll refund it. The lore of this game is truly a masterpiece. Game design is on another level that cannot be achieved its just a miracle. On very few Bosses i felt like wtf is this boss but overall i loved playing against so many bosses. Maybe a those few bosses deserve a rework or to be looked at like (elden beast he is more annoying then Malenia). Music always hits the right spot at right time. Graphics is just wow as dunky says "Its like walking in a well made picture". This game is just a piece of art that you should give it a try. This game defines what a truly open world game means
I should've played this game when it was released.

This Is The Game Of The Century.
Best game I will ever play

Caveman TL;DR at bottom

This game makes me go sad. I am alone in the dark by saying how I don't enjoy it, because everybody and their second cousin (twice removed) has absolutely devoted their heart and soul into promoting just how good Elden Ring's supposed to be. I am not in the minority, no, I am practically alone when I dislike this game, but I think I have some good points that should be made.

Firstly, this game feels like it was made for console. I do not like console. I do not enjoy a controller. I do not want to sacrifice my pretty boy baby keyboard and mouse so I can actually get a feel for this game, because it is a game that actively supports keyboard and mouse as a platform. Think of it like this: you go to the store, and buy a Nintendo game which is promoted to be compatible on your playstation. Now, you don't like Nintendo. Maybe it's cause you're still tilted over the rage super smash bros has brought you over the years, but when you hear that one of their games, supposedly the best, is compatible on a different platform, you take the chance and get it. Then, when you download the game on your playstation, it's not very fun as opposed to when you once tried it on a Nintendo console, which it was explicitly designed for, and you don't have. Other people have agreed with this first point: it's dumb to allow keyboard and mouse if it isn't well polished enough to be enjoyable ON keyboard and mouse. I'm with the southside P.C gang for life, and I ain't gonna pay for a $60 controller, re-learn how to use it, and then only use it for one game. It's just like DLC you have to pay for in order to make the base game fun.

Which leads me to my second, and more controversial take: Elden Ring is not very fun on keyboard. I don't know exactly what it is, but for one, not being able to dodge bosses in an omnidirectional way like you can on console is a genuine cap to your skills based on how those bosses attack you, which limits the amount of freedom the player has. Hitting "Q" to immediately lock onto enemies takes about 90% of the fun of out of using a mouse, because moving your mouse mid-combat is as effective as blowing out a forest fire by farting. Of course you can move it around to look at the surroundings, but if you aren't using the auto-locking feature on enemies mid-battle you better hope to god that your character can precisely aim their flailing sword using good ol' 8-directional WASD. 

"But... what about teh controller PLUS P.C??" I hear some cry, dorito and cheeto dust in the midst of having a war on your unwashed T-shirt from high school. Fair point, but the only reason I bought Elden Ring was because of keyboard compatibility. If it weren't, it wouldn't even be in my Steam Library, because that's where it'll have to stay now that I've breached the 2 hour playtime cap for steam refunds. I really don't want to dislike this game. It looks so, so good, and the strange, yet creative landscape along with the difficult gameplay (which I don't really mind) makes it an objectively good experience, so it's a shame that it's an experience that I can't take a part in because of how Console-centered this game seems to be. And, hell, why is it MY fault that I bought it? If you make a game that's promoted as P.C compatible, but is very heavily reliant on controller as it seems to be, why wouldn't you at least say, "Hey, douche. You need a controller."?


Caveman TL;DR: Game good no keyboard. Game bad- me want keyboard.
RAGING WITH HAPPINESS 

WILL INCREASE YOUR TESTOSTERONE

may also become a simp

I'm going to go against the grain on this one and not recommend it.  I know it's widely hailed and all that jazz, but I just can't get behind this game.  Even though I don't care for "Souls-like" games where you constantly die, I still decided to give it a try based on its glowing reputation.  Thinking that it might be "the one" to turn me into a souls-like believer.  Unfortunately that didn't happen.  It seemed cool from all the videos I watched, but not very fun once I started playing it.  I couldn't get into the story and lore of it either.  Just not my cup of tea I suppose.

it is fun but hard
This is my first ever soul-like game and initially I was worried that I will not like it. Therefore, I decided to wait even tho the game is/was GOTY. I bought Elden Ring few months ago after finishing Cyberpunk and needed something to play while waiting for Dragon Dogma 2 to come out ( what a shit show DD2 turned out to be lol). I absolutely LOVE this game. I am about 160 hours in, and still exploring Lyndell capital which means I have tons more to do.

it's been a wild journey for me, I am not gonna lie. I've had moments were I was like "screw this, I am done!!!" hahaha. It felt like torture at times, but something about this game kept pulling me in. I felt drawn into the game despite the immense difficulty, which is , I guess part of what a soul-like game is. 

The lore and story is amazing, and how can it not be? it was written by G.R.R Martin after all. The voice acting is crazy good and the graphics is breath taking. The world building is one of the best I've seen. No dungeon or cave feels the same, monsters and creatures are diverse and there is so much to explore, it is overwhelming.
The game does not hold your hand by any mean. You got no quest log, nothing that tells you where to go. You get vague clues from NPCs and that's it. You are on your own. From someone who comes from Ubisoft games (yea yea I know, don't judge me), Elden Ring feels like climbing the Everest for the first time. 

Pros

- Amazing Story
- Amazing Graphics
- Amazing World
- Amazing Combat system
- Bug free and very stable
- huge variety of armors and weapons 

Cons

- locked to 60 FPS ( no idea why they did that but there must be a reason )
- no support for ultra wide screen ( initially I thought it would bother me, but you get used to it)
- very hard to figure out quests without looking up hints online. I get the whole idea of exploration and stuff but some quests give close to zero clues. 

I can see why this game won GOTY award. It is really one of the best games I've ever played and I haven't even finished it. Elden Ring set the bar so high for action RPG games, I don't think it will be easy to dethrone it.

Good game
It's Dark Souls, but bigger. Yes, that's it. And it should be more than enough of a reason for anyone to play it.

FromSoftware has proven more than enough times that they're extremely capable of developing insanely memorable settings and encounters at a much smaller scale, and Elden Ring is their attempt at doing so for something that is, simply put, ridiculously big. With a much less linear progression and George R. R. Martin's influence, this game gives you a unique sense of wonder that simply can't be matched by any other.

You may ask: "Why is another open-world game worth my time when there are so many others like it out there?". The answer is that this is no normal open-world game, and I believe marketing it as such did it a fair amount of disservice. Elden Ring is filled to the brim with content, places to explore, creatures and enemies to find, items to discover, story to uncover (and fail to understand). Yes, it is less restrictive in progression than FromSoftware's previous games and the area the map covers is indeed massive, but it doesn't feel as much as an open-world game as it does simply a bigger Dark Souls that allows you to leave a boss fight or area you're struggling with at the moment to go do something else and come back later, just to find some other path on the way that takes you to a hidden cave you weren't aware of and ending up exploring a completely different place for hours on end until you remember what your original goal was. Is "open-world" the right term to describe this type of experience? Perhaps, but I feel like it's distinct enough in this case to warrant a clarification.

Regardless of that, this game is truly one-of-a-kind. Familiar enough for Dark Souls fans and welcoming enough to those who are playing it as their first FromSoftware game. It is harder to find reasons to not recommend it that aren't either ridiculous, nitpicky or simply a warning about how overwhelming in size and content it can be.
Perfection
I've little new to contribute, but want to say that Elden Ring isn't a twitch game. For me the biggest obstacle to progress has been my fear of heights. As a 75-year-old I'm glad to say that the game supports exploring at your own pace and taking your time to figure things out. Slower reflexes and dimmer vision shouldn't cause players to assume it's "not for them." I, at least, have been pleasantly surprised..
Y E S !
Let chaos take the world!
This game is one of those once in a lifetime things that when over, leave you in a state of constant longing. This was my first "soulslike" game and boy was I not disappointed. I'm not a "Gamer" and facing the challenging combat of Elden Ring is THE MOST FUN I have had with a game since RDR2.

The lore is deep but subtle and never force fed everytime you interact with the world. That's the main selling point of this game. THE WORLD. The world is beautiful yet unforgiving. It makes you work for everything and gives a purpose to every second you are a part of it.

I loved every second I played. And even though I loved how such games work, I don't think I'll ever try the other Dark Souls game, because frankly I don't think it will get better than this. That's the only downside to playing Elden Ring. VERY FEW GAMES WILL EVER MEASURE UP.

Thanks to the creators of the game for this experience. I'll be definitely be back for the DLC.

what the hell is a.
It took me about 2 years to finally say: I am going to try this. 

I have NEVER played a Soulslike game before and actually completed it. I tried a few Dark Souls games but they were just too hard at the time. I feel like maybe now I'd do a bit better, but...

This game is perfect in every way. The sheer feeling of discovering something on your own without looking it up gives me euphoria. Killing bosses after 50+ tries gives me euphoria. The sense of accomplishment. I actually lost my voice a bit after I killed M*L***A.  I would compare the feeling to my wedding day.

To be fair, I did play the game as a mage so I sorta feel less cool than the melee crowd, but I am going to play it again for a different ending very soon, using melee, maybe faith as well.

I also did not want to play this game because of motion sickness. Many many games are unplayable, including the Witcher 3, which breaks my heart. I did not feel motion sick AT ALL even once during this game. Not even the small lull headache that sticks around during the gaming. Nothing. Just good feelings.

If you are on the fence, take the plunge. You will not feel like you know what you are doing but just EXPLORE. Enjoy!

very fun

I enjoyed the first opening 20 or so hours of Elden ring and i'm not sure where exactly it happened, but it just stopped being enjoyable. I really liked the bosses in the first few encounters and each of them felt challenging and unique. Then at some point I kept seeing the same enemies and despite equipping better armor, learning patterns, and upgrading vigor I was still consistently being one shot in several boss encounters and sometimes just out on the open world. 

I really don't like to look things up unless i get absolutely stuck on something and i found myself needing to do so more often the more i played. I also can't keep track of the massive amount of people, places, equipment, quests, or where i'm actually at in those quests. I can't understand why some kind of journal wouldn't be included and you are just expected to remember every interaction you have in the game. Like I have a life outside this game and can't always be on it consistently, so coming back to just a 'hey, this is the part you're at in this quest' isn't just a nicety, it's kinda necessary. Not even a waypoint, just some way of looking up people and events.

I had really high expectations from this game and I genuinely don't see it. I feel like my time is just being deliberately wasted with stupidly massive areas, repeated enemies, and having to go through those repetitive enemies for smithing stones, gear, runes, etc over and over and over and over and over again if you don't want to be just one shot after ten minutes against a boss with obscenely inflated health or if you make one or two missteps. 

Still going to try to get through and will change my review if it just inexplicably becomes less of a slog to get through, but i really don't see that happening.

Brilliant game.
As an avid fan of Fromsoftware games but not a big fan of open-word games, Elden Ring has gave a immersive experience I haven't felt in awhile. Since it was a more ambitious souls-borne game( e,g, open-world), I was expecting to love the game. Overall the game is well suited for novice players and veterans alike. 

[h2] Open-Worldiness [/h2]

I felt that that the Open World was much more organic rather then gimmicky compared to most open world games I've played or seen. Furthermore, the game mechanics of soul-borne games does go well the format, since the games always empathized dungeons crawling and exploring. 

Moreover, the world is gorgeous. Every scene of the game can be seen as a spectacle. Everything in the map is rendered in the game. If there is a place you see, you can travel to that area. It is quite enchanting to explore the world blind. My first play though was over 120 hours, not because I was struggling but just doing other stuff such as exploring.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
If you are familiar with the souls games, you'll notice they brought back some mechanics present in dark souls 2, such as duel wielding to the game (Not powerstancing though). The gameplay is very fluent and has the familiar souls mechanics but with a few extra additions. For example, there are guard counters -counterattacking right after a block - and jump attacks. The jumping now has a dedicated button!

Weapons, unless they are unique weapons, don't have a fixed skill anymore. Now you can equip skills from items called Ash-of-wars. Different weapon types have access to different skills. For example, a colossal weapon could have access to a ash of war that can slam the ground and cause it to erupt proximate to you, while a thrusting weapon could have a fury of fast strikes. This makes build much more diverse as you can make a weapons more suited to your play style. 

Spells are pretty amazing and more ambitious then they were in previous souls games. There are different schools of magic which can tell you how that spell operates. Faith based magic has had an entire overhaul and is much more diverse. It makes it feel more thematic lore-wise. Unlike in the souls series, where most miracles(faith magic) was similar and too focused on utility. 

[h1] Criticism [/h1]

[b] While I adore the open-world, Elden ring eventually suffers from similar problems with other open world games [/b]

Despite, the world being cool to explore, eventually you lose reasons to go back to areas you already been though. You'll most likely only return to certain areas if you need a certain item.

Also, the dungeon designs and their bosses become repetitive. It really felt like Fromsoft chose quantity over quality with the side dungeons. I didn't really enjoy Catacombs since they felt way too similar and repeated enemies. Caves were more interesting, as they had more unique designs and ways to navigate the dungeon.

Moreover, even though there is a lot of content some areas feel empty, which is one of the big reasons I find the open world gimmick unbearable. Many developers appear to not know how to design well-made open world and only do it because it was a trend. Elden ring doesn't suffer from this as much, since as I said before the environment feels more organic rather then forced. Nevertheless, you start to notice the barrenness as you progress through the game more.

[b] Side quests could have been better then presented. [/b]

I felt there were that many side quests as I expect. Regardless, some side quests felt hard to follow along unless you were following a guide. To be honest, I think Dark souls handled side quests better; though they were more linear so it's not exactly an apples to apples comparison. This is a minor complaint.

[b] Sorcery lack diversity and Utility. It was not utilized to its fullest [/b]

While, I love the magic in this game. I felt like sorcery was not given as much love as incantations(faith based magic). Sorcery is mostly offensive, unlike incantations which have support, healing, and offensive spells. This is a pattern Fromsoft repeated again from the souls games. Sorcery was mostly offensive with some utility, while miracles were support based mostly with a few offensive spells. It appears they only applied this to sorcery, as incantations are diverse and have access to nearly every damage type in the game. I always enjoyed doing spellblade builds, so I am a bit disappointed. Knowing the lore behind sorcery in Elden ring, it doesn't appear it was utilized to its fullest potential. Hopefully the DLC changes this.

Final point...

[b] Can there be more ways of interaction with the environment  [/b]

Fromsoft have been doing the Souls formula for a long time and it hasn't changed dramatically. They can only do it so many times until they to start making changes. Since Elden ring is an open world game, I would expect their to be more ways to interact with the world. Such as more ways to find lore through exploring or interactions you can do with the many area. This would give more purpose to exploring dungeons and other optional areas. Maybe they can add this in the DLC?

 [h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Elden ring is not a game for everyone. If you are not a fan of souls games, you will not enjoy this game. Otherwise, you should try this out. Also the DLC is coming out soon, so it's a perfect time to give it try if you haven't.
verry good
From someone how finished Dark Souls 1,2 and 3, and all their DLSs, if you are in a similar situation but somehow didn't played Elden Ring yet, go for it, don't need to think twice about it, its really an enhanced version of DS3 with much better controls and mechanics, in an open world scenario, this game is simply second to none on this genre.

It's definitely one of the greatest games ever. I played it on PS5 and PC, no issues at all, only pure fun of world exploration and boss fights challenge. The lore is vast and deep, it will take a lot of time just to comprehend what's going on in this world as it always does in FromSoftware games, but in the end it's one of the best journeys in video games.
Ignore the hours played (4hrs), I also bought this game on SexBox One X Series X and played for over 100hrs (Str Build). This is NOT the PERFECT FROMSOFTWARE game (That's Sekiro), but it is the most expansive, lore heavy, & mechanically diverse game they have ever made. 

The size of the game is truly massive! Just when you think you've found the edge of the map, you will go down an elevator, push through a passage, or activate an item and stumble into a completely NEW area. BUT! There's more! Somewhere in the middle of most areas, you will possible find a passage that leads to the OTHER HALF of that area. 

This is NOT a PERFECT game, nevertheless it offers a consistently amazing experience.

I had a very difficult time getting into this game when in initially came out. I love Soulsborne games but for some reason, Elden Ring was not clicking with me. With the recent hype for the dlc and knowing that I was missing out on something special I gave it another chance and I'm glad I did.

 I wish dungeons, catacombs, etc, were a little easier to find and honestly I would have been stumped if it were not for the fextralife website and interactive map. I'm not asking for a giant sign saying "Dungeon to the right" but a little more clarity would have been very much appreciated early in my playthrough.

 The combat is the best in the genre and if a boss is too difficult- go explore the world. It's very easy to become OP in this game, with whatever build you want. I appreciate the added depth that jumping brings to the game too, it feels very natural. 

Super glad I finally got to play and enjoy the game and join in on the experience,

There is so much stuff that is excellent such as the scenery, gameplay, cutscenes, and items to collect. The more time you invest the worse the side content, its rewards and  its encounters feel. The vast majority of bosses are in multiple times, some are in up to nine times and even big lore bosses have clones loitering around. Some are just normal enemies with a health bar.

Awesome Game !!
I really wanted to like Elden Ring.
After months of hearing praise from all my friends, I decided to upgrade my GPU and actually play the game. Coming from Sekiro, I had pretty high expectations for Elden Ring. At first I was impressed by the visuals, the mystery and freedom the game left to the player. However, as I got accustomed to the games mechanics, I couldn't help but feel disappointed. 
I know how enthusiastic the Elden Ring community is about the game, hardly accepting any criticism, but in my opinion Elden Ring does not have an interesting combat system or a fun gameplay loop. Much of this is largely help back by the "open-world" style of the game. 
I recognize the tremendous amount of work that went into the artstyle, music and assets of the game. This is not the problem here.
Let's start with the combat system: This game punishes you for trying to play certain playstyles and forces you into using crutches to defeat bosses. If you want to play the game "your way" you will have to pay for it with a lot of your time and effort. For example, using summons makes some bosses 10x easier, some bosses are borderline impossible without them. The lack of any early hint or direction for how to start building your character puts you into an awkward position where it is hard to re-spec beyond just points (i.e. upgrading weapons, acquiring gear). Another gripe is just the nature of combat in Elden Ring. This is just my opinion, but dodge-rolling and waiting for an opening, just isn't as fun or epic as Sekiro's high octane fights. Beyond memorizing all attack patterns of your enemies, there is no element of "mastery" involved. It boils down to an arduous grind, which does not get remedied by satisfying rewards or story clues. For me, there is no power fantasy here. In Sekiro I felt like I bested my opponent in a straight duel, with both of us giving everything. In Elden Ring, you are essentially trying to find out how each boss was coded until you find out that you can go after his tail to defeat them. This just isn't fun to me. 
But fine, Dark Souls 3 is also a fan favourite, maybe the combat system just isn't for me or I didn't find the right weapons. What DS3 didn't have is open-world gameplay - something so utterly pointless, the development decision absolutely baffles me. Exploring this "world" is about as interesting as a university lecture on databases. It feels empty, with random enemies scattered all over. What do they offer? Absolutely nothing beyond runes and F-Tier items. It doesn't feel satisfying to go on a 2 hour detour just to find ... nothing. I went in blind, as advised by friends, and while playing I wished I had just watches some sort of walk through and took the shortest path to some of the more interesting enemies. The main bosses are intricate, well designed and hard. Too bad you are kind of forced to explore the empty boring wastelands of the lands between, unless you want to get "vigor-checked."
I think this game's problem is guidance. It is offering too much freedom to the player, so much so that it eliminates a sense of purpose and direction. Often you feel like your stats/gear just aren't good enough to make a fight winnable - not the type of power fantasy I'm after
just fuck around and find out

I Elden Rang.
Elden Ring is by far most overglorified Miyazaki sacred cow. Never saw so much praise for mediocrity. Yes this game is mediocre at best. 
First of all the open world doesn‚Äôt fit for souls games no matter what you believe but this is true. Sure the sense of scope and exploration will be satisfied for you‚Ä¶.for the first time. There is no way this game should be this big in the first place. I rather have more interconnected world like Demon souls or Dark souls where everything felt more fluid and in place. ER feels more like soul draining experience after some while. 
And here goes another revelation. To many overused mini bosses and in some cases main bosses become just another ‚Äútrash‚Äù mob walking in the field. Whoopie what an amazing discovery. I swear to god if you out of ideas why you creating open world in the first place? If you have been in 10 dungeons then the rest of 25 dungeons will be the same ones with same trash mobs and same mini bosses. Not even that but the worst part is when they started to add in the end of a game really really unnecessary difficulty mobs or should I say mini boss mobs that hits like truck and feel more like you fighting a boss but not a trash mob.  Again they lost their understanding what made their previous games so special and unique. 
The biggest shameful detail about this game is about boss encounters. Well what do you expect when you become to big and start to lose your mojo. Every major boss in this game has to many flaws. They move so unbalancing fast and do 5-6 hit combos that you are left only for misery. Someone gave good analogy: you move like Dark souls hero sluggish and slow but the rest of the enemies and especially bosses move in Dark souls 3 speed. Not even that but majority of them have to much of aoe moves. Thes pamming of aoe in this game by bosses is ridiculously funny. So where that leaves us? That leaves us in spot where you cannot recover where you cannot even hit them or have time to react because here comes another 5-6 hit combo and if you are not prepared better summon those silly spirits. This game was not designed for solo play. 
This is by far the most unbalanced game I‚Äôve experienced from From software. Either its to easy if you use summons or its to hard if you try to solo it. Very dissapointed by this game. Wished they returned to the form again where there was a balance in fights where bosses were memorable encounter but not just another grey bob standing but with different hat.

I explored every cm of the map and I can say its probably the best and most ambitious dark souls game.

The only thing shit about it are bosses, poorly designed and not memorable most of them, compared to the other games from FS.

The world design, finding items and secrets was a joy to explore.

The horse riding and combat is a very cool addition, the mounted combat being almost a new kind of gameplay that I enjoyed a lot.

The ashes of war and spirit summons are a nice addition. The crafting is also nice but barely used it.

The mechanics incorporated from Sekiro are a nice but do not add much to the game.

I liked the weather effects and time of day addition.

All in all, good experience, waiting for the overpriced DLC now.

"After investing a staggering 301 hours into Elden Ring, I can confidently say that it stands as a towering monument in the realm of gaming. From the moment I stepped into the Lands Between, I was entranced by its vast, interconnected world, teeming with secrets, challenges, and wonders waiting to be discovered.

The depth of lore and the intricate storytelling woven into every corner of the game kept me engaged throughout my journey. From the enigmatic characters to the haunting landscapes, Elden Ring delivers an unforgettable experience that transcends mere gameplay.

Combat in Elden Ring is a delicate dance of strategy and skill, where every encounter feels both punishing and exhilarating. The thrill of overcoming formidable bosses and mastering complex combat mechanics kept me coming back for more, even after hundreds of hours of gameplay.

But perhaps what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its sense of freedom and exploration. The vast open-world beckons adventurers to chart their own path, uncovering hidden treasures and forging their own destinies amidst the chaos of war.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a masterpiece that sets a new standard for open-world RPGs. With its breathtaking world, captivating storytelling, and deeply satisfying gameplay, it's a journey that will stay with me long after the credits roll. FromSoftware has once again proven themselves as masters of their craft, and Elden Ring is their magnum opus."

Rating: 10/10

Having platinumed Elden Ring twice on PS5, I recently jumped into the PC version in anticipation for the upcoming expansion. FromSoftware's reputation precedes them, and despite launch issues on PC, their games never fail to captivate. Even after over a hundred hours on console, this game continues to awe me on PC.

The gameplay remains as immersive as ever, drawing me into its intricately designed world and keeping me on the edge with it's intense combat. While not as replayable as some of FromSoft's other titles, this game still manages to feel fresh upon new playthroughs. With the expansion on the horizon, anticipation is high, fueled by FromSoft's history of delivering stellar DLC content.

In the end, FromSoftware proves once again why they're masters of their craft. As I prepare for another journey through The Lands Between, I'm reminded of the studio's prowess in forging unforgettable gaming experiences. I'm looking forward to exploring the Land of Shadow and kicking Messmer's ass (getting my ass kicked) in June.

I have played and finished all of the other Soulsbourne games (outside of Sekiro, which I've never played) and I just have such a love/hate with this one. Too many times it feels stupidly hard just for the sake of being stupidly hard. Bosses are make up for their blinding attack speed by adding super strength on top of that. It's like every boss studied at the Jose Canseco school of getting roided up out of your mind. Amazing is just the beginning of describing Elden Ring! Immersive, at times challenging, and friendly to any player just getting into Souls-like gaming. This game is open world and does not have a journal to keep track of quests in-game, however, there are plenty of guides online to use to follow along. With New Game+ this adds a whole replay factor, so if you didn't get a chance to find something in your first play-through you can hop in again with your current endgame level and obtain it; items, weapons, level, and spells carry over to the NG+. Multiple endings to unlock as well! For anyone wanting explore and get lost in a game, and get silly with builds, I highly recommend Elden Ring! 20/10

Despite it's many flaws, this is still easily one of the best games I've ever played. Period. I don't care that it's a AAA title under a big-name developer and publisher, this is a genuinely great experience. Not all of the gear is very special, but there are some very fun/cool builds to be made. The world is rich and evocative, on par with the original Dark Souls and Bloodborne in my opinion. This is also one of the few games where I actually just sit in one spot for a while and marvel at the scenery and landscapes. This actually feels like a grand adventure described in the medieval fantasy stories and old fairy-tales that inspired it.

[h1] Elden Ring's Beauty [/h1]

I want to firstly address that Elden Ring was my personal Game of the Year in 2022. 

I've been meaning to finally give this game a well deserved review before the DLC releases later in 2024.

If you've managed to play any From Software games in the past such as Dark Souls, BloodBourne and Sekiro, you may be surprised and even overwhelmed at the sheer size of Elden Ring's map, as it covers a wide density of areas above and below the depths of the surface. The more you continue to play, the more you are exposed to the sprawling amount of content at your feet, even right at the beginning of your journey.

Unfamiliar to the other entries of the game, Elden Ring will allow you to have the pure freedom to begin pacing throughout the game at your own leisure. Whether it be collecting resources for armor and potions, or jumping head first into a boss fight you're completely under leveled for, this game certainly doesn't hold your hand. It promotes exploration and allows you to always come back to specific zones whenever you feel more comfortable to tackle those challenges that await you. 

When it comes to Dungeons and catacombs, the design and layout of each dark and claustrophobic space is packed with monsters awaiting your every turn, and levers or mini puzzles for you to solve before you can then progress to fight the boss which occupies the area. Whilst the sheer amount of these catacombs have plenty to offer, as you progress you may start to notice some repetition in the way certain creatures are presented to you as the final challenge. This is one slight nitpick, but by all means doesn't take away from the full experience of Elden Ring.

The world of Elden Ring presents a beautiful soundtrack, which also brings along some truly breathtaking graphics as you may find yourself atop of a mountain, yearning to take a screenshot as soon as you can to capture what's in front of you. The OST massively compliments each boss fight, as you continue to find ways to bring down the mighty foe, your ears are continuously blessed with some fantastic instrumentals in the background.

Touching upon boss fights, Elden Ring keeps the challenge high for newer players to the genre, and even Souls Like veterans. You can choose to fight solo, co-op with your friends, summon other players across the world, and even bring out your bell to summon Spirit Ashes you continually collect throughout your playthrough. These Ashes vary in their ability to deal damage and attract attention to the creature you're fighting, so always use them to your advantage to understand how the boss attacks, and to find the most appropriately timed opportunities to land your hits. Each main boss is presented very strongly, some more so than others, with their look and aesthetics of character design truly being something that stands out to be taken in and appreciated by the player.

Something that works so well in Elden Ring is the freedom to mix and match different armor sets and weapons. The game incorporates magic, range and melee attacks, with even more damage type abilities ready to be implemented in the new DLC. It is incredibly satisfying to level up a weapon you love and see it deal a tremendous amount of damage to an enemy on its initial landing. As with other Souls games, you navigate through levelling your core attributes such as Vigor, Endurance, Strength and Dexterity, and this grants you many different ways to focus your build around, as the replayability of Elden Ring is truly on another level if you're someone who loves to create new builds and characters.

I understand and stress that this game won't be for everyone, especially if you like games with quest markers and a traditional way of telling you what/where to go next. But, if you do end up giving Elden Ring a try, please remember to take your time and soak in the first experience to its true potential as nothing can beat that initial immersive playthrough.

[h3] Happy gaming team! [/h3]

I forced myself to beat DS1 and Sekiro, and after clearing most of this game, I can see why people talk up FromSoft games. But for me, these games are not worth the stress. Never again will I stress about delayed and qued player attacks. We are the Elden Ring‚Ñ¢
Best Game on the market today and quite possibly Ever. True 10/10 experience.
I'm currently still playing through the game. This is technically my third time playing, though the first two times I didn't get very far whatsoever. 
Recently, with a lack of games to play, and hearing the news about Shadow of the Erdtree, I wanted to get back into Elden Ring, so instead I beat Dark Souls and Dark Souls 3. And just like that, I learned how souls games work. Now, that being said, you don't need to play any souls games before this, but keep in mind that this, like every other soulsborne title, is unforgiving and doesn't hold your hand even slightly. You are on your own in this world, and frankly, I like it that way.

This game feels like the culmination of Fromsoftware's work, melding together elements of Dark Souls with a beautiful new world, and a gigantic one at that. As of writing this, I am 75 hours into the game, and (as far as I am aware) am a little less than half way through it all. This game is massive, and the mistake I made the first two times I tried to play this game was rushing. Don't do that. Take your time, explore, appreciate every nook and cranny of the Lands Between, and trust me, there is a lot to see. This game is incredible, and playing it now for the third time after I managed to 'git gud', I can't put this game down. 

Day in and day out, all I can think about is Elden Ring, and it is a very special thing for any game to make me feel like that. 
This game isn't for everyone. There are points which will make you mad, and areas which can be painfully difficult if you're under equipped, and the game doesn't tell you anything. It is your adventure. Keep a notebook to keep track of quests, because there is no quest log, and place markers all over your map, because there are no objective markers. 

If you're in for a quick and simple fantasy RPG where you run from area to area slaying everything... This game isn't that. 
But if you're in for a long, hard-fought and rewarding adventure that you can lose yourself in, then yes, this game is the best of the best.

The game is truly breath taking and has a well thought out lore. Not to mention, theres a dlc coming out soon for a game that released two years ago. So put that in your pipe and tell me how good the game is.

Best game I've ever played.
So far this game is pointless. The main plot directs you immediately to an impossible boss which seems to require leveling by grinding through slogs of the same mobs. Very little side quests or structured content is apparent. If you enjoy truly unguided wandering in a confusing landscape filled with extreme danger at every corner, this game is for you.  If you are looking for something rich with story, rewards, and meaning, play something else
What a great game. The combat, compared to other souls-likes, is improved greatly. You're given a huge, huge amount of choices and builds to choose and start from, and none of them are necessarily bad. Also, the open world is done really well. Right from the start, you're dumped into this big, open world with no one really holding your hand throughout the entire game. You can go anywhere you want, and you can also avoid any dangerous area you want and come back later.

Though Elden Ring is an amazing game, I also must say that this game is quite hefty. The requirements are quite demanding and the game does crash every so often. It also can be quite easy due to the amount of "broken" weapons and summons provided, however, without the "broken" weapons and summons, the game is quite hard. The enemies are pretty unique, and the bosses are all challenging, fun, and designed very well.

melhor jogo melhor empresa melhor tudo ubisoft e uma merda sony e uma merda rockstar e uma merda mas e o goat segue intacto
Elden Ring, where do I start with this review, worth buying, to me no. I‚Äôm sorry, but I play games for fun, not to be a masochist for hours on end, such a painful experience. 

First and foremost, let's address the gameplay mechanics. While some may argue that mastering the game's mechanics is part of the experience, there's a fine line between challenging and frustrating. Elden Ring crosses that line with its clunky controls, which make no sense when it comes to modern-day controls. Rather than feeling like a test of skill, battles often devolve into an exercise in frustration, and leaving me frustrated.

The graphics, Elden Ring failed to impress me even on my powerful hardware. Despite playing in 4K, the visuals are underwhelming, with environments and character designs lacking the detail and polish expected from a modern title. Furthermore, the lack of support for ultra-wide screens only serves to exacerbate the issue. Not using my entire screen when even indie games manage to have this figured out, makes it quite a confusing choice.

It's baffling that in an era where seamless integration of controller support and intuitive UI design is standard, Elden Ring falls short in these areas. The on-screen prompts are cumbersome to navigate, reminiscent of a bygone era of gaming rather than a product of 2022. 

In conclusion, Elden Ring is a disappointment on multiple fronts. From its lacklustre gameplay mechanics to its subpar graphics and outdated UI design, it fails to live up to the lofty expectations set by people who talk about this game. While some may find enjoyment in the challenge it presents, for me, it will be remembered as a missed opportunity rather than a triumph of game design.

The hardest boss in this game is the buffering on rolling. Buffering means basically if you double tap something, it'll do it twice, which isn't a problem until you realize that when you get hit, if you spam dodge, you'll be forced to roll twice. I find it really bad, but just learn to dodge better, and you'll be fine. They only did so, so their game was harder. basically don't double tap dodge unless you wanna roll twice.
And when I say it's bad, I mean you can press it 0.1 milliseconds after you pressed it the first time and go all the way through with the first dodge. You'll end up dodging again after not pressing anything for one mississippi.

Played this a little bit, pretty fun.
Elden Ring is the newest installment from the company Fromsoftware and shares very similar tones with the previous Dark Souls 3 game. Using almost the same elements, the game will remind you vividly of DS3, that one being a bit further from the original Dark Souls 1, which made the ‚Äòsouls‚Äô genre so famous. Elden Ring requires a lot of expertise for its combat. It is a difficult game if you intend to play it alone without using the usually recognized "easy mode" like summoning players, npcs, or using the new ability ashes of war that allows you to call upon a creature to fight alongside you. And even with those facilitators, the game has a lot of difficulty spikes. Some will grant you great moments of conquest and others will simply make your veins pop in anger. The story has similar tones of vagueness and wonder all previous Fromsoftware games have. One will be enthralled by the mystic world and follow its clues checking items and searching for characters in this vast open world. Followed by a great soundtrack that can be enjoyed on its own, the game creates a fantastic atmosphere of wonder and wanderlust. While exploring you will face many different enemies that have many different ways of fighting. Some are simple, others require vast attention and reflexes, establishing the difficulty spikes previously mentioned. Akin to Dark Souls 3, I have found myself facing strange creatures that appear to not quite follow the rules of engagement. Some enemies have an impossible tracking. You can see by their models weirdly gyrating instead of actually moving their feet, as per example the runebears when they are to deliver their crashing hits. Others have this weirdly common act of delaying their attacks just to bait you into defending early. And some have the hysterical attacks that Dark Souls 3 was so fond of, flailing and screaming with endless stamina. This is quite a common trope in Elden Ring and gets tiresome quickly. That translates into many moments of frustration that may enrage you. Those cheap gimmicks in combat being the only perceivable crass flaw in the game, while everything else is composed of fantastic elements that produce a fantastic experience. As someone that enjoys acquiring achievements, this installment allowing you to near complete it in one go also deserves my personal praise. After having to go through DS3 multiple times for its damned rings, I never again want to be forced to NG+ in order to properly complete a game. Elden Ring is definitely a recommended game for the fans of the action rpg genre. It is not perfect, but it has great value, great mechanics, great characters and an incredible story.

Behold Elden Ring.
This re-did open world for me and this is how open world ought to be. The world should not merely complement the missions where traversal is simply the means to reach the objective, as in every open world game. No. The world ought to be alive in itself and it should urge players to explore every nook and cranny granting rewards (in ER - weapons, spells, incantations, secrets, etc.) for the effort. Moreover, barely anything that you think you could climb or reach is off limits. This is why the open world in this game blew me away. 

Other than that, pure pain and suffering for us masochists :')
This game open world its insane!!

majestic
I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

The Game is just absolutely fantastic! I recommend everyone to play this especially if you are into the Soulslike Genre of Gaming. Even If not the game is made SUPER accessible to newcomers to the franchise. Yes, The Game Is Difficult and will seem TOO difficult Near the beginning of your playthrough but thats kind of the point the entire game and even the dark souls games are all about overcoming the challenge. there is no handholding whatsoever . They kick you straight into the world and you are fully free to do whatever you want and fight whoever you want.
Typical dark souls recipe, but a super fun game! I'm going on 400 hours of play time of Elden Ring between PS5 and PC and I still haven't burned out. The insane amount of builds to try and play along with the meta pvp brackets i could log another 400 hours easily.

I have just started my second character and I still have areas unexplored before the DLC. Elden Ring is really the game that keeps on giving. It is initially a difficult learning curve - but in reality, once you upgrade your weapon of choice a few times, get some of those golden seeds in ya, it becomes more forgiving. Patience rewards you too. It's better to hang back and let the enemy attack first so you can learn their move set and find the gaps to attack, and don't be too greedy about it. You will be punished for trying to land a 10 hit combo.

One of the best games of all time!
My dad is 55, and I think he might be one of the oldest people playing this game. I got it for Christmas in 2021 from my uncle, and I was hooked from the start. Within a week, I had logged 24 hours on it. But I could tell it bothered my dad. He's a single father, and it's always been tough finding things to do together since Mom passed away. Then, one day, he surprised me by making his own Steam account and joining me in the game. At first, he was a bit lost, not knowing what to do, but when he asked me for help and we started playing together, it was like a whole new world opened up. It's become our thing now. Playing this game together has brought us closer than ever. We still hang out outside and do stuff, but now we have this special bond over the game. It's amazing how something as simple as a video game can bring so much joy and create so many memories.
AMAZING BOSSES

Never played any Dark Souls games, but this game takes the cake in novelty of environments and lore. Both highly detailed and interesting. Learning how to play was a bit of a challenge, but it made the experience better imo. Highly recommend to anyone willing to throw hours into a game.
they have so much shit to nerf, and so much else to make harder

it's like they didn't play their own damn game
I previously played Elden Ring on PS5 when it first launched and then didn't play it again until recently on PC. Even though it was my second time, the game gave me the same sense of exploration, discovery, and fulfillment it did when I played it for the very first time. 

The combat animation and mechanics are among the best with an extensive range of weapons and weapon types. Each weapon type has a variety of different permutations and unique animations. On top of this, the weapons can be further enhanced through different skills, affinities, and dual wields. There is also a broad library of magic that is just as vital to the gameplay as the melee and together they can weave an utterly satisfying combat experience. 

The game repeatedly blew me away in its exceptional level design and sheer breadth. The open world begs to be explored as you truly never know what you may find. You're challenged to think logically in various situations as your dwindling ability to heal, the enemy's intensity, and increasing amount of runes you're carrying work together to create an addicting tension that can be punishing.

I distinctly remember being shocked when I inadvertently discovered an entirely new region I didn't even know existed and this happened repeatedly. I remember the satisfaction of learning enemy movesets and using the knowledge of numerous deaths to finally defeat a challenging boss. Elden Ring is among one of the best games I've played--it is truly an experience--and I'm genuinely excited for Shadow of the Erdtree.

I waited until after I had beaten the game before I left a review. This was my first full playthrough of a FromSoftware game and without over exaggerating, this game changed me for the better. It taught me that persistence and an unbreakable will can get you through most challenges this game has to bring. It gave me a rich story and world to explore with detail found in every corner that most open world games will never have. It showed me how to appreciate the design of each of the bosses and see the art in every encounter. I'm glad that this was my first Fromsoft experience but I can say definitively that this will not be my last. I have found a new genre of games that I truly love and look forward to experiencing.

Also, remember, "seek rump."

Good game, thank you Michael Zaki.
Sometimes, all you want is to relax and have fun while playing a game. Unfortunately, Elden Ring is not very friendly towards non-professional players as it lacks the option to adjust game difficulty. Each time you die, you're forced to fight through a long path again to challenge the boss. This repetitive cycle becomes exhausting and frustrating, particularly when you spend hours trying but keep getting defeated. It's not the type of gameplay I was looking for, as I prefer an experience that doesn't feel masochistic.
Most everyone has heard of this game so i doubt i need to say much.

It's a great game, lots of lore and lots of fun.


jhnob
This game does everything that every other Souls title does, but worse. 

Instead of a linear progression through intricate levels with secret paths and fun but hard enemies, we have a massive and overwhelming open world that is filled with so much nothing. between point A and point B, you will find some boring low level mobs, maybe some souls or whatever, and a walking mausoleum here and there. The only people this helps are the people who can't play games unless there's an open world involved. To me, this cheapens their incredible linear design throughout the rest of the game, in places such as the Academy.
Not to mention the fact that there is, seemingly, no order at all to which you can tackle the bosses and other things on the map. This is good for the freedom that the open world offers, but it leads to incredible confusion and a feeling of being overwhelmed. There is a fairly obvious path that they want you to start with, but if you want to explore you will suffer until you head down said path and start to level. 
So...... what exactly is the point of the open world? to lure you into a false sense that there is lots of content in this game. As of writing this review, i have about 50 hours in the game. I have fought so many "bosses" in these throwaway corner-of-the-area dungeons (the ones that usually have a blue trail pointing towards them) that are nothing but more powerful versions of the mobs they spread across this benign world map. How the hell can you actually call that content? all you did was make them bigger and give them a couple extra moves + hp. i can't even safely say i have completed half of this game, as my time is split across multiple characters, but i can confidently say that probably half of what i have done has already been copied and pasted somewhere else in the world.

please for the love of everything, fix the NPC questlines. im so tired of having to look up how to progress NPC arcs. the cryptic dialogue they give is not fun or interesting, and how am i supposed to know what does and doesn't screw up a questline? i kill one boss on the opposite side of the map from someone and now they're gone. incredible. Nobody thinks that's fun.

it boggles my mind that this has a better reception than any other souls game, and the only reason is because it's open world. it's "more accessible" in this design than other souls titles, but it does not feel the same, or nearly as good.

I have tried again and again to enjoy this game, but it's missing something that the other titles have. I really can't put my finger on it, so i simply listed problems i have with the game as a whole.
