This is the exact game I've been hoping for for almost 10 years. Fromsoftware combat with a vast open world like skyrim. Beautiful locations to explore, awesome bossfights that take time to learn, loads of awesome weapons to use. Feels like the perfect spiritual successor to Dark Souls. Some people complain that bosses are reused too much, or that side dungeons get repetitive, but I didn't have much of an issue with that. Even if I did all of that is optional anyway. This game is a dream come true for me. 9.8/10

Upon his name as Godfrey, the first Elden Lord
Elden Ring, depending on my mood, is my favourite game of all time. It is a game that tells you to overcome all your challenges with a little learning and persistence.. in game, not out of game. As of writing this review, it might seem I haven't played too much, but I have 100% the game on xbox, and have gotten decently far on PC, and of course in time, I do plan on 100% it again. The reason I say this is because It'd be kind of weird to write a review like this from someone who appears to have not even beat the game yet.

The gameplay is pretty daunting at first. Souls games are infamous for being hard, and first time players of the game probably worry they might drop the game early because they can't get past an enemy/boss. If we were talking about the other souls games, I'd understand, but with how Elden Ring's world is built, you can just turn around and go somewhere else, level up, and kick that enemy's buttocks. The game is super flexible, and very welcoming to new comers in that regard. And after levelling up a bit, finding some gear and spells, the combat looks like a battle straight out of a cut scene. Getting used to boss attacks can be challenging of course, but super rewarding in the end, even if you levelled up to the point you can just beat them in ten hits.

The world is beautiful. Some people criticised the game after it won game of the year, claiming that it looks like a mobile game, but one good look at the trailer alone kind of throws that argument out the window. Every location, be it a flat plains, a hellish landscape, the snowy peaks of the mountains, or even underground (especially underground), all looks like a fantasy world you can easily get lost in. Each areas design and structure is out of this world, and should probably have an art museum open up somewhere for this single game alone. The game also doesn't tell you where you go to get to your next mission, at least not with a marker, fast travel points on the map, if close enough to a point of interest involving progression in the story, will point toward the next site of grace (fast travel point) that you need to go to, and you just follow the trail.

The story is something that's a little harder to explain, as in most games, it's pretty straight forward, whereas in this game, the best way to say it is it's not spoon fed to you. It is easy to pick up a general idea of the story so long as your brain isn't turned off whilst you're playing. You are sent to the land to become the elden lord, and in order to do that, you need to gather the pieces of the elden ring, from the main bosses in the game. These bosses are not random high health people, they do have a past, and a story, but again, the game isn't going to spoon feed you that. Technically the story happened over a thousand years ago or something, so you could say that you play the character who is introduced at the end of the book, who has taken up the mantle of ending the story. Your story in this game is simple, but it's built upon a very rich lore, that I believe was written by George R. R. Martin, the guy who wrote the Game of Thrones books. 

Side quests are not required, but if you do somehow find where to go next, they tell a pretty nice story, and sometimes even tell some sweet sweet lore to the world. some side missions are missable though, or you might just miss a part of a side mission and pick it up later in the side missions story. If you don't want to do the side missions, that fine, however, there is one side mission I highly suggest, It is the Ranni the Witch questline. You could technically argue it's main story, as it is connected to one of the bosses holing and elden ring, and doing this side mission unlocks an ending involving Ranni, however, it is labelled a side mission in the official guide, and is missable. Look it up if you hate how the side missions are structured (they don't tell you where to go to continue said story, how people have completed EVERY single side mission in one game, I don't know).

As a side note, if you're still worried you might drop the game, don't be afraid to use the internet or something. Look up where to find gear, where to level up best, How to upgrade your weapon, or look at specific side missions, and how to get to the next part of it. Some might say it's cheating to use the internet, but guide books have existed since before such easy internet reliability, and they're pretty much the same thing, but one is free... though on that note, there is a pretty cool official guide you can get for the game, that looks nice, and is pretty helpful with all the things I mentioned not being afraid of looking up online.

good game
Elden ring is a fantastic game in most ways.  Exploring this vast world is hugely entertaining, challenging, and sometimes frustrating.  This is a great addition to the fromsoft library.   It can sometimes suffer for its scope though.  Compared to other modern fromsoft games the mild philosophy of quantity over quality is noticeable as a fromsoft fan.  Some of the encounters (Especially the flying kind) are comparatively half baked and should have been thought out/playtested more.   Dont get me wrong, I love this game.  We just need to acknowledge its flaws as well as its strengths.

its elden ring
I just want to begin by saying that there is no shame in using a guide to help you play through this game. There are plot points you may miss if you are not a meticulous person who goes and talks to every person they can, and also after every little event that happens. I say this because this game, as well as other souls games, thrive on you looking into things. reading item descriptions, checking every corner, and talking to everyone. It may seem tedious, but i can assure you that if you just play the game to hack and slash or sling spells (which is fun), you're going to miss some of, if not the best, lore you have ever been blessed with. This game is worth giving your time and patience to. Miyazaki, and Martin are not amatuers when it comes to lore. And the know how to hide it, and place it for you to go searching. And if you think it, or any other souls game is too hard, just remember this. The game isn't decide to beat you down or make you quit. It is designed to force you to get better, and overcome while never giving up. Don't go hollow.

Seek maidens
REALLY GOOD SOULSLIKE GAME.
I finished the games 3 times already but I don't think I'll play it again. That's because the game is enjoyable but also frustrating. I cannot help but overlook the crucial flaws that the game has. I'll list them below - 

1. The game doesn't value your time. You have to do tedious farming over and over again to level up or otherwise the enemies and bosses will kick your behind. 

2. Some key bosses like Maliketh and mogh (2nd phase), Malenia (Optional boss) required if you want complete experience, Commander Nial (Required to reach Malenia) are completely absurd because of their mechanics and how poorly their mechanics are designed just to make the game frustrating. All of them have very small attack windows, Infinite stamina and op damage output. Malenia has lifesteal that also makes it too difficult to tank as well. Even with mimic tear these fights are absurd. Sekiro(another from software game) didn't have these issues at all. Sekiro was difficult but it felt fair. The mechanics were fair.

3. The Lack of navigation and direction of side quests and key elements( Like the locations of 2 dectus medallions, 2 haligtree medallions especially the one in albeuranics on the pot guy) are crazy bad. And I don't agree that this is a part of the exploration but rather it is a cheap marketing tactic used by the developers to force you to use the internet and youtube so that the game appears everywhere and reaches more audiences and sells more.

4. The world is simply hostile. Everything tries to kill you just like any other souls game. It gets very irritating sometimes especially when you are trying to explore or walk to a quest or boss. Even the side quest characters tries to kill you at the end ( Like Alexander jar, varre, millicent simply dies or you can kill her, Irina's father Edgar invades you at some point god knows why, Bernhal invades you in farum azula without any dialogue which was really strange as he just spit knowledge during volcano manor quest, Sellen meets a tragic ending no matter what you choose ). It just felt unnecessary as if fromsoftware doesn't know how to end the side quests on a good note. Not even one. 

At the end of the day I won't recommend the game to anyone because although I enjoyed the experience the amount of struggle and frustration overshadows it. To be honest screw fromsoftware games for making these masochistic games only because Myazaki likes to jerk off while playing his punishing games. He is actually a masochist look it up, thats why the games are so miserable. They create this beautiful fantasy world and write these amazing npc's and backstory but they won't let us enjoy it all without the misery. This is why fromsoftware games will never be as good as games like Witcher 3, Rdr2, Gta 4. And I finished every fromsoftware game except bloodborne. Game should be a source of entertainment not frustration or misery and Myazaki needs to finally understand that not everyone is a sick masochistic bastard like him.
Absolute cinema x100

just play it and feel it
I never played much soulslike games before, but this is the best soulslike game I ever played for sure! Recommended! 

Pros:
- Graphics are awesome. Game runs smooth on my older PC.
- Game is creative and fun all the way to the final boss. It never feels repetitive in a boring way.
- So many enemies, bosses, quests and items! Awesome!
- A lot of different class/styles to play.
- Game has lots of mods and I really recommend the seamless co-op mod!
- You can play the game on hard or normal, its up to you to explore and use the tools the game gives you.
- Controllers and animations feel really good and responsive.
- Crafting is not too complex, and its easy to upgrade weapons and spells.
- The world makes me wanna explore everything, which is great! They really made the right choice making this an Open World game.
- All in all a masterpiece game! 10/10

Cons:
None in my opinion. But if I had to write something it would be:
- Devs should have added something like the seamless co-op mod as a native feature for co op PvE adventure.
- I never liked anticheat stuff like EAC for games where you play solo or co op PvE, so they should have added a native toggle feature for this so players can choose themselves. Luckily there are mods that fixes these things, so its not a big issue :)

There's this absurd feeling in the oldschool roguelikes I've played that comes from being able to smash everything together. Selections from world mythology, fantasy epics, and decades of monster manuals can be packaged in ASCII art and delivered like they all belong side by side in a dungeon. This bliss feels, frankly, unadaptable. EXCEPT!! FromSoft executes it perfectly, aboveground and in more loving detail than anyone else out there. i am an elden lord x15
My first souls-like that I managed to play for more than an hour or two without rage-quitting. It is hard for sure, but man, this game really does live up to the hype. Took me 1.5 years of owning it to finally get committed to a run, and now I am well and truly hooked on this game, and so excited for the fact that I have Sekiro, Bloodbourne, Dark Souls and Demon Souls to give a try now that I "get it".  The world is the most beautiful world I have ever seen in a game. The combat is tight. Enemies are punishing. I died to Margit probably 50x, maybe more, but Godrick only took maybe 5-10x! And there are TONS of smaller bosses to take on too. So many castles and dungeons and caves to explore. So many items/weapons/armour to try out. Various builds to play with too. The value for your money is simply unmatched with this game.

Can't wait for the DLC in June, I should be done my first run by the time it drops.

CONS:

Firstly  you can literally miss pivotal things of the game play , i literally had no idea how to level ... had to google it cause i missed what seemed to developers some obvious landmark . but that is basically the number one rule of the game ... google things .. and google some more ... where are the mushrooms ... how can i beat something or where can i find it .. where is that staff or some other thing ...  ( i literally missed the tutorial cause i didn't jump, missed map marks , missed so many things , that i either in the end googled or saw in some videos )

Second ... items are rare and far between , the starting mage robe .. like the one you start with, seems to be the best.. had to google it multiple times cause i could not believe that in a game with so many interesting creatures and scenery i am stuck looking the same ... for the whole 100 hours i played it .. i had the SAME robe .... 

Thirdly .... i understand the whole dark souls thing about making it hard to kill bosses ... or maybe i am a bad player :) true ... but i literally had to be lvl 90 to beat a boss for which the community was recommending lvl 50-55 ... they give you the possibility to skip most of them , so that is nice :) ( i got to experiment more of the world because of that ) , but in the end i got stuck on some bosses and i literally have to walk aimlessly and kill the highest experience  giving critters on the map just for level ... more levels more stats and maybe i can beat them when i'm lvl 2000 :)

Lastly ... the side quests are very rare , nice stories , rare , and again a lot of googling to see how you can finish it :) or continue it. Also one key or mouse click and you kill the NPC that unlocks whole new area of the map :) ... 

I played 100 hours , enjoyed 50 :) so is good value i guess.
I cannot recommend it as i am left bitter tasting having to delete the game without finishing it .. can't roam same lands for XP and try the same bosses over and over again forever.
The best game in the last 5 years
(The PC port is kinda ass and stutters a lot)
Seigward's absence in "Elden Ring" has disappointed many fans, including myself. The character, known for his memorable encounters and distinct personality in "Dark Souls III," contributed to the unique atmosphere of the game. His absence in "Elden Ring" is indeed a loss for the series, as players will miss the opportunity to interact with this beloved character once again.

The absence of Seigward in "Elden Ring" is particularly striking due to the impact he had on the narrative and gameplay of "Dark Souls III." His questline, which culminated in a poignant and memorable encounter, added depth to the game world and resonated with many players. The absence of such a well-crafted character in "Elden Ring" is a notable omission that has left fans feeling a sense of loss.

On a different note, the comparison of Alexander the Great to a "terrible ripoff" is a bold statement that warrants further exploration. Alexander the Great, known for his military prowess and conquests, has been a figure of historical significance for centuries. His impact on the ancient world, particularly in the realm of warfare and empire-building, is undeniable. However, it is important to acknowledge that historical figures are often subject to varying interpretations and perspectives.

While some may view Alexander the Great as a symbol of conquest and expansion, others may critique the methods and consequences of his actions. The notion of a "terrible ripoff" suggests a strong disapproval of Alexander the Great's legacy. It is crucial to consider the diverse historical, cultural, and academic perspectives that shape our understanding of figures such as Alexander the Great.

In conclusion, the absence of Seigward in "Elden Ring" has elicited disappointment among fans, reflecting the impact of well-crafted characters on the gaming experience. Furthermore, the characterization of Alexander the Great as a "terrible ripoff" invites critical examination of historical figures and the varying perspectives that shape their legacies. These observations highlight the nuanced nature of storytelling, historical interpretation, and the impact of beloved characters in the gaming world.

Another incredible adventure from Fromsoftware. Their games have only gotten more approachable as time's gone on, so this is a good place to start if you'd like to try the series. Just know that it's very long (40+ hours casually) compared to earlier titles. I would recommend one of those if you want a shorter adventure. While I'm disappointed in the quality of this PC port (60 FPS cap, occasional shader cache stuttering, etc) this is hardly unusual for this studio. The Easy Anti Cheat makes the game take longer to launch and probably has some performance impact but I would not want to deal with cheaters in a game like this. I do wish you could disable it if you only planned on playing offline without needing to rename executable files. Solid 9.5/10 game with a 7.5/10 PC port.

Honestly, this is the best soulsborne game. I've played and beat every souls game including demon souls on ps5. To everyone who says the game is too difficult, I have some tips. The games layout is amazingly placed and spaced out. Go out and explore find better equipment, especially the wonderous physick and maybe some spirit ash summons, and find runes. I'm not going to say 'git gud' bluntly but there is a learning curve to the bosses, but once you understand their patterns you'll enjoy the bosses and game more.
In the grand scheme of things, heralding Elden Ring for its brilliance is akin to declaring that gravity tends to keep us grounded - it's a universally acknowledged truth at this point. Yet, here I am, compelled to throw my hat into the ring, or rather, the Lands Between, to sing praises of a game that has skillfully commandeered countless hours of my life, much to the bemusement of my wife, the occasional frustration of my four kids, and the sheer indifference of my two cats and slightly concerned dog.

Elden Ring is not just a game; it's a lifestyle choice, a commitment to exploring every nook and cranny of a world so vast and unforgiving that I often found myself wondering whether my real family might start sending out search parties to the sofa. From the towering bosses that sent me to my doom more times than I care to admit, to the breathtaking vistas that made those repeated demises somewhat bearable, this game is a masterpiece of masochism.

Jokingly, I told my family that Elden Ring was a complex tutorial on time management and resilience. My wife didn't buy it, especially after the third "just one more boss" at 2 AM. My kids have started using terms like "You died" far more frequently than I'm comfortable with, albeit in completely unrelated contexts. The cats seem to have aligned their nap times with my gaming sessions, and my dog has developed a keen sense for when I'm about to face a boss, choosing those exact moments to need a walk.

In all seriousness, Elden Ring is a testament to the art of video games. Its intricate world design, challenging combat, and rich storytelling are a beacon for what the medium can achieve. Yes, it demands time, patience, and a willingness to embrace failure as a teacher, but the rewards it offers in return are unparalleled.

To the developers, I offer my heartfelt thanks for this monumental achievement. To potential players, be warned: Elden Ring will consume your time, test your patience, and challenge your skills. But it will also reward you with one of the most fulfilling gaming experiences of your life.

And to my family, thank you for your patience, your understanding, and for not changing the locks on me. Yet. Here's to many more hours in the Lands Between‚Äîpreferably when everyone else is asleep, and the pets are fed.
10/10

I've played every game in this series, but this one could be my favorite.  There's a lot of good options for weapons and playstyle, and there's so many unique enemies, even if some of them are copies.  The actual core story path to the end is not too long, but the optional content is near 100 hours, not including replays. 

The gameplay is so good, it makes people hallucinate a story.  My only complaint is that the co-op is a bit clunky.  There's thankfully a mod for that, but I don't give the devs credit for community-made content.

It's the DARK SOULS (TM) of FromSoft games

goob
4/5 Stars

Probably the only open-world game on the market that successfully captured my heart in its gameplay. The world is vast and expansive, but has a lot of action and interesting things to do to not make it feel drawn out and boring.
The world itself is beautiful at every corner you can find, the developers really nailed the visual feel of each and every area to make it unique and feel monumental to reach a new area.
The weapons are varied and beautiful. Be it sorceries, incantations, or flashy weapons, you'll definitely find something to pick up and fall in love with.
This game even lets you summon Spirits which can allow you to buddy up with certain entities that would have acted as opponents for you in the past, but can fight alongside you using their Spirit Ashes in areas with daunting enough challenges.
The combat is punishing but (mostly) fair. It's FromSoft's signature combat system that defines their games and gives them that unique form of challenge, and you're sure to like it too.
The only things stopping me from giving the game a 5/5 is the boss difficulty scaling and weapon upgrades. While the upgrade system itself is fine, getting the materials for upgrading can occasionally be a hassle to go through since they can be hidden in obscure and easy-to-miss spots, but ultimately it's a minor issue at worst.
The far bigger issue in my opinion is the boss scaling. Most bosses are very easy with the right tools and equipment until the late game (mostly things you would fight after [spoiler]Fire Giant[/spoiler]), and afterwards bosses become extremely difficult to a near-unreasonable degree. Most of the time this works in the boss's favor as you can still learn and master the moveset with enough practice, but I think it would have been better if the spike wasn't so intense compared to the bosses before them.
Overall it's a great game and well worth the asking price of the game. I'd at least recommend trying it out if you have time to invest in it.
Gud Game

My first soulslike, great game in almost every aspect (my only problem is that it's easy to get overleveled when you actually explore the locations)
One of the greatest open world games ever, over 100 hours of content on a single playthrough and you still won't be done exploring this world. Every main location is unique and looks stunning, with something new on every corner. The great variety in weapons and  the many options provided to you by incantations and sorceries allow for a near unlimited amount of viable and creative ways to beat this game. If you happen to run into a boss you can' t beat and you don' t feel like trying over and over or walking away to level up, you can summon a co-op player or use spirit ashes to make it easier. 

Obviously there are a few cons, a lot of bosses have arbitrarly enhanced difficulty via use of delayed attacks, almost undodgeable attacks (looking at you Malenia) or hyper armor. Quite a few non main bosses are reskins of previously encountered bosses, especially the duo bosses, which are just two reused bosses in the same arena. However, due to the vast number of unique bosses this hardly takes away from the experience, unless you are expecting every boss to be on par with Sekiro's best.
In addition to the gameplay I personally found the soundtracks to be a little underwhelming at times, but you won't notice this when you are trying not to die.
The true ending is letting Aurelia take her little sister to see the stars

An ideal game for a lifelong gamer transitioning through the struggles of adulthood. As someone who missed out on the Dark Souls series, this was my first experience playing a game that rewards you for mastering certain skills and weapons outside of immediate game-breaking upgrades. If I'm being honest, the upgrades were almost necessary to survive and sometimes felt like it wouldn't be enough to overcome an upcoming challenge. There will almost certainly be a point where you will realize that you need to be upgraded, not the player tools. All in all, this game demands mastery for completion. There are ways to cheese the game but you will feel shame for using them. I'm looking at you, bleeders, sleepers, greasers, dragon seal users. I'm only kidding, that was the first way I beat the game, but I didn't feel like the victory was earned. Definitely the best game I've played in years, very refreshing from what's been put out recently from big name studios. Play it, you'll see what I mean. Not only will the lessons of mastery will apply to life but any history or art enthusiast will appreciate the references.  A masterful game. Can't wait for the DLC

Best open world game I've played, for Fromsoft to have done such an amazing job on their first attempt is a testament to how great they are as a video game development studio. Amazing world to explore, great characters and stories (though very convoluted to finish the quests), tight controls, lots of cool weapons and builds to try out. It's a very very good game.

Up there with Dark Souls in terms of its lore and atmosphere, though unfortunately plagued with a lot of unfairness in its gameplay, as I felt they were trying to just 1-up themselves in difficulty without much thought of how fun or fair it would be. Very much felt like luck played a large factor in whether I beat certain bosses. Some fights are just really bad and unfun, it's a shame that the bosses, which have been some of the strongest things about From's games, are at their weakest here.
Most damning is the final boss, its first phase is very cool and fun to learn, but the second phase is the worst boss that Fromsoft has ever done and feels completely unnecessary.

Elden Ring was a magical experience with its story telling and the expansive world and it teaches us the very basics of the game right at the start of the game, "If youre struggling with something, explore something else and then come back again when you are ready for the challenge". The story telling is on point, the world is beautifully designed, the NPC story quests are wonderfully interconnected(which is all optional but still connects to different endings without spoiling anything). To truly get the best out of the game, YOU MUST play it through blind in your first run. And then on the second time onwards, you truly start exploring things that you initially missed out. 

Fromsoft, you have done it again! Kudos.

As someone who is well-adverse in the Souls Universe, this one... takes the cake. The play-ability and exploration mechanics of an open-world souls-like game, combined with the exquisite depth of lore, makes this game a monument to my sins, a magnum opus if you will. Putting more than 80+ hours may not seem like an impressive feat, but does justify how much time I have given to the game to say the least. I cannot for the life of me think of a game with such beauty and grace conveyed in the lands between, that brings me back to oversea the plains as Elden Lord, Ranni's Consort and the Frenzied Flame Lord. 

This game encapsulates the very desire, the very purpose and accomplishment, pride and joy of beating it. I can only wait and sit on this throne, until the lands call upon me.... once more.

I've been a From fan ever since I was introduced to them during DS1 and I gotta say, I have always loved their titles from Sekiro to Bloodborne and back to the Souls series. But this game. THIS GAME. Is a marvelous piece of work; The music, the world itself, the character design, the boss fights. Not a single thing felt neglected in this game. After playing the game for hundreds of hours, I can rest assured in saying that this is my favorite game of all time and is easily the best game From has ever put out. If you take the time to read the items in the game to understand the lore you'll find many layers of complexity and many, many more moving gears to all of those layers. George R. R. Martin did a great job with his story writing (unsurprisingly). I cannot wait to play the DLC in June. If you are asking, "Should I purchase this game?", the answer is stop asking and get it right now. You are missing out on an experience no other game will come close to delivering.

A reserved thumbs up.
It's a beautiful game, with an incredible atmosphere, some intriguing ideas, and some delightfully intricate level design.
On the minus side, the plot and lore are impressionistic at best (i.e, come across as mostly incomprehensible, nonsensical or just plain random), the platforming elements are poor, and the edgelord approach to the gaming experience ultimately works against any real sense of immersion. Most major obstacles you don't overcome by getting good, but an unavoidable process of trial and error, over-levelling, or cheesing bosses.

worth it
The Blue Mommy called my name. "Pablo Erlenmeyer" she spoke. And I, a felled tarnished, rose from my slumber in search of the Elden Ring. Since i am Him, i skipped the tutorial area and went straight into Limgrave where i met a man who called me Maidenless. He was right. But he had the eyes of a trickster who would backstab me at any turn. So i killed him and abandoned my quest for the Elden Ring so that i may simp after the Blue Mommy from my dreams. I embarked on this new quest in this strange land and was immediately humbled by a giant knight on a horse. It was a challenge. My past versions of my life flashed before my eyes and gave me wisdom to slay this worthy foe. Then i emerged with great power and PTSD.

I met a side bitch who really wanted me to get the Elden Ring for some reason so i figured i would help her out while i was at it. After i made it to Margit, who humbled me further and gave me more PTSD, i stormed Stormveil Castle with accidental map exploits and made it to Godrick. Im not sure what he was smoking but he wanted to start shit so i had to put him down. Walking out, i was free from being bound by the mortal plane and realized that the mortal plane was fucking massive. With many trails and tribulations persevered, and many experiences that enhanced my PTSD, i found myself at Hogwarts. My waifus mom didnt seem to approve of my simping and tried to kill me. I was able to subdue her and obtain my loot. Soon i met Blue Mommy herself. Like many women in my simping experiences, she had me run errands for her and left me feeling sad and alone. 

Lost and betrayed, i wandered the land upon entering hell. It was called Caelid. There was another soul in this land who was like me. His mind lost. His soul broken. His name was Radahn. Unfortunately, we could not communicate and fought each other in mortal combat. Many others came to celebrate in this joyous occasion as Radahn found peace in his dying breaths. With the weight of the literal planets off his back and transferred to mine, i set off to claim my throne as Elden Lord.

Lindel. Day 32. That motherfucker Margit came back from the dead and ambushed me on my horse. I didnt take kindly to that and trained my sights on the giant tree in the sky. I will avenge you Torrent. Lindel. Day 69. I fought a giant ghost and stand before Margit, the slayer of Torrent. His name is Morgot? Why is music playing? He tried to make me touch Grass. The only thing he did was enhance my PTSD even further. I approach the tree. Ready to claim my throne. I can no longer sleep. Every time i blink i see the other versions of me get torn to pieces or falling to death. Knowledge itself is a curse. But now it was worth it. WHY THE FUCK CANT I ENTER THE TREE!?

I roam the land. There was a weird giant one eyed monster that shot fire. Like all the others, he too fell to my blade. I approach the volcano as my side bitch instructed. She caught on fire and died. Then i died and woke up in hell this time fr fr. This place. This can be my resting place. PLACIDUSAX IT WAS JUST A JOKE!? WHY IS THERE A SKINNY AND FAT MAN EMERGING FROM THE VOID!? DID THAT DOG BACKFLIP OFF HIS SWORD!?

Denied even death, i crawled out of hell and returned to Waifus Watchtower. Where i met a fellow simp who offered me advice. He could have killed me, but he was a fellow warrior who was plagued by PTSD. He reinvigorated me and encouraged me to keep going. To never touch grass and to Simp to the best of my ability, even if there is nobody to see me. So i did. Even when she didnt see. I still simped and i fought Astel. a giant skeleton centipede who bled despite being dead.

I returned to Lindel. I was ready to claim my throne. A mage stood in my path. He was like all mages and was all talk. Godfrey, the ghost i fought when i first came here was waiting for me in the flesh. It was an epic battle. He said "The World" and the whole arena exploded. His Stand Power was no match for me and i entered the tree. But what came next was a true battle of epic proportions. I fought God, who had turned the stone. He was unwilling to give up the Elden Ring. But as i lay defeated on the stone floor, a dear friend appeared. The very friend who encouraged me to stay simping, Jolder. Together we slayed God. But that wasnt all. A new creature appeared and looked to be made out of the heavens itself. Ready to face this foe, i turned and saw that Jolder had faded into dust. I was devastated, but i knew that this was my journey and i had to end it. Im not sure what happened. All i knew was that i fought. 

When i opened my eyes. She was there. Ranni. She came back. I slid the Elden Ring onto her ring finger and vowed the eternal matrimony. The world was remade and found new prosperity under her rule. Finally. The pain. The agony. The torment. All of it was fading away as i close my eyes.

Then i woke up. I was in Limgrave again. That snake spouting the same Maidenless drivel. All of it was a dream. A nightmare. I was denied paradise. Now.. i would see the world burn.

This game is pretty, but I couldn't get into it because I wasn't enjoying myself. Almost everything I met killed me several times over, and I couldn't find a way to improve my character or weapons. Or, rather, I found there are supposed to be ways but the explanations were confusing and I lacked the materials needed. I thought I would get the materials from difficult fights, but the ones I managed to complete gave me nothing but currency.

There's very little guidance aside from messages left by other players, and those are often actively unhelpful. I know I could look up tutorials online but I don't have a reason to want to. I'd rather just not play. From what I can tell, most of this game is about running back to the last place you died over and over until you don't die. That just does not appeal to me in the slightest.

Nice game. Great time indeed. Worth your money.
Beware of dog.
For me this turned out to be a delicious candy wrapped in a layer of dung. 

The good:

It's a From Software game, and as such the basic mechanics are solid, you got lore scattered throughout the game, and the areas are distinct and solid. The graphics are amazing, and there are some genuinely pretty areas that are absolutely breathtaking the first time you find them. The selection of weapons, shields, armors, consumables and various stat boosting items is fairly wide, you got a host of equippable special attacks (called Ashes of War in the game) and if you're a spellcaster the spell variety is huge, 

The bad:

PC is still marred with connectivity issues 2 years after the game's release, meaning that if you're into organic co-op or pvp, you will experience noticeably worse latency compared to the console version. Speaking of co-op, the AI come across as extremely poor at handling multiple opponents, and will often appear to "break" in the sense that enemies will wander around aimlessly without attacking. Alternatively, if the enemy is capable of casting spells, you can end up in a situation where they spam spells endlessly, and you end up stuck in a loop where you constantly have to dodge and can't close the distance to break them out of it. 

The game also suffer quite a bit under its size compared to earlier Fromsoft titles, which means that endgame bosses tend to become damage sponges to keep the game challenging. You can of course spec your character for status effects, as you can melt a lot of late game bosses with them, but personally I don't like that sort of pigeonholing in an action RPG.

The next thing on the list is that a lot of enemies have attacks to punish panic rolls, and while it was a nice change of pace back in Dark Souls 3, it quickly gets old when everyone and their grandma can and will punish poorly timed rolls. A noticeable amount of enemies also have "not technically input reading" dodges, as trying to attack them with projectiles or even melee attacks will trigger a dodge at the first frame of the attack animation. On the surface it makes sense, as one would expect enemies to try to avoid getting hit. However, if you lack the burst damage to bring them down, for example if you missed upgrade materials or don't have the proper damage stats, they can become extremely tedious to fight. With that said there are certain attacks that won't trigger the dodge, but then I'm back to this feeling of pigeonholing in an RPG again. A few enemies also have a "get out of jail free" card in the form of a backward skip they can't be staggered out of, adding to the tedium of bringing them down. 

A more personal gripe since I'm a Dark Souls 3 pvp veteran is that some enemies embody the worst behaviors of players back in DS3. They have infinite stamina, meaning they will roll spam forever because your attack animation trigger their "oh no, need to dodge" script. They also have infinite FP (Fromsoft's mana system), meaning they will spam spells out the wazoo, and while you try to dodge one they will cast another, stagger you out of your roll and make you eat an attack that will inista-delete you, It's like fighting the DS3 griefers with full Havel's armor and Dark Hand all over again.

If you have gotten so far, you might wonder why I still have over 1000 hours in this game. The answer is that despite all its flaws the game still provide a unique experience, and that's enough to pull me back in after I swear I will never play this game again and take a 6 month break. Make of it what you will.
G.OA.T

no horse shrex
I was never a "souls" player. Hell, I was never a role playing game player. In fact, I've never liked the genre very much in all my years of gaming. Even objectively great titles like Fall Out failed to convert me and my incessant need for the instant gratification of FPS games like Call of Duty and Battlefield. And then came Elden Ring. It truly is a masterpiece of a game. The map design is unique and incredibly expansive. The aesthetic is gorgeous and sometimes it honestly felt like I was gaming inside of an art painting. The game play itself, much to my delight, is very forgiving due to the fact that the game design is open world allowing players to go around bosses or avoid optional bosses entirely while leveling their character up. Elden Ring was much needed relief to players like me who had grown tired of top tier software developers lazily cranking out games for the sake of profit seeking rather than for the love of crafting engaging and challenging video games. Take it from me, a person who never spent more than a few hours failing at RPGs like Dark Souls, Elden Ring worth every penny.
Not my first souls game and will most definitely not be my last! Can always come back to this game at any point and get stuck playing for hours. Truly a masterpiece if I do say so myself
so good so great so good so great

"Elden Ring: A Triumph of Imagination and Challenge

FromSoftware has once again transcended the boundaries of gaming with their latest masterpiece, Elden Ring. This is not merely a game; it's an odyssey through a meticulously crafted world that breathes with life, death, and everything in between.

Set in the mythical and sprawling lands of the Lands Between, Elden Ring introduces players to a world ripe with lore, mystery, and danger. From the moment you step foot into this vast realm, you're greeted with a sense of awe and wonder that rarely dissipates throughout your journey.

At its core, Elden Ring is an action RPG that stays true to the developer's signature style of challenging gameplay and intricate level design. Combat is fluid, weighty, and punishing, demanding precision and strategy from players at every turn. Each encounter feels like a delicate dance of death, where one wrong move can spell disaster, yet every triumph is met with an unparalleled sense of satisfaction.

But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its world-building. FromSoftware has crafted a world that feels alive in every sense of the word. Every corner of the Lands Between is teeming with stories to uncover, secrets to unearth, and breathtaking vistas to behold. The sense of discovery is palpable, urging players to venture off the beaten path and explore every nook and cranny.

Furthermore, Elden Ring boasts a level of freedom rarely seen in games of this magnitude. Gone are the linear corridors of previous titles; instead, players are given the freedom to forge their own path through the world, tackling challenges in any order they see fit. Whether you're delving into ancient dungeons, battling towering bosses, or embarking on epic quests, the choice is yours, and the world responds accordingly.

Of course, no discussion of Elden Ring would be complete without mentioning its breathtaking visuals and hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. From the towering spires of castle ruins to the eerie depths of forgotten catacombs, every inch of the world is brought to life with stunning detail and atmosphere. And the music, composed by industry legend Motoi Sakuraba, perfectly complements the game's tone and themes, evoking a sense of melancholy and majesty that lingers long after the credits roll.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is nothing short of a masterpiece. It's a game that pushes the boundaries of what interactive storytelling can achieve, inviting players to lose themselves in a world of unparalleled depth and beauty. Whether you're a seasoned Soulsborne veteran or a newcomer to FromSoftware's , Elden Ring is an experience that demands to be played, cherished, and remembered for years to come."

Become Lord
For seasoned players in the Souls-like genre, Elden Ring stands out as a masterpiece that combines thrilling boss fights, dark humor, and immersive gameplay. As someone deeply familiar with these types of games, I found Elden Ring to be a captivating experience filled with memorable moments.

One of the most exciting aspects of Elden Ring is the spontaneous boss fights that can catch you off guard. The game doesn't hold your hand, and encounters with powerful foes can happen unexpectedly, adding an element of surprise and adrenaline to the gameplay. These moments of facing formidable adversaries without warning are reminiscent of the intense challenges found in Dark Souls, keeping players on their toes at all times.

Speaking of Dark Souls, Elden Ring carries on the tradition of the series' signature dark humor. From the classic "going to grab an item and being pushed off a cliff by an enemy" scenario to humorous NPC interactions, the game infuses light-hearted moments amidst its dark and ominous atmosphere, creating a perfect balance of tension and amusement.

However, one drawback I encountered was the limited co-op experience in Elden Ring. While teaming up with friends to tackle tough challenges is enjoyable, the fact that friends are removed from your game after defeating a boss can be a bit disappointing. I believe that implementing a seamless co-op system akin to Lords of the Fallen would enhance the game's immersive nature and encourage more cooperative gameplay throughout the journey.

Despite this minor drawback, Elden Ring remains a must-play for fans of the Souls-like genre. Its challenging gameplay, intriguing world, and blend of dark humor make it a standout title that will keep players engaged for hours on end. Whether facing off against epic bosses or exploring the vast and mysterious lands of the Lands Between, Elden Ring delivers an unforgettable experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

What a game! My first Souls game and it's a great one. The story is great if pieced together through bits and pieces, especially those NPC questlines which can be a real head scratcher to get through, if not downright impossible without looking up a guide. Yet, after having completed all those quests, the storylines are great and the lore feels in-depth and has weight to it. The combat felt great, having a great collection of weapon arts, sorceries and incantations, that I had tons of fun using. Graphically, the game is stunning yet my low end GPU can still run it on high settings, thank you to FromSoft for that. There aren't many negatives. The story never once felt dragged on, and each character's motivations felt meaningful and strong. The only thing might be, as I mentioned earlier, confusing optional quests. 
I'd give this game a 9.5/10 and I'd highly recommend it to everyone, especially those who have never delved into any Souls games before. This might be a great introductory game into the world of Souls, as it certainly was for me. Looking forward to 'Shadow of the Erdtree'!

fire giant a mfer
Elden Ring is a game that is as frustrating as it is compelling. FromSoftware has once again managed to create a title that tests the patience and skill of even the most seasoned gamers. However, despite its infuriating moments that can lead to fits of rage and abrupt quits, there's an inexplicable draw that keeps pulling you back into its twisted world.

The map of Elden Ring is nothing short of massive, offering a staggering amount of space to explore. Every corner is teeming with secrets, lore, and challenges waiting to be uncovered. The environments are masterfully crafted, drawing you in with their haunting beauty and mysterious allure. Whether it's scaling treacherous cliffs or delving into dark dungeons, each area begs to be fully explored, rewarding the intrepid adventurer with unforgettable experiences.

That being said, Elden Ring is not a game for the faint of heart. Its punishing difficulty and unforgiving combat mechanics will test your skills and patience to their limits. There will be moments where you'll want to hurl your controller across the room in frustration. Yet, there's a strange satisfaction that comes from overcoming these seemingly insurmountable obstacles, fueling your determination to press on.

For fans of the Souls-like genre and those who appreciate moody atmospheres and rich storytelling, Elden Ring is a must-play. It's a dark and maddening journey that will push you to your limits but rewards perseverance with moments of sheer triumph. Just be prepared to rage, quit, and then find yourself inexplicably drawn back for more.

Awsome
Best game
Pros:
¬∑ Beautiful art and world design, great views from almost any point of the map
¬∑ Massive map with a lot of areas to to explore
¬∑ 300+ weapons and 100+ unique abilities for them, over 100 incantations and 70 spells
¬∑ All weapon types have a distinct feel to them which keeps the game fresh over multiple playthroughs
¬∑ Most enemies are fun to fight and have a natural rhythm to them
¬∑ Updated game engine improves upon Dark Souls 3 with more consistent physics
¬∑ The horse given to the player early on is iconic and enjoyable to use
¬∑ Excellent sound track
¬∑ Each subcontinent (Limgrave, Liurnia etc) feels unique and has its own atmosphere
¬∑ Some great memorable bosses with quotable lines and unique visual design
¬∑ Most freedom in the series, the player can reach a huge amount of the game's map from the beginning
¬∑ Possibly the best character creation yet with seemingly limitless facial shape combinations
¬∑ Simple and effective UI
¬∑ Compelling side characters and 6 possible endings, with 2 of them being unique
¬∑ No pointless developer hand-holding - you start the game and do what you want

Cons:
¬∑ Huge difficulty spike after the game's midpoint that can make late-game combat tedious
¬∑ Map is so large you will often miss npc questlines, items, dungeons and bosses without searching online 
¬∑ Most of the bosses in the game (outside of remembrance) are repurposed normal enemies
¬∑ Most of the remembrance bosses do not have fun fighting mechanics, choosing style over substance
¬∑ Backstory and lore are by far the worst and most convoluted in the series
¬∑ The late-game areas do not have as nearly as much content as the earlier ones
¬∑ Plenty of obnoxious enemies with bad hitboxes and high stagger resistance (esp. Caelid and Mountaintops)
¬∑ Most late-game enemies are repurposed from early and mid-game
¬∑ Not as many good-looking or memorable armour sets as in the other soulsbournes
¬∑ Second phase of the final boss is an abomination and ruins the great atmosphere set by the first phase
¬∑ 4 of the 6 possible endings are almost exactly the same, the only difference being the background colour
¬∑ Finding weapon upgrade materials is a chore if it requires regular smithing stones and not somber ones
hONESTLY... made me feel things. not good things, but things

Mid
From the moment you step into the Lands Between, you're immersed in a world teeming with breathtaking landscapes, haunting ruins, and formidable adversaries. The sheer scale of the environment is awe-inspiring, inviting exploration at every turn. From desolate plains to towering castles and ethereal forests, each location feels distinct and alive, enriched with secrets waiting to be uncovered.

The combat in Elden Ring is where the game truly shines. It strikes a perfect balance between methodical strategy and intense action, offering players a wide array of weapons, magic, and abilities to unleash upon their foes. Every encounter feels like a high-stakes duel, demanding precision, timing, and adaptability. Whether facing off against towering bosses or battling hordes of lesser enemies, the exhilaration of victory is unmatched.

One of Elden Ring's greatest strengths lies in its storytelling. George R. R. Martin's influence is evident in the rich lore and intricate world-building woven throughout the game. From enigmatic NPCs to cryptic item descriptions, every detail serves to deepen the sense of immersion and intrigue. The narrative unfolds organically, rewarding players who take the time to piece together the fragments of the past.

GOAT
Greatest game of all times
This review was written in summer of 2022: 

There is nothing to not enjoy this game if you are one who does not give up easily. I started playing Elden Ring on my laptop which every systems requirements website said could not run it. I played it on the lowest graphics settings with one of the lowest resolutions possible in windowed mode. I still had an immense amount of fun. Is this game hard: yes. Are some of the boss movesets seemingly unfair: yes ahem Waterfowl Dance ahem. But, this game is still enjoyable. 
This is my first From Soft game, and it was intense. The only game that I could consider similar to this that I have played is Nioh, which I also completed base game on. The best piece of advice that I could give to anybody wishing to play this game is that if you don't completely give up, you will "git gud." The learning curve in this game is insane, and if you start NG+ or play on another account after beating the game once, that tutorial boss isn't so hard anymore. 
All in all, this is a great game, possibly the greatest game that I have personally played, and likely the greatest game to be released in this year.

Don't talk to me if you don't have this game
Good game, but not for everyone. The Souls style combat is at its best in a highly curated, tightly knit environment which, by the nature of an open world, is not possible here. While the attempt at something different is appreciated and adds a lot to the table, I don't think it was executed upon well enough to merit the praise I see Elden Ring receive. I'd even argue that the open world could be cut in half to better effect. It gets incredibly samey, mind numbingly so. You'll be wandering eerily similar caves and tombs for 30% of your experience, fighting the same bosses and enemies copied and pasted time and time again; Elden Ring really doesn't feel like it has respect for your time. I've played and replayed every Souls game, countless times. DS1 specifically is well into the hundreds of playthroughs. But when I came back to Elden Ring with a fresh save to prepare for the upcoming DLC, I simply couldn't stomach the redundancy of this slow burning open world.

Elden Ring - A Masterpiece in Gaming

Elden Ring is not just a game; it's an experience unlike any other. As a seasoned gamer, I've traversed countless virtual worlds, but none have left me as mesmerized and captivated as Elden Ring. From the moment I delved into its richly crafted universe, I was immersed in a breathtaking journey that seamlessly blended awe-inspiring landscapes, gripping lore, and exhilarating gameplay.

One of the standout features of Elden Ring is its vast open world, which feels alive and teeming with secrets waiting to be discovered. Every corner is meticulously designed, from towering castles to sprawling plains, each with its own story to tell. The sense of freedom to explore this expansive world is unparalleled, offering endless opportunities for exploration and adventure.

But what truly sets Elden Ring apart is its challenging yet rewarding gameplay. From epic boss battles to tense encounters with formidable foes, every moment is a test of skill and strategy. The combat mechanics are fluid and responsive, requiring careful timing and precision to emerge victorious. And with a wide array of weapons, spells, and abilities at your disposal, each encounter feels fresh and exhilarating.

Beyond its gameplay, Elden Ring also boasts a rich and immersive narrative, steeped in myth and mystery. The lore of the world is deep and intricately woven, inviting players to uncover its secrets through exploration and discovery. From ancient ruins to enigmatic NPCs, there's always something new to uncover, keeping you engaged and invested in the world around you.

Visually, Elden Ring is a masterpiece, with stunning graphics and breathtaking vistas that truly bring its world to life. From the haunting beauty of the night sky to the eerie depths of the dungeons, every detail is meticulously crafted, immersing you in a world of unparalleled beauty and danger.

In conclusion, Elden Ring is not just a game; it's a masterpiece of gaming. With its vast open world, challenging gameplay, and rich narrative, it sets a new standard for what a video game can achieve. It's a journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll, and one that I wholeheartedly recommend to any gamer seeking adventure, challenge, and immersion.

Very nice game! :D
I finally found something that brings me a bit of joy again.
Pros: 
+Weapon arts are awesome and make you feel like a badass. 
+Magic (sorceries) are fun. 
+Status effects can be inflicted on enemies and is not only a valid way of attacking, it's one of the strongest. 
+You can eat the heart of dragons to become stronger. 
+A massive sprawling area to explore. 
+Like...three-four ish chicks to simp over. which is triple what Dark Souls usually gets. 
+Not all quests follow the Dark Souls dogma of being extremely depressing by the end of it. 
+Lots of possible endings. 
+"I am Malenia, blade of Miquella."
Cons:
-Vigor actually matters a lot in this game. Something that will feel weird to most Dark Souls players. 
-Area scaling can get a bit much at times. Mostly the end game areas, but still. 
-Some areas/quests are near impossible to complete without a guide. For example, there's one where you have to sit at a very specific bonfire that isn't really explained at all. Don't get me wrong, exploring as much as possible will net you a good chunk of secrets from the game, but some of them are just too well hidden.
-"I am Malenia, blade of Miquella."

gutes
ranni top tier mommy
A game so good I clocked in 380 hours on my PS5 and bought it again on Steam and clocked another 140 hours (at the time of writing this review - Shadow or the Erdtree will push those hours up).

This game is astonishing in size and scope, the map is massive without being overwhelming and there are secrets squirrelled away everywhere. The world size is huge but I think one of the reasons the map isn't daunting is that fast travel sites of grace are plentiful and also that the map is not littered with icons - you get to place your own markers on the map. As you play the map just keeps getting bigger and bigger yet never becomes overwhelming for the reasons noted above. 

This was a joy and provided a real sense of discovery and wonder that I hadn't realise was missing from my open world experience up until I played this game. 

Combat is tight and feels fair for the most part although I avoid Rune Bears because they are ludicrously fast for their size and hit like a truck. The only real part of the game that can be not fun is actually the fight with final boss, the Elden Beast. If RnG doesn't play fair then it runs away constantly, which can make this fight a bit tedious rather than fun - the Radagon half of the fight is very fun mind you.

Anyway, this is one of my favourite games of all time alongside Bloodborne, Nioh and Baldurs Gate 3.


good times for shizzle

Elden Ring
My favorite part was when the Elden Ring said "I'm the Elden RIng"
This game is absolutely worth your time and your money. 
It is a brilliant game and was one of my favorite from the first hour of gameplay, now on New Game+ I think it's time for me to take a few minutes to tell you why I love it so much.
Yeah you're gonna die a lot, and the game is quick to teach you that you can't just expect to win every battle, but death is a setback, not a failure, and while there's no conventional "easy mode", the game gives you a ton of options to make your journey in the lands between easier, such as spirit summons or powerful sorceries, making it very accessible for players new to souls-like games (such as myself). 
In addition, if you do your homework and learn about the advanced mechanics of the game, like buff-stacking, you can easily get incredibly overpowered and stomp on even the hardest of skill-check bosses without breaking a sweat.
The music is incredible to does a lot to add grandeur to the environments and glory to the boss fights. The environments are stunning and really invite the player to explore the world and see what this diverse world has to offer. The graphics, while not at the top of what this generation has to offer, are saved by an incredible art style and artistic direction.
The friendly NPCs are well written and all have their own story and personality, the story really feels organic and the player does feel involved from start to finish, mostly due to the player needing to piece together details themselves to truly understand the world, making it feel like you're actually living it rather than reading it in a quest log.
The absence of a conventional easy mode creates a shared experience between players. If you struggled on a boss, you know millions of players before you did as well. Moreover, multiplayer mechanics like messages and bloodstains add to this experience by creating a sense of community and mutual aid that is really helping you get the determination necessary to overcome every hardships you might face. 

Now for the (few) cons, the game often has some stuttering issues, especially on low spec hardware, which can be quite irritating if it happens during a tense moment. 
Quests can be hard to complete without looking them up on a wiki, as it's quite easy to miss a step or lose track of NPCs. And although you're not supposed to finish them all in a single playthrough (to be fair it's already quite the achievement if you finished a single one without a guide), it can rebuke some players who might not want to put the hours to do multiple playthrough of the game.
Especially given the open world nature of the game, which kinda hurts the replayability, needing a lot of running around grabbing materials and items to get back on track on a new save file. This is mitigated however, by the fact that most items do stay in your inventory on NG+, sparing you the hassle of running errands before actually playing the game.
Also fuck that torrent resummon dialog box, i lost count the number of times i died because of it lmao.

TL;DR: Play this game, it's good :3

The best souls game I've ever played in my life
I am a 41-year-old single father to my 11-year-old son. When my son received this game as a Christmas gift from his uncle, he became engrossed in the game, racking up 24 hours of playtime in just one week. This concerned me, as I was already struggling to find quality time to spend with my son between his friends and YouTube. To connect with my son through his interest, I created a Steam account and purchased this game. Although I was initially confused by the gameplay, my son graciously hosted a game for me to join. I loved the experience - it was the most meaningful time we had shared since the passing of my wife. Gaming has brought my son and me closer, and we now spend more time together outside of the house as well.

gr80 m80
I love  hot Latina women

Miyazaki has had years to find a way to be innovative, but he seems to be stuck in the past. It seems every other franchise has evolved, but this one. Controls are still as clunky, unresponsive, and broken as all other installments. With next to zero accessibility options, (and I'm not talking about difficulty sliders). Role delay due to sprint and dodge being mapped to the same button, with no way to separate them through changing the bindings. Most other controls feel unresponsive at times. Also, for some reason, it seems they haven't enabled omnidirectional rolling when locked on, so you have to decide between being able to roll away from the boss (not locked on) or being able to hit the boss (locked on). Also when locked on when using a spear it just won't hit the enemy sometimes, it will stab where they were 5 seconds ago. The game studders heavily during the open-world segments, which make up a majority of the game. Delayed attacks and gank fights do not make the game more difficult, they ruin the combat flow and experience, so why does it seem that everyone needs them according to FromSoft? The PC port is also really bad and unoptimized, for keyboard and mouse, but whatever, just buy a controller to use. 

The art style, graphics, and spectacle of the game are beautiful, but it's ruined by the emptiness and repetitiveness of the world. You'll go to an eye-catching location on the map, just to realize there is nothing but reused bosses and poorly designed catacombs, which end up more akin to the Chalice Dungeons of Bloodborne. Even if you do decide to crawl your way through the copy-and-pasted catacombs and locations, all that you are rewarded with is a weapon or spell you can't use. During my first playthrough, I was excited to explore the beautiful world, but after every encounter, I felt my time was wasted, not even enjoying myself doing so. The open world feels barren and unnecessary like FromSoft saw Breath of the Wild do well so now they forced themselves to make it open-world. The map is too big for its own good with nothing filling it out.

The lore of the game is as grand and deep as every other FromSoft game, which is one of the many things I like about them. However, the way the lore and story are delivered to you hasn't changed since Demon Souls. Still, the only way to unravel the story is to rigorously read through the item description of everything in the game. Quests and NPC interactions are confusing, with no discernable way of knowing where to go without a guide. It is very easy to not finish an entire quest just from doing things accidentally out-of-order, in an OPEN-WORLD game. Needing to watch a 36-hour lore video on YouTube just to understand the story makes me question what hiring George R.R. Martin was even for, as his influence is just imperceivable when compared to the stories of past games.

Most bosses were easy except for like one bullshit thing they have that is only meant to get you the very first time you fight them. Melania is an easy, and predictable fight every time, right up until she uses waterfowl, where she requires you to do some bullshit zigzag that needs to be looked up in order to find out (or just use frost pot I guess :3) I have almost 300 hours and have beaten the game 3+ plus times as of this review, so don't take this review as just a person who got stuck on Tree Sentinal or Morgott, and just needs to "get gud" But also don't take this review as me entirely hating the game, I mostly enjoyed my time and I'd say at least 75% of the game is perfect, but it's just that 25% that makes me dread having to do another playthrough.

I forgot to put Torrent up there, so here he is. Riding Torrent on horseback just seems really unfinished, like something is supposed to be there but just never got made. Combat on Torrent is really boring, you just run in a circle pressing mouse 1. If torrent had I-frames or some kind of dodge I feel it would greatly improve that aspect of the game.

Also, PvP exists apparently, it's not that fun. (Meta builds are boring to fight every time I invade or get Invaded)

It's still a really good game and you should go out and play it [or not I don't really care] I just needed a way to express my discontent :) 

Bye-bye

GOOD
This game made me addicted to painful losses
There's a lot to like about this, but also a lot not to like.  I have mixed feelings about the open world aspect of the game.  It's a neat idea, but it makes the scaling and boss progression very strange.  The first natural boss that you'd likely run into, Margit, is very tough if you head to him right away, but you can explore the world and become very overpowered and easily overcome challenges that way.  On one hand, it's a really cool concept and you can get some fun exploration out of the game, but on the other hand, it makes playing the game feel a whole lot less natural and balanced than other souls games.  This game is tough to give a thumbs up because of its many gameplay issues, but I suppose I'd do so anyway.

Let's talk about those gameplay issues.  One of my biggest issues is a major issue with the controls: this game has the worst input buffering I've ever seen.  This is another intentional design decision to make the game artificially "harder", but this doesn't make the issue any better.  This game is very notorious for having an input-buffered roll go off *after* your char gets hit and sleeps on the ground for 2 seconds, which can often lead to you getting hit again.  And you better hope you didn't press an attack 3 seconds before the boss starts an attack animation, especially if you're using a slow weapon.

Unfortunately, the boss design is mostly not good.  I don't think this game is especially difficult, mostly because you can explore the world and become way too overpowered for the content you're doing, but they made an obsessive effort to try to make the game harder in an unfun and unfair way.  Most bosses spam their attacks way too often and give you far too few opportunities to respond safely.  The vast majority of bosses in this game have attack sequences where they'll end up dashing away or they go into the next attack too fast so you can't punish properly.  There are also a lot of attacks that bosses *might* do to follow up a previous attack, which makes punishing them a gamble.  For example, Margit does a slow overhead slam with his cane that you can easily punish... unless he pulls out his daggers and slashes you, which he does sometimes.  There's no indication, as far as I can tell, whether he'll do this or not, you're just gambling.

Another issue is that many bosses have some attacks that are far too quick to be fairly dodged.  Using Margit as an example again, those daggers that I mentioned are far too fast to avoid if you're close to him.  It feels like the devs were worried that the open world would let you trivialize content (still does), so they tried to compensate by giving most bosses total BS in a desperate attempt to make the game harder.  Either that, or they're just worried that souls veterans (of which I'm not) are getting too good at the games and so they need to rely on cheap ways to make the game harder.

Compounding this issue, at least for inexperienced players, is the way that poise works in this game.  It's a snowball.  If you're extremely good at getting your hits in where you can (or you can afford to tank boss abilities to get more hits in), then bosses will get stunned relatively easily and you can punish them for big damage.  If the result is stunning a boss, you can afford to be reckless because you won't get punished.  But if you aren't constantly keeping the pressure up, their poise regenerates very fast and you don't make any progress whatsoever.  This makes a huge difference between how most people would experience the game versus how someone with tens of thousands of hours mastering this content would experience the game: either you can make bosses drop like a rock by hitting them a few times, or you are just constantly running away from spam attacks that don't have clear punish windows.

As I've mentioned, since there isn't a linear sequence of boss progression, you can go out of your way to make your char very overpowered to trivialize most content, at least until you get towards the end game and notice a very hard-to-miss spike in difficulty.  But neither side of this experience is very fun to play.  Either content is so trivial that you can easily tank boss abilities and mow them over, or every hit does more than half your hp and you need to deal with constant BS attacks that are too quick to dodge and bosses that relentlessly refuse to let you punish them.  There are some small minority of bosses in this game that feel well designed and fun to play against, but most are not fun.  I think our standards should be higher than this.

After the mountaintops of giants = 6-7/10

Before the mountaintops of giants the game is extremely fun to explore, boss fights are omega difficult but rewarding, there are new places that are visually stunning to explore and overall a great experience other than the game randomly dropping from 60fps to 1fps and back to 60fps

After the mountaintops of giants the game becomes tedious with reused enemies and bosses who are no different from before but just deal extra damage while having more hp, the majority of main bosses also just become massive hp sponges with AOE attacks that aren't fun to fight, visually the game is still pretty good but hard to enjoy because of the enemies.

Say "git gud" all you want but i did the game 100% with the help of save reloading to do the endings.

Dark Souls 2 2 

Hindsight, parts of the game infuriate me to no end in choice or game design. But how much time I spent in this game and loving every hour of exploring and fighting through it? I can overlook it and even commend some parts of it. Nearly every build is supported ( Faith / Int / Dex / Arcane / STR / Etc) and given the tools to make it happen. But some builds can only work with LATE late game items, so its really just a NG+ gimmick. Open world feels exactly like what the FromSoft formula needed, well MORE open world. Absolutely beautiful game and plenty of ways to approach situations (except the hidden super boss)

BEST GAME EVER MADE!
TLDR this is my first souls experience and my god was it a good one! 

HOLY!  Elden Ring is a masterpiece, having mastered the art of showing without telling.  As a result, it is very different from other open-world games I have played such as Skyrim, Elden Ring has also mastered the art of sublety. For example, for a game like Skyrim, there are various elements such as the character dialogues, leveling system, various landmarks that I could clearly point to in contributing to the game's success. However, this is not the same with Elden Ring. It's hard to place my finger on one specific thing that makes the game so enjoyable. Many times I've gone in to play this game for half an hour, only to become immersed, losing track of time and playing for hours on end!

I cannot express my love for the game this was one of the best games i have ever, and will ever play!

Fantastic game.
It's easily one of the greatest games I've ever played. Might even be the greatest game I've ever played. It's really hard to put into words how much I love this game. I originally bought this for PS4 with over 1000 hours played between all console characters, with Platinum achievement (all 41 trophy's), but had to buy it again on Steam for the PC experience (glad I did). I fully plan to compete every achievement again and 100% at least 2 playthrough's between NG and NG+ on steam. I truly and fanatically love this game more than words can really describe.

If you are looking for a totally new experience in the Souls series and never gave this game a chance yet; please drop every game you're currently playing and play this game. As a former Call of Duty and competitive shooter addict, this broke my addiction and gave me a pathway to try new games. If you are new to the Souls series of games, this game is an excellent place to start. In alot of ways its very beginner friendly, however, its very challenging as well. This game encourages exploration heavily which is great as well.

This game is one of the greatest games of all time, and anyone looking for a decent review will find nothing but praises about this game. Its worth every penny, and in my case, worth every penny twice over. Please play it if you haven't. Don't deny yourself this beautiful exquisite gem of a game. Again, very challenging at times, but every good game should be.

big sword
I dont like Elden ring. so this Might seem biased at some points.

Elden Ring really resonated with me for about the first 50-80 hours (just a heads up I have north of 600 hours on ER on PS4) but then the game just eh'ed itself. the game is the most Middle grounds of the FS games. 

summing up Mediocre and frankly linear levels of DS3 in order to have a "Decent" line of progression. as for a newer player. they would literally quit the game after getting 2 sk by anything in Caelid. hence it is mainly used just for endgame purposes. and Yes. I know that Caelid is for more experienced players who want better things. I know. but the "Legacy dungeons" have little to no world building in them. very rarely any shortcuts. cause they just put a bonfire outside of the bosses doors now. which seems to me as an excuse to not design levels for interesting moments of "Holy shit Im back where I started."

it also perfectly sums up the "difficulty" of DS3's bossfights. but manages to tear apart the good parts. and add only bad parts. this one will be mostly a comparison to DS3 and ER, as both of them have a similar feeling in terms of combat. 

ER and DS3 have both the fastest (except BB) dodging gameplay for a FS game. both are quick and easy to move around. Cameras will sometimes go crazy but otherwise the dodging mechanics are basically Copy and pasted from DS3 (with the addition of an actual jump button!) anyways. onto the real point. Both ER and DS3 has similar types of Bossfights. Speedy. Hard hitting and decently portrayed. as said. I do not like ER's boss fights. DS3's bossfights never overstay their welcome. they only under-stay. a boss such as Gael and midir feel like you never want it to end. and the combos are just enough in order to stop anyone from trying to kill anyone, or throw a massive rant about how its "unbalanced"...

You see. this is where ER fucked up. ER copy and pasted the best parts about DS3's bossfights. e.g. the presentation, moves (honestly ER has some of my favourite moves in all of FS games) and well the design. but it lacks in 2 major points:

the Lore is just dogshit. Honestly I dont know who did it either George RR Martin or Mr Miyazaki. but the Lore in ER is by far the worst. there is literally nothing for a normal casual player to understand the lore. tbh on my first 2 playthroughs (both were blind) I had genuinely no idea wtf was happening and I just couldnt see myself understanding the lore and any given time. 

And secondly, it overstays its welcome. Most fights in DS3 can be similar, e.g. Crystal sage. but anyways. I have this huge problem with Radagon. I loved this bossfight to death when I first saw him. I even played through NG+ as him once. but my love for him has only faded. Radagon has 1 major problem. he doesnt change at all. his entire boss fight is literally just him repeating the exact same combo which never ends btw. with either a move that is fair to dodge or an absolutely unfair Poke. which deals stupidly high DMG btw. I know the entire community is probably gonna say "git gud" cause why not. but seriously I hate these 30 second long Combos. which only give you 1 or 2 hits at the end of it (I use UGS or GS's only, never dex weapons) 

anyways. i really dont recommend this game. i find it just boring and repetitive.
I hate this game so much, had a lot of rage inducing moments, mainly because I'm not that good at the game (git gud, so to speak). 

Nevertheless 10/10, loved it, would play again.
Lime Gravy
pog
