Its addicting. I dont want to work. I just want to play it.
It's a good game, if you want to start with the soulslike genre this might be the best starting point. It is very polished and the least unfair compared to DS1-3. Open World is sometimes a little empty, but in general there are a lot of sectrets to find and it rarely feels pointless exploring. Difficulty seems fine to me, there are some encounters that are really challenging but i never felt cheated. For fans of the Souls series or souls like games in general this game should be a no brainer. For everybody else it still is a very safe recommendation and worth its money.

I was wrong, this game deserved GOTY.
Elden Ring is simply a monumental achievement from From Software, a magnum opus from the great Miyasaki himself, its a fantastic RPG that is designed very meticulously and beautifully, the atmosphere of the Lands Between is on point and captures the "Dark Souls" feeling tremendously, the game play is at its peak, it stays true to the combat roots of souls games past and just feels ever so tighter, the addition of jumping in this game may feel strange at first but it adds a whole other level of combat, the lore of the game again is fantastic with the help of George R.R Martin even though you would have a better time watching lore videos on YouTube but that's just souls games. 

It is a masterpiece for what it is, is it Dark Souls 4? No, in my opinion some of the areas do feel to big with not to much going on, personally i prefer a more streamlined experience but for what its worth, i have enjoy pretty much every second of this game.

MAY CHAOS TAKE THE WORLD

AV 10/10
gore
yis
Try fingers
But hole
Pickle...

on a more serious note, this is genuinely one of the greatest games i've ever played and not putting it in my top 10 would be criminal after the hours of enjoyment i've had. the world is breathtaking, there isn't a single area of the game where if you stop and take a breather for a second or two, you'll be hitting F12 a couple of times. the variety of locations are insane. i won't say much to avoid spoilling, but i was often shocked at the amount of ideas they managed to cram into this world without it feeling unnatural. there are some traps in the game that teleport you to late game areas, and you'll be shocked at how big the map is, how cool the areas are and how the fucking common dog just one taps you. it makes it so when you actually reach these locations through progression, it feels really good to not get one shot or actually one shot the enemies that were giving you such a hard time. besides that, exploration is fun and feels actually really good. usually in your skyrims and copy pasted ubisoft open world titles, you just look at your compass at the top of your screen, and hold W in the direction that has the most appealing icon. sure you're "exploring", but you're not actually looking at the route you're taking. in elden ring, the compass only tells you the cardinal directions, so if you want to find anything, you either have to look at your map to see if there are any points of interest or actually look around using your eyes to spot interesting things. this gave me the same feeling i had with breath of the wild a few years ago where i'm supposed to do one thing, but i just see another cool thing after another i just get sidetracked for hours. the bosses are what you expect from a soulslike, tough, maybe rage inducing (if you suck) but fair. if you haven't played a soulsbourne game like i have before this one, this is easily the best intro you could have to them. all the bosses are great, the build variety you can have in this game is seemingly limitless + if you struggle too much on a boss, you can just go into the open world and come back when you're better. the only flaws i have with this game is that it's in a serious need of a questlog (it's not normal that i have to have the wiki open on my second monitor just to remember what a NPC said 60 hours of gameplay ago) and it could take the ULTRAKILL way of death. what i mean is that if you die, you click R, no loading screen, you spawn right back into the boss room. i fucking hated the commander niall runback
souls games will always be special to me, because of my favorite mechanic.
your character doesn't get better, you do.
Nice open world game
d
game hay

will defo end up depressed when i finish this

One of the best games I've ever played in my life
Edit: still true statement
    Elden Ring is the second worst entry in a terribly dull series of games, only behind Bloodborne. It keeps up the Souls tradition of keeping whatever "story" it has hidden behind item descriptions that people pretend to read, and if you bother to do so you'll only be met with abstract fantasy tropes that make the world feel more paper thin and pointless. Something worth noting due to the devoted fans often praising the story and George RR Martin's name being used in the game's marketing campaign.

    As for gameplay, if you have played a Fromsoft game before, you have played Elden Ring. The only real difference is they have added a horse. The core combat mechanics of Souls games are solid in terms of how the player controls, attacks have a great deal of weight given to them with fast kill times, cool status effects and a lot of stagger on heavier weapons. This is all wasted on the terrible enemies who are not fun to fight. The vast majority of enemies and even bosses have incredibly simple AI whose only directive seems to be lunging as fast as they can in a straight line towards the player, to a point where difficulty can frankly just be measured by how fast an enemy is. It's very lazy and the dumb AI is just begging to be cheesed and when you add in the fact that many of the later bosses are simply faster and have longer range than most weapons and fighting styles a player might find fun as well as having the ability to pivot the upper halves of their bodies like a robot on a dime to hit a player that just dodged their attack, the game starts downright demanding it. 

     Probably the game's greatest sin, however, is how lazy the world design was. One of Elden Ring's selling points was it's huge map and open world design. The game is indeed big, but much like Skyrim, in order to fulfill the promise of a large map they simply copy pasted enemies, dungeon designs and even bosses. Once you've reached a certain point in the game you get the feeling that you've already seen it all and you're just going through the motions doing the same things all over again, and that's because you have and you are.

    If you're looking to Elden Ring for a thrilling RPG? Look elsewhere. A mechanically dense fantasy action game? Look elsewhere. A large and detailed world with exciting and varied exploration? Look elsewhere. Elden Ring is best looked at as simply a minimalist generic dungeon crawler that *might* give you some challenge if you aren't skilled in the art of cheese and nothing more.

Also, I wish there were more swamps. I only counted like 6 or 7.

Elden Ring is a fantastic sequel to Lord of the Rings, and has made an amazing addition to the trilogy. It was even better than Aragorn's Quest for the PS2. 10/10

It takes bits of both the best and, yes, a little bit of the worst, of each of the previous Soulsbourne games and manages to negotiate an incredible experience. Absolutely one of the best games I have ever played, and feels like what Souls was always meant to be.

Just buy it
More addicting than heroin:

I had never played a souls like game before Elden Ring. Purchased it on release week on the Xbox and my mind was suddenly opened up to a whole different genre. I Spent a straight week and a half at my best buddies apartment just so we could play through at the same time. Learning everything together and summoning each other when we got tremendously down bad. Switched my build multiple times till I got a bleed build, which was broken when the game came out. Now I'm trying builds that I didn't even know existed. I remember beating the Elden Beast for the first time at 3 in the morning while screaming my lungs out and the feeling of accomplishment and reward from beating the main story was something I knew I'd never get back.

Then I got it on PC and I got that feeling over and over and over again. 

Most beautiful, rewarding, content rich game I've personally ever played. Metal as fuck.

Buy the game.
One of the greatest of all time

@ 100 hours play time 
Score 3/10
Horrible combat, controls, keybindings, camera, boss fights and target lock-on.
Bosses have fluid move sets and great mobility that look cool this can't be said for your character. The player is stiff, limited, locked into slow clunky moves that can't be canceled.

Exploration was great for 20 - 30 hours but it got to the point where I don't care anymore due to the gameplay being so poor. Can't be bothered to finish the game.    


@ 7 - 8 hours play time 
Score 7.5/10
Pros
Great open world to explore.  If it was not for the open world I would not play this.
Lots of variety in enemy mobs.
Good loot.

Cons 
The usual bad combat (roll around) in all these types of games. It was bad 20 years ago, but at least back then you could blame the less powerful hardware.

PC port is terrible and it is to be expected from this company.
1) Keybindings and controls, most of the times I am fighting the controls and camera 
2) During boss fights, with Auto-lock on or off, camera will lock to other enemies that are far in the background. 
3) A lot of unexplained controls on PC like how to two had a weapon.
4) Example, no key bind for the mount they expect you to hold "E" then take your hand off your mouse and use the directional arrows to select it or other abilities. Really, can't just let us bind to some other key? 
5) No support for 3440x1440p
6) Very lazy PC port, at least the stuttering is gone that was there at launch.

very sadly, yes. 11 out of 9
I can't get bored. Map is giga huge and beautiful. Best game so far 10/10.
I picked this up nearly when it came out. Jumped in without knowing what souls-like was. Went cool character creation, great graphics, the world looks cool no wonder people are raving about this game. Then got absolutely murdered, over and over again. Highly discouraged I've put the game away 3 times. About a month ago I decided to give it another go. I really took my time to really understand the tutorial and abilities. Finished the tutorial boss who had once absolutely stomped me. Used a few beginner guides on direction on where and what to do at lower levels. Also learned where to get your mount because I didn't know that was a thing and the game tells you nothing. A major thing I learned was not all enemies can be beaten early on for newer inexperienced players. I've been conditioned from other games, you take out who you see.  This is trial and error, if someone is too hard just simply come back later. Once I wrapped my head around that the game was way more enjoyable. Saying that, some bosses are extremely rage inducing and will take plenty of attempts to beat. However, I feel I'm a pretty average gamer and I completed it. I think if you are patient and hard headed enough to keep trying anyone can beat this game. So if you're interested about it or the upcoming DLC and worried about difficulty try it anyway. Its hard, yes..  but not impossible. Once you figure out most patterns you can destroy a lot of bosses... and dying 20+ times and finally kicking their ass does feel rewarding. Just keep in mind this game never lets you feel like a god so don't get a big head as you die because of a miscalculated dodge roll into your demise.
- Can't drag the map or use the mouse cursor on the map, just WASD and the "controller" cursor on the map. There is literally no purpose for the mouse cursor on the map. Why is it even there then? 
- Can't rebind button for map because it is for whatever reason hardcoded to G.
- Dodge and sprint are on the same button. Holding button for sprint and short press for dodge. This is beyond stupid because it automatically results in a delayed dodge because the dodge starts when you let go of the button instead the moment you press it. 
- Can't use quickslots / quickspells, not even with mouse and keyboard where are more than enough buttons.
- Incredible bad mouse and keyboard controls. Rather Fromsoftware has no idea how PC controls work or they simply don't care, both possibilities are equally stupid especially in 2022. But since they put dodge on a delay just to increase artificial difficulty I would guess they made mouse and keyboard controls on purpose so incredible bad. For example Lord of the Fallen, Lies of P, Surge 1+2, Star Wars Fallen Order or Hollow Knight, all of them are souls like and all of them have exquisite mouse and keyboard controls. 
- "JuSt pLaY iT wItH cOntRolLeR iT is beTtEr."
Of course that game is better with a controller because Fromsoftware put literally zero effort on making a good mouse and keyboard support. That don't make it right. I know there's a contingent of Fromsoftware fans who insist that the only way to play is naked, in a blizzard, being harried by hungry wolves but there's no logical reason for a third person action game to be better with controller, or with mouse and keyboard - you don't much benefit from the greater aiming precision of a mouse, or the analogue movement of a controller (and analogue keyboards are a thing too)... Just imagine there comes a game to console were the main input device is controller and the game is not really playable with that. There would be a terrible outcry. But even for games that are designed around mouse and keyboard in mind get a proper controller support such as Anno 1800. Must be some kind of magic... 

Fromsoftware's games are designed around controllers. They've essentially been using the same layout since Demon's Souls in 2009. If Fromsoftware hadn't also made Sekiro, a fast-paced combat game, I doubt Elden Ring would even have a jump button today, it's the single biggest change in years. Otherwise you still use the D-pad to swap between weapons and items, still use the shoulder buttons to attack with whatever is in your left or right hand, still use the same face buttons to drink a potion and two-hand a weapon.

Those controls must have carved permanent neural pathways into the brains of every Fromsoftware designer at this point, which would explain why the PC layout seems to be trying to replicate the controller experience, rather than adapting it to the mouse and keyboard's strengths.
Pain O' Pain

I'm immensely love elden ring , the exploration and its boss design and the loving lore.
but i can't recommend whoever that seek the fair challenge like fromsoft previous game, why?

because of elden ring absurd dodge lag which never seen in previous fromsoft game, never. 
i don't know why this technical issue is introduced in elden ring and never even get fix after so many years of release. in a game that relies to be dodging almost frame perfect in SO MANY occasions. this is game breaking. and the mouse lock on system were also inferior and infuriating. like i rely the directional axis to change lock on target??? so i pan the camera when fighting boss and the same time change the lock on target? and then lock on jump to another target from miles away and i died in middle of the heat lmao. the most absurd control i've encountered in my life. these technical issue is too much to bear and making the experience suck. despite they're absolutely fixable but they're not for unknown reason. 

just to be clear, i did not find the game too hard as i can beat tree sentinel by level 1 and no hit. but the entire experience is suffered from these cheap technical issue. if it's their design in the first place then they losing my absolute respect for them, because this is not how challenge work.

so no, i'm not gonna recommend this game from a lazy dev to anyone. those are the most basic technical issue but still present in the game.

edit: i'll absolutely change my review to positive if they're at least fix this two problem.

Wonderful
Buckle up, boys. This will be a long one.

I'm writing this as a reminder to how I'm currently feeling so that future me can look back and appreciate how much this experience meant for us.

My journey to the Elden Ring started with the very first trailer at E3. As a big Fromsoftware fan, I was thrilled as was countless people. During the silence between trailers and info, memes and culture around the game grew and expanded, "Oh, the Elden Ring". Being in those communities who were waiting in anticipation was amazing, and something I consider to be part of the overall experience of this phenomenal game.

I couldn't play it when it first came out. I didn't have a pc powerful enough and I didn't want to play it on my PS4. In my mind, I wanted to experience it at its best. And that I did, 2 years later. Avoiding spoilers, which I really care about, was difficult. Every time I would go on social media, there's always the "possibility of getting spoiled" always sprung up. Needless to say, when I got to play the game, I hadn't spoiled myself at all, successfully avoiding it all.

As I launched the game for the first time, I remembered the unbelievable hype right before the game came out. I thought to myself, 'Could it meet those high expectations?' And it sure did, exceeding those expectations by a long margin. This sentiment is shared among the players and critiques alike. Elden Ring and Fromsoftware really did come out on top.

What is there to say about Elden Ring? The world they crafted is dense and beautiful. After the endgame, I would find myself looking beyond into the scenery and simply gasp in awe. The detail they put into crafting the world of the Lands Between is exemplar. The combat fluid just the way Fromsoftware perfected it. The variety of weapons always gives you endless options of trial and error which went along with the freedom of changing your stats to attempt different strategies.

The lore, ah, the lore... truly outdid themselves again. I have never been invested in the lore of a game before, not as much as now. Even though it is vague and leave a lot to interpretation, I still adore this fragmented world. And those stories went alongside the characters and many bosses in Elden Ring. Never did I fight so many bosses and consider how 'cool' or 'amazing' they are because of the lore. There's so much to be said in this department and I could go on hours discussing the detail and care the devs poured into maintaining. Seriously, amazing.

With the dlc coming, my journey within the Lands Between isn't over yet. I will be back riding my trusty steed in no time. Until then, I bid this world farewell.

10/10
best game ever.

ÂΩìÁÑ∂ÔºåÊàòÊñó‰ΩìÈ™åÔºå‰πüÂêåÊ†∑ÊòØ‰ª§‰∫∫Ê¨≤ÁΩ¢‰∏çËÉΩÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÂõ†Á¥†„ÄÇÊú¨‰ΩúÁöÑÊàòÊñóÁ≥ªÁªüÂá†‰πéÂØπ‰ªñÂàõ‰ΩúÁöÑÊâÄÊúâÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºåÈÉΩËøõË°å‰∫Ü‰º†Êâø‰∏éÈù©Êñ∞„ÄÇÈüßÊÄßÁ≥ªÁªüÂíåÂèåÊåÅÁ≥ªÁªüÂõûÂΩíÔºåÈáçÁî≤Âíå‰∏∞ÂØåÊ≠¶Âô®ÁöÑÊÑè‰πâÂÜç‰∏ÄÊ¨°Ë¢´Âá∏ÊòæÔºåÂØπ‰∫éÂ¶ÇÈ™ëÊû™Á≠âÈáçÊ≠¶Âô®Âä®‰ΩúÊ®°ÁªÑÁöÑÊîπËâØÔºåÊúâ‰∫ÜÊõ¥Â§öÊ†∑ÁöÑÊ≠¶Âô®ÈÄâÊã©„ÄÇÊú¨‰Ωú‰∏≠Ë¢´Âä†‰ª•‰∏∞ÂØåÁöÑÊ≥ïÊúØÁ≥ªÁªüÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÊñ∞Âä†ÂÖ•ÁöÑÊàòÁÅ∞Á≥ªÁªüÂíåÂè¨Âî§Á≥ªÁªüÔºåÂ∞§ÂÖ∂ÊòØÊàòÁÅ∞Á≥ªÁªüÂ∏¶Êù•ÁöÑÊûÅ‰∏∫Êñπ‰æøÁöÑË∞ÉÊï¥ÊàòÊäÄ‰∏éÊ≠¶Âô®ÂèòË¥®ÁöÑËÉΩÂäõÊúâÁùÄÁõ∏ÂΩìÂ§ßÁöÑÂèØÊåñÊéòÊΩúÂäõ„ÄÇÂ∞ΩÁÆ°ÈïøÊó∂Èó¥ÁöÑÊé¢Á¥¢ÂêéÔºå‰ºöÂõ†‰∏∫Á¥†ÊùêÁöÑÂ†ÜÁ†åÂíåÈáçÂ§ç‰ΩøÁî®ÊÑüÂà∞Áñ≤ÊÉ´Ôºå‰ΩÜÊÉäÂøÉÂä®È≠Ñ„ÄÅÈô©Ë±°Ëø≠ÁîüÁöÑÊàòÊñóÂç¥Ë∂≥‰ª•ËÆ©‰∫∫ÂøÉÊΩÆÊæéÊπÉ„ÄÇ

È≠ÇÁ≥ªÂàóËÆ≤ÊïÖ‰∫ãÁöÑÊñπÂºèÁõ∏ÂΩìÁã¨ÁâπÔºå‰∏îÂèàÂÖ∑Êúâ‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑÂÖ±ÊÄß„ÄÇ‰∏ÄÊó†ÊâÄÁü•Âú∞Êù•Âà∞Ëøô‰∏™‰∏ñÁïåÔºåÈÅáËßÅÂêÑÁßçÂêÑÊ†∑Á•ûÁßò‰∏î‰ºüÂ§ßÁöÑÂ≠òÂú®Ôºå‰∫≤Ë∫´ÁªèÂéÜËÆ∏ËÆ∏Â§öÂ§öÁöÑÈöæÂÖ≥ÔºåÊàòËÉú‰∏Ä‰∏™Âèà‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊõæÁªèÈÅ•‰∏çÂèØÂèäÁöÑÊïå‰∫∫ÔºåÂπ∂Âú®ÊóÖÈÄîÁöÑÁªàÁÇπÂæóÂà∞Êª°Êª°ÂΩìÂΩìÁöÑÂÖÖÂÆûÊÑü„ÄÇÊúÄÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊòØÔºåÂ§ßÈáèÁ¢éÁâáÂåñ„ÄÅÂú∫ÊôØÂèô‰∫ãÔºå‰ª•Âèä‰ºóÂ§öË∞úËØ≠‰∫∫NPCÔºåËÆ©ËøôÊÆµÂÜíÈô©ÊïÖ‰∫ãÂÖ∑ÊúâÂæàÂº∫ÁöÑÂºÄÊîæÊÄß„ÄÇÈÄöÂÖ≥ÂêéÔºå‰ªçÁÑ∂‰ºöÂØπËøôÊÆµÊïÖ‰∫ãÂ≠òÂú®ÂæàÂ§öÁñëÊÉëÔºåÂú®Êé¢Á¥¢Ê∏∏ÊàèÂêÑÁßçÁªÜËäÇÁöÑËøáÁ®ãÈáåÈÄêÊ≠•Ê∑±ÂÖ•Ëøô‰∏™Â∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑ‰∏ñÁïåÔºåÊúÄÁªàÊ≤âËø∑ÂÖ∂‰∏≠„ÄÇËâæÂ∞îÁôªÁéØÁÆóÊòØËøôÁßçÂ§ßÂÜíÈô©‰ΩìÈ™åÁöÑÁªàÊûÅÂΩ¢ÊÄÅ„ÄÇ‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢Âú®‰∫éÊú¨‰ΩúÁöÑÂú∞Âõæ‰ΩìÈáèÂíåNPCÊï∞ÈáèÈÉΩËææÂà∞‰∫ÜÁ≥ªÂàó‰πãÊúÄÔºåÂâßÊÉÖÁöÑ‰ΩìÈáè‰πüÂõ†Ê≠§ÂèòÂæóÊõ¥Â§ßÔºå‰ΩøÊ∏∏ÊàèÁöÑÁΩëÁä∂Âèô‰∫ãÊúâÁùÄÊõ¥Â§ßÁöÑÊΩúÂäõÔºåÊØè‰ΩçNPCÈÉΩÊúâËá™Â∑±ÁöÑÊïÖ‰∫ãË¢´ÂèëÁé∞ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøá‰∫ÜËß£‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºåÁ†¥Ëß£‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑË∞úËØ≠ÔºåÂºÄÂêØ‰∏ÄÊù°Êù°ÂÖ®Êñ∞ÊïÖ‰∫ãÁ∫øÔºåÊúÄÁªà‰Ωø‰∏ñÁïåË¢´‰∏≤ËÅîÊàê‰∏ÄÁâáÂ∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑÂèô‰∫ãÁΩëÔºåËøôÊó∂‰Ω†‰ºöÈô∑Ëøõ‰∫ÜÂÆ´Â¥éËã±È´òÈÇ£Ëø∑‰∫∫ÁöÑÂèô‰∫ãÈô∑Èò±ÂΩì‰∏≠‰∏çÂèØËá™Êãî„ÄÇÂè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÁî±‰πîÊ≤ªÈ©¨‰∏Å‰∏éÂÆ´Â¥éËã±È´òËÅîÂêàÂàõ‰ΩúÁöÑÁ•ûÁßò‰∏ñÁïåÔºå‰πüÂÖÖÊª°‰∫Ü‰ª§‰∫∫Âç∞Ë±°Ê∑±ÂàªÁöÑÂú∫ÊôØÂíåÊïå‰∫∫ËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÂú®ÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÂÜíÈô©ÁöÑÁªèÂéÜÊõ¥ÊòØÈöæ‰ª•Â§çÂàª„ÄÇÊ≠£ÊòØÁî±‰∫éÊ∏∏ÊàèÂá∫‰ºóÁöÑÁæéÊúØÈ£éÊ†ºÊâÄÂ∏¶Êù•ÁöÑÊ≤âÊµ∏ÊÑüÔºåÂéöÈáçÂà∞Êó†‰ª•Â§çÂä†ÁöÑÊ∏∏Êàè‰ΩìÈáè‰ª•ÂèäÁ≤æÂ∑ßÁªù‰º¶ÁöÑÂÖ≥Âç°ËÆæËÆ°ÔºåËâæÂ∞îÁôªÁéØÊòæÂæóÂ¶ÇÊ≠§Ëø∑‰∫∫‰∏î‰ª§‰∫∫Ê≤âÈÜâ„ÄÇ

yes

Easily one of the best games ever made. There is a constant positive feedback loop of exploration where you are both discovering interesting content and getting frequent new items (weapons, armors, spells, crafting recipes, etc) that can significantly alter the way you choose to play the game. There is a huge build variety and it is fairly easy to respec or just readjust into different builds to try out different playstyles.

This game is huge, almost too huge, but I think it remains insanely compelling throughout, but I love every fromsoft souls game so YMMV but I think it has something for everyone and a lot of ways to mitigate difficulty

With the Shadow of the Erdtree coming out I want to express my love for the original Elden Ring experience. To the great warrior Alexander, to the lake of rot. Elden ring was my first experience with the souls-borne franchise. Like most people I want to be in a world where I can leave my chair and imagine my self slaying dragons or picking flowers. Elden ring drops you off in this world with rich story telling, cool bosses, and beautiful landscapes which was made possible by FromSoftware team. If you have free time on your hands Give Elden ring a chance, you wont regret it, best game I have ever played.
(P.S Miyazaki please add A death blight swamp for the DLC)

From Software has created an open-world masterpiece with a lot of content and places to explore. Open world is well above average compared to other games. In many ways, the game feels like a combination of all FromSoftware's Souls titles. It was a great decision to select the best aspects of the Souls games and consolidate them into one. If you enjoy boss fights, you'll be kept busy as there are over 100 bosses in the game. A lot of options to make your builds, with various weapons, armor, sorceries and more.

I GOT GUD
Elden Ring brings a fresh take on the action RPG genre, blending the signature challenging gameplay of FromSoftware titles with an expansive open-world setting created in collaboration with George R.R. Martin. Players can expect a deeply immersive experience filled with rich lore, intense combat, and breathtaking environments. "cant wait for shadow of erdtree"

gg
This is a very mixed review reflecting the conflicted feelings I have about this game.
On the one hand there are a lot of aspects of the game that I enjoyed:
The graphical beauty of it, the variety of combat styles. etc.
But the one overarching deficiency that troubled me throughout
my time spent with the game is the extremely limited cohesive story
that is being told in the game.

I feel most engaged by games that are providing an immersive
experience to the player by virtue of their narrative but Elden RIng,
while visually beautiful and compelling, did only provide me
with the barest scraps of story telling. What the game does do
is world-building which could have been used as a foundation
for good stories but was unfortunately not used much in that way.

In the end the game kept me somewhat interested by keeping
me busy with its mechanics but at the same time the progress
through the game felt mostly meaningless rather than important.
The fallen leaves unfortunately do not tell a story.
It would have been great if they did.

In summary if you are a player with a strong interest in well told stories
then you should probably avoid this game since you won't get much
of that. If your focus is a lot more on combat mechanics and the visuals
then maybe this game is a fit for you.
Best game I've ever played. Do yourself a favor and buy it.

good shit
One of the best games i've ever played.
Elden Ring came out and told the ubisoft-open worlds to sit tf down and see how it's done, and it slaps the shit out of those kinds of open worlds because it literally just says "here's your goal, good luck" instead of filling your entire map in question marks, lvl ranges, points of interest, and whatever else to jangle keys in front of your eyes, which is refreshing, because everyone enjoys the sense of discovery.

My main gripes with the game stem from how the game tackles questlines, and it's a gripe I also have with DS3, in that how to progress certain quests, or even start some, feels like you need some walkthrough open (because why would I go back to this one merchant who sold nothing of perceived value because I heard some howling in the wild, or investigate this one well that's out of the way?). Small things like that adding up and culminating in "they told me something incredibly vague or just said goodbye, how was I supposed to know I'd encounter them on this tiny path, off to the side, in the dark?" happening numerous times.

That and if you don't like enlarged insects there's plenty of areas in the game where your stomach will churn and your mind will immediately tell you to get the fuck out of whatever god forsaken shithole you just wandered into, so if you have some kind of entomophobia... I wouldn't venture into the place with giant ants.
Absolutely amazing, an actually difficult game.

Mind Blowing
MAY CHAOS TAKE THE WORLD
Armor and shields actually do stuff in some boss fights, vs the tried and true go-naked-and-roll-around-stabbing-the-butt-for-30-minutes tactic.  As in, wearing armor and blocking with a shield doesn't break poise immediately like every other Souls game.  My big complaints are horsey combat is pretty derpy and you never know when to heal your horsey until you feed your horsey, sometimes it's super difficult to know where to go next so explore everywhere and talk to every NPC you can, and the biggest complaint:

9/10 enemies and bosses jump around like FleaMen in Castlevania on pogosticks, spinning, slashing, jumping around some more, getting 27 attacks in a row off just hammering you until you do run out of poise and get staggered.  Like imagine they have a Dex bar and it's 12 times longer than yours will ever be. It's super annoying.  You can't roll away because they keep coming, and you can't attack because you were rolling and ran out of Dex, and you can't drink because they keep attacking.  The combat is really different from any other Souls game, and then add mounted combat fights on top of it.  You'll still die a lot, just in ways you aren't used to.
Legendary game, BUT it does have some bad elements compared to other souls games. 
Here are the few of them:
1. Reuse of bosses as a mid level mobs. 
2. Copy and paste tombs. 
3. Zones that are balanced based on the level of your character but you wont have a idea besides the difficulty. So you play the game, discover new zone and now you are 50 lvls ahead and one shot everything even zones bosses... The basic auto-scaling of HP and damage of enemies would fix this. To play this game to its full potential i recommend googling "RECOMMENDED LEVEL BY LOCATION | ELDEN RING WIKI". And tackle the zones on its level.

good
What a game! I've been a gamer for almost 30 years now and I can't recall a gaming experience with so much depth as Elden Ring. This was my first time on the souls-like genre so there were many new things to learn but the journey was worth it. 
To me Elden Ring is a masterpiece and a work of art in so many levels, from the lore, level design, the combat system. The transitions from area to area and the degradation of the world as you progress offer unique feelings and truly captivate one's soul. 

Becoming an Elden Lord is an experience unlike any other and I strongly believe that it's a must for all gamers out there.
 
Thank you FromSoftware!

I like
Great game, even for people new to FromSoft titles (like me) if you're willing to put in some time and work. Exploring the vast, great looking world is rewarding as you find dungeons, loot and optional bosses (most are). The enemies, especially the bosses though, are also really well designed.

However, some small criticism: While the enemy variety is ok, there are a bit too many copy-pasted ones for my taste, especially with some of the bosses (looking at you, Commander Niall, copy of Commander O'Neil but with bs summons) and mini-bosses/bigger enemies (why do we need so many dragons?).

That said, buy it and if it's too hard, there's always an overabundance of guides for builds, bosses etc. so even Soulsborne newcomers can beat it.

[strike] Also fuck Malenia [/strike]

The freedom to challenge a boss later till you get stronger is really nice. def can't wait to see what happens in the dlc and what bosses/weapons are there
Elden Ring is a glorious adventure in which one embarks on a quest to repair the Elden Ring and become Elden Lord and, perhaps, rule the Lands Between.  The Lands Between display a wide range of fantastical scenery which inspires awe in the beholder; one may explore the ruins of ancient civilizations, castles, caves and more. 

 Numerous items can be found which tell the reader of the lore of the game; the closer you pay attention to NPC dialogue and item descriptions, the more you will learn about the Lands Between and the role the major characters play in its history.

Some people complain that graphical assets, locations, and enemies are simply "cloned" as needed, but frankly there is enough variation in enemy types and justification for their presence if you pay close attention.  Furthermore, if you didn't encounter various enemies multiple times, it would be more difficult to take advantage of learning their move-sets, so I don't really think this is something to complain about.

On that note, in this game is a more streamlined variant of the play-style typically found in the Dark Souls series which boasts an array of different gimmicks which can help the player in creating "almost" whatever build they want in order to complete the game.  I say almost because it is both possible and even likely that a player will screw up their first character if they don't bother to look up a guide for it first, but this is alright in my opinion; this is the sort of game where you have to be wiling to learn from your mistakes and adapt to changing circumstances if you wish to overcome the challenges the game presents you with.  Even in the face of the Waterfowl Dance, there is a way to prevail.

This game can be difficult, especially if you aren't used to games like this.  However, beating it is that much more meaningful as a result.  Be prepared to feel anger, frustration, and watch as your character dies  over and over again, but always remember that your eventual victory will be that much sweeter.  Buy the game and have fun.

Joguinho
I've been playing the souls series for a long time. I was one of the few peeps playing pvp in 4:1 on Demons Souls on the old ps3 before Dark Souls was even announced. Elden Ring is a great game, truly beautiful, and I highly recommend it. But there are ways it needs to improve and with the dlc coming soon I hope they can address some of these issues.

Here are some of the main things bothering me when coming back to it;

Movement controls- I'm glad the devs realised that jump needs to be assigned to a separate input to roll/backstep/sprint, and that console controllers have limited amount of buttons, but on PC we should be able to assign different keys for all. A separate bindable input for roll, backstep and sprint, not just have them all lumped together on the same input.

Menus/spells/items- This game uses the very same menu system and item/spell selection system as the first game from back in 2009. Back then it wasn't even good. I understand that this can't get fixed for the dlc but on PC we could easily have a hotkey system whereby we can assign say 1 to 9 for whatever spells/items we want to use, rather than scrolling through a list in one direction with one key. Honestly this system is clunky and annoying. Since they fixed the spellswitch glitch waaaay back at the start of Dark Souls the menus have seemed laggy and cumbersome too.

Open world- The open world is okay but I think I prefer the interlinked dungeon feel of traditional souls games, particularly Dark Souls 1. I tried to explore every nook and cranny and kill everything in my first playthrough and it took nearly 250 hours. Still missed a few things. By the time I got to the end game I was completely sick of wandering around exploring vast spaces and things felt very barren with nowhere near enough good loot. Also, do we have to keep having to explore these white snow areas looking for items that only show up as white blobs on the ground? 

I don't want to get into pvp because there is just so much wrong. I haven't seen souls games as decent pvp games since the dawn of DS2 tbh, but the pve and coop is great.

Apart from that game 2EZ need hard mode.
all i know is death and bonk and im all out of death
Best game I've ever played, never felt disappointed, unrivalled masterpiece! ‚ù§Ô∏è

yes
Greatest game of all time
tl;dr - very good game, terrible anti-cheat implementation

------------------------------

my main issue is with the games performance, and its because of easy anti-cheat. don't get me wrong, its better than nothing and in a souls like game on pc cheaters are abundant, but there is such a significant drop in my fps from 90 -> 40 with easy anti cheat. for a game developed by a company that seems to have enough resources i expected a better optimized solution that wouldnt impact the performance so negatively.

im not really sure why easy anticheat kills my frames, but it does operate on the kernel level which is kinda intrusive, and the fact that it doesn't even reliably catch cheaters is just laughable. why is this thing even here? 

i ended up just disabling it and enjoying the game at a respectable frame rate, playing online isn't even worth it when it drops my frames by half. 

aside from the anti-cheat the game is massive and absolutely fun to play. if you want to sink a good amount of hours into something this game can do it.
It truly lives up to all the hype.

Finally completed a Fromsoft game, and this was probably the best RPG I've ever played.
TOGETHAAAA, WE CAAAN DEVOWAAA THE VERY GAWDS
Despite having 84 keys on my keyboard and only being allowed to use 10 of them, it was worth it. Combat is clunky on MnK but after a few hours(days) you do get used to it. Story is cool but you will have to look online how to do it because there is no quest journal, even though it is an open world game.

It is a beautiful and immersive game, though, since it does have an official PC release the FPS should not be locked to 60 and it would've been nice if FromSoftware had allowed us to completely customise keybindings by now, 2 years later. The ray tracing is still as pointless as it was on release, there's no noticeable difference between having it on off other than the -15 frames per second. I don't even think reflections are ray traced.

Multiplayer is available at the cost of PvP being enabled, meaning, if you want to play along with your children or partner, expect to be ganked every 5 minutes. It's just tedious and annoying so I'd advise just playing alone in offline mode if that doesn't sound appealing.

DLC is on it's way, I'm looking forward to an extension of the main story and harder bosses (like Malenia), I'm also interested to find out who this new antagonist is, I've found some scraps of his existence in the standard game but only in really secret locations so hope to find out why he's been erased from history. Was it him who first burned the Erdtree? Hopefully along with the DLC we may have some standard game improvements, 2 fingers crossed.

is game
Favorite part is being able to help friends and others pass bosses and level them up.

The sweaty pvp can be avoided if you're just trying to enjoy yourself.
Playing solo and using summons, is one way to go about this. Other times you just make a meet up spot with your buddies and enter passwords to make sure you can see each other. Enter the fog walls asap so noone can invade and if they do invade they go away instantly, cya fun sucker. Sometimes we will just off them together real quick but, when you start a new character or helping a new player it can be a bit stupid. 

It would be awesome to have a full pve mode where you and your friends can do whatever you like without pvp. As some of my friends that aren't usually into this style of game can still have fun. I can't ask most of them to play anymore which is pretty lame. 

There are still cool things to experience besides pvp. You have story, lore, builds, different weapons attack styles, spells, ect. It's all fun to mess with.
I put another 100~200 hours on ps5 and plat it on there as well. Love this game, and other souls like. I just think it would be awesome to have an pve only mode on each of them so I can not only help my friends but also my wife without a random being toxic. 

It is amazing that it doesn't matter what our level is or New Game+ progress, we can still be summoned using passwords. Love it. Thank you for this feature.

Pvp is fun sometimes, but it should be opt in. You can get your butt kicked when I feel like kicking it.

"Elden Ring: A Triumph of Gaming Excellence"

Elden Ring, the collaborative masterpiece by game director Hidetaka Miyazaki and renowned author George R. R. Martin, has emerged as a paragon of gaming excellence, captivating both veterans and newcomers alike. Released amid high expectations, the game not only met but surpassed them, delivering an unparalleled experience that has redefined the action RPG genre.

One of Elden Ring's standout features is its expansive open-world design, seamlessly blending Miyazaki's signature intricate level design with Martin's rich lore. The vast and interconnected landscapes of the Lands Between invite exploration, offering a sense of awe and discovery reminiscent of classic adventure tales. Each region is meticulously crafted, adorned with breathtaking visuals and atmospheric storytelling that immerse players in a world teeming with secrets and mysteries.

The game's combat system is a symphony of precision and challenge, demanding mastery from players while rewarding strategic thinking. From the diverse array of weapons and magic to the colossal and awe-inspiring boss battles, Elden Ring creates an adrenaline-pumping experience that keeps players on the edge of their seats. The freedom to approach encounters in various ways adds depth and replayability, ensuring that each playthrough feels unique and personalized.

Elden Ring's narrative, co-authored by Martin, unfolds with a captivating blend of dark fantasy and intricate storytelling. The lore is woven into the fabric of the world, encouraging players to piece together the history and unravel the enigmatic tales of the characters they encounter. The result is a narrative tapestry that engages players intellectually, adding layers of depth to an already compelling gaming experience.

The game's success is not only attributed to its gameplay mechanics and storytelling but also to its atmospheric soundtrack, which complements the visuals and enhances the emotional resonance of the journey. From haunting melodies to adrenaline-pumping battle themes, the music elevates Elden Ring to a cinematic level, making it a truly immersive and unforgettable experience.

In conclusion, Elden Ring stands as a testament to the potential of collaborative creativity in the gaming industry. Its open-world design, challenging combat, rich narrative, and captivating soundtrack converge to create a gaming masterpiece that will be remembered as one of the finest examples of the medium. Elden Ring not only meets the expectations of fans but also sets a new standard for excellence in the world of video games.

Tis nice
Elden Ring descends upon the gaming landscape as an opus of epic proportions, reaffirming that gaming greatness knows no bounds. FromSoftware's collaboration with Bandi Namco has birthed a magnum opus, a captivating journey that surpasses expectations, weaving a narrative tapestry as intricate as the Souls series and as expansive as the Lands Between itself. At the core of Elden Ring's brilliance lies its boss encounters‚Äîa symphony of challenge, strategy, and visual spectacle that elevates the game to an unparalleled zenith. Among these titans, Godrick the Grafted stands out as a macabre masterpiece. His lore, intricately connected to the lineage of the First Elden Lord, paints a picture of a fearsome warrior who revels in the grotesque act of grafting fallen adversaries onto his formidable frame. The visceral horror of facing Godrick is matched only by the visual splendor of his battle, where the player must navigate a nightmarish ballet of limbs and blades. This fight as one of the first in the game was extremely exciting to me, and although death was a common encounter, learning his attacks, and how to dodge them was one of the best experiences I have had to the souls-like introduction for new Genres for me in general. Similarly, the tragic tale of Rennala, Queen of the Full Moon, unfolds amidst a mesmerizing encounter. Her connection to mystical forces and the celestial bodies adds layers to her character, while her battles are a dance with the ethereal, as illusions and magical prowess create an enchanting yet formidable adversary, the background especially of the serene moonlight ankle-deep lagoon in her second phase is splendiferous to say the least. Morgot, the Omen King, looms as a figure of abandoment, yet faith, his twisted lore intertwined with forbidden sins, and being born as an ogre, a species dishonoured and disregarded by the Royal family. The encounter with Morgot is a battle against unseen omens, an explination as to his sturdy faith in the erdtree, not phased by the rebellion amongst him. Starcscourge Radahn, with his ominous ties to the Gravatational Magic, he has mastered to ride his horse that is far too small for his towering body now, and eventually to the point of keeping the stars at a standstill, hence his name, his body embodies a relentless force of destruction. His lore and battle intertwine seamlessly, the player thrust into a cataclysmic clash with a figure whose wrath reverberates through the very foundations of Elden Ring's universe, a ferocious warrior, rotted away from the inside out, awaiting a warriors death. Rykard, Lord of Blasphemy, another one of the optional, yet beauteous bosses, delves into the dangers of forbidden knowledge and unchecked ambition. His twisted agreements, of being fed to a serpent in order to become more powerful than any demigod could have dreamed off, planning to rebel against the Golden Order, and his descent into madness are unveiled in a nightmarish encounter, challenging players to confront the consequences of meddling with the unknown, in front of the lord of blasphemy. The encounters with the Fire Giant, Malekith the Black Blade, Godfrey, Dragonlord Placidusax, and Radagon of the Golden Order are equally enthralling, each contributing to the grand narrative tapestry of Elden Ring. In the grand tradition of FromSoftware's design philosophy, each boss battle is a meticulously crafted challenge, a dance of death that demands players not only to master the intricacies of combat but also to uncover the lore that shapes these formidable adversaries. Visually and aurally, Elden Ring is a sensory masterpiece. The boss battles against colossal foes such as the Fire Giant and Dragonlord Placidusax are visually stunning, their towering forms and devastating attacks immersing players in a cinematic experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, along with the beautifully crafted cutscenes that make the game that much more enthralling. As for sidequests, and main quests for that matter, even though they dont tell you specifically are amazing, and Millicents questline, a young girl who writhes with scarlet rot, and is in desperate need of help, takes you deeper into an emotional level and understanding of the lore in the game in ways you could never imagine. Truly this is a masterpiece, and for new time souls players like me, I went in expecting to be met with rage and annoyance, similar to that of cuphead and others in the past, which had this difficulty, but surprisingly it was so fun, i'd find myself spending hours upon hours on end exploring the lands between without even realising how much fun I've had! Whether its strolling through the beauteous airy green lands, tainted with golden light that is Limgrave, or the abstract, subzero, and graceful silence in the mountaintops of the giants, each environment has its own story to tell, and I pray that you too will experience such fun in Elden Ring as I did, and am still doing so to this very day! In conclusion, Elden Ring is a triumph‚Äîa testament to storytelling, character design, and gameplay innovation. Each boss encounter is a chapter in a saga that captivates and challenges, setting new standards for the Souls-Like genre. Elden Ring is more than a game; it's an odyssey, an immersive experience that cements its place as a monumental achievement in interactive entertainment. A must-play for veterans of the Souls series and newcomers alike, Elden Ring stands as a beacon of excellence, etching its mark in the annals of gaming history, and after 100%ing the game, I can agree with absolute certianty why it won game of the year for 2022, astounding artwork, profound lore, incredible game!

fun
I just 100% it.
It has its moments, but overall, Elden Ring is the soulsbourne genre perfected.

They have taken Dark Souls 1's ingenious level design idea and implemented it; 
Dark Souls 2's glorious mechanic ideas and fleshed them out;
Dark Souls 3's MP and side quest system and have made both enjoyable;
Bloodborne's enemy design and movesets;
and Sekiro's inspiring environmental setting design.

On top of it all, they have even managed to create it in such away that it is not only distinguishable from all of the above, but it has also become a wake-up call to other AAA studios to step up their game and has become a standard of open-world RPG games.

It is a game with a high learning curve, but it is much more user-friendly than any of its predecessor, so even if you feel like you're doing something wrong, the punishment for it isn't that big (ex, you don't need to start a new character if you wanna respec)

On top of it all, the community is very talented and has created multiple high-quality mods which can enable you to expand your fun - the best one yet is the co-op mod where you can finish the game together with your friends in one session (no summons other than in the beginning necessary)

I love this game. Wish I could forget I played it so I could replay it again fresh.

Buying this game was the best decision I could make. Although the difficulty was a little hard at first, killing the tree sentinel for the first time had me hooked. I had absolutely no idea where to go from there, and was let off into a grand open world. From there I knew I had to become the Elden Lord. As I am writing this, I have beaten the game 3 times, and plan on getting the other 3 endings as well. The more and more I keep playing, the more and more I discover. really great game
(M&K review)

If you're on the fence about this game and you're expecting a well-balanced, well-designed combat system that feels intuitive and responsive, don't buy it. This isn't a finely-tuned, extremely well tested, and flawlessly crafted action RPG; it's intentionally made to feel sluggish, clunky, and tedious. This game suffers from many poor design aspects, some of them seemingly intentional decisions and others just a product of bad programming, which is pretty much par for a fromsoft game. 

Expect many deaths due to intentionally badly designed mechanics that are made purely to result in a player death, as they have no logical reason for being that way otherwise, E.G.: the mount handling and mounted combat, various inconsistencies in combat, re-queueing interrupted actions without additional player input or very delayed responsiveness of actions that then causes multiple queued actions to occur successively.

The good parts of the game are the visuals, the exploration, voice acting, and overall feel of the world. Fromsoft usually does get the survival/survival-horror aspects of the game right. I do generally really enjoy the exploring and the aspect of returning to a lower-level area after increasing your levels/gear and feeling how much stronger your character is compared to when you first went to the area. The good pretty much ends there though as the majority of the game is based around the dynamic and fairly robust combat system that was just poorly implemented in some aspects, and hindered greatly in other aspects by bad design choices.

The most glaring issues are the camera and lock-on system. You fight a lot of VERY large enemies, as well as have many areas of small corridors, often filled with ambushes and many multi-target encounters. The game's combat tends to feel the best fighting mid-size enemies one-on-one, when the camera is not busy being occluded or otherwise veering off in directions that don't allow the player to properly see mechanics and dangers. The targeting system has issues with multi-target encounters, as it will often switch targets mid-swing and has no way to turn off the auto-switching (even turning off all the "auto" options does not stop this behavior or even prevent what it seems to imply), and on top of that some enemies have their target cursors placed somewhere higher up on the body and your character will swing their weapons upwards towards the location of the target reticle, which will frequently cause attacks to miss (at least with smaller weapons, like most dex-based weapons). Unfortunately, because of the large, erratic movements of some enemies it's almost a necessity to use lock-on, especially with how particular the game can be about the enemy hitboxes, and this compounds the issue with the camera field-of-view problems. Sometimes you will have to turn off targeting and manually adjust the camera to actually see certain attacks or move out of certain mechanics, which feels particularly clunky with all the animation locking and sluggish movements of your character.

Some inconsistencies between what the enemies and player can do are also very aggravating at times, such as enemies being able to swing their weapons unhindered through most objects. Typically projectiles, unless the enemies arms are clipping through the wall, will actually be stopped by said objects, but melee weapons can go through objects, walls, and even through boss barriers (which, if you're unlucky, you can be hit through after the entry animation finishes). This wouldn't be as annoying if your character's weapons didn't bounce off most non-breakable objects and cause you to become animation locked by the reeling, while enemies can swing their entire arm through the wall unhindered, especially in the MANY small/tight corridors and catwalks with walls throughout the game. This really just feels like bad/lazy design, especially when enemies can corner the player this way but the player attempting to use the geography strategically will be punished for it. The body blocking by most enemies feels janky in many situations as well, as most enemies that attack you in groups  can attack through each other without hurting each other, can't be rolled through, often can't be rolled around if they are close to a wall (even if your character would fit through the space), and could only be pushed away with certain special skills. 

Point blank, mount handling and mounted combat both feel awful in this game. The mount handling is nearly as bad as Black Desert's, with a ridiculously bad turning radius, excessive inertia, and extremely limited capability to maneuver smaller areas. Turning in the opposite direction will literally cause the horse to run multiple steps in the direction it is facing, so if you are close to a cliff it can cause you to fall off of it, and handling anything besides straight forward movement is basically akin to F1 racing. (But don't worry, enemy mounts can do 0-point turns at any angle, even without the horse moving its feet!) The horse has EXTREMELY limited things it can do: double jump, sprint, and allows the player to attack with a very limited, slow moveset with very small range (at least with most smaller dex weapons). If enemies surround you on your horse near a wall (usually because they beam in from the enterprise) you typically cannot jump over them, cannot knock them away (because horses definitely aren't known to be able to do tha- oh wait, the enemy horses do all the time), and often won't even be able to turn around, so your only option is to try and dismount which is a long animation you can be attacked during. It really feels like they made this big world, then at the last minute thought "hey, maybe we should add something to let the player move faster" so they hastily added a mount then tried to implement the bare minimum of mounted combat because of all the mounted enemies.

The auto-facing towards the player some enemies do during certain mechanics can be pretty awful also, but that seems to have been an intentional design choice. I don't really agree with it, as most enemies already do a 180+ degree swing, and making the auto-facing cause it to be an even larger arc as a result is not particularly fluid or "realistic" feeling. Instead of designing mechanics that intentionally try to counter players attempting to flank the enemy, they went with this to force more direct dodging, and it just feels cheap and lazy honestly, especially when the quick-step skill is solely designed around flanking the enemy. I'd rather the enemy alter the move to be a 270-360 degree swing without changing the direction they're facing, or a backswing instead if the player is flanking them, so there's still risk but it wouldn't feel so janky. 

This game heavily favors specific playstyles (just like DS1 did), and some of them trivialize things, while others make the game exponentially harder. There are a lot of options for combat, but you can't easily switch between them because of the game's RPG nature and scarcity of upgrade materials. You may end up feeling pigeonholed in certain sections of the game where your build is less effective or a boss specifically counters it. 

Finally, the animation locking I'm indifferent on in and of itself, but certain long animations being uncancellable and even the fastest weapons in the game being slower than some enemy attacks that can start and end before your swing completes really make the combat feel awful sometimes, especially when it's a VERY fast move they can chain to the end of other animations that can usually can 1-shot from full hp. RNG seems to decide a lot of which mechanics are used too, so you can't always expect consistency from bosses.

tl;dr - a good basic system and fun exploration/survival feel, but combat is plagued by bad/lazy design choices and shoddy coding.
A game that is so infuriating that you can't stop playing. The beauty of the game also helps. You can truly have any play style and enjoy this game.

Play Elden Ring. 

I was totally left speechless while playing this game for the first time on a ps4. (Yes I bought this game twice.) It took me roughly 150 hours to complete my first playthrough and it was a memorable experience with Lots of hardship against Margit, getting lost in Liurnia and getting sniped multiple times by a golem at Morne castle. 
I had to watch a video of who to kill to progress. It was Godrick at stormveil. 
Altus plateau and the capital is where Elden Ring really peaked in my opinion. Including the Ashen Capital. 
I can play this game over and over again. (500h total) There is so much variety for builds and so many secrets yet to be discovered. And to boot PvP and multiplayer. Even tho crossplay between ps, xbox and pc is not possible. The best game ever made. No doubt in my mind. 
Waiting for the DLC patiently. (i'm going insane.)

Only played for about 50 hours and I'm in love with this game. Don't recommend this to people who get angry easy, but just the challenge makes the game so fun. WORTH THE PRICE 100 PERCENT 11/10
hard
I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 15 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 12 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he let me borrow his controller. Me and my son then played in turns and I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

In my opinion, the greatest game of all time. I wish I could experience this game for the first time, again. What a magical experience. (I have 500 hours on console, which is where I experienced the game for the first time.)
My friend bought it for me because I didn't like Souls games. I'm very glad he did. It's my new Skyrim. But better. LOTR meets GOT meets Miyazaki. It's definitely one of my favorite games. Highly recommend.

lol, bonk
I liked just about everything.
underrated gem
Really great Fromsoft game. Probably their best work in terms of improving upon the souls formula. It does almost everything right. Things that were annoying to newcomers or in general are improved on such as fast travel on demand, really really frequent checkpoints, healing items are restored upon resting, simplified upgrade system and I can go on and on about the quality of life improvements. Lore and environment design is just top tier as always. Almost anything positive about previous games still applies to this one.

Though it suffers from some negatives that most open world games do but they tried their best to alleviate this. Open world activities such as the ruins, catacombs and caves all start to blend and feel really similar after a few and the similar designs of each don't help with this. Lots of recycled enemies as bosses which gets rather boring after some time.

With all that being said, I was hooked for a few weeks playing this nonstop. I definitely think it's worth playing or at least trying. They've made the game super accessible so no longer should you be worried about the difficulty. It's easily their most accessible game for everyone.

great game
Honestly, I don't know what to think about Elden Ring anymore.
My first playthrough was amazing and I had a blast exploring every last bit of the world, but with every repeated playthrough it lost more and more of its initial magic, fun, and laid bare a lot of flaws.
I was just doing another playthrough to set myself up for the upcoming DLC, but I just couldn't deal with all the games bs anymore. 

[b]Positive ; [/b] 

-amazing world with lots to explore
-some very good and fun bosses
-the music is amazing
-combat is mostly good and there are a lot of fun builds you can come up with
-some very nice NPC's+Questlines (unless you miss them, which is most likely going to happen without a guide)
-a lot of Sites of Graces for fast travel, and very short runbacks to bosses if you end up dying.
-[strike]fun mods [/strike]
 
[b]Negative ; [/b]

-recycling of bosses and degrading them to random enemies is insane (and people complained about Dark Souls 2...)
-big bosses are janky as hell and you constantly fight the camera aswell
-almost every enemy, and especially bosses delay their attacks. Some more, some less. It just feels bad.
-input reading is so blatant that they didn't even try to hide it
-catacombs are the same terrible copy pasted mini-dungeons over and over again..and there are a LOT of them 
-gank squads + enemies behind pretty much every corner
-still very unbalanced
-Open World (yup, that one caused me to either be way too strong or way to weak all the time.)
-small delay / input buffer ; thanks, I hate it.


To wrap this up; Elden Ring is by no means a bad game, infact, it is a good one and 
I dont regret the money/hours spend on it.
I wouldn't be surprised if you'll have your fair share of fun with Elden Ring too.

As it stands now, however, I just cant look past it's issues and have to give it a no.
